NARRATIVE: On January 1st 2019 at approximately 01:50AM I was dispatched to the area of 7th and Walnut for a vehicle accident. I was advised by Bloomington City Dispatch that one of the vehicles had left the area. It was described as a black Mercedes SUV and it had turned onto 7th street traveling west. Once I reached the area I made contact with Karen Lirot, she stated that she was working tonight for Uber and was dropping off subjects outside of Kilroy's Sports located at 319 N. Walnut street, Bloomington IN. Karen stated that the front seat passenger was starting to exit the vehicle when she noticed a black Mercedes SUV traveling south on Walnut. As the vehicle attempted to pass Karen it struck her 2006 Mercury SUV on the passenger side causing light damage to the vehicle. The SUV then continued south on Walnut then turned west onto 7th street at a high rate of speed. Karen's vehicle had a skid mark from the front passenger door to the back of the vehicle, her passenger side mirror was also broken. It appears the suspect vehicle should have damage on the passenger side front bumper. Photographs were taken of Karen's SUV and will be placed with this case, I completed a vehicle field crash from and provided Karen a copy of that for her insurance.

V1 and V2 were traveling W/B on 10th St approaching the intersection of 10th and Pete Ellis Dr. V1 rear ended V2 causing damage to the vehicle.D1 stated that he was traveling W/B on 10th St directly behind V2. D1 advised that he got distracted and took his eyes off the road for a second before rear ending V2. V1 air bags deployed, but D1 was not injured. D2 advised that she was traveling W/B on 10th St. D2 advised that she had her left turn signal on, to turn S/B onto Pete Ellis Dr. D2 stated that she came to a complete stopped at the traffic light before she felt the impact of V1 rear ending V2. D2 advised that she had a complaint of pain of 5 out of 10 to her head and was treated on scene. Due to D1 following to closely, V1 rear ended V2 causing damage to V2.

Assisting Officer: Mark Norris #38. He spoke with Robin Rupp who was riding her bicycle with her husband Steven Gilbert, who was the bicyclist involved in the crash.Explain in narrative: Type of Crash: Vehicle vs. BicycleV1 was traveling south bound on Jordan Avenue, and approaching the 4 way stop intersection at 7th Street and Jordan Ave. Upon my arrival V1 was stopped facing southbound on Jordan Avenue at the intersection. The bicyclist was traveling westbound on 7th Street approaching the intersection. Upon my arrival the bicyclist was lying on his back, on the asphalt, on Jordan Avenue. The bicyclist was being medically evaluated by BHAS Truck 2164.D1 said she was traveling southbound on Jordan Avenue in V1 approaching the intersection of Jordan Avenue and 7th Street. D1 said she came to a stop at the intersection in V1. D1 said she looked left (east) and saw the bicyclist on 7th Street coming toward the intersection. D1 said she thought the bicyclist was going to stop at the 4 way intersection. D1 said she then looked right (west) and did not see anyone. D1 said she then proceed southbound through the intersection. D1 said that's when the bicyclist was struck by V1. D1 said she believed the bicyclist did not stop at the stop sign on 7th Street. V1 had damage to the entire front windshield. The bicyclist said he was traveling westbound on 7th street approaching the intersection of Jordan Avenue and 7th Street. The bicyclist said he was stopped at the 4 way intersection on 7th Street, with his bike shoe unclipped from the pedal to balance himself on the roadway while stopped. The bicyclist said he saw V1 traveling southbound on Jordan Avenue approaching the intersection and begin slowing down. The bicyclist said he clipped his bike shoe back into the pedal and began to proceed westbound on 7th Street due to thinking V1 was going to come to a complete stop. The bicyclist said when he proceeded through the intersection he was struck by V1. The bicyclist thought V1 did a rolling stop at the intersection. Officer Norris spoke with Robin Rupp who said she saw the crash, but did not see who stopped or disregarded the stop sign. The bicyclist was transported to IU Bloomington Health ER for complaint of pain to his right shoulder and chest area along with a scrape on his right knee.V1 was towed by Blands Towing. Photos are available for this incident.

Property Owner, Trenton Jones, noticed that a stone driveway pole had been hit by an unknown vehicle. Trenton stated he arrived at the residence last night,12-31-2018 at 10:00 PM and noticed the damage at 08:00 AM 01/01/2019. Unknown make or model of vehicle or suspect information. The pole had been knocked over in the yard.It appears the vehicle was traveling west on E. Convenantar Dr. When the vehicle approached a left hand corner at Trenton's residence, the driver ran off the roadway and onto Trenton's driveway. The vehicle then struck the stone driveway pole, went into a ditch and then re-entered the roadway.

Spoke to D1 and could detect the odor of an alcoholic beverage emanating from his exhaled breath. D1 stated V1 was traveling west bound on Arlington Rd and just after he passed Rajumi St a deer ran into V1's path. D1 stated he swerved to miss the deer and lost control and V1 slid off the north side of the roadway. He further stated V1 traveled a short distance off the road and into a large tree causing damage to the front of V1. D1 had visible head injuries and cuts with bleeding on his arms as a result of the crash. D1 submitted to a PBT and that result was .08. Due to D1's injuries SFST's could not be performed. D1 was treated by EMS on scene and refused transport for further medical treatment. V1 was towed due to disabling damage.

On 1/1/2019, at approximately 3:30AM, Officers arrived to the scene of a reported hit-and-run involving a dark colored vehicle. While on scene, it was determined that the suspect driver (D1) was intoxicated, and was arrested at the scene. The suspect did not provide a statement regarding the accident. (this report will be linked to crash report B19-00023)Upon further investigation of the crash, I did locate V2, a maroon Mazda MX-5 (V2), parked immediately west of the intersection of E 7th and N. Waldron. V2 had damage along the driver side of the vehicle, and the front driver side wheel well. The suspect vehicle, a black Jeep Wrangler (V1), had also sustained corresponding damage to both the right and left sides of the front bumper.Based on my observations, it did appear that V1 had been driving intoxicated, traveling westbound on W. 7th St. between N. Elm and N. Waldron, when he sideswiped a parked V2 on the front driver side. After striking V2, V1 continued westbound on W. 7th St., just short of N. Elm St., side-swiping another parked vehicle near the intersection of E. 7th and N. Elm St (B19-00023), at which time, V1 sustained catastrophic damage rendering it inoperable. V1 then backed up onto the sidewalk adjacent to the 2nd vehicle, and was apprehended by Officers on scene.

Vehicle 1 was traveling behind Vehicle 2 east on 3rd St. Both vehicles pulled into the right turn lane into merge onto the on ramp onto southbound SR 37. Vehicle 1 rear ended Vehicle 2 as the vehicles were about to merge onto the ramp.Driver 1 stated that she was looking to her left at traffic prior to merging and she rear ended Vehicle 2Driver 2 advised that he was waiting on traffic in order to pull onto the ramp when he was rear ended by Vehicle 1.

Driver of vehicle one traveling east in the right lane of State Road 46 West did not see driver of vehicle two traveling east on State Road 46 West in the left lane. Driver of vehicle one attempted to change lanes and collided with driver of vehicle two.

Explain in Narrative (type of crash under damage amount): V1 was making a left turn.Upon my arrival, V1 was parked and facing north in the gravel lot. V1 was making a left turn from the gravel parking lot to go south bound on Indiana Avenue prior to striking the pole.D1 said he was in the gravel parking lot on the east side of Indiana Avenue and the south side of 17th Street in V1. D1 said he went to turn left to go southbound on Indiana Avenue and struck the first pole knocking it over. V1 obtained damage down the lower side of the V1 on the driver side. Photos of V1 were taken.No injuries occurred.

Manner of Collision: HEAD ON BETWEEN TWO MOTOR VEHICLES
NARRATIVE: Driver two stated vehicle one come around the curve left of center and he attempted to get out of the way and vehicle one hit him.Witt #1. Stated he was behind the White truck (vehicle #2) and vehicle one drove left of center and hit vehicle two (2). Witt #2 Stated she was behind vehicle one (1) and vehicle one was speeding and drove left of center a few times before hitting vehicle two (2) Witt #2 stated vehicle one drove left of center and vehicle two attempted to get out of the way and vehicle one hit vehicle two in vehicle two's lane.Marks on the road indicated vehicle one was left of center and impact was in vehicle two's lane of travel.

Walnut Street is a straight stretch of roadway that primarily runs north and south through the city of Bloomington, Monroe County, IN. In the area where the crash occurred, Walnut Street is straight with a slight downhill grade.The weather at the time of the crash was clear but cool with a temperature of 39 degrees.V1, a blue 2005 Honda Pilot, was traveling north in the right hand lane of a multi lane one way section of Walnut Street. V1 began to turn into the left hand lane, in order to turn on to 14th Street when V1 struck V2 in the right front and side of V2. V1 came to a controlled stop on the west side of the roadway after the contact was made.V2, a red 2014 Chrysler Town and Country was also traveling north on Walnut Street. V2 was in the left hand lane. As V2 was approaching 14th Street, It was struck in the right side by V1. V2 came to a controlled stop on the west side of the roadway after the contact with V1.D1, Anna C Grimes, said she was traveling north, in the right hand lane, on Walnut Street, when she realized that she needed to turn left on to 14th Street. D1 said she put her left turn signal on and began to turn into the left hand lane when she accidentally struck the side of V2.D2, Tammy L Davis, stated that she was traveling north on Walnut Street in the left hand lane. D2 said that as she was nearing 14th Street, V1 turned into the side of her vehicle. D2 said the impact caused her vehicle to be pushed towards the west side of the roadway but she was able to bring her vehicle to a controlled stop.Both drivers advised that they were uninjured in the crash. Both vehicles sustained damage but were able to be driven from the scene.

D1 AND V1 LEFT SCENE WITHOUT PROVIDING ANY INFORMATION TO OWNER OF WALL WHICH IS PRIVATE PROPERTY OF 919 W KIRKWOOD AVENUE.OWNER OF WALL STATED HER WALL WAS DAMAGED BY AN UNKNOWN VEHICLE. PICTURES WERE TAKEN. CRIMINAL CASE WAS DONE. FOLLOW UP NEEDED. END.***SUPPLEMENT 1/29/2019: CRIMINAL CASE MADE INACTIVE. NO VEHICLE INFORMATION DISCOVERED OR INSURANCE INFORMATION. END. ***
V1 WAS BACKING WESTBOUND INTO 5510 S OLD STATE ROAD 37 AND BACKED INTO V2 THAT WAS PARKED FACING EASTBOUND.

V1 and V2 were both backing out at the same time prior to the crash.D1 said he was backing out of his parking space to leave the parking lot in V1. D1 said as he was backing V1 out, V2 was backing out at the same time where V1 and V2 collided. V1 had minor damage to rear driver side bumper.D2 said he was backing out of his parking space to leave the parking lot in V2. D2 said as he was backing V2 out, V1 was backing out at the same time where V1 and V2 collided. V2 had damage to the front passenger side quarter panel.Both parties said the same statement when speaking to them regarding on how the crash occurred.

V2 was traveling northbound through the Walmart parking lot and had the right of way with no stop sign. D1 stated that he did not see V2 and turned in front of it, crashing the front passenger side of V1 into the drivers door of V2. Neither vehicle sustained disabling damage.

Driver of vehicle one left the roadway, stuck a street sign, then drove into a pond. Driver of vehicle was was arrested for operating while intoxicated endangerment IC 9-30-5-2, and operating while intoxicated BAC at least .15, IC 9-30-5-1.

D2 provided D1 with a valid phone number after crash occurred. D1 said he called D2 while still on scene and was provided the right contact information. D1 said after speaking to D2, D2 left the scene. I made contact with D2 who came back to the scene so a report could be made. V1 was traveling westbound on E. 3rd Street approaching the light at Hawthorne and was in the far right hand lane. V2 was traveling westbound on E. 3rd Street in the left hand lane. V1 merged over from the right hand lane to the left hand lane prior to the crash occurring. D1 said he was traveling westbound on E. 3rd Street in V1 and was in the far right hand lane between Faculty and Hawthorne. D1 said he turned his signal on, and went to merge lanes from the right lane to the left lane when V2 came speeding up E. 3rd Street also westbound in the left lane. V1 struck V2. Vehicle 1 had damage to the front driver side fender and quarter panel area. D1 thought V2 was traveling possibly 40mph.D2 said he was traveling westbound on E. 3rd Street in V2 and was in the left hand lane. D2 said he saw the light turn from red to green at E. 3rd Street and Hawthorne, and was continuing westbound. D2 said as he was approaching, he saw V2 turn signal come on and change lanes from the right lane to the left hand lane appearing to turn onto Hawthorne from E. 3rd Street to go southbound. D2 said V1 struck V2. V2 had damage on the passenger side door. Driver 2 advised when asked for vehicle insurance called Progressive to get his policy number. Progressive advised his payment for renewal had not gone through at the time when he made it previously. D2 while on scene and speaking with Progressive was able to get a policy number and provide information prior to leaving the scene. No injuries occurred.

D1 was driving V1 northbound on Walnut Street in the center lane. While attempting to move into the left lane, V1 struck V2's driver-side rear bumper.D1 stated that he was too close to V2 and attempted to change lanes to avoid striking V2 at the last minute.V1 sustained damage to the passenger-side front bumper. V2 sustained damage to the driver-side rear bumper.V1 was towed to Ken's Westside. V1's license plate had expired in April and D1 stated his insurance coverage had lapsed.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY

Manner of Collision: HEAD ON BETWEEN TWO MOTOR VEHICLES
NARRATIVE: V1, maroon GMC Sonoma, was traveling south on Curry Pike north of Gifford Road. V2, white Ford Fiesta, was traveling north on Curry Pike in the right lane north of Gifford Road. V1 traveled left of the center line and began traveling south on Curry Pike in the northbound lanes. V1 struck V2 head-on in the right northbound lane of Curry Pike. V1 came to final rest facing south in the northbound lane of Curry Pike at the area of impact. V2 rotated clockwise after impact and came to final rest facing southeast across both northbound lanes of Curry Pike.D1, Burris Jr, stated he was traveling south on Curry Pike. D1 stated he diverted his attention away from the roadway while checking his cellular telephone for a text message. D1 stated he looked up and realized he was traveling south in the northbound lanes. D1 stated he struck the front of V2 with the front of V1.D2, Felix, stated he was traveling north on Curry Pike in the right lane. D2 stated he observed V1 travel left of center and continue southbound in the northbound lanes. D2 stated he began to slow but was unable to swerve to avoid V1. D2 stated V1 struck the front of V2 with the front of V1.Evidence shows damage to the front of V1. Evidence shows damage to the front of V2. Evidence shows the impact occurred in the right northbound lane of Curry Pike north of Gifford Road. D1 was cited for driving left of center, operating with a suspended and driver's license and using a telecommunications device while driving. Both D1 and D2 refused medical treatment at the scene.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: D1 STATED THAT HE WAS PULLING OUT OF THE PARKING LOT OF 1870 SOUTH WALNUT STREET, TO GO NORTH ON TO SOUTH WALNUT STREET.D1 STATED THAT AS HE WAS TURNING LEFT, GOING NORTHEAST, ONTO WALNUT STREET THAT THE FRONT OF V2, WHICH WAS TRAVELING SOUTH ON WALNUT, DID MAKE CONTACT WITH THE REAR PASSENGER SIDE OF V1.D1 STATED THAT DAMAGE WAS DONE TO BOTH VEHICLES.D1 WAS UNSURE WHICH SOUTHBOUND LANE V2 WAS IN.D1 ALSO MENTIONED THAT V2 DID NOT HAVE ITS HEADLIGHTS ON. IT SHOULD BE NOTED THAT IT WAS STILL DAY LIGHT, BUT THE CONDITIONS WERE CLOUDY AND THERE WAS SIGNIFICANT RAINFALL.D2 STATED THAT SHE WAS IN THE LEFT SOUTHBOUND LANE, TRAVELING SOUTH ON WALNUT STREET.D2 STATED THAT SHE DID SEE V1 PULL OUT OF THE PARKING LOT OF 1870 SOUTH WALNUT STREET, BUT SHE COULD NOT STOP.D2 STATED THAT THE FRONT OF V2 DID MAKE CONTACT WITH THE REAR DRIVER'S SIDE OF V1, RESULTING IN DAMAGE TO BOTH VEHICLES.NEITHER VEHICLE WAS TOWED DUE TO DISABLING DAMAGE.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: D1 was headed E/B on Old SR 37, approaching N Walnut St. D2 was headed N/B on N Walnut St, in the left lane, approaching Old SR 37. D1 started to turn left onto N Walnut St from Old SR 37 when V2 struck V1 in the front passenger side of the vehicle. D2 was transported from the scene by EMS for possible injuries. D1 denied injuries at the scene. Both vehicles were towed from the scene due to disabling damage. D1 stated that he was headed E/B on Old SR 37, approaching N Walnut St. D1 stated that he stopped at the intersection and checked for traffic. D1 stated that he believed the roadway to be clear, so he began to turn left onto N Walnut St. D2 stated that V2 then struck V1 in the front passenger side. D1 stated that he never saw V2 until it struck his vehicle. D1 stated he believed that D2 was driving without her headlights on, causing him to not see her. It should be noted that when I checked the front of V2, the headlights were on. D2 stated that she was headed N/B on N Walnut St, approaching Old SR 37. D2 stated that as she approached Old SR 37, V1 pulled directly out in front of her, giving her no time to react. D2 stated that V2 then struck V1 in the front passenger side. D1 stated that she was driving with her headlights on.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: Vehicle 1 was traveling west on 10th Street approximately 510 feet east of the State Road 45/46 Bypass. Vehicle 2 was on 10th Street facing northwest and was slowly attempting to move into the right turn lane approximately 500 feet east of the State Road 45/46 Bypass.Driver 1 stated she had pulled out of a 2709 E 10th Street and was traveling west on 10th Street when she noticed Vehicle 2. Driver 1 advised she noticed that Vehicle 2 was stopped and she stated she stopped to see if Vehicle 2 was going. Driver 1 stated Vehicle 2 was not moving so she continued on and noticed Vehicle 2 was moving. She stated she tried to move over and was struck in the side by Vehicle 2. Driver 1 advised that she continued on to Tulip Tree Apartments on 10th Street before attempting to turn around and come back after realizing there was damage. Driver 1 described Vehicle 2 as an older red SUV.Driver 2 left the scene of the accident.No one involved complained of pain.Driver 1 had a driver's license from the Republic of Turkey.There was damage to the driver side of Vehicle 1. The damage to the Vehicle 2 is unknown. Video footage was located of the accident. Vehicle 2 appears to be a red Honda CR-V. It appears to enter the roadway and stops partially in the center and on the westbound side of the road. Vehicle 2 then appears to begin attempting to move across lanes and into the right turn lane. Vehicle 2 is traveling slowly due to traffic is backed up at the traffic light. Vehicle 1 is seen traveling west at a high rate of speed and does not stop at any point for Vehicle 2 even though it is already traveling into the lane. Vehicle 1 is seen striking Vehicle 2 and continuing on without stopping. Vehicle 2 is seen waiting momentarily before getting into the turn lane and continuing on as well.Photographs were taken of the damage and placed into evidence.

D2 stated he was stopped at the light facing southbound at the intersection of South Curry Pike and West State Road 45. D2 stated V1 rear ended him and then drove around his vehicle, crossing the double yellow median and then crossing in front of traffic and left westbound on West State Road 45.V1 was never located. D2 described V1 as a maroon single cab Dodge Ram truck, with dark tinted windows and LED headlights. D2 was unable to see the license plate.Photos were taken of V2 and logged into evidence.

Unit 1 was travelling west on ST RD 46 from the junction of Lori Ln. Due to slick road conditions, the car slid on an icy section of road, ran off the south side of the roadway and overturned into a ditch. Unit also hit some trees as it rolled over. Unit ended up on its drivers side.
D-1 stated that as she was traveling west bound on SR 45 a deer ran into her lane of travel at which time V-1 stuck the deer.

Vehicle 1 (white 2007 Dodge Ram) was northbound on SR37, approximately 100 ft north of Monroe Dam Road in the right lane. As vehicle 1 traveled north on the ice covered roadway, it slid into the left lane. Vehicle 1 then traveled west off the roadway and into the grassy median. Vehicle 1 came to rest after striking a culvert in the median. This resulted in damage to the front grill and passenger side wheel of the vehicle.Driver 1 (William F. West) advised that he was traveling northbound, approximately 100 feet north of Monroe Dam road. Driver 1 advised that he lost traction as he continued north and slid off the roadway and into the median. He advised that this resulted in damage to his vehicle.Evidence at the scene showed tire tracks off the roadway and into the median at the location of the crash. Damage to the vehicle was consistent with the story provided by the driver. The roadway in the area was also found to be slick and hazardous. The vehicle was towed from the scene by Weaver's Wrecker Service.

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: Driver 1 was driving on 10th Street from Unionville approaching Smith Road. After he passed Smith Road and he started to round the curve, he stated he noticed an accident in the opposite lane (B19-00588). Driver 1 stated he then attempted to slow down but hit a patch of black ice causing him to slide into the opposite lane and rear-end Vehicle 2 causing major damage to the rear of vehicle 2. Vehicle 2 was pushed into vehicle 3 but it is unknown if any damaged was caused to the front of vehicle 2 or vehicle 3 due to both cars sustaining major damage from the previous accident. Driver 1 had complaint of pain to his hand and shoulder but did not seek medical attention. *both D2 and D3 were transported to the hospital for injuries they stated they sustained from the prior accident. Both cars were also towed due to the damage from the prior accident.

D1 STATED HE WAS TRAVELING EASTBOUND ON W STATE ROAD 45 NEAR SPARKS ROAD EXITING A CURVE WHEN HE LOST CONTROL OF HIS VEHICLE DUE TO THE ICY ROADWAY. V1 LEFT THE ROADWAY ON THE NORTHSIDE OF THE ROAD, OVERTURNED NUMEROUS TIMES, AND CAME TO A REST IN A FLAT AREA JUST PAST THE EMBANKMENT APPROXIMATELY 50 TO 75 FEET OFF THE ROADWAY. WHILE RESPONDING TO THE CRASH I OBSERVED THE ROADWAY WAS BECOMING ICY. D1 HAD CUTS ON BOTH THE LEFT AND RIGHT HANDS AS WELL AS AN ABRAISION ON THE LEFT SIDE OF HIS FOREHEAD DUE TO IMPACT FROM HITTING HIS HEAD ON THE CAR ROOF. D1 REFUSED TO BE TRANSPORTED TO IU HEALTH BLOOMINGTON TO BE EVALUATED FURTHER ALTHOUGH WAS SEEN BY MEDICAL STAFF ON SCENE. THE VEHICLE WAS TOWED DUE TO DISABLING DAMAGE.

V1 WAS TRAVELING SB ON S PARK RIDGE RD BEHIND V2. AS V2, A TRANSIT BUS, BEGAN TO SLOW IN ORDER TO LET PASSENGERS OFF, V1 FAILED TO STOP PRIOR TO COLLIDING INTO V2. THE FRONT OF V1 COLLIDED WITH THE REAR OF V2.D1 STATED THAT SHE WAS BEHIND V2 AND DID NOT SEE HIM BEGIN TO SLOW DOWN TO STOP AND HIT HIM FROM BEHIND.D2 STATED THAT HE WAS STOPPED TO LET PASSENGERS OFF WHEN V1 STRUCK THE REAR OF THE BUS.

On 01/05/2019 at 2128 hours I arrived at the intersection of Atwater Avenue and Jordan Avenue in response to a two vehicle collision. I spoke with D1 who stated she was driving south on Jordan Avenue approaching the light at Atwater Avenue going about 20mph. D1 stated she thought the light was green at the time and went through the intersection where V1 and V2 collided. D1 stated to me after that she did not think the light was green when she drove through it. V1 sustained damage to the front passengers side. The bumper was smashed in and the right headlight was cracked. The wheel well over the front passenger tire was also bent in. D1 stated that her car would not start and that it was leaking a bunch of fluid. D1 called AAA and they came to tow the vehicle out of the roadway. I then spoke with D2 who stated she was traveling east on Atwater Avenue in the left lane approaching Jordan Avenue. D2 stated the light at Jordan Avenue had been a consistent green and that she was approaching the light going the speed limit. D2 then stated that D1 drove south through the intersection at a high rate of speed and collided with her vehicle. V2 sustained damage to the front drivers side. The drivers side bumper was smashed in and the bumper was hanging off the car near the ground. The front drivers side headlight was completely shattered and there were several wires and a container of liquid hanging out of the car. The hood was also pushed upwards and D2 stated her drivers side door was sticking when she opened and closed it.V2 was also towed from the area by AAA.

I, Officer Mark Freeman, was completing a traffic stop on the right side of the roadway and was walking back towards my police vehicle. I looked up and saw a car coming at me in the lane I was standing in. I put my arm up to motion her over and as I was about to jump onto the hood of my car, the driver (D1 in V1) swerved to the left into another lane without signaling her turn. She moved directly into the path of another vehicle (V2) and braked hard. The driver of the 2nd vehicle (D2 in V2) applied his brakes in an attempt to avoid striking V1, but rear-ended V2.It did not appear that V1 or V2 was traveling faster than the posted speed limit of 55 MPH.I did ask driver 2 (D2) if he had observed a turn signal come on from the vehicle he stuck (V1), and he stated that he didn't observe one.It should be noted that I was in a fully marked police vehicle and had my rear emergency lights on that was clearly visible to approaching traffic.Based on what I had observed, it is my professional opinion that driver 1 (Wang) made an unsafe lane change, and coupled with the fact that she was breaking hard in traffic, that she caused the accident to occur, and that driver 2 couldn't avoid the accident based on her actions. My emergency lights were visible for at least a half a mile, and driver 1 had plenty of time to slow down and make a safe lane change to move away from my police vehicle with my emergency lights activated.

Unit 1 was travelling north bound on South ST RD 37, near the exit for I69. Unit in left lane. Whilst going straight in their lane of travel, a red Toyota Tacoma came up inbetween unit 1 in the left lane, and an unknown vehicle in the right lane. The Tacoma proceeded to pass both cars, travelling on the center line and colliding with the passenger side of unit 1. Red Tacoma carried on Northbound and Unit 1 pulled off the road to report the incident. Damage to both passenger side doors, dents and paint damage.

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
Manner of Collision: HEAD ON BETWEEN TWO MOTOR VEHICLES
NARRATIVE: Driver 1 was driving on 10th Street from the Unionville area. Once she passed the intersection at Smith Road, she began to slide in the curve on the road. Driver 1 stated she slide on the ice into the opposite lane and into oncoming traffic. Driver 1 attempted to stop but continued sliding on the black ice. Driver 1 said she saw driver 2 coming towards her in his lane and that Driver 2 attempted to drive off the road to avoid her but could not. Driver 1 and Driver 2 then collided causing major damage. Driver 1 stated that a couple minutes later, she was then rear-ended by another vehicle (B19-00594). Driver 1 was transported to the hospital for her injuries (several lacerations to her knees/legs). Driver 2 stated he was on 10th Street headed towards the Unionville area and approaching the intersection with Smith Road when he saw Driver 1 sliding around the curve and into his lane. Driver 2 attempting to drive off his right side of the road to avoid collision but could not. Driver 1 and Driver 2 collided. Driver 2 stated a couple minutes passed and Driver 1 was rear-ended by another car that slide into Driver 2's lane. Driver 2 was transported to the hospital for his injuries (lacerations to knee, neck pain, etc).*large amount of black ice on road when officers arrived.

THE OWNER OF V2 STATED HE WAS NOTIFIED BY MANAGEMENT OF BEDRAK CAFE THAT HIS VEHICLE WAS STRUCK IN THE PARKING LOT AND THE OFFENDING VEHICLE HAD LEFT THE SCENE. A WITNESS WAS ABLE TO PROVIDE A VEHICLE DISCRIPTION AND PLATE NUMBER OF THE OFFENDING VEHICLE. THE PLATE WAS A INDIANA PASSENGER PLATE WITH NUMBER ASN191. THE VEHICLE DISCRIPTION OF THE VEHICLE WAS A MAROON PASSENGER VEHICLE. I PLACED A CALL TO THE WITNESS WHO INDICATED THAT THE OFFENDING VEHICLE STRUCK V2 HARD ENOUGH TO MAKE IT SURGE FORWARD. W 1 PROVIDED A PHYSICAL DISCRIPTION OF D1. SHE SAID THE DRIVER WAS AN ASIAN MALE, IN HIS 20'S WEARING GLASSES AND HAD SHORT HAIR. SHE ADDED THAT IT LOOKED LIKE V1 HAD BACKED NORTH FROM A PARKING SPACE WHEN IT STRUCK V2. THE PLATE INFORMATION PROVIDED BY THE WITNESS DID RETURN TO A 2008 MAROON TOYOTA, REGISTERED TO A DUC HUNG LE. AS OF TODAYS DATE I HAVE NOT LOCATED THE OFFENDING VEHICLE. ON 01/06/2019 I WENT TO 2677 E 7TH ST APT A AND OBSERVED A MAROON TOYOTA WITH A MATCHING PLATE NUMBER THAT THE WITNESS PROVIDED. I THEN MADE CONTACT WITH MR. HOANG DO WHO ADMITTED TO OPERATING THE 2008 MAROON TOYOTA IN THE PARKING LOT OF 409 S WALNUT YESTERDAY. HE ALSO SAID HE STRUCK A VEHICLE BUT DID NOT THINK THERE WAS ANY DAMAGE. MR. DO SAID HE DID NOT ATTEMPT TO MAKE CONTACT WITH THE OWNER AND LEFT. MR. DO WAS CITED FOR LEAVING THE SCENE.

V1 WAS TRAVELING WB ON W BLOOMFIELD ROAD AT THE INTERSECTION FOR THE I-69 SB ENTRY RAMP. V2 WAS IN FRONT OF V1 NEAR THE TRAFFIC SIGNAL AT THE SAME INTERSECTION. V1 STATED THAT A WATER BOTTLE ROLLED INTO HER FLOORBOARD AND WEDGED ITSELF BEHIND HER BRAKE PEDAL, NOT ALLOWING HER TO BRAKE. SUBSEQUENTLY, THE FRONT OF V1 COLLIDED WITH THE REAR OF V2.*UPDATED V1 INFORMATION, INITIALLY ENTERED INCORRECT VIN, MAKE, MODEL*

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: Vehicle 1 was traveling northbound in the 7300 Block of South Old State Road 37 when it lost traction due to ice forming on the roadway. Vehicle 1 slid across the southbound lanes and traveled off the west side of the roadway into the gravel driveway of 7390 South Old 37 and continued sliding into the grass separating 7390 and 7380 South Old 37 before colliding with a concrete retaining wall separating the two properties.Vehicle 2 was parked in the driveway of 7380 South Old State Road 37 investigating an earlier collision and sustained numerous scratches and dents to the passenger side doors and quarter panels from the mud and gravel debris dislodged during vehicle 1's slide. Vehicle 1 and 2 did not contact each other during the collision and no injuries were sustained by any persons involved.No significant damage was observed to the lawn, driveway, or retaining wall.

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: Vehicle 1 was northbound in the 7300 Block of South Old State Road 37 when ice forming on the roadway caused the vehicle to lose traction. Vehicle 1 began sliding into the southbound lanes and ultimately traveled off the west edge of the roadway into a ditch and stand of trees/vegetation.Driver 1's injuries included a complaint of neck pain and minor lacerations to his arms, hands, and legs. Driver 1 was evaluated by EMS at the scene and was not transported to the hospital.

V1 HAD JUST TURNED TO GO SOUTH IN THE PARKING LOT OF LUCKYS MARKET AT 2424 S WALNUT ST.V2 WAS BACKING OUT OF A PARKING SPACE IN THE ROW THAT V1 WAS PULLING INTO.D1 SAID WHEN SHE TURNED SHE DID NOT REALIZE 2 WAS BACKING OUT. SHE SAID AS SHE TURNED SHE HIT V2.D2 SAID HE HAD BACKED MOST OF THE WAY OUT OF THE PARKING SPACE WHEN HE SAW V1 COMING AT HIM AND THEY COLLIDED.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: D1 stated that she was at the intersection of W. 3rd Street and S. Cory Lane preparing to turn left, N/B, into the private lot located at 1918 W 3rd Street; Culver's Ice Cream. D1 stated that she had the green light, not turn arrow, and began entering into the intersection to make her turn. D1 stated that upon entering into the intersection she did not see V2 traveling W/B and V2 collided into the passenger's side of V1. D1 stated that V1 then rolled-over onto its' top and rested on the Northwest side of the intersection. D2 stated that she was traveling W/B on W. 3rd Street approaching the intersection at S. Cory Lane. D2 stated that upon approaching the intersection she had the green light to proceed into and through the intersection. D2 stated that upon entering into the intersection V1 pulled out in front of her and V2 collided into the passenger's side of V1. W1 stated that she was in the S/B turn lane off of W 3rd Street, at the intersection of S. Cory Lane, when the Accident occurred. W1 stated that V1 entered into the intersection to proceed N/B into the private lot at Culver's when V2 that was traveling W/B collided into the passenger's side of V1. W1 stated that V1 then rolled over onto its' top and rested on the Northwest side of the intersection. W2, Off-Duty Ellettsville Officer Alex Leggio, was not witness to the accident, but had dash camera footage of the event. After reviewing the video it confirmed the details in all parties statements listed above.All parties involved in the collision were transported to the IU Health Bloomington Hospital for Medical Evaluation, The following injuries have been reported; D1 had a complaint of pain to her right flank or "ribs". Front Seat Passenger of V1, Denise Terrell, reported a possible right collarbone break and had a minor cut to her chin.Rear Driver's side Passenger of V1, Jasper Keithley, reported a complaint of pain to his head.Rear Passenger's side Passenger of V1, Emmalyn Keithley, reported a complaint of pain to the abdomen and right arm.D2 had a complaint of pain to her chest and right arm. D2 would later refuse medical treatment at the hospital.Front Passenger of V2, Cameron Rayhill, reported a complaint of pain to his abdomen and shoulders. Rear Driver's side passenger of V2, Connor Guthrie, suffered a detached esophagus, laceration to the liver, and laceration to the spleen. Mr. Guthrie was transported by helicopter from IU Health Bloomington Hospital to Riley Hospital in Indianapolis. Mr. Guthrie is still listed in Critical Condition at the time of this Initial Report. At this time, based on the investigation detailed in the initial report, it appears that due to D1 failing to yield right-of-way to V2 resulted in the collision between V1 and V2.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY

BOTH VEHICLES WERE LOCATED AT THE BLOOMINGTON FIRE DEPARTMENT STATION 3 LOCATED AT 810 N. WOODLAWN AVE. D1 OCCUPIED V1 AND BACKED OUT OF WHERE HE WAS PARKED AND INTO THE UNOCCUPIED V2. D1 STATED HE WAS USING V1'S BACK UP CAMERA BUT DID NOT SEE V2 ON THE SCREEN. V1 HAS MINOR DAMAGE IN THE FORM OF A DENT AND LIGHT PAINT SCRAPES TO THE REAR DRIVER SIDE SIDE PANEL ABOVE THE WHEEL WELL. V2 HAS MINOR DAMAGE TO THE REAR DRIVER SIDE BUMPER IN THE FORM OF PAINT SCRAPES.

V1 WAS HEADING EAST ON W. KIRKWOOD AVE. V1 TURNED LEFT AT THE INTERSECTION OF W. KIRKWOOD AVE. AND N. COLLEGE AVE., TRAVELING NORTH AND THE WRONG WAY OR A ONE WAY. V1 SWERVED TO AVOID ONCOMING TRAFFIC AND STRUCK V2 ON THE PASSENGER SIDE REAR CORNER, WHICH WAS PARKED ON THE EAST SIDE OF N. COLLEGE AVE.D1 STATED THAT SHE WAS FOLLOWING HER PHONE GPS AND NOT PAYING ATTENTION WHEN IT SAID TO "TURN LEFT NOW". D1 STATED THAT SHE TURNED LEFT AND REALIZED IT WAS THE WRONG WAY ON A ONE WAY. D1 STATED THAT SHE WAS ATTEMPTING TO AVOID HITTING ONCOMING TRAFFIC AND SWERVED TO THE RIGHT, STRIKING V2. D1 STATED THAT SHE CONTINUED UNTIL SHE COULD PULL INTO A PARKING SPOT TO STOP.V2 WAS PARKED AND UNOCCUPIED ALONG THE EAST SIDE OF N. COLLEGE AVE. V1 was traveling South on I69 Southbound just south of the intersection with State Road 46 near mile marker 120. V1 was traveling in the right hand lane of travel when the vehicle ran off the roadway. V1 struck a road sign at the edge of the road and continued to drive off the roadway. V1 then came back onto the roadway before overturning twice in the roadway. V1 landed back upright and was facing Northeast. V1 continued driving forward and struck the concrete barrier wall. V1 sustained significant damage on many areas of the vehicle. D1 advised that he had been tired and fell asleep while driving. V1 was towed by Hawkins Towing to a friend of the owner at a private residence. D1 was treated on scene by EMS personnel for minor lacerations to his head. D1 submitted to SFST tests which did not indicate any intoxication. D1 was cited for Driving while Suspended with a prior conviction in the last 10 years. Passenger of V1 was treated at the scene for complaint of pain to his ankle.

V1 was attempting to turn onto N State Road 46 from E 3rd St at the intersection when the driver lost control of the vehicle and proceeded to strike the curb causing disabling damage to her vehicle. D1/V1 stated as she was turning right onto N State Road 46 from E 3rd St, her lost control of her vehicle prior to it striking the curb which caused significant damage to her left rear tire/wheel assembly area. V1 was towed from the scene by Rick's Towing due to disabling damage.

The management for the Circle S gas station at 2110 N Walnut St reported that vehicle 1 backed into a gas pump in their lot on 1/7/19 at 2:20 am. Management stated that the driver did not leave any information because it appeared there was no or very little damage to the pump. Management later found the a safety valve under the pump had been damaged. Management provided the plate number and images from security camera of the vehicle and driver. At the time of report I was unable to make contact with driver 1. The plate number and drivers license information does match the vehicle and driver in the images from the security camera. On 2/22/19 I located vehicle 1 at 221 E 16th St and made contact with the owner, Jon Noble. Mr Noble advised that he didn't think he did any damage to the pump and thought the clerk getting his license plate was enough.

D1 stated he was northbound on South Curry Pike when he was approaching the intersection of South Curry Pike and West Roll Avenue. D1 stated the vehicle in front of him stopped suddenly to make a left hand turn at the intersection right in front of him. D1 stated he did not have enough time to stop so he swerved around the vehicle and ran off the roadway and hit a fire hydrant and then came to final rest in a ditch.The fire hydrant is owned by the City of Bloomington.V1 sustained major right front damage and had to be towed due to disabling damage.No injuries were reported. No other vehicle were involved.

V1 was backing northbound out of a parking space, in the parking lot on the north side of the Gladstein Fieldhouse. V1 then backed into the large yellow curb directly behind the parking stall V1 was leaving. V1 had minor damage to the drivers side rear bumper. There was no damage to the curb. D1 stated that he was backing northbound and checked his mirrors. D1 stated that he did not see any obstructions or problems and continued to back. D1 stated that he then felt a bump and noticed that he had struck the curb. The vehicle did not need to be towed and there were no injuries at the scene.

State Road 46 is a four lane, two way highway that runs primarily east and west. At the time of the crash traffic was medium to heavy. It was dark outside and it had rained just prior to the crash, leaving the ground and road wet. Vehicle 1, a black Dodge Ram, was traveling west on SR 46 west of I 69. V1 traveled off of the roadway into the median. V1 hit the guard rail, flipped over the guard rail, then came to rest on the driver side of the truck in the middle of the median between two guard rails. Driver 1, Bradley Dewees, stated he was traveling west on SR 46 west of I 69. D1 said he remembered little of the crash. D1 said all he remembered was traveling west on SR 46 in the passing lane (left lane) when all of a sudden he hit the guard rail and flipped onto the driver side of the truck. Witness 1, Det./ Sgt. Eric Chaudion of the Ellettsville Police Department, was heading east on SR 46 just east of Curry Pike. W1 stated he watched V1 traveling west on SR 46 miss the curve and proceeded into the median. W1 said he watched as V1 climbed over the guard rail and started coming towards his vehicle. W1 told me he slowed down and merged into the right lane do to V1 coming towards his car. W1 watched as V1 flipped on its side and continued towards his car. W1 stated V1 came to rest a short distance later in between both guard rails. Evidence shows V1 was heavily damaged all over the truck and possible totaled. Evidence shows V1 was located flipped over on its driver side. Evidence shows heavy damage to the guard rail. Evidence shows D1 had been drinking alcohol prior to the accident. **Later D1 admitted to have been drinking just prior to the accident. He blew a .192% BaC on a Portable Breath Test (PBT) while still on scene. D1 also attempted to leave the crash scene prior to the arrival of law enforcement.

D1 STATED SHE WAS PARKED IN AN EAST FACING SPACE AND BEGAN TO BACK SOUTHWEST. D1 INDICATED SHE LOOKED IN HER MIRRORS PRIOR TO BACKING. D1 SAID SHE COLLIDED WITH V2 IN THE CENTER OF THE LANE. D2 STATED SHE WAS PARKED IN A WEST FACING SPACE AND LOOKED IN HER MIRRORS PRIOR TO BACKING EAST. D2 STATED SHE COLLIDED WITH V1 IN THE CENTER OF THE LANE.

V2 was parked facing E/B on Kirkwood. V1 was traveling E/B on Kirkwood attempting to parallel park in front of V2. V1 backed into V2 causing damage to the vehicle.D1 left the scene of the accident.V2 was parked facing E/B on Kirkwood. V2 was not occupied and I was not able to speak with the owner of V2. I made contact with two employees that work for the organization. I spoke with both employees who advised that they where sitting in the office when they heard a loud noise that they indicted sounded like a vehicle striking another vehicle. They advised that they went outside and noticed that the gray Chevrolet bearing plate (YFF165) which belonged to the organization had been struck.W1 was traveling E/B on Kirkwood Ave. W1 observed a black SUV with Indiana plate (TA****) back into V2 and drive away from the scene.Due to D1 unsafe backing, V1 struck V2 causing damage to V2.

On 1/7/2019 the Monroe County Sheriff's Office responded to a disturbance occurring at 4111 West Vernal Pike Lot 102 in Bloomington, Monroe County, Indiana where a male had been run over by a pickup truck. While officers were responding to the scene, Monroe County Central Dispatch received 911 calls from Andrew Ducker who was at Lot 102 and Ozzy Vaught who was the driver of the pickup truck involved. Ozzy Vaught advised dispatchers that he was the driver that hit a person, however left due to the volatile atmosphere at lot 102 and believed that it was unsafe to remain there until officers arrived. Ozzy Vaught met Deputy Dillon at a nearby grocery store and cooperated with the investigation.EMS and Deputy Walls and Brooks arrived at lot 102 and located the male that had been struck by the pickup truck, Wade Osborne. Deputies and EMS personnel at lot 102 requested additional assistance due to the volatile nature of the other individuals at the property. During the investigation, cell phone video recorded by Andrew Ducker showed Wade Osborne standing on the front porch of lot 102 and Ozzy Vaught and Gage Vaught inside of a silver Chevrolet truck parked in the street. The Vaughts and Mr. Osborne were attempting to yelling derogatory statements at each other and challenging the other to a fight. Near the end of the recording, Mr. Osborne exits the porch towards the Vaught's truck. The camera is pointed towards the ground, however the truck can be heard moving and a loud banging sound is believed to be Mr. Osborne striking the rear driver's side of the truck bed. Moments later, the truck can be heard moving and people screaming that the truck is on top of Mr. Osborne.Evidence at the scene suggests that the Chevrolet struck Mr. Osborne and his Lincoln Town Car during the incident. The Chevrolet sustained damage to the driver side front bumper and the Town Car sustained damage to the passenger side doors and rear quarter panel.Additional information regarding this investigation can be requested through the Monroe County Sheriff's Office Records Division for Report # M19-00778.

Primary Cause-Driver Factor-Unsafe Speed: D1 was traveling too fast for the conditions. The conditions were that V2 had stopped in traffic and V1 collided into the rear of V2. D1 should have driven at a reduced speed to avoid colliding into the rear of V2.SR46 is a highway that runs in a eastern and western direction through Monroe County. Trailway Drive is a local county road that runs in a northern and southern direction and intersects with SR46 1000 feet west of the crash. In the area of the crash the roadway is straight with an uphill grade. The road conditions were dry.V2 (white 2017 Dodge Ram 2500) was traveling westbound on SR46 and was stopped in traffic. V1 (2016 black Honda Civic) was traveling westbound on SR46 and was unable to stop. V1 collided into the rear of V2.D1 (Amira Morgan) stated she was traveling westbound on SR46 and saw V2 stopped. D1 stated she applied the brakes but was unable to stop and struck the rear of V2. She was wearing her seat belt.D2 (Jonathan Spiller) stated he was traveling westbound on SR46 and stopped in traffic due to a semi slowly traveling up the grade. D2 stated that V1 failed to stop and struck the rear of his vehicle.During the course of my investigation, I observed disabling damage to the entire front end of V1. I observed minor damage to the rear bumper and trailer hitch area of V2. There were no skid marks on the roadway. No injuries were reported as a result of this crash.The crash investigation showed the primary cause of the crash is unsafe speed on the part of D1. This was determined by driver statements and damage sustained to both V1 and V2.

V1 was traveling south on North Union Valley Road. A large tree branch fell from a tree and hit V1. D1 stated that it was very windy and he did not see the branch fall. D1 stated that he struck the branch as it was falling.

D1 (TAYLOR ROSEBROCK) WAS TRAVELING WESTBOUND ON 3RD STREET APPROACHING CURRY PIKE. D1 DISREGARDED RED LIGHT AT 3RD STREET AND CURRY PIKE. V1 STRUCK V2. D2 ADVISED D1 RAN RED LIGHT.

V2, gray Honda, was stopped at the traffic light in the right lane on SR48 eastbound at Profile Parkway. V1, beige GMC, was traveling east on SR48 behind V2. V1 failed to stop behind V2 and struck the rear of V2 with the front of V1. D1, Monteilh, stated he was behind V2 on SR48 near Profile Parkway. D1 stated he let off the brake and struck the rear of V2 with the front of V1. D2, Schwartz, stated he was stopped in the eastbound lane of SR48 at the traffic light. D2 stated V1 struck the rear of V2.Evidence shows minimal visible damage to the front of V1. Evidence shows minimal visible damage to the rear of V2.

V2 was parked stationary facing southbound in the SPEA parking lot. V1 was facing westbound prior to backing out of the parking space prior to the crash.D1 said he was backing out of his parking space in V1. D1 said when he was backing V1 out of its parking space V2 was right behind him. D1 said V1 then backed into V2. V1 had no noticeable damage to the rear bumper area.OP1 who was sitting in the driver seat of V2 parked stationary in the SPEA parking lot waiting for a friend. OP1 said V1 backed out striking V2. V2 had minor damage to the rear passenger corner side quarter panel area. No injuries occurred. Photos were taken.
D1 was back out of a private lot at 121 W Allen and struck the gate.
V1 backed into V2. V1 left the scene quickly. The witness knew who the driver was of V1 and was able to assist the police. A probable cause affidavit was completed to D1 for LSA.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: D1 STATED SHE WAS TRAVELING EAST ON 3RD STREET AND PROCEEDED INTO THE NORTH BOUND TURN LANE FOR GATES DR. D1 INDICATED SHE HAD THE GREEN LIGHT AND BEGAN TO MAKE HER LEFT TURN. D1 SAID SHE WAS THEN STRUCK BY V2. D2 STATED HE WAS TRAVELING WEST ON 3RD STREET IN THE NORTHERN MOST LANE. D2 SAID AS HE ENTERED THE INTERSECTION OF GATES DR, THE TRAFFIC SIGNAL WAS GREEN. D2 SAID V1 APPEARED IN FRONT OF HIM AND HE WAS UNABLE TO AVOID COLLISION AND STRUCK V1.

V1 was traveling northbound on Hartstrait Rd, passing the intersection of Woodyard road, when a deer came from the northeast corner of the intersection and struck the front passenger side of V1. The deer collided with V1 around the headlight and grill area. V1 was driveable.
V2 was parked facing East in the parking lot of 2813 E 3rd Street; Barnes and Noble.V1 was parked to the West of V2 and backed into the rear bumper of V2 before fleeing the scene.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: Driver two was shopping at Kroger South and come out to her vehicle. While loading food a man advised her that when the car next to her pulled in, drivers two vehicle was hit and he seen her vehicle shake. The man was parked in front of vehicle one and two. Driver one walked out of Kroger with a cart full of food and I advised her that she hit vehicle two. She stated she did not and advised she used to be the Clerk and a trustworthy person. She then stated the damage to her vehicle was old and it was an old car. She did not have a DL or reg for the vehicle. She also stated the damage was at a different height. I got a tape out and on both vehicle one and two the damage was the same, 18" off the ground. Damage on vehicle one and two was fresh.

P1 STATED THAT HE WAS WALKING ON THE EAST SIDE OF MULLER PARKWAY JUST OFF OF THE CURB IN THE ROADWAY. P1 STATED THAT D1 WAS TRAVELLING SOUTHBOUND ON MULLER PARKWAY AND WAS SWERVING ALL OVER THE ROADWAY. P1 STATED THAT D1 THEN GRAZED HIS LEFT KNEE, CAUSING HIM TO FALL AND A COMPLAINT OF PAIN. D1 THEN FLED THE SCENE.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: V1 STOPPED AT THE STOP SIGN AT LAKEVIEW AND 46. THEN ATTEMPTED TO TURN WEST ONTO STATE ROAD 46. WHILE DOING SO, HE STRUCK V2 THAT WAS ATTEMPTING TO TURN ONTO LAKEVIEW DRIVE FROM 46. V2 HAD THE RIGHT OF WAY.VEHICLE 1 MOVED FROM POINT OF IMPACT. NO DIAGRAM.

Traffic Control: RR CROSSING FLASHING LIGHTS AND GATES
NARRATIVE: V1 was traveling directly behind V2, north bound, on Curry Pike. V2 was stopping for a railroad crossing and V1 crashed into the rear of V2.

D1 ADVISED HE WAS EAST ON W 3RD ST AT OFF RAMP FOR N BOUND SR 37 TO W 3RD, IN THE SOUTHERN MOST LANE, THE LEAD CAR, AND DID NOT REALIZE THE LIGHT WAS RED FOR HIS LANE OF TRAFFIC. D1 SAID AS HE CONTINUED THROUGH THE INTERSECTION AT APPROXIMATELY 30 MPH HE SAW V2 TURNING FROM NORTH BOUND TO WEST BOUND IN FRONT OF HIM AND TRIED TO BREAK BUT COULD NOT IN TIME AND STRUCK THE DRIVER'S SIDE OF V2 WITH THE FRONT OF V1. D1 COMPLAINED OF NECK PAIN BUT REFUSED MEDICAL ATTENTION.D2 ADVISED SHE WAS IN THE WESTERN MOST LEFT TURN LANE OF THE SR 37 N BOUND OFF RAMP AT A GREEN LIGHT TURNING LEFT (WEST BOUND ONTO W 3RD ST) AT APPROXIMATELY 20 MPH, WHEN V1 DROVE EAST BOUND ON W 3RD ST THROUGH THE RED LIGHT STRIKING THE DRIVER'S SIDE OF V2. D2 ADVISED ALL TRAFFIC WAS STOPPED BUT THE N BOUND EXIT RAMP TRAFFIC FROM SR 37 N WHEN THE CRASH OCCURRED AND SHE DID NOT SEE V1 UNTIL SHE WAS IN THE INTERSECTION AND IT WAS TOO LATE TO AVOID THE CRASH. D2 COMPLAINED OF LOWER BACK/SHOULDER/KNEE PAIN ON HER LEFT SIDE, STATING THAT THE LOWER BACK PAIN WAS PROBABLY THE WORST. D2 REFUSED MEDICAL ATTENTION.

D2 stated he was stopped facing westbound at the intersection of West Tapp Road and South Leonard Springs RD when V1 failed to stop behind him and rear ended him. D2 complained of neck pain and was treated on scene and was not transported.D1 fled the scene and was not located. The identity of D1 was discovered by officers after a friend of D1 showed up on scene and told officers who was driving the vehicle.Pictures were taken and logged into evidence.V1 sustained minor damage to the right front bumper and V2 sustained major damage to the left back bumper.

V1 and V2 turned west bound on East Linda Lane. V1 was stopped in the lane of travel and began to back up. V1 backed into V2. The muffler on the passenger side of V1 struck the front drivers side bumper of V2.

V1 was driving north on US 45/46. V2 was stopped in traffic facing north on US 45/46. V3 was also stopped in traffic facing north on US 45/46.D1 stated she was driving north on US 45/46 passing Range Road. D1 stated that her son was making funny noises because of the construction site they were passing. D1 stated she looked away from the road to see what her son was looking at and when she looked back to the road V2 was stopped in front of her. D1 stated she could not brake in time and collided with the rear bumper of V2.D2 stated that he was stopped in traffic facing north on US 45/46 when D1 collided with his rear bumper. D2 stated that the collision pushed his vehicle forward and collided with V3 until coming to reset on the sidewalk.D3 stated that he was stopped in traffic facing north on US 45/46 when V2 collided with his rear bumper.

V1 and V2 were traveling S/B on College Mall RD. V1 rear ended V2 causing damage to the V2.D1 advised that she was traveling S/B on College Mall RD. D1 stated that she got distracted and took her eyes off the road for in attempt to locate Kroger. D1 advised that when she turned her head she realized that traffic had stopped ahead of her. D1 stated that she slammed on her brakes, and rear ended V2 causing damage to V2. D1 advised that she was not injured. D2 advised that she was traveling S/B on College Mall RD. D2 advised that traffic had slowed down and another vehicle in front of her had come to a complete stop. D2 stated that she began slowing down before she felt the impact from V1. D2 advised that she was not injured.Due to D1 following to closely, V1 rear ended V2 causing damage to V2.

D1 STATED HE WAS DRIVING SOUTH ON N BOTTOM ROAD TOWARDS W. SIMPSON CHAPEL WHEN A DEER RAN ACROSS THE ROAD. D1 STRUCK THE DEER WITH THE FRONT OF HIS VEHICLE. I LOCATED THE DEER AND IT HAD TO BE PUT DOWN.VEHICLE MOVED PRIOR TO MY ARRIVAL.

Primary Cause-Driver Factor-Unsafe Speed: V1 was traveling too fast for the conditions. The conditions were that V2 was slowing behind another vehicle preparing to make a right turn. V1 should have driven at a reduced speed to avoid colliding into the rear of V2.SR46 is a highway that runs in a eastern and western direction through Monroe County. Chafin Chapel Road is a county road that runs in a northern and southern direction and intersects with SR46, 50 feet west of the crash. The roadway in the area of the crash is straight with a downhill/grade. The roadway was dry at the time of the crash.V1 (2014 blue Jeep Cherokee) was traveling westbound on SR46 behind V2 (2012 gray Dodge Caravan). V2 was slowing behind another vehicle preparing to make a right (north) turn. V1 was unable to slow or stop before colliding into the rear of V2.D1 (John Bennett) stated that he was traveling westbound on SR46 and had crested the hill. As he was traveling down the grade he observed V2 slowing. D1 stated he applied the brakes, but was unable to stop before colliding into the rear of V2. He was wearing his seat belt.D2 (Clesta Keller) stated she was traveling westbound on SR46. A vehicle in front of her was preparing to turn right on Chafin Chapel Rd. D2 stated she was slowing and then was struck in the rear by V1. She was wearing her seat belt.During the course of my investigation, I observed 20 feet of skid marks on the roadway from V1. V1 had damage to the entire front end. V2 had damage to the rear bumper and back hatch area. No injuries were reported as a result of this crash.The crash investigation showed that the primary cause of the crash is Unsafe Speed on the part of D1. This was determined by driver statements, skid marks on the roadway, and damage sustained to both vehicles.

UNKNOWN DESCRIPTORS ON V1/D1. V2 WAS PARKED IN THE WEST PARKING LOT OF 581 E. HILLSIDE DR. IN A PARKING STALL. SOMETIME BETWEEN 2200 HOURS ON 1/8/19 AND 1500 HOURS ON 1/9/19 V2 WAS STRUCK. V2 SUSTAINED DAMAGE IN THE FORM OF SMALL DENTS, SCRATCHES, AND PAINT SCRAPES ALONG THE PASSENGER SIDE OF THE VEHICLES FRONT AND REAR BUMPER AND QUARTER PANEL. IT IS BELIEVED THAT V1 WAS PARKED IN THE STALL TO THE LEFT AND WHILE BACKING UP, STRUCK V2.

D1 stated he was traveling westbound on West 3rd Street in the far right lane. As D1 approached the intersection at South Landmark Avenue a pedestrian stumbled out into the roadway causing D1 to clip the pedestrian damaging the passenger side mirror. D1 stated he had the green light. I spoke with the pedestrian who stated he was crossing the street at South Landmark Avenue when he was struck by a vehicle. The pedestrian stated he had a few alcoholic beverages this evening and I did observe the odor of alcohol on his person. The pedestrian reported pain on his back as well as his head. I observed a small abrasion on the right side of his head. He was transported to IU Health Bloomington by EMS truck 214. It should be noted that both D1 and the pedestrian went to 215 S. Westplex Ave after the accident occurred to make the report. During my investigation it was discovered that D1's license is suspended infraction. A citation was issued. Photos were taken at the scene.

D2 stated she was heading South on College Avenue in the right hand lane near Dodds Street. D2 stated as she was going around the corner V1 struck her driver side door pushing her off the roadway.D2 stated that V1 left the area very quickly.

Vehicle 1 was southbound on I-69 north of the 125mm. V1 was behind the Other Participant when OP's trailer struck a construction barrel. The barrel was pushed out into the roadway and V1 collided with the barrel causing damage to V1.Driver of V1 stated he was southbound on I-69 behind the Other Participant. The Other participant struck a construction barrel with his trailer and it went out into the roadway. Driver of V1 stated the barrel came out into the path of his vehicle and he was unable to avoid colliding with it. Driver of V1 struck the barrel and caused damage to the front end of the vehicle. The Other Participant stated he was southbound on I-69 north of the 125 mm and was pulling off the roadway onto the emergency strip. OP stated the trailer he was pulling clipped a construction barrel and pushed it out into the roadway. The barrel ended up in the path of V1 who collided with the barrel.The Other Participant:Martin Minton, DOB: 03/06/19892005, green, Chevrolet, pick-upPlate # TK196LCKVIN# 1GCHK39UX5E211866Trailer Plate # L492972018 modelVIN# 4P5DH1424J3027820Insurance Info: National Trust Ins.Policy # CA100011857-01

Manner of Collision: HEAD ON BETWEEN TWO MOTOR VEHICLES
NARRATIVE: V1 was traveling S/B on Patterson DR. V2 was traveling N/B on Patterson DR. V1 struck V2 while disregarding a red traffic control signal. D1 left the scene of the accident.D2 advised that he was traveling N/B on Patterson DR approaching the intersection of 2nd ST. D2 advised that the traffic control signal had turned green in his direction and he proceeded through the intersection. D2 advised that V1 heading S/B on Patterson DR continued through traffic to turn E/B on 2nd St. D2 advised that he then felt the impact of V1. D2 advised that D1 left the scene. D2 had a complaint of pain of 7 out of 10 to his left arm and was transported to IU Health Bloomington for his injury. I spoke with W1 who advised that he witnessed the accident. He stated that he was directly behind V2 when the traffic control signal in his direction had turned green. W1 advised that D1 traffic control signal had turned red and he saw D1proceed through the intersection as well before striking V2. W1 advised that D1 left the scene.Due to D1 disregarding the traffic control signal, V1 struck V2 causing damage to V2.
DRIVER ADVISED THAT SHE WAS TRAVELING SOUTH EAST ON W WOODYARD ROAD WHEN SHE RAN OFF THE ROAD, HIT A POT HOLE AND LOST CONTROL OF HER VEHICLE.

DRIVER NUMBER 1 STATED SHE WAS DRIVING VEHICLE NUMBER 1 TRAVELLING EAST BOUND SR46 APROXIMATELY 5225 BLOCK WHEN VEHICLE NUMBER 2 PULLED OUT IN FRONT OF VEHICLE NUMBER 1 SLAMMING ON BRAKES CAUSING VEHICLE NUMBER 1 TO REAR END VEHICLE NUMBER 2.DRIVER NUMBER 2 STATED HE WAS EAST BOUND SR46 WHEN HE OBSERVED A SCHOOL BUS WEST BOUND SR46 ILLUMINATE ITS STOP LIGHTS AND SIGN. VEHICLE NUMBER 2 CAME TO AN ABRUPT STOP AND WAS STRUCK BY VEHICLE NUMBER 1.

Driver was east bound on State Road 46 when a deer entered the roadway in his lane of travel. The driver was unable to avoid hitting the deer with the front of his vehicle causing heavy damage. The driver drove the vehicle to Community Chrysler on south Walnut St in Bloomington, IN. I met the driver at Community Chrysler to take the crash report.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: Vehicle 2 was traveling east on Second Street. Vehicle 1 was traveling south on Mitchell St. Both vehicles stopped at the 4-way stop at the intersection of Second and Mitchell at the same time. Both driver's stated that a third vehicle proceeded through the intersection first. Because vehicle 1 and 2 arrived at the intersection at the same time, Vehicle 2 had the right of way and began into the intersection. Vehicle 1 failed to yield right of way to vehicle 2 and the vehicles collided in the middle of the intersection. Vehicle 2 has damage to the front and Vehicle 1 has damage to the passenger side of the vehicle. Driver of vehicle 1 reported minor chest pain but denied any medical treatment from EMS. Driver of vehicle 2 had no injuries. Both vehicles still drivable and were not towed.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: V1 was traveling north on Fee Lane, and was attempting to make a left turn to head west on 11th street. V2 was heading south on Fee Lane at the same intersection. V3 was stopped at the stop sign on 11th street, facing east, at the same intersection. V1 turned left from Fee Lane, to go west on 11th street, failing to yield to V2. V2 then struck V1 in the passenger side door, causing V1 to be pushed towards 11th street, and ultimately making contact with the front bumper of V3, with the driver side rear door of V1.D1 stated he was attempting to turn left onto 11th street, to go west, and did not see V2 until it was too late. D1 stated he was then struck by V2 in the passenger side door. D1 said the impact caused his vehicle to be pushed into V3, striking V3 with the driver side rear door. There was heavy damage to the passenger side door, and light damage to the driver side rear door, but the vehicle was able to drive away from the scene. D2 said she was traveling south on Fee Lane. D2 said V1 turned towards 11th street right in front of her, and she was not able to get stopped in time. D2 said she then struck V1 in the passenger side door with the front end of her vehicle. There was heavy damage to the front end of V2, and the vehicle had to be towed away from the scene by Bland's Towing. D3 said he was stopped at the stop sign on 11th street, facing east. D3 said V2 struck V1 in the passenger side door, which caused V1 to be pushed towards his vehicle. D3 said V1 struck the front bumper of his vehicle, with the driver side rear door of V1. There was very light damage to the front bumper of V3, and the vehicle was able to drive away from the scene.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: V1 WAS TRAVELING EB ON E DILLMAN ROAD, ATTEMPTED TO CROSS S OLD SR 37 AND HIT V2 WHO WAS TRAVELING NB IN THE REAR DRIVER'S SIDE.D1 STATED THAT SHE DID NOT SEE V2.D2 STATED THAT V1 STRUCK HIS VEHICLE.FOLLOWING THE COLLSION, BOTH VEHICLES MOVED FROM THE POINT OF IMPACT OFF THE ROADWAY, SO NO DIAGRAM COMPLETED.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
Manner of Collision: HEAD ON BETWEEN TWO MOTOR VEHICLES
NARRATIVE: VEHICLE 1 WAS TRAVELING WEST BOUND ON WEST GORDON PIKE. VEHICLE 2 WAAS TRAVELING NORTH BOUND ON SOUTH ROGERS STREET. VEHICLE 1 STUCK VEHICLE 2 IN THE FRONT PASSENGER DOOR AT THE INTERSECTION OF SOUTH ROGERS STREET AND WEST GORDON PIKE.DRIVER 1 STATED SHE WAS GOING STRAIGHT, THOUGHT IT WAS HER TURN, TWO CARS WENT BEFORE HER.DRIVER 2 THOUGHT ITWAS HER TURN AND THEN WAS T-BONED IN THE INTERESECTION.BOTH DRIVER 1 AND DRIVER 2 REFUSED ANY MEDICAL ATTENTION. BOTH VEHICLE 1 AND VEHICLE 2 WERE DRVIABLE AND DRIVEN FROM THE SCENE.

V1 was traveling northbound on High Street. V1 slid on the ice causing V1 to leave the roadway, driving thru a fence.D1 stated that she was traveling northbound on High Street when her car began to slide on the ice. V1 slid off the roadway, going thru a fence.

V2 was traveling southbound on N Dunn Street approaching E Kirkwood Avenue. V2 stopped at the red stop sign at the intersection of N Dunn Street and E Kirkwood Avenue. As V2 proceeded through the intersection, continuing southbound, V1 came from the west eastbound. V1 is an electric motor-driven "Lime" scooter. V1 was riding on the sidewalk on the north side of E Kirkwood Avenue and did not stop at the intersection. Police were not called to the scene and D2 later reported the accident. D1 stated to D2 that they were not injured on scene, but later complained of numbness. V1 was operating on the sidewalk and did not stop at the red stop sign, causing a collision with V2.

Driver 1 stated he was stopped behind vehicle 2 southbound on Kingston Dr at the red light for 3rd St. Driver 1 stated the light turned green and vehicle 2 started to go, but then stopped. Driver 1 stated he then collided with the rear of vehicle 2. Driver 1 stated vehicle 2 was not using a turn signal. Driver 2 stated that he intended to turn right when the light changed to green and that he had his turn signal on. Driver 2 stated when the light turned green he started to pull forward to turn, but then stopped because a pedestrian was crossing 3rd St from south to north in his path. Driver 2 stated vehicle 1 then hit him from behind.

On January 11th, 2019, D2 reported a collision that occurred the night prior on January 10th, 2019. There was video surveillance of the collision. I observed the video surveillance. D1 is seen traveling north of S Fairfax Road then turns into the Fairfax Inn parking lot. D2 is seen traveling south through the parking lot. D1 collides into the left side of D2 at a right angle. D1 then reverses back onto Fairfax Road (almost hits another vehicle) then drives north. Video shows the collision occurred January 10th, 2019 at 7:17 P.M. D1 left the scene of the accident. D1 did not make contact with D2.Investigation is on going to locate D1.***Supplement 1/20/2019***D1 was located and interviewed. D1 admitted to being involved in the collision and stated he left the scene because he panicked and "freaked out" because the vehicle was not plated and possibly did not have insurance.

V1 fled the scene. V1 and V2 were facing North on Faculty Lane. D2 stated that she turned left out of the Atwater Parking Garage on to Faculty Lane. D2 stated that as she turned on to Faculty Lane D1 started to back up. D2 stated that she stopped and was unable to get out of the way when V1 struck V2. D2 stated that she pulled in to the nearby alley and D1 followed her. D2 stated that D1 asked her if she was hurt and noticed that she was on the phone and drove off East bound down the alley. D2 described the vehicle as a newer dark blue Subaru Crosstrek. D2 was unable to get any plate information.

Vehicle #1(Black 2013 Mazda 3) was slowed in traffic, eastbound on SR 46, at the intersection of 3rd Street. Vehicle #2 (Silver 2010 Volkswagen Eos) was stopped at the stop light eastbound on SR 46, at 3rd Street. Vehicle #1 struck Vehicle #2 in the rear. This resulted in damage to the front of Vehicle #1, and light damage to the rear of Vehicle #2.Driver #1(Evan Tiffany) stated he was stopped at the traffic light on SR46, at the intersection of 3rd Street, when the light turned green. Driver #1 stated that he thought Vehicle #2 had began accelerating, but realized Vehicle #1 was still stopped before he could stop in time to avoid the collision. Driver #2(Emma Schilling) stated she was stopped in traffic on SR46 eastbound at the intersection of 3rd Street. Driver #2 stated that while she was stopped at the light, Vehicle #1 rear ended her.

D1 stated that she was in the private parking lot of 350 S Landmark Avenue, preparing to leave. D1 stated that she began pulling out of the parking stall, SE/B, and turning left. D1 stated that it was at this time she noticed P1 in front of her vehicle at which time V1 collided with P1.P1 stated that she was walking through the parking lot W/B towards to the business at 250 S Landmark Avenue. P1 stated that V1 pulled out of a parking stall striking her right knee. P1 stated that her knee "popped" at impact and has a complaint of pain.At this time based on the statements provided at the scene, due to D1 improperly turning resulted in the collision between V1 and P1.

Vehicle 2 was backed into a parking spot in the parking lot of 502 W. 2nd Street facing east bound. According to a witness at approximately 11:00 AM vehicle 1 backed into the front of vehicle 2 knocking out the headlight and cracking the grill. Vehicle 1 then left the scene of the accident.No information is known about the vehicle owner or driver of vehicle 1.

Manner of Collision: HEAD ON BETWEEN TWO MOTOR VEHICLES
NARRATIVE: V1 was facing southbound in the parking lot at 205 S Madison St. V2 was facing northbound in the parking lot. V1 was stolen and attempted to exit the lot glancing off V2 as it left. V1 then traveled west across Madison St, glancing off a small tree, and then traveled south striking another tree head on. The male driver, then fled the area.

V1 was parked in parking space at Vectren at 205 S Madison street facing SB. An unknown driver got in the unlocked vehicle that was running and drove the vehicle into a fence just south of where it was parked. The unknown driver then fled the scene.

V2 was slowing or stopped facing south, on Jordan Avenue, at the intersection of 10th Street and Jordan Avenue. V1 was traveling south on Jordan towards 10th Street. V1 then rear ended V2. V2 had light damage to the rear bumper. V1 had no damage. D1 stated that he was traveling south on Jordan towards 10th Street. D1 stated that he looked over for a minute to talk to his friend and did not notice that V2 had stopped in front of him. D1 stated that V1 then rear ended V2. D2 stated the same story that she was stopped at the light and V1 rear ended V2. There were no injuries reported at the scene and no vehicles had to be towed from the scene.

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: V1 was traveling eastbound on State Road 45/46 at approximately 35-45 MPH. V2 was also traveling eastbound on State Route 45/46, approximately 1 car length behind V1 according to D2. D2 advised me that he was in the lane to the left of V1. The roadway at the time of the accident had 2-3 inches of snow accumulation with persistent snowfall as well. D2 advised me that while behind V1 he observed V1 begin to lose control. He stated that the rear end of V1 began to swing to the right. D2 said at this point he left his lane and move 1 lane over to the left, to the center turn lane. D2 stated that V1 then turned completely sideways in the roadway and traveled north across the lanes of traffic and impacted his front right bumper and tire. When I asked D1 about the incident he confirmed the sequence of events that D2 had previously advised me of. He stated he was going straight and suddenly lost control.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: V1 and V2 were traveling east on West 3rd St. At the intersection of W 3rd and hwy 37 V1 stopped in the right side turn lane to travel north onto HWY 37. V2 stopped in the left side turn lane to travel north on HWY 37. As the traffic light turned green both V1 and V2 accelerated and began to turn left onto HWY 37 North. At that time V2 collided with the rear driver side corner of V2 causing damage to the rear of V1 and the front of V2.D1 stated that she was in the right side turn lane attempting to travel onto HWY 37 and as she was driving V2 collided with the rear of her vehicle. D1 stated that she was not aware what lane V2 was in when they began to turn. When asked D1 stated that she was unsure if she stayed in the defined lane, but believed that she did.D2 stated that they had been in the left turn lane to travel onto HWY 37 and as they began to turn V1 veered from the right turn lane and traveled into the left turn lane causing V1 to be in the line of travel of V2. D2 stated that he attempted to apply his brakes but was unable to in time to avoid the accident. D2 stated that is when V2 collided with the rear of V1.Damage to the vehicles did match the statement made by D2.

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: State Road 46 is a four lane, two way highway that runs primarily east and west. At the time of the crash, it was dark outside, it was snowing, and the roadway was slick with slush and ice. A winter storm advisory had been in affect. Vehicle 1, a yellow state highway dump truck with a large snow plow on front, was traveling east on SR 46, approaching the Curry Pike intersection. Vehicle 2, a white ford pick-up with a snow plow on the front, was turning south onto Curry Pike from westbound SR 46. V1 struck the passenger side of V2. V2 spun counter clockwise before coming to rest facing northwest in the middle of north bound Curry Pike and east bound SR 46. V1 came to a stop facing east on SR 46 in the middle of north bound Curry Pike. Driver 1, Carl Strange, stated he was traveling east on SR 46 approaching the Curry Pike intersection. As he came to the intersection, D1 said the light turned red. D1 said he applied his brakes, but his truck slid through the intersection. D1 told me he struck V2 with the large plow that was attached to the front of his truck. D1 said he finally came to a stop in the right lane of SR 46 facing east in the middle of the northbound Curry Pike. Driver 2, Steven Deckard, said he was turning south onto Curry Pike from westbound SR 46. D2 said the traffic light had indicated his right of way by flashing a green turn arrow to turn south onto Curry Pike. While starting to head south on Curry Pike, D2 advised that V1 struck his truck near the rear passenger side of his vehicle. D2 told me his truck spun counter clock wise before coming to rest facing northwest in the middle of north bound Curry Pike and east bound SR 46.Evidence shows little to no damage to V1. Evidence shows heavy damage to the passenger side of V2. Evidence shows heavy snow fall at the time of the crash with slush, snow, and ice on the roadway. Evidence shows the traffic light was fully operational at the time of the crash.

Driver one state while driving East on Bethel Lane, his vehicle got away from him. Vehicle one drove off the road and hit a utility pole and knocked it down. Tacks in the road indicate vehicle one attempted to slow/stop leaving approximately 300 feet of tire track marks before hitting the pole.

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: Driver #1 stated she was traveling west on Robinson Road when she lost control due to the current weather conditions. At the time of the crash, it had been snowing overnight with approximately 4 inches of snow on the roadway and it was still currently snowing. Driver #1 stated she went off the roadway where her vehicle struck a tree, causing severe damage to the front and sides of the truck. I met the driver and vehicle at Pritchards towing for the report as the weather conditions extended out arrival to the scene and for safety reasons it was better to get the vehicle loaded and away from the crash area to avoid any other crashes.

V2 was parked in the parking lot in a parking space facing south unattended. V1 was plowing snow in the parking lot and was backing up southeast in direction prior to the crash. D1 said he was plowing snow in the parking lot on the northeast corner at the intersection of 6th Street and Dunn Street in V1. D1 said V2 was the only vehicle in the parking lot at the time. D1 said he put V1 in reverse and backed up striking V1 bumper into V2 rear passenger quarter panel.Both V1 and V2 had minimal damage.Pictures of the accident are available.Owner of V2 was notified of accident and provided crash number.

Vehicle 1 was traveling south on North Thomas Road attempting to turn right (west) onto West Prominence Point. The roadway was snow-covered. No diagram was completed. Invoice for sign replacement attached.

THE OWNER OF V2 STATED THAT HE HAD PARKED V1 IN FRONT OF HIS RESIDENCE, 452 EAST LAURELWOOD DRIVE, FACING WEST.THE OWNER OF V2 STATED THAT AT SOME POINT AROUND 12:00 AM ON 01/12/2019 ANOTHER VEHICLE DID MAKE CONTACT WITH THE REAR PASSENGER CORNER OF V2, RESULTING IN DAMAGE TO THE REAR PASSENGER CORNER OF V2.D1 DID NOT STOP AND DID NOT MAKE CONTACT WITH THE OWNER OF V2.THERE IS NO SUSPECT/VEHICLE INFORMATION IN REGARDS TO V1 OR D1.V2 DID NOT HAVE DISABLING DAMAGE.

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: V1 was driving southbound through the Wright Quad circle drive when he lost control of his vehicle and struck a curb. Wright Quad is a one way circle drive that curves and is on a hill. V1 was driving the wrong way.I spoke to D1 who stated he had just dropped off some people at Wright Quad. He stated he was unfamiliar with the area and did not realize it is a one way road. D1 then began driving southwest through the drive. D1 stated that as he reached the hill on the turn, he stepped on the brakes however they locked and he could not stop or turn his vehicle. He stated this was when his vehicle struck the curb. He stated the rear wheel also struck the curb when he finally came to a stop. There is major damage to the entire front wheel, some scuffs on the front bumper, and some minor damage to the rear wheel. V1 had to be towed.

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
