Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS

THERE ARE LARGE RUT MARKS IN THE GRASS. PICTURES WERE TAKEN OF THE SCENE, VEHICLE, AND THE INJURY TO D1. THERE WERE NO PHOTOGRAPHABLE INJURIES TO THE FRONT RIGHT PASSENGER. Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: Driver #1 stated he was heading south on Strain Ridge Road when he lost control of his vehicle due to the snow covered roads. This sent Vehicle #1 left of center where it struck Vehicle #2, which was driving north on Strain Ridge Road. Vehicle #2 attempted to swerve off the right side of the roadway to avoid the crash but was unable to do so.

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: This crash occurred on southbound Interstate 69 at the 124 mile marker. Interstate 69 is multi-lane interstate, divided by a guardrail, that primarily runs north and south. At the scene of the crash there were three lanes southbound.Vehicle #1, a 2016 Ford F-350 pickup truck, was southbound in the far left lane. Vehicle #2, a 2019 Freightliner conventional cab semi pulling a 53 foot box trailer, was traveling in the far right lane. As vehicle #1 was attempting to pass vehicle #2, it hit snow/slush on the roadway, lost control, slid across the middle lane and into the driver side of vehicle #2.Driver #1, Jonathan Crill, stated that he was southbound on I-69 in the far left lane when he hit snow/slush causing him to lose control. Driver #1 stated that his vehicle slid across the middle lane and into the side of vehicle #2 who was traveling in the far right lane. Driver #2, Marcel Laloi, stated that he was traveling south on I-69 in the far right lane. As vehicle #1 was passing in the far left lane, vehicle #1 hit snow/slush, lost control and slid into the side of vehicle #2. Evidence on the scene indicates that vehicle #1 was traveling too fast for road conditions, hit snow/slush causing driver #1 to lose control and hit vehicle #2.

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: Driver 1 stated that he was rounding the turn from Briarcliff Dr onto northbound Valley View Dr. Driver 1 stated that a truck parked on the side of the road blocked his view around the corner. Driver 1 stated that when he came around the corner there was a City of Bloomington snow plow stopped in the road. Driver 1 stated he tried to stop, but slid downhill on the snow/slush covered roadway. Driver 1 stated that he clipped the front of the plow and then slid into a mailbox at 3131 N Valley View Dr. Driver 2 stated that he had gone around a car that was stuck going uphill on Valley View Dr and had stopped in order to back up to lay down snow melt to assist the stuck vehicle. Driver 2 stated that vehicle 1 then came around the corner onto Valley View and tried to stop, but lost control and slid into the plow.

V2 is an Indiana University Police Department marked squad car (#35217). V1 had just been pulled over by V2 after D1 was observed driving erratically. V1 was sitting facing east on Atwater Ave just east of Eastside Dr. V2 was parked behind V1 on the traffic stop.Officer T. Zeiser was speaking with D1 at the driver's window. D1 showed signs of heavy intoxication. D1 took his foot off of the brake and turned the ignition off while leaving the vehicle in drive while speaking to the officer. V1 then rolled backward and collided with the front of V2, damaging both vehicles.D1 was arrested for OWI, Driving without Ever Receiving a License, and Driving While Suspended-Prior. D1 does not have a license, but nonetheless has suspended privileges anyway (IN OLN 8010525860).D1 consented to a blood draw and results are pending.On 03-25-19 IUPD received a copy of D1's alcohol analysis toxicology report. D1 had more than .400 g/100 mL of ethanol in his blood. His BAC was so high that the ISDT lab was unable to provide a more exact result. The lab also found .011 g/100 mL of methanol, also. On 08-14-19 IUPD received the drug analysis report, which showed no substances that the lab tests for.

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: DRIVER 1 ADVISED HE WAS NB ON SR 37. DRIVER 1 ADVISED HE WENT TO TURN EAST ONTO S OLD SR 37 AND LOST CONTROL OF HIS VEHICLE SLIDING OFF THE N SIDE OF S OLD SR 37 AND INTO A CULVERT.

V1, maroon Honda, was traveling north on I69 near the 130 mile marker. V1 traveled off the east side of the roadway. V1 struck a ditch, rolled and came to final rest on its wheels in the ditch facing northwest. D1, Leinheiser, stated he was traveling north on I69 in the left lane. D1 stated V1 pulled to the right suddenly. D1 stated he began to slide on the wet roadway. D1 stated he traveled off the right side of the roadway, struck a ditch and the vehicle rolled over. Evidence shows tire marks leading from the from I69N off the right side of the roadway. Evidence shows damage to V1 consistent with a rollover collision, including damage to the roof. Evidence shows it was snowing and the roadway was wet during the accident investigation. V1 was also occupied by a white female, Courtney Hester, DOB 8-19-1998, who advised she was not injured in the collision.

V1 was traveling westbound on N Old State Road 37 passing the intersection at N Hillview Drive. As V1 entered the slight curve in the road, it began to lose traction due to the poor road conditions. The roadway was covered in slush slow that made it slick. V1 slid off the roadway onto the north side of the road and into a tree. The tree broke and fell overtop of V1, pinning the passenger inside. The passenger was removed from the vehicle and transported to the hospital. D1 was treated on scene and not transported. V1 was then towed from the scene by Rick's Towing. The poor road surface conditions caused V1 to slide off the roadway and collide with a tree.

At approximately 2345 hours on 1/12/2019 V1 was backing northwest in the northern parking lot of The Arch apartment complex. V1's driver side rear bumper struck the driver side front bumper of V2. V2 was parked facing west.V1 advised that while backing she did not see V2. V1 had a small chip missing from the rear bumper. There was very minimal paint transfer to V2.

Vehicle 2 was traveling southbound on I69, near mile marker 106. Vehicle 2 lost control and ran off the roadway into guard rail.Occupants of Vehicle 2 activated flashers and had exited the vehicle, moving to the rear of the vehicle. Shortly after,Vehicle 1 was traveling southbound on I69. Vehicle 1 lost control and slid off the roadway, hitting Vehicle 2 and causing Vehicle 1 to spin and finish facing northbound. Vehicle 1, while spinning, hit both occupants of Vehicle 2 who were standing toward the rear of their vehicle.Occupants of Vehicle 2 were transported to IU health. According to medical staff, the passenger sustained an open fracture to the right leg, the driver sustained a compound fracture to the left leg.

Vehicle 2 was parked on E Southern Dr. In front of the residence located at 210. Vehicle 2 was parked on the south side of the roadway facing east. Vehicle 1 was traveling east on E. V1 WAS TRAVELING EB ON E 10TH STREET. V2 WAS TRAVELING EB ON E 10TH STREET IN FRONT OF V1. WHILE TRAVELING, THE FRONT OF V1 COLLIDED WITH THE REAR OF V2. DRIVER OF VEHICLE 1 STATED SHE WAS GOING EAST BOUND ON W. FULLERTON PIKE AT REDDY WAY WHEN SHE HIT A PATCH OF ICE. SHE STATED SHE RAN OFF THE ROAD WAY AND IMPACTED ON THE GUARDRAIL CAUSING MINOR DAMAGE TO GUARDRAIL AND DAMAGE TO THE PASSENGER SIDE FRONT OF VEHICLE 1.

V1/D1 IS UNKNOWN, LSA.V2 WAS PARKED UNATTENDED IN FRONT OF 105 E. WILSON DR. OWNER STATED SHE PARKED HER CAR AT 0800 WITH NO DAMAGE. SHE WAS INFORMED THAT THE TRASH TRUCKS CAME THROUGH AROUND 0830. V1 was parked in the Village Pantry (1320 E 3rd Street) parking lot facing westbound. MICHAEL ROBINSON, WHO WITNESSED THE ACCIDENT, WAS INSIDE THE GAS STATION LOCATED AT 1115 SOUTH WALNUT STREET.MR. ROBINSON STATED THAT V1 WAS PARKED ON THE DRIVER'S SIDE OF V2.MR. Vehicle 1 was traveling west on 3rd street directly behind vehicle 2. Both vehicles proceeded through the intersection of 3rd and the State Road 37 North ramp. Vehicle 2 had to stop just after the intersection due to traffic being stopped at the next intersection. Driver of vehicle 1 was unaware vehicle 2 was coming to a stop. When driver of vehicle 1 noticed vehicle 2 was stopping he attempted to miss vehicle 2 but was unable because he was to close and collided with vehicle 2. Vehicle one has damage to front passenger side and Vehicle 2 to rear driver's side. No injuries from this accident. Both vehicles were able to drive from the accident scene.

Vehicle 1 (2019 Volvo Semi) was traveling east on SR46 in the right lane, approximately 2000 feet east of Curry Pike. Vehicle 2( White 2015 Ford Fusion) was traveling east on SR46 in the right lane, approximately 2000 feet east of Curry Pike. Vehicle 1 backup up, striking vehicle 2. This resulted in damage to the front of vehicle 2. Vehicle 1 turned south onto I69, before being stopped by police in Lawrence County.Driver 1 (Krishnamoorthy Periyathamby) advised that he was traveling east on SR46, and missed his turn for I69. He advised that he backed up in traffic so that he could turn south on I69. He advised that he did not see any vehicles behind him and was not aware that he struck any. Driver 1 was not aware a crash occurred until he was stopped by law enforcement.Driver 2 (Kirstin Moore) said that she was stopped at the stoplight in the right lane east bound behind a semi-tractor trailer. When the light turned green, the truck reversed and backed up, hitting her car with the bottom bar on the rear of the box trailer. It then proceeded forward and made a wide right turn onto the southbound merge ramp to I69, continuing out of sight. Vehicle 1 and 2 were driven from the scene.. No obvious damage was located on the rear of Vehicle 1. Neither driver reported injuries to law enforcement.

D1 advised she was driving westbound on Third Street. Driver Distracted (explain in narrative): D1 was looking at paperwork in the front passenger seat.V1 and V2 both were traveling southbound on Jordan Ave. Both V1 and V2 were at the intersection of E. 7th Street and Jordan Ave. V1 was directly behind V2 prior to the crash. Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY

D1 SAID AS HE STARTED TO TURN LEFT, JUST STARTING IN TRAFFIC, HE DID NOT SEE V2 AND TURNED INTO V2. D1 SAID HE DID NOT SEE V2 PRIOR TO PULLING OUT. D1 ADVISED V1 DOES NOT HAVE CAR INSURANCE.D2 SAID SHE WAS EAST BOUND ON W 3RD ST JUST WEST OF THE ENTRANCE FOR THE GAS PUMPS AT KROGER WEST IN THE NORTHERN MOST LANE, AT APPROXIMATELY 30 MPH, WHEN V1 PULLED OUT RIGHT IN FRONT OF HER AND THEN STRUCK THE SIDE OF V2. D2 SAID V2 THEN SPUN 180 DEGREES TO THE SOUTH AND THEN WEST, STOPPING FACING WEST, AND SOMEHOW DID NOT HIT ANYTHING ELSE.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: D1 was headed N/B out of the parking lot of 528 S College Ave, Kroger, approaching W 2nd St. D2 was headed E/B on W 2nd St. D1 stopped at W 2nd St and waited to turn left and travel W/B on W 2nd St. D1 believed the roadway to be clear and proceeded to enter the E/B lane of W 2nd St, striking V2 on the passenger side of the vehicle. No injuries were reported at this time. Both vehicles were able to be driven from the scene. D1 stated that she was headed N/B out of the parking lot of 528 S College Ave, Kroger, approaching W 2nd St. D1 stated that she stopped at W 2nd St and waited to turn left. D1 stated that D2 was headed E/B on W 2nd St, and stopped to let her make her turn. D1 stated that she believed to roadway to be clear and proceeded to make her turn. D1 stated she then struck V2 in the passenger side with the front of her vehicle. D1 stated that she did not see V2 until it was too late. D2 staed that she was headed E/B on W 2nd St, passing 528 S College Ave, Kroger. D2 stated that she stopped to let D1 turn W/B onto W 2nd St, however D1 was on her phone not paying attention. D2 stated that she then had a green traffic signal, so she proceeded straight toward S College Ave. D2 stated that V1 then struck her rear passenger side with the front of her vehicle.

D1 ADVISED SHE WAS TRAVELING SOUTH ON ROCKPORT ROAD, NEAR ROCKEAST ROAD WHEN SHE STRUCK A LARGE POTHOLE IN THE ROADWAY. D1 ADVISED THAT SHE CONTINUED ON FOR A SHORT TIME, STOPPING IN THE DRIVEWAY OF 8992 ROCKPORT RD, WHEN SHE REALIZED THE POT HOLE HAD CAUSED HER LEFT FRONT TIRE TO GO FLAT.

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: Driver one was driving through the parking lot at Edgewood High School towards Edgewood Drive. Driver two was backing out of a parking spot and driver one admitted that she did not see driver two and struck driver two's vehicle in the passenger rear quarter panel and pushing driver two's car into vehicle 3. Vehicle three sustained damage to the passenger side rear bumper.Vehicle one sustained damage to the passenger side front quarter panel, bumper, and headlight assembly area. This impact occurred at approximately 7:55 AM on January 17, 2019. It was dark and raining near 33 degrees Fahrenheit. The parking lot has overhead lights illuminating the parking lot less than 50 feet from the crash site. The light was illuminated and working as intended upon my arrival.

D1 STATED HE WAS BACKING FROM A SOUTH FACING PARKING SPACE AT THE LOT LOCATED AT 4TH ST AND DUNN. D1 SAID AS HE WAS BACKING HE LOOKED AT HIS DRIVERS FRONT TO MAKE SURE IT CLEARED THE PARKED VEHICLE NEXT TO HIM AND STRUCK V2. D2 STATED HE WAS EAST BOUND THROUGH THE LOT AND V1 BACKED INTO HIM.

D1 STATED HE WAS TURNING RIGHT ONTO TECUMSEH AND THE BRAKES WENT TO THE FLOOR AND WHEN HE TURNED HE WAS GOING TO FAST. THE DRIVERS DOOR CAME OPEN AND HE FELL OUT OF THE TRUCK. BUT WAS ABLE TO GET VEH INTO NUETRAL AS HE FELL OUT. THE TRUCK THEN CONTINUED UP HILL THROUGH TWO YARDS AND STRUCK THE HOUSE AT 640 W TECUMSEH. IN THE AREA OF THE FRONT DOOR.

Vehicle 2 was driving north on S. Curry Pike and entering the intersection with a green light, heading north when an emergency vehicle entered the intersection with emergency lights and sirens engaged. V2 applied his brakes to yield to the emergency vehicle. Vehicle 1 was following behind V2 and attempted to apply his brakes to avoid colliding with the rear of V2's vehicle. V1 then collided with the rear of V2 causing significant damage to V1 and minor damage to the rear of V2. V1 was not operable after the incident and was towed privately at a later time. V1 was still operable. Driver 2 stated that he did not hear or see the emergency vehicle entering the intersection until D2 had entered the intersection himself. Driver 2 then said that he applied his brakes and Vehicle 1 collided with the rear of his vehicle.Driver 1 stated that he suddenly saw V2 braking and then heard the sirens from the emergency vehicle. D1 then attempted to stop but collided with the rear of V2.

D1 ADVISED HE WAS BACKING NORTHEAST TO GO SOUTH FROM THE FRONT ROW OF THE PARKING LOT FACING THE SCHOOL (WEST BOUND) AT 3901 N KINSER PIKE AND DID NOT SEE V2 WAS STOPPED IN TRAFFIC BEHIND HIM AND STRUCK V2 WITH V1. D1 SAID HE WAS GOING 2-3 MPH AS HE WAS BACKING FROM THE PARKING SPACE AND HE DID NOT RECALL CHECKING HIS CENTER AND OUTSIDE DRIVER'S REAR VIEW MIRROR, BUT DOES RECALL CHCEKING THE PASSENGER OUTSIDE REARVIEW MIRROR. D1 SAID THE DRIVER OF THE CAR NORTH OF HIM WAS ALSO BACKING FROM IT'S PARKING SPACE AT THE SAME TIME.D2 SAID SHE WAS N BOUND FROM THE PARKING LOT JUST EAST OF THE FRONT ENTRANCE OF THE SCHOOL AT 3901 N KINSER PIKE, JUST BEHIND THE FIRST ROW OF CARS, NEAR THE BAND DIRECTOR'S TOWER, LEAVING THE LOT, BUT THERE WAS A CAR NORTH OF HER IN THAT FIRST ROW OF PARKING BACKING OUT SO V2 WAS STOPPED IN TRAFFIC, AND V1 BACKED OUT OF THE SPACE IT WAS IN AND INTO V2, STRIKING THE DRIVER'S SIDE IN FRONT OF THE DRIVER'S DOOR.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: On the 17th of January 2019, at approximately 12:15am. I was dispatched to thearea of Moores Pike and Smith road for a vehicle accident. Once I reached thislocation I noticed a large amount of debris in this intersection located on thewest side of this intersection. I then located a silver Honda passenger carsouth of the intersection. I then spoke with the driver who identified himself as Brandon Nelson, he statedthat he was driving east as he approached the intersection. As he came to a stopa black SUV approached him at a high rate of speed and failed to stop behindhim. The SUV then struck Brandon on the rear driver side causing a substantialamount of damage. The SUV then fled east on Moores pike, at this time the driverfailed to provide Brandon with his information for the vehicle accident. Brandondescribed that driver as a white male that was wearing a brown jacket, andBrandon felt the driver might have been impaired. The SUV fled east on Moores pike as Brandon's mother and father attempted tocatch up to him, they stated that they lost the vehicle in the area of SR46headed into Brown County. The SUV should have a substantial amount of damage onthe drivers side front bumper and headlight area. It was described as being anewer black SUV. A field form was completed and provided to Brandon and photographs were taken tobe placed with this case. Officers checked the area but failed to locate the SUVon tonight's date. A state crash report was also completed for this case.On the night of January 17th around 10:00PM I spoke with the driver of the SUV that was involved with this case. Jason Myers had called into the Bloomington Police Department and stated that he was the suspect in this case and that he wanted to talk with me about the accident. Jason stated that he suffers from PTSD and that he had got triggered last night and that he had to leave. Jason stated that he was driving his SUV as he approached the intersection he didn't see the vehicle in front of him. Jason stated that he struck the vehicle in front of him and then stopped to check to see if he was okay and provide him with his information. Jason stated that he called 911 to report the accident and as he talked with the other driver he noticed the male was on the phone.He could hear a female on the phone yelling for the other driver not to talk with him and to stayaway from him. Jason stated this put a great deal of stress on him and this triggered his PTSD and that he had to get away from. Jason admitted to being the driver and was understood that he committeda crime by leaving.Jason was issued a citation for operating with a expired drivers license and a Misdemeanor citation for leaving the scene of a vehicle accident.

Driver of V1 stated she was stopped behind V2 at the yield sign attempting to pull out of the Wal-Mart parking lot beside the gas station when V2 started to pull out into the eastbound lane of State Road 45 at which time V1 started moving forward as well, when V2 stopped abruptly at which time V1 struck V2 in the rear of the vehicle. Driver of V2 stated she was attempting to turn eastbound on State Road 45 and started to pull out into the eastbound traffic lane and then noticed an oncoming vehicle in the eastbound lane of State Road 45 and could not safely enter the highway and therefore she stopped her vehicle at which time she was rear ended by V1.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: W1 STATED HE WAS DRIVING NORTHBOUND ON SOUTH WALNUT STREET WHEN V1 PULLED OUT THE PRIVATE PARKING LOT OF 1919 SOUTH WALNUT STREET IN FRONT OF V2 AND V2 HAD NO TIME TO STOP.D1 STATED HE THOUGHT HE HAD ROOM TURNING LEFT OUT OF 1919 SOUTH WALNUT STREET AND DID NOT SEE V2.D2 STATED HE WAS DRIVING NORTHBOUND ON SOUTH WALNUT STREET WHEN V1 PULLED OUT IN FRONT OF HIM AND HE DIDN'T HAVE TIME TO STOP.NO INJURIES WERE REPORTED.V1 SUSTAINED MINOR DAMAGE TO THE LEFT SIDE OF V1. V2 SUSTAINED MAJOR FRONT END DAMAGE.

V2 was traveling southeast on Arlington Rd when V2 was rear ended by V1 who was also traveling southeast. D2 stated she came to a stop because there was an oversized truck pulling into a driveway. D1 also stated that V2 came to a stop because of an oversized truck pulling into a driveway but could not stop in time. It was daylight with clouds and the roads were slightly wet.

D1, Natalia Eraci, met with me at the IU Police Department headquarters at 1469 E 17th Street, Bloomington IN 47408 at approximately 1207hrs to report her involvement in a crash that occurred at the intersection of 3rd Street and Indiana Ave.D1 stated she was westbound on 3rd Street approaching the intersection of Indiana Ave in the left lane. D1 stated she attempted to turn right onto Indiana Ave from the left lane when she realized she was in the wrong lane. D1 stated she continued to turn and noticed V2, which was in the right lane of 3rd Street, was also turning right onto Indiana Ave. D1 stated as she turned next to V2, she heard a noise, but never felt any impact. D1 believed the sound was a result of a box shifting in the trunk of V1. D1 stated she slowed down in the event that she made contact with V2, but stated V2 never made an attempt to alert her or stop. D1 stated she continued to her destination (Wildermuth Intramural Center) where she got out of V1 and realized there was fresh damage to the rear passenger side of V1. D1 then stated she came to IUPD to report the collision. D1 described V2 as being a light blue sedan, but didn't have any further information than that. At this time, the driver of V2 has not attempted to contact police.

Driver 1 stated he was driving north through the lot of 2300 N Walnut St and was turning left. Driver 1 stated his windows were fogging up and he was trying to wipe them off when he turned to sharply and struck a light post in the lot.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: V1 TURNING LEFT FROM MADISON ONTO 17TH STV2 DRIVING WEST ON 17TH ST. V1 FAILED TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY TO V2 V1 STRUCK V2

V1 and V2 were westbound on State Road 46(Main St.) side by side on the westbound one way pair, just west of the intersection of Sale Street in Ellettsville, Indiana. V1 attempted to turn left into the alley behind 221 N. Sale Street from the outside right hand lane and struck V2 in the side. V2 had the right of way in the inside lane. Driver 1 admitted fault at the scene. WITNESS: CHARLES BELL 812-318-4292 WAS DRIVING WESTBOUND BEHIND V1 AND SAID V1 TURNED INTO THE SIDE OF V2.

V3 AND V2 WERE SLOWED IN BUMPER TO BUMPER EASTBOUND TRAFFIC ON STATE ROAD 46 (500 BLOCK OF E TEMPERANCE) FOR THE TRAFFIC LIGHT AT HARTSTRAIGHT ROAD. V1 CLAIMS HIS BRAKES FAILED AND HE REAR-ENDED V2, PUSHING IT INTO V3.

V2 and V1 were both facing eastbound on E 17th St. at the red light at the SR 45/46 Bypass. V2 was in front of V1 when V1 rear ended V2.D1 advised that he was facing east on E 17th St. at the red traffic signal at the SR 45/46 Bypass. D1 advised that he was behind V2 waiting to turn right. D1 advised that he was looking left to watch traffic when he saw V2 pull forward out of the corner of his eye. D1 advised that without looking forward, he assumed V2 had gone through the intersection and began pulling forward himself, causing a collision. D2 advised that she was facing east on E 17th St. at the red traffic signal at the SR 45/46 Bypass waiting to turn right. D2 advised that she was the first car in line. D2 advised that she was attempting to turn right on red, so she pulled forward enough to see the oncoming traffic. D2 advised that when she came to a complete stop before turning, V1 collided with the rear of V2.V1 sustained a bent bumper and paint transfer on the front right corner.V2 sustained a cracked rear bumper cover on the driver's side.

D1/V1 left the scene prior to my arrival.V2 was parked at the time of the accident. The owner of V2 stated that his vehicle was parked facing W/B on W Howe St from 01/12/19 until he noticed the damage on today's date, 01/18/19. The owner believes that a person named Max Williams backed into his vehicle, due to a business card with Max's information being left on the driver's side window. V2 sustained damage to the driver side of the vehicle, just behind the driver's door. V2 was able to be driven from the scene. At this time the investigation into the leaving the scene of the accident is ongoing.

D1-LEGGIO STATED HIS FOOT SLIPPED OFF THE BRAKE OF V1 CAUSING A REAR END COLLISION WITH V2. V2 WAS STOPPED ON S WELMIR DRIVE TRYING TO TURN ONTO N CURRY PIKE WHEN THE COLLISION OCCURED. THERE WAS MINOR TO NO DAMANGE TO V2. V1 HAD DAMANGE TO THE FRONT.

V1 was traveling east on 10th street approaching the intersection of 10th street and Jordan Avenue. P1 was running along the same street, trying to catch a bus at the same intersection. P1 ran out onto 10th street in front of V1. V1 did not see P1 in time, and struck P1 in the lower left knee area with the front bumper of V1. The accident occurred on 1/18/2019, but P1 did not report the accident until 1/22/2019. P1 stated D1 stopped when the accident occurred and checked to see if he was ok. P1 stated to D1 he was ok, and they both left the scene. P1 said he was only reporting the accident for insurance reasons. It should be noted this is not a hit and run accident. I had to check the hit and run box, only so I could advance through the ARIES system. This should be classified as Personal Injury Crash, and the driver of V1 fulfilled her requirement by stopping to check on the pedestrian.

D1 STATED SHE WAS DRIVING SOUTH BOUND ON SOUTH LEONARD SPRINGS ABOUT 100 FEET SOUTH OF WEST CEDAR CHASE DRIVE WHEN HER RIGHT FRONt TIRE LEFT THE ROADWAY AND SHE WAS UNABLE TO CORRECT IT AND STRUCK A TREE.W1 STATED HE WAS TRAVELING SOUTHBOUND ON SOUTH LEONARD SPRINGS IN FRONT OF V1 WHEN HE LOOKED IN HIS MIRROR AND SAW THE VEHICLE LEAVE THE ROADWAY AND D1 WAS UNABLE TO CORRECT THE VEHICLE BEFORE STRIKING THE TREE.NO INJURIES WERE REPORTED.

Driver 1 (D1) advised that she was attempting to make a right hand turn on the green light while heading east bound on W 3rd St. D1 stated that she was then turning right to head south bound on S Patterson Dr. D1 stated that because of the snowy road conditions that her car slid out of her lane and into the turn lane of north bound traffic. D1 advised that her vehicle (V1) then made contact with vehicle 2 (V2). Driver 2 (D2) advised that he was stopped at the stop light facing north bound on S Patterson Dr. D2 explained that as he was waiting on the light to turn green V1 hit his vehicle while making the turn. V1 was towed from the scene due to heavy front end damage. V2 was driven from the scene by the owner.

V1 WAS TRAVELING WESTBOUND ON FLUCK MILL ROAD, WHILE PLOWING AND SANDING, WHEN D1 FAILED TO LOWER THE DUMP BED PRIOR TO GOING UNDER A RAILROAD OVERPASS. SAID DUMP BED THEN STRUCK THE OVERPASS CAUSING DAMAGE TO V1.

Vehicle 1 was traveling north on North Matthews Drive in approximately the 6800 block when it ran off the roadway due to the roadway surface conditions (snow). Vehicle 1 traveled down an embankment and struck a tree. Damage to the vehicle was on the driver's side.No injuries were reported to me at the scene of the collision.Photographs were taken and are available upon request.

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: On 01/19/2019 at 1944 hours I was driving southbound on Jordan Avenue approaching the intersection of 10th Street when I noticed a vehicle stopped at an angle in the middle of the intersection. Dispatch then advised that the traffic accident had just occurred there.It should be noted that road conditions were extremely poor due to the large amount of snow the surrounding area was receiving tonight. The roads were not plowed and the snow was falling heavily with several inches having already fallen.I spoke with D1 who stated he was traveling southbound on Jordan Avenue attempting to stop at the red light at 10th Street. D1 stated he tried to stop but continued to slide and eventually slide into the intersection where he struck V2. V1 sustained damage to the front bumper. There was a dent in the middle of the bumper and it was also loose when touched.D2 stated she was driving slowly westbound on 10th street at the Jordan Avenue intersection when V1 slid through the intersection and struck her on the passenger side. D2's passenger complained of pain from her right knee and that her head also hurt from hitting it from the impact. EMS came to look at V1 and she signed a release form stating she thought she was okay.V2 sustained damage to the passengers side. The front and rear passenger side door was smashed inward and D1 stated her passenger was unable to open the passenger side door. Due to the poor weather conditions Chandler's Towing Company came to tow V2.

V1 WAS SOUTHBOUND ON UNION VALLEY WITH DOUBLE YELLOW LINE AT INTERSECTION. V1 TURNED CONTRARY TO THE DOUBLE YELLOW LINE CROSSING NORTHBOUND LANE OF UNION VALLEY TO ENTER THE PRIVATE DRIVE OF CVS PHARMACY LOCATED AT 4444 W.S.R. 46, BLOOMINGTON, IN. V2 WAS TURNING FROM W.S.R. 46 WESTBOUND TO GO NORTH ONTO UNION VALLEY WITH RIGHT OF WAY. VEHICLES COLLIDED. NO DIAGRAM. BOTH VEHICLES LEFT SCENE AND MOVED INTO PARKING LOT OF CVS PHARMACY PRIOR TO MY ARRIVAL.

Manner of Collision: HEAD ON BETWEEN TWO MOTOR VEHICLES
NARRATIVE: Vehicle 1 was southbound on Walnut St and Vehicle 2 was northbound. Vehicle 1 started down a hill near Hoosier St. Vehicle 1 lost control and began sliding down the hill due to road way conditions being snow and ice covered. Vehicle 1 was unable to regain control and slide into the northbound lane and hit vehicle 2. The vehicles hit on the front driver's side. Vehicle 2 was able to drive from scene and vehicle 1 had to be towed due to disabling damage. No injuries reported from this accident.

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: On 01/19/2019 at approximately 07:05 P.M. Vehicle #1 (2015 Audi Q5) was traveling east on Sample Road approximately 700 feet from Old State Road 37 North in Bloomington, Indiana. There was heavy snow coming down and several inches of fresh snow on the road. V1 was decending down a hill and due to the fresh snow on the road surface V1 lost control and began to slide sideways. V1 struck a tree on the south side of Sample Road. V1 struck the tree with the right rear passenger door. After striking the tree V1 came to a rest in the ditch on the south side of the Sample Road.Driver 1 (Zelin Fu) stated the he was traveling east on Sample Road approaching Old State Road 37 North. D1 said there was heavy snow fall on the road and that he lost control coming down a hill and struck a tree on the rear passenger side of the vehicle. D1 advised that his vehicle came to a rest in the ditch on the south side of Sample Road. V1 was towed from the scene. V1 sustained heavy damage to the rear passenger side of the car and was towed from the scene due to disabling damage.Investigation at the scene was consistent with D1 statement. There was a male passenger in the front of the vehicle and a female passenger in the rear of the vehicle. The female had minor lacerations on her face from the crash. Both passengers were transported from the scene to the hospital. Due to the weather the passengers were transported in a fire department SUV because the ambulance became stuck due to the weather. No enforcement actions were taken and no other injuries were reported.

V1 was traveling northbound on N Walnut Street in the east lane and V2 was traveling northbound on N Walnut Street in the west lane. V1 attempted to turn left onto N Old State Road 37 from the east lane on N Walnut Street. As V1 attempted to turn left, it collided with V2, which was to the left of V1 in the west lane. The front left of V1 collided with the right side of V2. V1 was towed by Pritchard's Towing due to disabling damage and being in the roadway. D1 admitted fault in the accident when questioned. D1 attempted to make an improper left turn from the east lane of N Walnut Street onto N Old State Road 37. D1 did not see V2 to the left of him in the west lane, resulting in a collision.

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: Driver was eastbound on Wylie Rd from Wayport Rd when her vehicle left the right side of the roadway. The vehicle slid off the roadway and down a steep embankment several feet and came to rest near a creek. The weather conditions in the area were heavy snow fall with several inches on the roadway.

D1 STATED HE WAS EASTBOUND ON RATLIFF ROAD WHEN HE CRESTED OVER THE HILL AND RAN OFF THE NORTH SIDE OF THE ROADWAY AFTER THE HILLCREST. D1 THEN STATED WHEN HE ATTEMPTED TO STEER BACK ONTO THE ROAD, THE TAIL END OF V1 SLID AROUND AND TURNED THE VEHICLE SIDEWAYS. ONCE V1 WAS SIDEWAYS, IT CAUGHT THE GRASS AND ROLLED OVER TWICE.D1 WAS SEEN BY EMS BUT SIGNED A MEDICAL RELEASE AND DID NOT HAVE ANY INJURIES.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: Vehicle 2 was traveling west on Rogers Rd. And vehicle 1 was heading south on High St. Vehicle 2 entered the traffic circle at the intersection of High and Rogers. Vehicle 2 was attempting to continue west through the traffic circle and continue onto Winslow Road. Vehicle 2 was passing the entrance to the traffic circle for High street. Vehicle 1 was attempting to enter the traffic circle from High St and failed to yield right on way for vehicle 2. Vehicle 1 struck Vehicle 2 in the back passenger side door. Vehicle 1 then left the scene. EMS checked the driver and passenger and determined no injuries. Vehicle 2 had damage to the back passenger side door.

Driver 1 (D1) advised that she was heading south on S Rogers St. D1 stated that she came over the hillcrest on S Rogers Street just north of W Howe St when she lost control of the vehicle (V1) due to the weather conditions. D1 advised that V1 then crossed over the center lane and hit a tree on the passenger side of the vehicle at the residence of 409 S Rogers St.D1 stated that she had a complaint of pain to her head. The passenger in the vehicle also had a complaint of pain to his head and right knee. Both individuals were transported to the hospital via ambulance.

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: V1 and V2 were southbound on the SR 45/46 Bypass approaching the red traffic signal at E 10th St. V2 slowed to a stop at the traffic signal and V1 was unable to slow down quickly enough, causing a collision. D1 advised that he was traveling southbound on the SR 45/46 Bypass approaching the E 10th St. intersection. D1 advised that V2 slowed to a stop in front of him, but due to the heavy ice on the roadway he was unable to stop in time, causing a rear end collision.D2 advised that he was traveling southbound on the SR 45/46 Bypass approaching the E 10th St. intersection. D2 advised that as he was slowing to a stop, V1 rear ended him. V1 sustained minor cracks and scratches to the front bumper.V2 sustained a crack to the rear bumper cover. D2 advised that he'd had neck surgery and was worried that the impact was significant enough that he may have problems later. D2 advised that he felt no pain currently, and did not want an ambulance.

On January 19th, 2019, at approximately 1000 hours, Jeremiah Baker and Leanna Crecelius were on foot on Old State road 37, approximately 200 yards south of the Fairfax road intersection, checking if there was damage from a non-reportable accident causing minimal damage between Ms. Crecelius' red Buick Le Sabre, license 727THV, and a blue Dodge Dakota, TK908NCH, driven by Mr. Baker. The blue Dodge was parked north of Ms. Crecelius' Buick in the middle of the northbound lane with both Ms. Crecelius and Mr. Baker standing between the vehicles, when John Cassidy, driving a black Chevrolet Silverado, TK993MYP, struck the rear of the red Buick traveling north at approximately 20 to 30MPH. The red Buick was pushed by the impact into Mr. Baker and Ms. Crecelius, knocking them off of the road way and into the shoulder before striking the Dodge Dakota. Fire and EMS responded and Mr. Baker was checked at the scene and signed a release. Ms. Crecelius was transported to IU Health Bloomington with a head laceration and possible concussion. Mr. Cassidy was uninjured. I, Indiana Conservation Officer arrived and took Mr. Baker's, Mr.Cassidy's and Ms. Crecelius' information for an accident report. I was only able to take a few pictures of the scene and a picture of damage to Ms. Crecelius' Buick before the weather started interfering with my equipment.I spoke to Mr. Cassidy and he advised that he was traveling north bound at approximately 20 to 30 MPH due to the heavy snow and ice when he saw the vehicles in the road way and attempted to brake but because of the ice he was not able to slow down before the collision. Mr. Cassidy's Chevrolet was damaged in the front passenger's side. Mr. Baker's Dodge was damaged in the rear of the vehicle and Ms. Crecelius's Buick was damaged on the front and rear of both the driver and passenger side. Both Mr. Cassidy and Mr. Baker's vehicles were drivable and Ms. Crecelius' vehicle was able to be pushed off of the roadway into Ms. Crecelius' property.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: V2 was westbound on SR 46 West with the right of way. V1 was attempting to pull out of Capital Avenue onto SR 46 and struck V2. NO DIAGRAM....BOTH VEHICLES MOVED FROM POINT OF IMPACT PRIOR TO MY ARRIVAL. V1 BACKED OUT OF ROADWAY ON SR 46 AND BACK ONTO CAPITOL AVENUE. V2 CONTINUED TO THE PARKING LOT OF PIZZA PANTRY JUST WEST OF CAPITOL AVENUE.

Driver 1 (D1) advised that he was driving southbound on N Rogers Street in the area of the W 11th Street four way stop. D1 reported that his vehicle's (V1) windshield had salt and debris on it that he was unable to clear off causing a glare. D1 advised that because of this he did not see the stop sign at the junction and did not stop. D1 advised that as he entered the four way stop V1 made contact with vehicle 2 (V2). Driver 2 (D2) advised that she was headed east bound on W 11th Street. D2 explained she had stopped at the stop sign at the intersection and cleared all directions. D2 reported that when she went through the intersection her vehicle was struck by V1 on the driver's side front area. Both parties denied medical attention on scene. Both vehicles were towed from the scene due to incapacitating damage.

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: V2 was facing westbound on E 17th St. waiting to turn into a parking lot when V1 rear ended V2.D2 advised that he had been traveling westbound on E 17th St. past N Jordan Ave. D2 advised that he had slowed to turn right into the parking lot of St. Paul's Catholic Center. D2 advised that he slowed nearly to a stop due to other cars and road conditions. D2 advised that when he slowed down, V1 rear ended him.D1 advised that she was traveling westbound on E 17th St. past N Jordan Ave. D1 advised that V2 appeared to be stopped in front of the entrance to St. Paul's Catholic Center. D1 advised that she attempted to stop, but that V1 has known troubles stopping on snow and she was unable to stop before colliding with the rear of V2. V1 sustained moderate front end damage.V2 sustained a broken rear bumper cover and several dents and scratches on the rear liftgate.

DRIVER OF VEHICLE 1 STATED HE WAS TRAVELING NORTH ON S. FAIRFAX WHEN HIS CAR SLIDE OFF THE ROAD AT 6475 S. FAIRFAX RD. VEHICLE 1 HIT A METAL/BARBED WIRE FENCE TAKING OUT ONE OF THE FENCE POSTS. VEHICLE 1 WAS TOWED OUT OF THE DITCH AND TOWED TO A LOCAL PARKING LOT, DRIVER WAS CITED FOR DRIVING WITHOUT A LICENSE.

On 01/20/2019 at 0500 hours I met with D1 at the IU Motor Pool to take a crash report that happened at 1900 E. 10th Street. D1 stated he was plowing the south circle drive of Eigenmann Hall due to the heavy snowfall. D1 stated he was at the southeast corner of the south circle drive when he backed into a yellow pole. The pole was not damaged. V1 sustained damage to the shoot assembly for the spreader (a metal part on the rear of the vehicle that spreads salt). The metal spreader was dented all the way down the shoot with yellow paint transfer on it from the pole.

V1 WAS TRAVELING EAST ON E ANDERSON ROAD WHEN IT SIDE SWIPED A TREE CAUSING DAMAGE TO THE PASSENGER SIDE OF V1.THE ACCIDENT WAS REPORTED AT THE COUNTY HIGHWAY DEPARTMENT AND THE INVESTIGATION WAS CONDUCTED THERE.

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: On the evening of January 19th to the morning of January 20th, Bloomington Indiana had received several inches of snow. The roadways in spots were still snow covered or had slush on them. Specifically exit ramp 123C off of Interstate 69 was hard packed snow covering the entire exit ramp.Vehicle 1 (grey 2006 Mini Cooper) was traveling south on Interstate 69 taking exit 123C behind Vehicle 2 (white 2017 Jeep Cherokee) Vehicle 2 slowed in traffic that had slowed down for the road conditions on Exit 123C. Vehicle 1 was unable to slow down enough to avoid a collision with Vehicle 2 and struck Vehicle 2 in the rear, causing heavy front end damage and deploying the air bags of Vehicle 1. Driver 1 (Lane Fulton) stated he had exited Interstate 69, behind Vehicle 2. Driver 1 stated he did not anticipate the exit ramp to still be snow covered and noticed traffic in front of him had began to slow down. Driver 1 stated he applied his brakes and began to slide and attempted to go left off of the exit ramp to avoid a collision with Vehicle 2, however was unsuccessful. Driver 2 (Jeffrey Smith) stated he had exited I-69 and traffic in front of him began to slow down. Driver 2 stated he applied his brakes to slow down, looked in his rear view mirror and could see Vehicle 1 approaching him at a high rate of speed and not slowing down. Driver 2 stated he attempted to "out run" Vehicle 1 by attempting to speed up, however Vehicle 1 struck him in the rear. Driver 1 was issued a citation for speed too fast for conditions, 9-21-5-1.Based upon road conditions, my observations of the crash scene and driver's statements, I determine the primary cause of this crash to be speed too fast for conditions by Driver 1.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: D1 STATED NO INJURIES. D1 STATED WAS DRIVING EAST ON E 3RD ST APPROACHING S LINCOLN STREET. D1 STATED LIGHT WAS RED AND HE STARTED BRAKING BUT SLID AND STRUCK V2.D2 STATED NO INJURIES. D2 STATED WAS DRIVING NORTH ON S LINCOLN STREET TRYING TO CROSS E 3RD STREET. D2 STATED HAD GREEN LIGHT AND V1 SLID INTO HER.IT SHOULD BE NOTED THAT THE ROADWAY DID HAVE A LAYER OF SNOW ON IT AND WAS SLICK.DAMAGE TO FRONT OF V1, DRIVERS SIDE DOOR AREA OF V2. NO PICTURES. END.

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: Interstate 69 in this area runs north and south. On the evening of January 19th into the morning of January 20th, Bloomington received several inches of snow and the roadway was still covered in spots with snow/slush/ice. Vehicle 1 (black, GMC Envoy) was traveling south on Interstate 69, in the center lane. Vehicle 1 switched to the far left lane at approximately the 123.5 mile marker, hit snow/ice in the roadway and lost control, hit a construction barrel, left the roadway to the right and impacted into a large ditch full of ice/water. Vehicle 1 became immersed into 2 to 3 feet of water. The impact with the ice/water caused damage to all four sides of Vehicle 1. Driver 1 (Michael Tetzloff) stated that he was traveling in the center lane of I-69, traveling approximately 80 miles per hour. Driver 1 stated that he switched lanes to the far left lane and then lost control of Vehicle 1 and left the roadway. Driver 1 stated he was not injured in the crash. Driver 1 admitted that he was speeding and going too fast for the roadway conditions. Witness 1 (Tim Lam) stated that he was traveling south on I-69, behind Vehicle 1. Witness 1 stated that Vehicle 1 was traveling at a high rate of speed. Witness 1 stated Vehicle 1 switched lanes from the center to the far left lane, spun out and left the roadway to the right. Witness 1 stated he stopped to render aid to Driver 1. Driver 1 was issued a citation for speed too fast for weather conditions 9-21-5-1. Based upon evidence at the scene, my observations of the roadway conditions and witness statements, I determined the primary cause of this crash was speed too fast for conditions by Driver 1.

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: On 1/20/2019, at approximately 6:15PM, I, Officer Lucas, arrived to the scene of an accident involving a black 2013 Toyota Camry (VIN: 4T1BE32K23U219559) and a black 2016 Chevrolet Tahoe (VIN: 1GNSKCKC4GR346383) at the intersection of S. College Ave. And W. 1st St.After requesting medical personnel for D1's complaint of knee pain, I spoke with both drivers.D1 stated that she "thought the light was green," and stated that she was proceeding eastbound on W. 1st through the intersection of S. College Ave. D1 stated that she attempted to brake upon seeing D2's vehicle in the intersection, but was unable to stop due to snow/slush on the roadway, and struck V2 on the rear passenger side.V1 suffered heavy front-end damage, and was towed due to disabling damage.D2 stated that he was traveling southbound on S. College Ave., through the intersection of W. 1st St., when he was struck on the right passenger side of his vehicle by V1. D2 stated that he had the green light, and had already almost made it entirely through the intersection when his vehicle was struck by V1. D2 and the four other individuals in V2 had no complaint of pain.V2 was still driveable, and was able to leave the scene.It should be noted that V2 was struck with such force that it was spun nearly 360 degrees across the roadway, and pushed over an adjacent curb on the east side of S. College Ave.Based on the scene, statements, and location of damage to V2, my investigation has yielded that V1 was traveling eastbound on W. 1st St. At a speed that was unsafe due to the conditions of the road. V1 was unable to stop prior to entering the intersection of W. 1st and S. College Ave., striking V2 on the rear passenger side.SUPPLEMENT NOTE 4/30/2019: I was contacted by the owner of V2, Tyler and Ashli Moore, who informed me that the vehicle being driven was actually a newly purchased 2016 Cadillac Escalade (VIN: 1GYS4KKJ2GR226443), which bore a plate registered to the aformentioned 2016 Chevrolet Tahoe. The information for V2 has been corrected.

Driver stated that he was getting off the off ramp on to S College Ave Exit when he got into the slush. Driver stated he tried to correct the vehicle when he over correct and went of the side of the off ramp.

DRIVER OF VEHICLE 1 STATED HE WAS NORTH BOUND ON S PATTERSON DRIVE APPROACHING THE INTERSECTION WITH W ALLEN ST. THE LIGHT FOR NORTH BOUND TRAFFIC WAS RED. AS D1 BEGAN TO BRAKE, V1 SLID ON THE ICE WHICH WAS ON THE ROADWAY. D1 STATED HE BEGAN TO SLIDE INTO THE INTERSECTION AND OBSERVED V2 APPROACHING FROM THE EAST. D1 ATTEMPTED TO ACCELLERATE TO CLEAR THE INTERSECTION, BUT WAS STRUCK BY V2.DRIVER OF VEHICLE 2 STATED HE WAS WEST BOUND ON ALLEN STREET APPROACHING THE INTERSECTION WITH S PATTERSON DRIVE. THE LIGHT FOR WEST BOUND TRAFFIC WAS GREEN. AS V2 CAME TO THE INTERSECTION, D2 OBSERVED V1 ENTER THE INTERSECTION DIRECTLY IN FRONT OF V2. D2 ATTEMPTED TO STOP, BUT COULD NOT AVOID THE COLLISION.

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: I-69 at the 123mm is a 6 lane divided highway with a guardrail barrier separating the north bound and south bound lanes. I-69 123mm exit ramp C, exits off of the right side of I-69 south bound and crosses a bridge over both lanes of I-69. The exit ramp was covered with snow at the time of the crash.Vehicle 1, a maroon 2006 Chevrolet HHR was traveling south on I-69 and attempted to take the 123mm exit ramp C to go south on SR 37 Business Route into Bloomington. Vehicle 1 lost traction in the snow and started to swerve. Vehicle 1 slid off the right side of the exit ramp, down an embankment and into a ditch coming to an uncontrolled stop. Driver 1, Julie Hill stated that she was attempting to exit I-69, when she hit the snow on the exit ramp and her vehicle started to slide. Driver 1 stated she "fish tailed" back and forth a few times but was unable to maintain control of her vehicle. She stated she slid off the road and became stuck in the ditch.Driver 1 stated she was uninjured and did not require medical attention. Vehicle 1 sustained minor damage to the front bumper. Driver 1 requested a crash report for her insurance company. Vehicle 1 had to be pulled out of the ditch my a tow truck.

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: D1 stated he was westbound on SR45/46 Bypass between the IU Foundation and Fee Lane in the left hand lane. D1 stated he began to change lanes to get into the right lane to overtake a slower moving vehicle when his vehicle began to slide on the icy roadway. D1 stated he was unable to stop or steer V1 and V1 struck the curb and ran off the road way. D1 stated his vehicle became stuck on the hillside in the snow and ice. There was no obvious damage to V1, however I was unable to inspect the under-carriage of V1. V1 had to be removed from the hillside by Hawkins Towing. V1 was drivable and was not towed from the scene.

V1 and V2 were northbound on Walnut Street toward the traffic light at OLD State Road 37. Traffic was very congested following the Indiana University Men's Basketball game. V2 was in front of V1.V1 is IUPD-KO police vehicle #263.D1 stated traffic was stop and go. He said V2 stopped ahead of him and he was not ready to stop himself. He said he attempted to brake but could not stop in time to avoid a collision.D2 stated he had stopped in traffic when V1 suddenly collided with the rear of V2. His daughter was in the front passenger seat and complained of extreme neck pain. An ambulance responded to the scene, stabilized her, and transported her to IU Health Bloomington Hospital.In accordance with Implied Consent, all drivers submitted to a PBT and registered .000 readings. No one showed signs of intoxication.I followed up at the hospital with the injured juvenile passenger. She had whiplash but ultimately no signs of major injury.D1 and D2 stated they were not injured.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: Vehicle 2 was traveling east on Atwater Ave. on an emergency run with lights and sirens activated. Vehicle 1 was traveling north on Henderson St. As vehicle 2 approached the intersection of Atwater and Henderson the light was red. The driver slowed almost to a stop and made sure all vehicles had stopped. There was another vehicle that stopped in the left lane of Henderson. Vehicle 2 then proceeded through the intersection with due regard. Driver of vehicle 1 stated that he did not hear the sirens as he approached the intersection. Once the driver of vehicle 1 noticed the fire truck, the driver slammed on his brakes. Because of the snow and ice on the roadway, vehicle 1 was unable to stop and slid into the intersection and into vehicle 2.Vehicle 1 had significant damage to the front. Vehicle 2 had minimal damage to the rear passenger side. After completion of my investigation, based on the damage it appears vehicle 2 was well into the intersection when the collision occurred and vehicle 1 failed to yield the right of way to an emergency vehicle.

D1 parked his car in the parking lot in front of his home on 1/19/2019 at approximately 9:30 PM. At 2:00 PM on 1/20/2019 he noticed damage to the rear passenger side bumper of V1. D1 stated that he noticed the damage after he left his home and arrived at a destination close by. D1 stated that the damage would have had to happened while it was parked during the night. It should be noted that there was significant snowfall the night before leading to unsafe driving conditions.

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: DRIVER 1 ADVISED HE REMEMBERED TRAVELING SOUTH EAST ON W HENNESSEY ST AND THAT THE NEXT THING HE REMEMBERED WAS WAKING UP HAVING HIT A TREE AND CAR AT THE RESIDENCE OF 1617 W HENNESSEY ST. IT APPEARED FROM TIREMARKS THAT VEHICLE 1 HAD FAILED TO NAVIGATE THE TURN DUE TO ROAD CONDITIONS AND EXITED THE ROADWAY STRIKING THE MAILBOX AT 1617 W HENNESSEY ST AND ALSO VEHICLE 2 WHICH WAS PARKED IN THE DRIVEWAY BEFORE STRIKING A TREE IN THE YARD.

V1 was traveling westbound in 3rd Street. V2 was traveling northbound on Lincoln St. V1 struck V2 in the intersection and fled the scene.D2 stated that he was traveling northbound on Lincoln St. He observed V1 traveling westbound on 3rd St and attempting to stop. V1 slid on the snow covered road and struck V2 in the intersection. V1 then fled.

DRIVER 1 (DANIEL YEBOAH) WAS SOUTHBOUND ON NORTH OLD STATE ROAD 37 APPROACHING CASCADES PARK TRAIL.DRIVER 1 OBSERVED TRAFFIC COMING TO A STOP AT ABOVE INTERSECTION. DRIVER 1 STATED HE APPLIED THE BRAKE AND BEGAN TO SWERVE. SNOW/SLUSH WAS IN SOUTHBOUND LANE OF TRAVEL. DRIVER 1 LOST CONTROL, WENT LEFT OF CENTER AND COLLIDED WITH V2 WHICH WAS TRAVELING IN THE OPPOSITE DIRECTION.
V1 WAS TRAVELING SB ON N MOUNT TABOR ROAD, SLID ON ICE AND WENT OFF THE ROAWAY HITTING A TREELINE WITH THE REAR OF THE VEHICLE.

V1 WAS TRAVELING EASTBOUND ON TAPP ROAD NEAR THE ROUNDABOUT AT I-69 WHEN IT REAR ENDED V2 WHO WAS STOPPED AT THE ROUNDABOUT. D1 STATED HE WAS TRYING TO DOWNSHIFT TO SLOW DOWN BUT THE ROADWAY WAS ICY AND COULDN'T STOP IN TIME BEFORE REAR ENDING V2. D2 STATED HE SAW V1 IN HIS REAR VIEW MIRRORS DRIVING TOO FAST AND ATTEMPTED TO MOVE FORWARD BUT COULDN'T GET OUT OF THE WAY IN TIME. THE ROADWAYS DID HAVE ICE AND SNOW ON THEM.

D1 advised she was traveling East on W. Tapp Rd traveling at approximately 20 miles per hour when she lost control of her vehicle. D1 stated that the car spun out and traveled off the roadway hitting a mailbox and resting in the ditch at the address of 3716 W. Tapp Road. It should be noted that the roadway was very poor due to recent snowfall and snow pack/ice.

V2 was parked stationary and unattended facing south in the south end of the parking lot in a parking space. V1 pulled into the lot and turned right to park between V2 and another vehicle prior to the crash.D1 said she pulled into the parking lot and was driving east bound in V1. D1 said as she was pulling into her parking space in V1 her front left driver side bumper made contact with V2 rear passenger side bumper.W1 said he was walking through the parking lot facing west and noticed V1 going to park. W1 said he then saw V1 strike V2 as V1 was attempting to pull into a parking space.I spoke with the Jason who is the responsible party for V2 who was not on scene due to being out of town for work. He was given the crash number and informed to let the registered owner his mother know what occurred.Both vehicles had minor damage.

At approximately 1800 hours on 1/21/2019 V1 was travelling southbound approaching the intersection of 3rd Street and Jordan Avenue. V2 was stopped at the intersection, facing south and waiting to turn west onto 3rd. V1 rear ended V2, causing minor impact damage. D1 stated that he was in the west lane (for right turn only), travelling south toward 3rd and Jordan. D1 advised that he attempted to move into the left lane so that he could continue southbound through the intersection. D1 stated that as he was trying to change lanes he noticed a vehicle in his blind spot, preventing the change. D1 stated that he then immediately applied his brakes, but did not have adequate time to slow down before impacting V2. There was a minor crumple in the front bumper of V1, however D1 advised that he wasn't sure that it hadn't already been there. D1 estimated his speed to be 20-25 mph. D2 stated that he was sitting in the west lane on the north side of 3rd and Jordan, waiting to turn west (right) onto 3rd. D2 advised that his vehicle was not moving when it was impacted by V1. Neither party gave conflicting stories and neither complained of injury or requested medical attention.

On 1/21/2019, at approximately 2:50PM, I arrived to the southbound lane of SR 37, approximately 500ft south of SR 45/46 Bypass regarding a report of a vehicle hitting a concrete median.Upon arrival, all occupants of the blue 2004 Toyota RAV4 (V1) had exited the vehicle and were standing by the concrete median, with no complaint of pain or injury.D1 informed me that she was driving southbound on S. SR 37, south of SR 45/46 Bypass, when her vehicle struck a patch of ice, causing V1 to spin out of control and strike the concrete median with the front of her vehicle. The damage required V1 to be towed from the scene.The witness, Linda Server, corroborated D1's statement, informing me that she was located behind V1, and witnessed V1 hit ice on the road, spinning across both lanes of traffic and striking the concrete median.I did check for damage to the median, however, there appeared to be only slight paint transfer from the impact of V1.

East Boltinghouse Road is a county road that runs in a eastern and western direction in Monroe County. East Earl Young Road is a county road that runs in a northern and southern direction and intersects with East Boltinghouse Rd. 1000 feet east of the crash. The roadway way is straight/level and was ice covered in the area of the crash.V1 (white 2010 Jeep Cherokee) was traveling east on East Boltinghouse Rd. V1 ran off the roadway and struck a fence in a field south of the roadway.D1 (Will Phillips) stated that he was traveling east on East Boltinghouse Rd. A plow truck was traveling westbound and taking up the entire westbound lane. D1 traveled along the edge of the roadway (south side) to allow as much room as possible. D1 stated he slide off the road and struck the fence. He was wearing his seat belt.During the course of my investigation, I observed damage to the entire front bumper area of V1. I also observed damage to the fence alongside the roadway. Patches of ice were on the roadway in the area of the crash. The plow truck and driver information is unknown. No injuries reported as a result of this crash. The name of the property owner is unknown. However, their residence was identified by a neighbor. Crash information was left at the residence located at 3505 East Boltinghouse Rd.The crash investigation showed that the primary cause of the crash is Ran Off Roadway on the part of D1. This was determined by damage sustained to V1 and driver statement.

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: Driver was traveling on S. Shields Ridge Road when he hit a large patch of ice in the roadway. When the drivers vehicle hit the ice the driver lost control of the vehicle and ran off of the roadway. The vehicle ran into the yard of 6930 S Shields Ridge Road damaging several small trees in the front yard of the residence.
