NARRATIVE: Narrative By Chief Deputy William Jay HumphreyEllettsville Police Department January 21 2019Time 10:22amDriver#1 ArmesDriver #2 KnappDriver #1 in Vehicle #1 going south on Sale Street Ran Red Light and struck Vehicle #2 going East Bound on Temperance Street.Driver Vehicle #1 at Fault (Failure To Yield) .

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: Driver one stated he was going around the curve on Leonard Springs Road and his rear end spun into the oncoming lane and hit vehicle two. Vehicle two stated vehicle one hit her

D1 STATED SHE WAS STOPPED BEHIND V2 NEAR THE INTERSECTION OF CURRY AND BROADWAY WAITING FOR THE STOPLIGHT FOR S CURRY PIKE AND W 3RD ST. WHILE STOPPED BEHIND V2, D1 STATED SHE MUST HAVE LET HER FOOT OFF THE BRAKE ENOUGH FOR THE CAR TO ROLL FORWARD, CAUSING V1 TO REAR END V2.THERE WAS MINOR DAMAGE, HOWEVER, D2 REQUESTED AN ACCIDENT REPORT DUE TO V2 BEING A COMPANY TRUCK OWNED BY NAPA.

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: This crash occurred on Interstate 69. I-69 is a multi-lane, two way interstate that primarily runs north and south and is divided by a grass median. The roadway conditions at the time of the crash were clear in some spots, but slick and hazardous in others. Vehicle #1, a white 2012 Ford Focus (plate# AAZ860 Indiana ), was traveling northbound on I 69 at the 110MM. Vehicle #1 hit a patch of ice on the roadway, which made driver #1 lose control. Vehicle #1 ran off the roadway and struck a guard rail face, on the right (east) side of the road. V#1 then slid down the guard rail for about 300 feet before coming to a stop with the back bumper on the guard rail. Driver #1 (Shayna Craft) stated that she was traveling north on I 69 when she hit a patch of ice on the roadway. After hitting the patch of ice, she lost control of the vehicle and hit the guard rail. D#1 stated that her car started sliding along side of the guard rail until it came to a stop with the back bumper still on the guard rail.Evidence on the scene indicates that V#1 had hit a patch of ice on the roadway, lost control, and hit the guard rail on the right side of the road. V#1 than slid down the guard rail for about 300 feet before stopping with the back bumper on the guard rail.

V1 and V2 were both traveling North on SR 45/46 from 10th street, approaching the intersection of SR 45/46 and Range Rd. SR 45/46 is a four lane, two way road at that location, with a raised curb median. Both V1 and V2 were in the westmost lane, V1 was following V2. Traffic was slowed or stopped in front of V2, causing V2 to come to a stop. V1 did not notice traffic was stopped in time, and was unable to come to a stop before striking V2 in the passenger side rear bumper. V1 tried to avoid V2, and struck V2 with the driver side front bumper of V1. D1 said she was following V2, and it looked like a vehicle in front of V2 came to a sudden stop, causing V2 to come to a stop. D1 said she could not stop in time, and swerved to the right to avoid V2. D1 said she struck V2 in the passenger side rear bumper, with the driver side front bumper of V1. D1 said as she continued, the collison also caused damage to driver side rear quarter panel of V1. D2 said he was following traffic, and the car in front of him came to a sudden stop. D2 said he had to slam on his brakes, and was able to come to a stop. D2 said he was then struck from behind by V1.

V2 was parked behind Hodge Hall on the north end of the parking lot facing north. V1 was in a parking spot across from V2 facing south when D1 backed his vehicle into V2. V2 sustained damage to the driver's side rear bumper. I spoke to the owner of V2 who stated he had left his car parked from 1400 hours until he returned at approximately 2040 hours and noticed the damage. There was noticeable debris on the ground, however the debris appeared to be from another vehicle (V1). D2 was not on scene as he had left the area after striking the vehicle. Camera footage shows D1 backing his car into V2. On 02/19/19 I was able to make contact with the suspect (D1) who was arrested for Leaving the Scene of an Accident. D1 stated that on the night of the accident, he did get in his vehicle, put his car in reverse, and consequently back into V2. D1 stated he checked for damage to V2 but stated he did not see any so he left. There is major damage to the rear bumper of V1.

V1 WAS TRAVELING WESTBOUND ON BETHEL LN, AROUND A CURVE AT 2900 E BETHEL LANE, WHEN V1 WENT OFF THE ROADWAY STRIKING A BRICK BARRIER IN THE FRONT YARD OF 2900 E BETHEL LN. D1 STATED HE WAS GOING TOO FAST AROUND THE CORNER AND LOST CONTROL OF THE VEHICLE. THE ROAD DID HAVE SNOW AND ICE ON IT. THE OWNER OF 2900 BETHEL LN STATED SHE PUT THE BRICK BARRIER UP TO PREVENT CARS FROM RUNNING OFF THE ROAD AND HITTING HER HOUSE.

D1 WAS TRAVELING SOUTHBOUND ON S. OLD SR 37 JUST SOUTH OF E. DILLMAN RD. D1 HIT A LARGE PATCH OF ICE ON THE ROADWAY, AND LOST CONTROL OF HER VEHICLE. D1 RAN OFF THE ROAD, AND SLID INTO THE DITCH ON THE WEST SIDE OF THE ROAD.D1 NOR HER PASSENGER WERE INJURED, AND DECLINED MEDICAL TREATMENT.D1 WAS TOWED BY D1'S FATHER. THE VEHICLE WAS DRIVEABLE AFTER BEING TOWED, AND WAS DRIVEN AWAY FROM SCENE.D1 COLLIDED WITH A ROAD SIGN. THE SIGN WAS A 4 WAY INTERSECTION ADVISORY SIGN OWNED BY THE MONROE COUNTY HIGHWAY DEPT.

VEHICLE 1 WAS TRAVELING NORTH BOUND ON OLD STATE ROAD 37 SOUTH. VEHICLE 1 SLID ON ICE, SPUN OFF THE ROADWAY, AND STRUCK A SNOWBANK.DRIVER 1 WAS UNINJURED AND REFUSED ANY MEDICAL ATTENTION.VEHICLE 1 WAS DRIVABLE AND WAS DRIVEN FROM SCENE.

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: This crash occurred on Interstate 69. I 69 is a multi-lane, two way roadway which primarily runs north and south and is divided by a grass median. The roadway was mostly clear, but with snow/slash on parts of the roadway.Vehicle #1, white 2015 Chevy Silverado (plate#TK454NDN Indiana) was traveling northbound on I 69 at the 113MM. V#1 hit a patch of ice in the roadway. V#1 lost control and hit the bridge wall, then slid around and hit the wall with the back end. V#1 came back around and stopped facing north on I 69.Driver #1 (Joseph Kurzendoerfer) stated that he was headed northbound on I 69 when he hit a patch of ice. D#1 stated that then the vehicle started to slid and he hit the bridge wall head on. The vehicle slid around and struck the wall with the back bumper. D#1 stated that his vehicle slid back around and stopped in the roadway facing north.Evidence at the crash shows that V#1 was traveling northbound when he hit a patch of ice that made him lose control and hit the bridge wall.

V1 WAS TRAVELING WESTBOUND ON TAPP RD AT THE INTERSECTION OF RAYLE PLACE WHEN D1 STATED THERE WAS A VEHICLE IN THE NORTHWEST CORNER OF TAPP RD AND RAYLE PLACE IN THE DITCH. D1 STATED THEY ATTEMPTED TO AVOID THE VEHICLE IN THE DITCH, SWERVED AND WENT INTO THE DITCH IN THE NORTHWEST CORNER OF TAPP RD AND RAYLE PLACE. D1 STATED SHE DIDN'T HAVE INSURANCE FOR THE VEHICLE.
D-1 stated that he was traveling west bound on Fullerton Pike when his vehicle lost traction due to the road surface conditions and slid off the right side of the roadway.

D1 STATED HE WAS EASTBOUND ON SR 46 WHEN V2 WAS STOPPED TO TURN LEFT ONTO E KINGS RD. D1 STATED HE DID NOT INITIALLY SEE V2 BECAUSE IT BLENDED IN WITH THE SNOW AND WHEN HE ATTEMPTED TO STOP, THE WET ROADWAY AFFECTED V1'S ABILITY TO STOP.

Both vehicles were traveling west on 10th Street approaching the State Road 45/46 Bypass. V2 was traveling in front of V1. Both vehicles were in the turn lane to turn north onto the bypass. V2 was stopped for the red light. As V1 attempted to stop behind V2, V1 struck the rear end of V2. D1 would not provide much information about the crash. D1 only stated that the ground was wet and he believes his vehicle slid. D1 also stated the V1 was not his and did not believe the vehicle had valid registration or insurance. D1 had minor damage to the right side of the front bumper. V1 was towed by Ken's Westside for not having valid registration and no proof of insurance. D1 had a suspended learner permit.D2 could not provide much information on the crash. D2 stated she was at the light and then felt V1 hit the back of V2. V2 had minor cosmetic damage to the right side of the rear bumper. None of the drivers or passengers complained of pain or requested medical attention. D1 had three passengers, including two small children in the back seat (5 and 10 years old). Neither was in a child safety seat.D1 showed signs of intoxication and was arrested for Operating While Intoxicated and Neglect of a Dependent. He was also issued a citation for Driving While Suspended. See ARMS report under the same case number for more information regarding his arrest.Officer Weitkamp Supplement: On 12/15/2019 I received an ISDT Toxicology report stating that Montgomery's blood contained 2.5 ng/mL of 11-Hydroxy Delta-9 THC, 83 ng/mL Delta-9 Carboxy THC, 7.9 ng,mL of Delta-9 THC.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: V1 WAS TRAVELING NB OUT OF A PRIVATE DRIVE ON KIRKWOOD. A VEHICLE HEADING EB ON KIRKWOOD STOPPED AND WAVED V1 ON. AS V1 CROSSED THROUGH THE EB TURN LANE, V1 STRUCK V2. D1 ADVISED SHE WAS UNABLE TO SEE PAST THE VEHICLE THAT WAVED HER ON AND DID NOT SEE V2 UNTIL THEY COLLIDED. V1 WAS DAMAGED ON THE FRONT BUMPER AND THE FRONT PASSENGER SIDE AIRBAG DEPLOYED. D1 ADVISED SHE WAS STRUCK IN THE CHEST BY THE STEERING WHEEL. SHE INTIALLY REFUSED MEDICAL TREATMENT THEN LATER REQUESTED TO BE CHECKED OUT BY THE AMBULANCE STAFF. D1 WAS NOT TRANSPORTED TO THE HOSPITAL AND SIGNED AN SOR.V2 WAS TRAVELING EB ON W KIRKWOOD AVE ABOUT IN THE TURN LANE ON KIRKWOOD TO TURN NB ON ROGER. AS D2 APPROACHED THE TURN LANE, V1 CAME OUT OF A PRIVATE DRIVE AND TURNED LEFT IN FRONT OF V2.THERE WAS DAMAGE TO THE FRONT BUMPER. D2 VOICED A COMPLAINT OF NECK PAIN BUT DID NOT REQUEST AN AMBULANCE AT THE TIME OF THE INCIDENT.

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: While traveling south in the parking lot, unit 1 stated that the vehicle slid on the ice when she attempted to stop. Unit 2 was traveling west in the parking lot and was struck on the front, passenger side area of the bumper after unit 1 could not come to a complete stop in time.

VEHICLE 1 WAS TRAVELING WESTBOUND OUT OF THE DRIVEWAY OF 4709 S. NICOLE DR. VEHICLE 1 STUCK VEHICLE 2 ON THE DRIVER SIDE DOOR. VEHICLE 2 WAS PARKED IN THE CUL-DE-SAC OF S. NICOLE DR.DRIVER 1 WAS UNINJURED AND REFUSED MEDICAL TREATMENT.VEHICLE 1 WAS DRIVABLE AND DRIVEN FROM SCENE. VEHICLE 2 WAS LEFT PARKED, AND DRIVER'S EXCHANGE INFO WAS GIVEN TO OWNER OF VEHICLE.

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: Vehicle 1 (black, 2012 Hyundai) was westbound on Smithville Road, east of State Road 37. Smithville road was covered with ice/snow. Driver 1 (Tony Eck) was attempting to stop at the intersection with State Road 37. Driver 1 was unable to stop, slid off of the road, and struck a stop sign. Vehicle 1 struck the sign post with its front driver side fender/door area.The stop sign was still upright, but needed reset.

V1 WAS TRAVELING EB ON E FLEENER ROAD, WHEN IT PARTIALLY RAN OFF THE ROAWAY, HAD A TIRE GET STUCK IN THE SNOW, THEN THE REAR DRIVER'S SIDE OF HIS VEHICLE CROSSED LEFT OF AND CENTER AND STRUCK V2 THAT WAS TRAVELING WB ON FLEENER ROAD. D1 STATED THAT HE DROVE OFF THE ROAWAY, HAD A TIRE DIG INTO THE SNOW, THEN THE REAR OF HIS VEHICLE HIT V2.D2 STATED THAT HE WAS TRAVELING WB ON FLEENER AND WAS STUCK BY V1.THE ROAWAY WAS NARROW, WAS CLEARED OF SNOW AND HAD LOOSE SAND.

Vehicle 1 and Vehicle 2 were stopped at the intersection of Victor Pike and State Road 37 at the traffic light. V2 was stopped behind V1 at the light. V1 began to back up from it's stopped position to make room for a semi-tractor trailer turning right onto Victor Pike from SR 37. V1 collided with V2 while backing up causing damage to V2. Both vehicles moved back from the intersection prior to my arrival. Driver of V1 stated he was stopped at the intersection of Victor Pike and SR 37 at the traffic light. Driver of V1 stated a semi tractor trailer was turning right onto Victor Pike from SR 37. Driver of V1 stated he looked behind him but did not see V2 in his mirrors and began to back up to give the semi room to turn. Driver of V1 stated as he was backing up he collided with V2 and caused damage to the vehicle. Driver of V2 stated she was stopped at the intersection of Victor Pike and SR 37 at the traffic light behind V1. Driver of V2 stated she saw V1 starting to back up and could not get out of the way in time because there was another vehicle behind her. Driver of V2 stated V1 backed up and collided with the front of her vehicle and caused damage.

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: V1, Ford Ranger, was traveling south on Old SR37 north of Empire Mill Road. V1 traveled off the west side of the roadway into a ditch. V1 rolled after impact with the ditch and came to final rest upside down.D1, Gerkin, stated she was traveling south on Old SR37. D1 stated she began to slide on the snow covered roadway and traveled off the right side of the road. D1 stated she struck a ditch and rolled.Evidence shows the roadway was snow covered during the accident investigation. Evidence shows V1 traveled off the west side of the roadway. Evidence shows damage to V1 consistent with a roll over accident.

Manner of Collision: HEAD ON BETWEEN TWO MOTOR VEHICLES
NARRATIVE: WITNESS INGALLS STATED HE WAS PARKED IN HIS VEHICLE ALONG THE CURB AT 3406 S WALNUT ST, FACING EAST. HE OBSERVED V1 PULL INTO THE DRIVEWAY, WEST BOUND, THEN BEGIN TO TURN RIGHT, INTO AN EMPTY PARKING SPACE NEXT TO V2. INGALLS ADVISED HE OBSERVED V1 COLLIDE WITH V2. HE WATCHED AS DRIVER 1 EXITED V1 AND INSPECT BOTH VEHICLES. D1 THEN GOT BACK INTO V1 AND FINISHED PARKING. D1 THEN WENT INTO THE BUILDING. OWNER OF VEHICLE 2 WAS NOT PRESENT AT THE TIME OF THE COLLISION. I HAVE FOUND NO VIDEO CAMERAS IN THE AREA.DRIVER ADVISED HE DID NOT REMEMBER STRIKING V2 WHEN HE PULLED IN, BUT DID ADMIT TO GETTING OUT TO LOOK AT HIS VEHICLE TO SEE IF THERE WAS ANY DAMAGE PRIOR TO GOING INSIDE OF THE BUILDING.

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: D2 WAS SITTING AT THE THREE WAY INTERSECTION ON PROFILE PARKWAY FACING SB PREPARING TO TURN RIGHT ONTO ZENITH DRIVE. D2 STATED IT WAS VERY SLICK AT THIS INTERSECTION.D1 WAS TRAVELING SB ON PROFILE PARKWAY WHEN D1 ATTEMPTED TO STOP BUT WAS UNABLE TO DUE TO THE ICE. D1 MADE CONTACT WITH D2'S DRIVERS SIDE REAR BUMPER WITH THE PASSENGER SIDE BUMPER OF D1'S VEHICLE. BOTH VEHICLES MOVED FROM THE SCENE BEFORE MY ARRIVAL.

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: Vehicle 1 was southbound on Ketchum Rd south of Thrasher Rd. D1 lost control of the vehicle on the snow covered road and drove off the roadway on the east side of Ketchum Rd. V1 overturned as it made impact with the ditch and fence and came to rest upside down. The impact caused damage to V1 and to the fence.Driver of V1 stated he was southbound on Ketchum Rd south of Thrasher Rd. Driver of V1 stated another vehicle was northbound on Ketchum Rd and caused him to swerve to the right to avoid a collision. Driver of V1 stated when he swerved he lost control of the vehicle on the snow covered road, turned 180 degrees and ran off the roadway. Driver of V1 stated he impacted with the ditch and a tree, overturned the vehicle and came to rest on a fence.

V2 was towing a BigTex trailer. There were two roof top air conditioning units loaded on the trailer. The units were situated on the trailer in a single file.Primary Cause-Driver Factor-Unsafe Lane Movement: V1 was unable to make a safe lane change given the conditions. The conditions were that V2 was traveling in the right lane. V1 attempted to change lanes from the left to the right lane which V2 was already occupying. D1 should have waited for a clear path to avoid colliding with the trailer of V2.I69 is a interstate that runs in a northern and southern direction through Monroe County. The crash occurred 50 feet north of the 128.6MM. In the area of the crash construction work was being conducted. This caused the left lane to be closed and traffic was being diverted into the right lane. The roadway is straight/level.V2 (2007 black Ford F250 towing a 2018 black BigTex trailer) was traveling southbound in the right lane of I69. V2 was towing a trailer carrying two large roof top air conditioners. V1 (2018 white Ford Transit van) was traveling southbound in the left lane on I69. V1 attempted to change lanes due to left lane closure. V1 struck the left side of the trailer and left lower front corner of the front air conditioning unit.D1 (Larry Twigg) stated that he was traveling southbound on I69 in the left lane. He attempted to travel into the right lane due to the left lane being closed. D1 stated he did not see V2's trailer and struck the left side of the trailer with his passenger side of V1. He was wearing his seat belt.D2 (James Brown) stated he was traveling southbound in the right lane of I69. V1 struck the left side of his trailer and air conditioning unit. He was wearing his seat belt.During the course of my investigation, I observed damage to the left front corner of one of the air conditioning units. I did not observe any damage to the trailer or V2. I did observe damage to the right front headlight, passenger side mirror, and passenger side rear fender area of V1. No injuries were reported as a result of this crash.The investigation showed that the primary cause of the crash is Unsafe Lane Movement on the part of D1. This was determined by damages sustained to V1 and the air conditioning unit, and driver statements.

Manner of Collision: HEAD ON BETWEEN TWO MOTOR VEHICLES
NARRATIVE: Vehicle 2 was traveling east on Allen St. Vehicle 1 was traveling west on Allen. Driver of vehicle 1 stated that when traveling up the hill she started to lose traction on the roadway because of ice and having poor tires. The driver then lost control and went left of center colliding head on with vehicle 2. Both vehicles had significant damage to the front.Driver of vehicle 2 stated that as he started down the hill just east of Adams vehicle 1 suddenly went into his lane of travel and struck him head on. Driver of vehicle 2 did not have time to try to avoid the collision.Driver of vehicle 2 was transported to the hospital for injuries from the accident and pain in the right wrist was main complaint. Driver of vehicle 1 was transported for injuries from the accident and head pain was main complaint. 2 small children were in the back of vehicle 1. One age 7 and one age 2. Driver of vehicle 1 stated both children were in a seat belt but not child restraints. The 7 year old was transported by ambulance to the hospital for his injures with leg pain as main complaint. The 2 year old was transported to the hospital by grandpa and seen by hospital staff for head pain. Front seat passenger of vehicle 1 had no injuries.Vehicle 2 was towed due to disabling damage.

V1 WAS TRAVELING SOUTHBOUND ON SOUTH ROGERS ST WHEN IT WENT THROUGH THE INTERSECTION OF WEST 1ST STREET, RAN OFF THE ROADWAY ON THE SOUTH EAST CORNER OF THE INTERSECTION AND STRUCK A WALL. IT IS UNKNOWN IF D1 STOPED AT THIS INTERSECTIONS STOP SIGN.D1 STATED SHE WAS DRIVING HOME FROM WORK WHEN SHE THINKS SHE FELL ASLEEP PRIOR TO THE ACCIDENT. D1 STATED SHE LEFT WORK EARLY AND WAS GOING HOME DUE TO HER HAVING ISSUES STAYING AWAKE AT WORK. D1 STATED IT WAS POSIBLY DUE TO HER NEW MEDICATIONS OR AN UNKNOWN MEDICAL ISSUE. I RAN D1 THOUGH HORIZONTAL GAZE NYSTAGMUS WHICH SHE PASSED AND SHE SHOWED NO OTHER SIGNS OF IMPAIRMENT. D1 WAS COMPLAINING OF PAIN TO HER NECK, LOWER BACK, NOSE AND KNEES.W1 STATED SHE DID NOT SEE THE COLLISION BUT WHEN SHE CHECKED ON D1 SHE THOUGHT D1 WAS UNCONCIOUS.

On 01/23/2019 at 1745 hours, V1 and V2 were traveling southbound on the SR 45/46 Bypass approaching the intersection of E 10th St. V2 was slowing in traffic due to the red traffic light and V1 collided with the rear of V2.D1 advised that she was traveling southbound on the SR 45/46 Bypass approaching the intersection at E 10th St. behind V2. D1 advised that the traffic signal was red and V2 applied his brakes. D1 advised that she also applied her brakes, but was unable to stop before colliding with the rear of V2.D2 advised that he was traveling southbound on the SR 45/46 Bypass approaching E 10th St. D2 advised that the traffic signal was red so he was slowing down, and V1 rear ended him.V1 sustained a crack to the front grille.V2 sustained some light scratches to the rear bumper cover.

Unit 1 was parked, facing the building, in the parking lot of Andy Mohr Honda. After exiting the building, unit 1 backed out of the parking space so he could leave. while backing, unit 1 backed into unit 2. Nobody was inside of unit 2. Unit 2 was parked in the parking lot, facing south. After striking unit 2, unit 1 proceeded to leave the parking lot and head north on Liberty Dr. The witness stated that unit 1 came to a complete stop after striking unit 2, and any reasonable person would have been able to realize that they were in an accident.After speaking with the employees and the witness, the driver of unit 1 returned to the location. After speaking with the driver of unit 1, he stated that he did not realize he had struck another vehicle and in fact had returned to exchange the product he had originally purchased.

V2 was backing from her driveway into the roadway. V1 was traveling southwest on Olcott Blvd. V1 struck V2 and kept going.D2 state that she had backed out of her driveway onto the right side of the roadway. She had just put the car in drive to go forward, however she was not moving. She advised that V1 rounded the curve in the middle of the roadway and struck her car. V1 then kept going.V1 did drive left of center striking V2.

V1 was traveling eastbound in the north lane of SR 45/46 approaching Milo B Sampson Ln. V2 was also traveling eastbound in the south lane of SR 45/46 approaching Milo B Sampson Ln. V1 veered into the south lane of SR 45/46 and initially struck the front driver side of V2. V1 sustained minor damage to the entire passenger side of the vehicle. V2 sustained minor damage to the entire driver side of the vehicle. D1 stated that he was traveling eastbound on SR 45/46 and was attempting to change lanes. D1 stated he glanced in his right side mirror and did not see a vehicle next to him. D1 stated when he changed lanes he never saw V2 until he hit the vehicle.D2 stated she was traveling eastbound on SR 45/46 and never realized V1 was changing lanes. D2 stated the next thing she knew she was hit by V1. There were no injuries at the scene. Neither vehicle was towed.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: V1 WAS WB ON JACOB DR TURNING LEFT ONTO GATES DRIVE.V2 WAS SOUTHBOUND ON GATES DR AT JACOB DR.D1 SAID HE DID NOT SEE V2 COMING WHEN HE TURNED LEFT. HE SAID HE THINKS HIS A POST BLOCKED HIS VIEW. D1 SAID WHEN HE TURNED HE COLLIDED WITH V2.D2 SAID AS HE DROVE SOUTH V1 PULLED INTO THE SIDE OF HIM.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: Vehicle 2 was traveling west on a private drive. Vehicle 1 was traveling east on a private drive. Both vehicles came to a stop at the intersection of S. Kingston Dr. Vehicle 2 was attempting to continue west through the intersection and Vehicle 1 was attempting to turn north onto Kingston. The vehicle in front of vehicle 1 proceeded through the intersection. Vehicle 2 then started to go through the intersection. Vehicle 1 failed to yield right of way to vehicle 2 and pulled out in front of vehicle 2. The vehicles then collided in the intersection. Driver of vehicle 1 stated he did not see vehicle 2 until they collided. Vehicle 2 has minor damage to the front passenger side bumper/grill. Vehicle 1 has significant damage to rear passenger door. No injuries reported from the accident. Vehicle 1 was towed from the scene due to damage.

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: D1 STATED HE WAS WESTBOUND ON CHRUCH LANE WHEN HE CAME OVER THE HILL BEFORE THE STOP SIGN AT S VICTOR PIKE. AS HE CRESTED THE HILL, HE NOTICED V2 BUT WAS UNABLE TO STOP BEFORE REAR ENDING V2.

DRIVER OF VEHICLE 2 STATED HE WAS WEST BOUND ON 3RD STREET, PASSING THROUGH THE INTERSECTION WITH NORTH BOUND I 69. AS HE ENTERED THE INTERSECTION, HE NOTICE V1 WHICH WAS DIRECTLY IN FRONT OF V2, STOP SUDDENLY. D2 ATTEMPTED TO BRAKE, BUT THE ABS ACTIVATED AND V2 ROLLED INTO THE REAR OF V1. THE DRIVER OF V1 THEN LEFT THE SCENE WITHOUT EXCHANGING INFORMATION.

BOTH VEHICLES WERE EAST BOUND ON THE SR 45 / 46 BYPASS, JUST WEST OF COLLEGE AVE, IN THE LEFT LANE.D2 SAID A THIRD VEHICLE IN FRONT OF HIM SUDDENLY BEGAN BRAKING, CAUSING HIM TO SWERVE AND BRAKE. AS HE DID SO, HE WAS REAR ENDED BY V1.D1 SAID THAT HE SAW V2 BRAKE, TRIED TO AVOID IT, BUT REAR ENDED V2.NO REPORTED INJURIES.

D1 STATED WHILE STOPPED SOUTH ON FRANKLIN RD WAITING IN TRAFFIC, HIS FOOT SLIPPED OFF THE ACCELERATOR. D1 SAID HE WAS NOT ABLE TO STOP HIS VEHICLE BEFORE IT STRUCK V2. D2 STATED WHILE STOPPED SOUTH ON FRANKLIN RD WAITING FOR THE TRAFFIC SIGNAL AT 3RD STREET TO CHANGE, SHE WAS STRUCK FROM BEHIND BY V1.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: Unit 1 stated that he was at a stop at the intersection of Allen and Adams street. Unit 1 stated he was turning onto Adams street off of Allen street. As he entered the intersection, he struck unit 2 who was already traveling through the intersection. Unit 2 stated that she was traveling north through the intersection when she was struck on the passenger side of her vehicle. The driver of unit 2 complained of pain in her head, neck, and back.

V2/D2 STATED "I WAS STOPPED IN THE ROADWAY ON N. KINSER PIKE NEAR VAUGHN CLIP WAY AND THE ENTRANCE TO NORTHLANE DR, DUE TO A VEHICLE INFRONT OF ME STOPPED, WAITING TO MAKE A LEFT HAND TURN INTO NORTHLANE DR. WHEN ALL OF THE SUDDEN I WAS REARENDED BY V1. SMALL 22 MONTH OLD SAMUEL IN CAR SEAT, ALSO TREATED AT HOSP."V1/D1 STATED "I WAS NORTHBOUND ON N. KINSER PIKE, WHEN ALL OF THE SUDDEN THE VEHICLE INFRONT OF ME WAS STOPPED. I REARENDED V2."

OWNER OF V1 LEFT V1 PARKED SE AT 528 S COLLEGE AVE FACING SE AT 1500 HOURS. OWNER OF V1 RETURNED TO V1 AT 1800 HOURS AND FOUND DAMAGE TO THE REAR PASSENGER DOOR.DAMAGE CAPTURED ON BWC1613.NO SUSPECTS.

Driver 1 stated that she pulled into the parking space and stopped. She stated she put her car in park and took her foot off of the brake and the car "jumped" forward and into the building. The vehicle had very little damage but the building sustained a great deal of damage. The car went through a glass corridor and support beam. Driver 1 stated she had received a recall on her vehicle stating that it might "jump out of gear". Driver 1 stated she had not had a chance to get it fixed. When backing the vehicle out of the building, it took a great deal of effort to get the vehicle back over the parking curb. Unsure if it was a recall issue or if the driver accidentally hit the gas instead of the brake when parking.No injuries.Owner of the building is IU Health Bloomington. Contact information is Mike Carroll 812-372-8481
V2 was parked on Waldron Street just North of the intersection of 6th Street and Waldron Street.V2 was side swiped by V1 which was heading North on Waldron Street.V1 was unable to be located.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: V-1 was traveling south on Curry Pike going through the stop light at Curry Pike and Vernal Pike when V-2 was making a left hand turn onto vernal pike striking V-1. Both D-1 and D-2 stated that they had a green light. I spoke to a witness by the name of Ashley Woodward with a phone number of (812)369-1077 she stated that she was behind D-1 when the crash happened. Mrs. Woodward stated that D-1 and herself had a red light as they were traveling south on Curry Pike and that the green turn arrow was on for both turn lanes. Mrs. Woodward stated that D-1 continued into the intersection through the red traffic light that is when D-2 was turning west onto West Vernal Pike and both vehicles collided.

V1 WAS BACKING OUT OF HANDICAP PARKIND SPACE AT THE US POST OFFICE AT 520 S WALNUT ST.V2 HAD PULLED ALONGSIDE OF THE BUILDING BEHIND V1.D1 SAID WHEN HE WAS BACKING UP V2 QUICKLY PULLED NEXT TO THE BUILDING AND STOPPED. HE SAID HE COLLIDED WITH V2.D2 SAID SHE PULLED NEXT TO THE POST OFFICE TO DROP OFF SOMEONE TO GO INSIDE. SHE SAID WHEN SHE STOPPED V1 BACKED INTO HER AND HIT THE FRONT DRIVERS FENDER WITH IT'S REAR PASSENGER SIDE BUMPER. SHE SAID D1 YELLED AT HER AND THEN DROVE OFF.OTHER LOCATION OF INVESTIGATION: OFFICER WEISHEIT WENT TO D1'S RESIDENCE AND MADE CONTACT WITH HIM. OFFICER WEISHEIT ADV V1 HAS PRIOR DAMAGE ON THE VEHICLE AND COULD NOT TELL WHAT OR IF THERE IS NEW DAMAGE FROM THIS CRASH.PRIMARY CAUSE FOR D2 LISTED AS OTHER/DRIVER BECAUSE THE AREA D2 STOPPED IN WAS MARKED "NO PARKING"MARKED WITH A YELLOW CURB.

THIS OCCURRED IN THE CITY OF BLOOMINGTON, COUNTY OF MONROE, STATE OF INDIANA.V1 WAS DRIVING SB ON N COLLEGE AVE. V1 COLLIDED WITH A USPS MAILBOX POSTED ON THE SIDEWALK. V1 THEN COLLIDED WITH LANSCAPING ON THE SIDEWALK.D1 SAID HE WAS DRIVING SB ON N COLLEGE AVE. HE SAID HE DID NOT KNOW HOW THE COLLISION OCCURRED AND THAT HE POSSIBLY FELL ASLEEP. D1 COMPLAINED OF PAIN TO HIS RIGHT WRIST AND WAS TAKEN TO IU HEALTH BLOOMINGTON HOSPITAL. D1 DID NOT SHOW SIGNS OF IMPAIRMENT.USPS AND BUTLER WINERY PROPERTY OWNERS WERE NOTIFIED. USPS MAILBOX WAS DESTROYED, ESTIMATED DAMAGE OF $500.00. BUTLER WINERY DAMAGE WAS ESTIMATED $3000.00.CASE INACTIVE.OFFICER S. ROSE #1665 01/24/2019

Vehicle 1 was traveling directly behind vehicle 2. Both vehicles were traveling west on Tapp Rd. The vehicles proceeded west through the intersection of Tapp and Rockport Rd after the light changed green. Vehicle 1 came to a stop shortly after due to the vehicles in front of her stopping. Driver of vehicle 1 stated she looked down at her phone and when she looked up, Vehicle 2 had came to a stop. Driver of Vehicle 1 was unable to come to a stop and collided with vehicle 2. Vehicle 2 has minor dame to the rear and vehicle 1 has significant damage to the front. Vehicle 1 was towed due to disabling damage. Back seat passenger of vehicle 2 were checked by EMS due to a bloody nose from the accident but was not transported to hospital.

D1 STATED THAT HE WAS LEAVING THE PARKING LOT AT 1531 S CURRY PIKE, TRAVELING WEST. WHEN D1 PULLED ONTO CURRY PIKE GOING NORTH, D1 STATED HE FELT AND HEARD A COLLISION. D1 PULLED INTO THE ADJACENT PARKING LOT AND STOPPED. D1 OBSERVED DAMAGE TO HIS VEHICLE ON THE PASSENGER SIDE, IN FRONT OF THE FRONT PASSENGER DOOR. D1 STATED THAT HE HIT A SNOW PILE, AND THAT HE HAD NOT SEEN THE SNOW PILE PRIOR TO ENTERING TRAFFIC. D1 NOTIFIED DISPATCH TO START A CALL FOR A 10-50 AND TO HAVE A SUPERVISOR EN ROUTE.

V2 was parked facing south, in front of 1600 N. Willis Dr lot 210.D1 said he was trying to drive up the hill, and as he passed V2, V1 began to slide sideways and backwards, due to the ice on the ground. V2 struck V1 causing damage.No reported injuries.

V1 was parked facing south in the University Gym parking lot at 2721 E 10th St. V2 was parked to the left of V1. V1 pulled forward and to the right, colliding with V1.Owner 1 advised that he parked his car for work in the University Gym parking lot at 2721 E 10th St. O1 advised that he left work at 1800 hours and found a scrape on the left front corner of V1. O1 advised that there was a note with a name and phone number on his windshield. I called the number and spoke to D2, who provided all the information I needed and agreed to meet with me.D2 advised that she was parked in the University Gym parking lot at 2721 E 10th St. next to V1. D2 advised that at 1000 hours she began to leave her parking space and turn right, and scraped V1. D2 advised that she left a note with her name and phone number on the windshield of V1. V1 sustained scrapes and a broken reflector on the front left corner.V2 sustained a minor dent and paint transfer on the front right corner.

V1 was parked in the parking lot located at 3601 W SR 46 in the Arby's parking lot. V1 was unattended from 10:45am to 3pm. D1 stated she returned from shopping and her car had been hit in the rear end of the vehicle. V2 was unable to be located. There was no plate number or information on the vehicle.

Driver one stated he was exiting the parking lot and scrapped the front of vehicle two with the passenger side fender flare. Driver one stated vehicle two was parked in the parking lot facing north. Driver one stated there was another fire truck on his left and was attempting to avoid that truck. Driver one stated no one was hurt.

Primary Cause (explain in narrative): See narrative for details. V1 was traveling southbound on Woodlawn Avenue and turned to go left (eastbound) on 7th Street. pedestrian was crossing crosswalk northbound prior to the accident.On 01/25/2019 at approximately 1028 hours, I was dispatched to 7th and Woodlawn Avenue by the gates for a person struck by vehicle and informed vehicle left the scene. While enroute to the location I was informed by dispatch no plate information or type of vehicle was known. Upon arrival, I spoke with the victim Christopher Franck. Franck said he did not need an ambulance but was going to be taken for a medical check out since it is his work policy. I asked Franck what occurred. Franck said he was at the intersection of 7th Street and Woodlawn Avenue at the crosswalk. Franck said he was walking northbound to cross the street, and was in the middle of the crosswalk. Franck said he did not see any vehicles in the intersection at the time when crossing. Franck said the next thing he knew he was struck by a vehicle. Franck said he was unsure of what type of vehicle and didn't have any plate information. Franck said the driver was a female, blonde hair and around 40-50 years of age. Franck said the female driver exited the vehicle after the crash and asked a couple times if he was okay. Franck said he then told her to leave to her face, so he would not scream at her. Franck said the female driver then left scene. Franck said he did not want her charged for the accident. Franck said he felt the vehicle was traveling around 15mph. After speaking with Franck, I spoke with Kruse who was right behind Franck when the accident occurred. Kruse said the vehicle was southbound on Woodlawn Avenue, and turned to go eastbound on 7th Street. Kruse said he was unsure if the vehicle came to a complete stop. Kruse said he thought the vehicle was a possible SUV and silver in color, but had no further information. Kruse said he observed the female driver looking at her cell phone prior to the accident. Kruse said the female did exit her vehicle and ask if Franck was ok. After speaking with Franck, I took photographs of his injuries. Franck had scrapes on his left elbow, right, hand, and right knee. I then drove the area, and looked for cameras for potential video footage, but was unable to locate cameras where the incident occurred. I placed the SD card in a sealed and clear bag where it was placed into locked locker # 6. I then sent the IUPD evidence tech an email pertaining to this incident. Photographs of the incident are available.

V1 was traveling north on Bottom Road, near Wylie Road, D1 advised that the road was water and ice covered, D1 stated that while traveling north on Bottom Road V1 lost traction and slide off the side of the roadway and into water. Driver and Driver's boss requested that driver be given a PBT to make sure that driver was not impaired, as this is a company vehicle. Driver was tested, at his request, and registered a .000 BrAC.

V1, a large Miller charter bus, was backing through a narrow parking drive in the lot of Assembly Hall during an Indiana University Men's Basketball game. V2, IUPD-IN police vehicle #65, was parked unattended in a parallel space designated for emergency vehicles.D1 stated that ESG Security employees directing traffic within the lot had directed him into an area of the lot that V1 could not navigate out of. D1 stated ESG then started waving him backward to help him back out of the crowded area. D1 stated that, following the direction of this ESG worker, he inadvertently backed V1 directly into the side of V2 after misjudging the amount of space he had.

D2 was traveling west on E Bethel Rd turning left on N Hinkle Rd yielding to oncoming traffic. D1 was traveling west on E Bethel Rd behind V2. D1 stated that she did not see V2 stopped in the roadway yielding to oncoming traffic and rear ended V2. Neither vehicle sustained disabling damage.

V1 was driving northbound on Indiana and was forced to make a turn due to traffic for the IU basketball game. V1 then turned right into the private drive (near the red lot) across from the IU Credit Union. V1 then struck a bent pole that was near the entrance to the drive. I spoke to D1 who stated he had been attempting to drive north toward the stadium for the IU game when he came to a barricade near 17th and Indiana. D1 stated he then attempted to turn his car around pulling into the grass lot area across from the IU Credit Union. As he was making the turn, he felt his passenger side rear tire hit the pole. D1 stated he then got out and realized his vehicle had hit the bent pole and popped a hole in his tire. The only damage was to the rear passenger tire.

Sequence Of Collision Events: V3 was not struck by V1 or V2. However, V3 was struck by debris that was propelled from V1.Contributory Cause-Driver Factor-Driver Asleep Or Fatigued: D1's attention was taken from the roadway due to D1 falling asleep.SR45 is a highway that primarily runs in a western and eastern direction through Monroe County. South Duncan Road is a county road that runs in a northern and southern direction and intersects with SR45, 100 feet west, of the crash. The roadway is straight with an uphill grade. V1 (2015 silver Subaru) was traveling westbound on SR45. V1 crossed the center line traveling partially into the eastbound lane of SR45 and collided with V2 (2018 blue Nissan). V2 was traveling eastbound on SR45 and was struck by V1, causing minor damage to the driver's side door and rear fender area. V3 (2015 black Dodge SUV) was traveling eastbound on SR45 behind V2. V3 was struck by debris from V1's driver side mirror. This caused minor damage to the driver side rear door.D1 (David Gronski) stated that he was traveling westbound on SR45. He stated that he may have fallen asleep and crossed the center line, striking V2. He was wearing his seat belt.D2 (Donald Ingle) stated that he was traveling eastbound on SR45. V1 crossed the center line and collided with his vehicle, on the driver side. He was wearing his seat belt.D3 (Diane Dale) stated she was traveling eastbound on SR45 behind V2. V1 crossed the center line and struck V2. V3 stated that debris from V1 struck her vehicle. She was wearing her seat belt.During the course of my investigation, I observed damage to the front driver side fender, and mirror of V1. I also observed damage to the driver side door and rear fender area of V2. V3 had damage to the diver side rear passenger door. No injuries were reported as a result of this crash.The crash investigation show that the primary cause of the crash was Left Of Center on the part of D1. This was determined by damages to all three vehicles and driver statements.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: The driver of vehicle 1 stated he was backing out of a parking space and saw vehicle 2 coming at what he considered a high rate of speed. He then stated that vehicle 1 made contact with vehicle 2. The driver of vehicle 2 stated she was looking for a parking space when vehicle 1 hit vehicle 2 on the passenger side door. There were scratches on the rear bumper of vehicle 1 and damage to both passenger side doors of vehicle 2.

V1 WAS TRAVELING EB ON W 17TH STREET BEHIND V2. V2 WAS STOPPED WAITING FOR ONCOMING TRAFFIC TO CLEAR IN ORDER FOR D2 TO TURN LEFT INTO A PRIVATE LOT OF WESTERN SKATELAND. AS V1 WAS YIELDING ONCOMING TRAFFIC WAITING TO TURN, V1 STRUCK V2 FROM BEHIND. THE FRONT DRIVERS SIDE OF V1 STRUCK THE REAR PASSENGER SIDE OF V2.

D1 and D2 were headed N/B on N Walnut St, approaching the intersection of N Old SR 37. D2 slowed as he approached the intersection in preparation to make a left turn onto N Old SR 37. As D2 slowed, D1 was not able to slow down in time, causing V1 to strike V2 in the rear of the vehicle. D1 reported no injuries at this time. D1 reported pain in his neck, however refused medical service. Both vehicles were driven from the scene. D1 stated that she was headed N/B on N Walnut St, approaching the intersection of N Old SR 37. D1 stated that D2 stopped abruptly in the intersection, causing V1 to strike V2 in the rear. D1 stated that she never saw D2 indicate his intention to turn. D2 stated that he was headed N/B on N Walnut St, approaching N Old SR 37. D2 stated that he indicated his intention to make a left turn onto N Old SR 37, and began to slow down. D2 stated that as he slowed, waiting for oncoming traffic to pass, his vehicle was struck in the rear by V1. It should be noted that I observed that the turn signals on V2 were operational.

V1 WAS TRAVELING EAST ON 7TH STREET; WHEN V1 COLLIDED WITH V2. THE ACCIDENT IS A SAME DIRECTION SIDESWIPE, AND V2 WAS PARKED AND UNOCCUPIED, AT THE TIME OF THE COLLISION.

V1 WAS TRAVELING WEST ON E. BETHEL LANE AND WHILE COMING DOWN A HILL THAT WAS ICE COVERED SLID OFF INTO THE DITCH STRIKING A UTILITY POLE.

This crash occurred in the back parking lot of Cook Medical located at 750 Daniels Way Bloomington Indiana 47404. The parking lot is level with multiple parking spaces. Vehicle #1 a blue 2017 Subaru Outback was backing southeast out of a parking space. Vehicle #2 was backing northwest out of a parking space that was across from vehicle #1's parking space. Vehicle #1 and vehicle #2 collided while both were backing out of their spaces. Driver #1, Michelle Arnett stated that she was backing out of her parking space and did not see vehicle #2 until the crash occurred. Driver #2, Gabriel Wheeler stated that he was backing out of his parking space and did not see vehicle #1 until the crash occurred. Evidence on the scene indicates that both vehicle #1 and #2 were attempting to back out of their parking spaces, neither driver observed the other vehicle prior to the crash. Minimal damage to both vehicles and both were drivable.

It is seen that V1 is in the westbound lane of S College Avenue and collides with V2, causing the driver's side mirror to break off. No other information about V1 or D1 is known.
V1 was traveling south bound on South Breeden Road. V1 ran off the the east side of the roadway and struck a sign. V1 then continued and struck a utility pole. The roadway was snow and ice covered.

WHEN HE SWERVED LEFT TO AVOID A DEER. D1 STATED THAT HE TURNED BACK TO THE RIGHT TO RETURN TO HIS LANE, BUT LOST CONTROL ON THE ROADWAY CONDITIONS. Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: V1 was traveling northbound on S. Old State Road 37 between S. Rogers St. and S. Fairfax Rd. at speeds too fast for the weather conditions as the road is ice covered. V1 struck the guardrail on the eastside of the roadway causing disabling damage to V1. D1 is hearing impaired therefore no driver statement was able to be obtained. D1 was taken by EMS for immediate medical attention.

Driver 2 stated she was stopped at the light at Collegemall Road and E 3rd Street. She stated she was on Collegemall facing south. She stated that Driver 1 rear-ended her. She stated they did not call the police at the time and they exchanged information. Driver 2 stated that when she woke up today, her neck hurt so she came to the department for a report. Driver 1 stated that he was behind driver 2 and attempted to stop but could not stop in time. Driver 1 stated he rear-ended driver 2. I did speak with driver 1 over the phone to obtain his information. I did not see the damage to his car.

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: I69 is a multi-lane, two way interstate that primarily travels north and south. In the area of the 106.5 mile marker, it is a four lane divided highway, with a metal guard rail on both sides of the shoulder. The roadway curves to the east and has a bridge. At the scene of the crash, the roadway was slick, covered with ice.Vehicle 1 (2014 White Mazda CX-5) was traveling northbound on I69, approaching the 106.5 mile marker. V1 traveled on the east side of the shoulder and then went to the west side of the roadway striking the metal guard rail. V1's trajectory forced the vehicle back eastbound, causing the vehicle to overturn. V1's final rest was on the east side of the roadway, on the shoulder inverted, just south of the bridge. Also to be noted, the vehicle was facing westbound when it was inverted. Driver 1 (Cooper Bybee) stated he was traveling northbound on I69 approaching the 106.5 mile marker. D1 stated that when he was going around the curve, he noticed the roadway was slick. D1 stated that he lost control of the vehicle and struck the guard rail on the west side of the roadway. D1 stated that his vehicle flipped, and he escaped from the inverted vehicle. D1 was checked out by EMS personnel at the scene. D1 had minor cuts and abrasions. D1 refused medical treatment. Based off the facts and circumstances, I have determined the primary cause to the crash was D1 was traveling too fast for weather conditions. No citations were issued at the scene of the crash.

V1 had damage to the front passenger bumper area. D2 said she was traveling eastbound on E. 17th Street in V2. D2 said V1 pulled out of the apartment complex garage into her lane of travel and struck V2 on the front driver side door causing damage. Both parties advised they did not need medical treatment.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: Curry Pike is a local roadway that runs in a northern and southern direction through Monroe County. Jonathan Drive is a local roadway that runs in a eastern and western direction and intersects with Curry Pike.V1 (2008 red/silver Chevrolet Cobalt) was stopped in the left turn lane at the traffic light, facing southbound on Curry Pike. V2 (2014 black Ford Focus) was traveling northbound on Curry Pike in the right lane. V2 was traveling through the intersection and V1 attempted to make a left turn. V1 struck V2 in the front diver side fender area. This caused V2 to rotate in a clockwise direction coming to rest in the westbound turn lane, facing east on Jonathan Drive.D1 (Robert Michael) stated that he was stopped at the intersection of Curry Pike and Jonathan Dr. He was preparing to make a left turn and thought he had a green turn arrow. He proceeded and struck V1 in the front fender. He was wearing his seat belt.D2 (Sarah Curtiss) stated she was traveling northbound on Curry Pike in the right lane. She was traveling through the intersection with a green light and was struck in the front fender by V1. She was wearing her seat belt.W1 (Dusty Hendrickson) stated that he was directly behind V2 traveling northbound on Curry Pike. W1 stated that V2 had a green light and was traveling through the intersection when V1 collided into the front of V2.During the course of my investigation, I observed debris in the intersection indicating the point of impact. I observed disabling damage to the entire front end and fender area of V2. I observed damage to the entire front end of V1. No injuries were reported as a result of this crash.The crash investigation showed that the primary cause of the crash is Failure To Yield Right Of Way on the part of D1. This was determined by driver and witness statements and damage sustained to both vehicles.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY

AS V2 CONTINUED SB THROUGH 3RD ST, V1 ATTEMPTED TO MERGE TO THE RIGHT AND THE PASSENGER SIDE OF V1 STRUCK THE REAR DRIVERS SIDE OF TRAILER OF V2.I WAS UNABLE TO MAKE CONTACT WITH D1 REFERENCE THIS ACCIDENT.D2 STATED THAT HE WAS TRAVELING SB ON COLLEGE AVE AT 3RD ST IN THE MIDDLE LANE. D2 STATED THAT V1 WAS TRAVELING SB ON COLLEGE AVE APPROACHING 3RD ST IN THE LEFT LANE WHICH IS A LEFT TURN ONLY LANE. D2 STATED THAT HE DID NOT KNOW IF A COLLISION OCCURRED AT THAT TIME. D2 STATED THAT, AT THE INTERSECTION OF WALNUT AND GRIMES, D1 YELLED AT HIM AND TOLD HIM THAT HE HAD HIT HER VEHICLE. No other officers assisted.Prior to the accident V1 was traveling south on Jordan Avenue approaching University Avenue. Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: On 01/28/2019, at 0845 hours, I was dispatched to the intersection of East 17th Street and North Indiana Avenue regarding a car that had struck and injured a pedestrian and left the scene. I arrived and met with pedestrian Craig Schildmeier, who advised that he had been walking eastbound on the sidewalk on the south side of East 17th Street, approaching the intersection with North Indiana Avenue. He said when he was about halfway through the crosswalk, a red compact car, which was driving northbound on North Indiana Avenue, rolled through the stop sign without stopping while turning left onto East 17th Street. Schildmeier reported that as the vehicle drove through the crosswalk, he attempted to avoid being struck, but the driver side mirror of that vehicle struck his backpack. He stated that impact with the mirror damaged the driver side mirror, spun his body counterclockwise and his left rear heel was then run over by the rear driver side wheel of the vehicle. Schildmeier fell to the ground as a result, but he observed that the license plate read "693YUE". He could not tell me what state the license plate was from, but he did note that the vehicle was a "Zipcar" rental car. Schildmeier advised that the vehicle was driven by a white female around 20 or 21 years of age with brown hair and glasses. After striking Schildmeier, he reported the vehicle drove west on East 17th Street and then turned north (right) on North Dunn. Schildmeier advised that he lost sight of the vehicle as it approached the area of North Dunn and East Varsity Lane. Schildmeier reported that he believed his left foot to be bruised, but he refused an ambulance and had a friend pick him up from the scene. I put out a description of the vehicle to dispatch and advised them to also provide that information to Bloomington Police Department. I then checked the area for vehicle, but was unable to locate it. I requested that dispatch contact Zipcar to attempt to gather further information. I was advised that the information would be passed to their security team, who would then contact IUPD. Jennifer Navarro, the driver of the Honda, called IUPD after being contacted by Zipcar. I spoke with her briefly by phone, then went to the Zipcar parking location near the intersection of East 7th Street and South Woodlawn, where I examined the Honda. The driver side mirror on the vehicle was intact, however it was of a break-away design that can fold towards the body of the vehicle then spring back into place. There were some very light scuffs on the driver side mirror that I attempted to photograph, along with a less than half inch abrasion on the inside of the driver side mirror that appeared to have been made by the mirror collapsing after an impact. The gas cap cover also appeared to be misaligned, but when questioned, Navarro said that damage was there prior to her renting the vehicle. When I interviewed Navarro at her residence, she confirmed that she was driving the Honda on North Indiana at East 17th Street around 0837 hours. She stated that as she came up to the intersection, she heard and felt a "bump" on the driver's side, but did not see anyone or any vehicles when she looked around. Navarro stated that she stopped at the stop sign, looked both ways and continued, turning left on East 17th Street as she assumed she had hit a bump in the road. Navarro was adamant that she did realize that she had struck a pedestrian and insisted that she would have stopped had she known. She advised that she would be happy to pay any medical expenses that Schildmeier might have as a result of the crash. When I called Schildmeier back to advise him of the results of the investigation, he informed me that he had just learned that his ankle was fractured as a result of the crash. I advised him that I would update the crash report accordingly.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: D1 was headed W/B out of the parking lot of 3477 W 3rd St., approaching S Liberty Dr. D2 was headed S/B on S Liberty Dr., passing 3477 W 3rd St. D1 then proceeded W/B across S Liberty Dr., in an attempt to get to 500 S Liberty Dr, Kroger. As D1 crossed S Liberty Dr, V2 struck V1 in the front passenger side with it's front driver side, causing a collision. Both vehicle drove to a nearby parking lot to report the accident. V1 was towed from the scene by private tow due to disabling damage. V2 was driven from the scene by owner. No injuries were reported by either driver or the 3 passengers in V1 at this time. D1 stated he was headed W/B out of the parking lot of 3477 W 3rd St., approaching S Liberty Dr.D1 stated he stopped at the intersection of S Liberty Dr to check for cross traffic. D1 stated that he believed the roadway to be clear so he proceeded W/B across S Liberty Dr in an attempt to get to 500 S Liberty Dr, Kroger. D1 stated that as he crossed the S/B lane he was struck by V2 in the front passenger side. D1 stated that he did not see V2 until the last second. D1 also made the statement that the accident was his fault while I was on scene. D2 was headed S/B on S Liberty Dr., passing 3477 W 3rd St. D2 stated that as he passed the entrance to the parking lot of 3477 W 3rd St, V1 pulled directly out in front of him, causing V2 to strike V1 in the front passenger side with V2's front driver side. D2 stated that he did not see V1 until the last second, and hit his brakes in an attempt to avoid V1, however he was unable.

V1 was east bound on Maxwell as it approached the dead end. V1 failed to come to a stop at the clearly marked sign. V1 continued east through a wooded area at a high rate a speed striking three trees before coming to a stop. D1 was found trapped inside V1. Officer conducted a OWI investigation and the results are pending at this time.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: V1 was stopped in the parking lot of Chase Bank. V2 was traveling E/B on 3rd ST. V1 pulled out into the road way striking V2. D1 advised that she was stopped in the parking lot facing N/B attempting to turn W/B on 3rd ST. D1 advised that she saw a white vehicle traveling E/B on 3rd ST but stated that she believed that the vehicle was turning S/B into the parking lot. D1 advised that she was not exactly sure and could not recall what she saw. D1 advised that she pulled out into traffic to turn W/B on 3rd ST before she felt the impact of V2. D1 was not injured. D2 advised that she was traveling E/B on 3rd ST. D2 advised that while traveling E/B V1 turned out into the road in front of her V2. D2 advised that she then felt the impact of V1 before she lost control of V2 and collided with pavement bricks located on private property (2613 E 3rd ST). It should be noted that the pavement bricks shifted slightly due to the impact of V2 but was not damaged. D2 advised that she had a complaint of pain of 5 out of 10 to her abdomen. Due to D1 failure to yield right of way, V1 struck V2 causing damage to the vehicle.

V1 was driving east on 11th St approaching Fee Ln. V2 was also driving east 11th St approaching Fee Ln.D1 stated she was driving east on 11th St and noticed that V2 was slowing down. D1 stated she attempted to brake but did not react quick enough and collided with V2's rear bumper.D2 stated he was driving east on 11th St towards Fee Ln. D2 stated that he was beginning to brake due to the stop sign at 11th and Fee. D2 stated that when he started to slow down V1 collided with his rear bumper.

V1 was heading West on 17th Street from the Woodlawn Avenue intersection.D1 stated that she turned right on to 17th Street from Woodlawn Avenue and proceeded to hit the curb on the North side of the road. D1 continued saying that she panicked and accelerated and over corrected her steering and ended up hitting the curb on the South side of the road. D1 went on to say that she continued to panic and accelerated and her vehicle spun 360 degrees. After D1 spun V1s drivers side rear tire went up over the North curb where V1 came to a final resting state off the roadway. The rear drivers side tire had broken off V1.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: THIS OCCURRED IN THE CITY OF BLOOMINGTON, COUNTY OF MONROE, STATE OF INDIANA.V1 WAS DRIVING EB ON W 14TH ST. V2 WAS DRIVING NB ON N WALNUT ST. V1 CAME ACROSS THE INTERSECTION EB TOWARDS E 14TH ST. V2 COLLIDED WITH V1 IN THE INTERSECTION. V1 COLLIDED WITH A STOP SIGN AS A RESULT OF THE COLLISION.D1 SAID HE WAS DRIVING EB ON W 14TH ST. Driver of V1 stated he was southbound on I-69 near the Monroe/Morgan county line. Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: Other Explain in Narrative (type of crash): slide off, V1 slid off the roadway into a parked car on the shoulder due to unsafe speed and icy roadway conditions. Damage done to the rear of both vehicles.V1 was traveling northeast on Lingelbach Lane towards the Evermann Apartments Parking Lot. D1 stated that he then applied his brakes to slow down and slid on ice causing V1 to strike V2. D1 stated that V2 was parked in a marked parking stall and was unoccupied at the time of the crash. V2 was parked and unoccupied at the time of the incident.There were no injuries at the scene and no vehicles had to be towed.

D2 WAS STOPPED IN TRAFFIC IN FRONT OF 121 EAST 17TH STREET, FACING WEST ON EAST 17TH STREET.D2 STATED THAT THERE WAS A LONG LINE OF CARS STOPPED EAST OF THE INTERSECTION OF NORTH WALNUT STREET AND EAST 17TH STREET.D2 STATED THAT AS SHE WAS STOPPED THAT THE FRONT OF V1 DID MAKE CONTACT WITH THE REAR OF V2, RESULTING IN DAMAGE TO THE FRONT OF V1 AND TO THE REAR OF V2.D1 STATED THAT HE WAS DRIVING WEST ON EAST 17TH STREET.D1 STATED THAT HE LOOKED DOWN AND THEN LOOKED BACK UP BUT HE WAS UNABLE TO STOP V1 BY PRESSING ON THE BRAKES.D1 STATED THAT DUE TO THE SLICK CONDITIONS AND THE SNOW ON THE ROAD THAT V1 DID SLIDE AND DID MAKE CONTACT WITH THE REAR OF V2, RESULTIING IN DAMGE TO THE REAR OF V2 AND THE THE FRONT OF V1.NEITHER VEHICLE SUSTAINED DISABLING DAMAGE.

V2 was driving North on N Kinser Pike and V1 was approaching N Kinser from Vaughn Knapp drive. As V1 was approaching the T intersection they attempted to stop but due to the snow covering the road and the steepness of the hill started sliding and entered N Kinser Pike's north lane of travel.
