D1 said that they honked their horn to warn V2 that they could not stop in time but inevitably collided.D2 stated that they were driving north on Kinser and they observed V1 unable to stop entering the roadway. D2 said that they attemtped to steer away from V1 but did not have traction due to the snow on the surface of the road.

V2 was parked in the Campus View Apartments parking lot on 1/28/19 at approximately 2000hrs and complainant, Jennifer Nguyen, stated she returned to V2 at approximately 1655hrs and found it had been damaged.Damage to V2 consisted of a dent in the rear driver's side bumper. Damage is consistent with a low speed impact from another vehicle bumper. V2 was parked facing in a southeast direction. No noticeable paint transfer was noticed on V2.There are no cameras in the lot and no witnesses to the damage have come forward.

Vehicle 2 (Jeep Patriot) was on East 10th Street at North Dunn Street facing westbound. Vehicle 2 was stopped in traffic about to make a south bound turn onto North Dunn Street. Vehicle 2 was rear ended by vehicle 1 (Nissan Rogue).Vehicle 1 was traveling west bound on East 10th Street approaching North Dunn Street. Vehicle 1 rear ended vehicle 2 which was stopped in traffic.

V1 AND V2 WERE STOPPED AT A STOPLIGHT, AT THE INTERSECTION OF EAST 3RD STREET AND SOUTH WALNUT STREET, HEADING NORTH ON SOUTH WALNUT ST. V1 WAS STOPPED BEHIND V2, IN THE EAST MOST LANE OF SOUTH WALNUT STREET. WHEN THE LIGHT TURNED GREEN V1 AND V2 PROCEEDED NORTH. AT THE LIGHT V2 BEGIN TO MAKE A RIGHT TURN ON TO EAST 3RD STREET. AS V2 MADE A RIGHT TURN A PEDESTRIAN WAS IN THE WALKWAY, GOING NORTH ACROSS 3RD STREET, CAUSING V2 TO STOP. V1 WAS UNABLE TO STOP IN TIME AND TRIED TO SWERVE INTO THE LEFT LANE TO AVOID A COLLISION. THE FRONT PASSENGER SIDE OF V1 THEN MADE CONTACT TO THE REAR DRIVER'S SIDE CORNER OF V2, RESULTING IN DAMAGE TO BOTH VEHICLES.NEITHER V1 OR V2 HAD SUSTAINED DISABLING DAMAGE.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: V1 TURNED LEFT FROM DAYS IN DRIVE ON TO W STATE ROAD 45/46 BYPASS AND STRUCK V2 WHICH WAS TRAVELING EAST ON STATE ROAD 45/46.D1 STATED THAT V2 WAS DRIVING FASTER THAN THEY REALIZED.D2 STATED THAT HE WAS TRAVELING EAST IN THE LEFT LANE WHEN V1 CUT ACROSS AND STRUCK HIS VEHICLE.

V1 WAS EAST BOUND ON THE SR 45 / 46 BYPASS, IN THE LEFT TURN LANE. D1 SAID HE WAS TRYING TO MAKE A U TURN TO GO BACK WEST BOUND ON THE BYPASS, DUE TO THE OTHER CRASH EAST OF THE INTERSECTION. D1 SAID HE WAITED UNTIL HE GOT A GREEN ARROW, THEN STARTED HIS U TURN, AND CRASHED INTO V2.V2 WAS SOUTH BOUND ON COLLEGE AVE, IN THE RIGHT LANE. D2 SAID SHE HAD THE GREEN RIGHT TURN ARROW, AND STARTED TO TURN RIGHT. AS SHE DID SO, SHE CRASHED INTO V1, WHICH WAS MAKING A U TURN. BOTH DRIVERS HAD GREEN TURN ARROWS AT THE TIME OF THE CRASH. THERE WERE NO REPORTED INJURIES.

V1 was EB on Patterson drive and was approaching Rogers street. V2 was in front of V1 and was stopped in traffic. V1 failed to get stopped and struck V2 in the rear causing minor damage to both vehicles.D1 stated that she saw V2 stopped but just didn't get stopped in time.D2 stated she was stopped in traffic and was hit from behind by V1.
D1 stated she was backing out of the driveway and did not see V2 parked in the street prior to colliding with it.

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: I69 is a 4-lane (two-way) roadway that is primarily divided by a grass median. At the location of the 106.5 mile marker there is a metal guard rail on the middle portion of the roadway going into a concrete traffic barrier for a bridge. This area also has a downward grade with a curve towards the right hand side.Vehicle 1 (1999, Gold Ford F150) was northbound on I69 approaching the 106.5mm when it lost traction with the roadway. V1 then began to slide from the driving lane into the passing lane. V1 continued to slide out of control until it struck the concrete traffic barrier on the inside portion of the interstate. V1 then bounced from the inside concrete traffic barrier to the outer concrete traffic barrier where it again struck the concrete wall. V1 then bounced off the concrete barrier again and continued in a northwestern direction into the grass median where it finally came to an uncontrolled stop.Driver 1 (dawn Tipton) indicated the following: She was traveling northbound on I69 and all she remembers is hitting a wall, and then hitting another wall and then she hit a guard rail and her truck stopped.It is the opinion of the investigation officer that the primary cause of this crash is speed to fast for weather conditions and as such, D1 is at fault. RRK

V1 and V2 were traveling southbound on Walnut Street. V1 struck V2 in the rear as V2 was slowing for traffic.D1 stated that he was traveling southbound on Walnut St and saw that V2 was slowing. He attempted to stop and thought he could, however he ended up striking V2 in the rear.D2 stated that she was traveling southbound on Walnut St. She had slowed for traffic in front of her and as she did, she was struck from behind by V1.V1 did strike V2 in the rear causing damage to both vehicles.

THIS OCCURRED IN A PRIVATE PARKING LOT, IN THE CITY OF BLOOMINGTON, COUNTY OF MONROE, STATE OF INDIANA.V1 AND V2 WERE IN THE PRIVATE PARKING LOT OF KROGER 520 S LIBERTY DR. V2 BEGAN BACKING OUT OF A PARKING SPOT. V1 BEGAN BACKING UP AND COLLIDED WITH V2.D1 SAID SHE WAS FACING SOUTH IN THE PARKING LOT. SHE SAID SHE SAW AN OPEN SPOT AND DECIDED TO REVERSE SO SHE COULD TAKE THE PARKING SPOT. D1 REVERSED NORTHBOUND AND COLLIDED WITH V2. D1 ADMITTED FAULT FOR THE ACCIDENT.D2 WAS FACING SOUTHWEST. D1 SAID HE WAS BACKING OUT OF A PARKING SPOT. D2 REVERSED NORTHEAST AND WAS MOSTLY OUT OF THE SPOT WHEN V1 COLLIDED WITH HIS VEHICLE.D1 WAS IDENTIFIED BY HER VALID OHIO DRIVERS LICENSE.D2 WAS IDENTIFIED BY HIS VALID INDIANA DRIVERS LICENSE.BOTH DRIVERS ADMITTED TO DRIVING THEIR RESPECTIVE VEHICLES.CASE CLOSED.

V1 and V2 were east bound on SR 46 W at Arlington Road, when V1 was following V2 too closely. Due to the winter weather and snow on the road way V1 rear ended V2 who was stopped or slowed for traffic at the traffic turn light.No injuries at the scene, neither required a tow. V2 stated no damage on scene, V1 had minor damage to front bumper.

D1 STATED SHE WAS DRIVING NORTH ON N. STATE ROAD 69 GOING AROUND 50MPH DUE TO IT SNOWING. V1 WAS APPROACHING SAMPLE RD WHEN V1 STARTED TO SPIN OUT AND STRUCK A METAL GUARD RAIL. V1 STRUCK THE GUARDRAIL WITH ITS FRONT BUMPER.

V1 WAS TRAVELING WB ON W STATE ROAD 45 APPROACHING THE INTERSECTION OF S LEONARD SPRINGS ROAD. V2 WAS STOPPED IN TRAFFIC IN THE CENTER STRAIGHT LANE TO CONTINUE WB ON W STATE ROAD 45. AS V1 ATTEMPTED TO ENTER THE LEFT HAND TURN LANE AND OVERTAKE V2 TO TURN SB ON S LEONARD SPRINGS ROAD, THE PASSENGER'S SIDE VIEW MIRROR COLLIDED WITH THE DRIVER'S SIDE REAR AND FRONT QUARTER PANELS OF HER V2. V1 CONTINUED TO TURN SB ON S LEONARD SPRINGS ROAD WHERE D2 CONTINUED TO FOLLOW AS THE DRIVER OF V1 FAILED TO STOP. D2 EVENTUALLY LOST SIGHT OF THE SUSPECT VEHICLE ON W FULLERTON PIKE.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: DRIVER OF VEHICLE 2 STATED SHE WAS EXITING THE PARKING LOT OF MCDONALDS AT 1919 S WALNUT ST. AS SHE PROCEEDED DOWN THE EXIT, V2 BEGAN TO SLIDE ON THE ICE THAT WAS PRESENT AT THE EXIT. V2 SLID TO THE EDGE OF ROADWAY AT WALNUT ST. AS V1 WAS TRAVELLING NORTH BOUND ON WALNUT STREET IN THE RIGHT LANE, IT STRUCK THE FRONT END OF VEHICLE 2. V1 DID NOT STOP TO EXCHANGE INFORMATION.THERE IS NO INDICATION THAT V1 EXITED THE ROADWAY PRIOR TO STRIKING V2.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: D2 WAS DRIVING NORTH ON SOUTH PATTERSON.D1 CAME TO THE STOP SIGN ON ISAAC DRIVE FACING EAST TOWARDS SOUTH PATTERSOND1 PULLED OUT INTO TRAFFIC ONTO SOUTH PATTERSON AND STRUCK D2 IN THE DRIVERS SIDE FRONT BUMPERD1 STATED HE WAS UNABLE TO SEE V2 BECAUSE THE PASSENGER SIDE OF HIS VEHICLE OBSTRUCTED HIS VIEWD2 STATED HE WAS DRIVING NORTH ON SOUTH PATTERSON WHEN V1 PULLED INTO HIS LANE OF TRAVELSUPPLEMENT 2/2/2019, CORRECTED D1 INSURANCE POLICY NUMBER AND ADDRESS

BOTH VEHICLES WERE EAST BOUND ON THE SR 45 / 46 BYPASS, AT THE INTERSECTION WITH KINSER PIKE, IN THE RIGHT TURN LANE.D1 SAID SHE TRIED BRAKING, BUT SLID INTO V2.D2 SAID V2 WAS STOPPED WHEN IT WAS REAR ENDED BY V1.NO INJURIES REPORTED.

Fullerton Pike is a two lane asphalt county road. It was recently improved with new asphalt resulting in a small ledge separating the road from the shoulder. V1, Pontiac Vibe, was traveling east on Fullerton Pike near Sims Lane. V1 traveled off the south side of the roadway and began to slide in a clockwise direction. V1 struck several small saplings before coming to final rest with the driver's door resting against a tree trunk.D1, Devine, stated he was traveling east on Fullerton Pike. D1 stated he was distracted with the use of his cellular telephone and traveled off the right side of the road. D1 stated he began to spin and struck several trees. Evidence shows tire marks leading from the eastbound lane to the wooded area along the south side of the roadway. Evidence shows damage to the front bumper cover, driver's door and left rear portion of rear bumper cover. D1 was transported to Monroe Hospital where he submitted to a blood draw. The toxicology results are pending upon analysis by the State of Indiana Department of Toxicology, Incident 19ISPC001122.On May 11, 2019, I received the Toxicology Report from Indiana State Department of Toxicology. The report indicated Devine had a Blood Alcohol Content of 0.098 g/100mL. A copy of this report will be forwarded to Monroe County Prosecutor's Office for a decision on charges.

Manner of Collision: HEAD ON BETWEEN TWO MOTOR VEHICLES
NARRATIVE: Driver 1 stated she was making a right hand turn from S Clarizz Blvd to E Covenanter Drive. Driver 1 stated after she made the turn she hit a slippery spot and lost control of her vehicle causing her to cross the center line into on coming traffic. Driver 1 stated she struck vehicle 2 head on in the east bound lanes of E Covenanter Drive.Driver 2 stated she was traveling east on E Covenanter Drive approaching S Clarizz Blvd. Driver 2 stated vehicle 1 came into her lane and that it happened so fast she struck vehicle 1 head on.

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: VEHICLE 1 (BLUE CHEVROLET) WAS DRIVING EAST BOUND ON WEST STATE ROAD 45 46 BYPASS. VEHICLE 1 RAN OFF THE RIGHT SIDE OF THE ROAD AND HIT THE ARLINGTON ROAD OVERPASS WALL. DRIVER 1 TOLD ME THEY HIT A PATCH OF ICE. VEHICLE 1 HAD DAMAGE ON THE FRONT LEFT AND REAR LEFT OF THE CAR. VEHICLE 1 WAS NOT DRIVABLE AND WAS TOWED BY KEN'S WESTIDE TOWING (812) 336-9050 TO RICK'S TOWING LOT (812) 876-7108.

Driver one said that she was traveling northwest on E Monroe Dam Rd when 2 deer ran into the roadway. Driver one said that he collided with one of the deer causing damage to the front passenger side of Unit one. Driver one then moved Unit one to a safe location and called in the accident.I went to the location of the accident and observed a injured deer on the side of the roadway. I put the deer down.
V2 WAS STOPPED, FACING SOUTH, ON E SR 45 DUE TO UTILITY WORK WHEN V1, TRAVELING SOUTH, REAR ENDED V2. D2 HAD A GENERAL COMPLAINT OF PAIN AND D1 HAD A SMALL SCRATCH ON HIS LEFT HAND.

Vehicle 1 was traveling west on 3rd Street approaching Swain Avenue in the north lane. Vehicle 2 was traveling west on 3rd Street approaching Swain Avenue in the south lane. Driver 1 stated she forgot the road was a one way road and attempted to turn south onto Swain Avenue from the north lane of 3rd Street without her turn signal. She stated at that point she struck the front passenger side of Vehicle 2 with the rear driver side of her vehicle. Driver 2 stated he was traveling west when Vehicle 1 began turning left in front of him without warning. He advised Driver 1 struck the passenger front side of his vehicle with the rear driver side of Vehicle 1.No one involved complained of pain.There was damage to the rear driver side fender of Vehicle 1 and there was minor damage to the front passenger bumper and fender of Vehicle 2.

D2 was traveling westbound in the parking lot of the gas station when V1 backed into V2. V1 stated that he was attempting to back into a parking spot and didn't see V2. V1 collided with the passenger side of V2.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: V1 was traveling eastbound through a parking lot at 223 S Pete Ellis Dr. V2 was traveling southbound through the parking lot. V1 pulled out in front of V2.D1 was traveling through the parking lot, cutting across lanes of travel. D1 pulled out in front of V2, which was southbound in a lane of travel.D2 stated that she was unable to avoid V1 as he had cut across parking stalls traveling through the parking lot.V1 did fail to yield to V2 causing damage to both vehicles.

D1/V1 WAS IN PARKING STALL IN FRONT OF THE BUILDING. D1 HAD HIS FOOT ON THE BRAKE BUT IT SLIPPED ONTO THE GAS PEDAL DUE TO HAVING WIDE AND WET BOOTS. V1 STRUCK EXTERIOR OF EAGLE FINANCE CAUSING DAMAGE TO THE INTERIOR WALL AND FRONT BUMPER OF V1.

SR48 is a multi-lane roadway that is locally named 3rd Street. The east and westbound lanes are separated by a raised concrete median in the area of this collision.V1, black Nissan, was traveling west on SR48 in the left turn lane approaching stopped traffic east of Curry Pike. V2, green Subaru, was stopped in the left turn lane of SR48 westbound east of Curry Pike. V1 failed to stop behind V2 and struck the left rear corner of V2 with the front right corner of V1. V1 then traveled onto the raised concrete median divider with the front driver's side tire. D1, McGary, stated he was traveling west on SR48 in the left turn lane approaching Curry Pike. D1 stated he didn't realize V2 was stopped in the left turn lane ahead of his vehicle. D1 stated he applied his brakes and swerved to the left to attempt to avoid impact with the rear of V2. D1 stated he struck the left rear corner of V2 with the front right corner of V1. D2, Hero, stated she was stopped in the left turn lane of SR48 east of Curry Pike. D2 stated V1 struck the rear of V2 while she was stopped in the left turn lane. Evidence shows damage to the front right corner of V1. Evidence shows damage to the left rear corner of V2. D1 advised he did not have insurance for V1. D1 was cited for no insurance and V1 was parked in a private parking lot.

DRIVER OF VEHICLE 1 STATED SHE WAS SOUTH BOUND ON LEONARD SPRINGS ROAD APPROACHING W TAPP RD, BEHIN VEHICLE 2. D1 OBSERVED V2 BEGIN TO BRAKE TO TURN ONTO TAPP RD. D1 ATTEMPTED TO BRAKE, BUT WHEN SHE APPLIED THE BRAKES, V1 BEGAN TO SLID ON THE ROADWAY. V1 REAR ENDED V2. D1 ADVISED HER TIRES DO NOT HAVE GOOD TREAD AND THAT MAY HAVE CONTRIBUTED TO HER SLIDING. DRIVER OF VEHICLE 2 STATED HE WAS SOUTH BOUND ON LEONARD SPRINGS ROAD APPROACHING W TAPP RD. D1 ACTIVATED HIS LEFT TURN SIGNAL AND SLOWED DOWN TO TURN EAST ONTO TAPP RD. AS V2 STOPPED IN THE ROAD WAY TO WAIT ON APPROACHING TRAFFIC, V2 WAS REAR ENDED BY V1.

V1 AND V2 RESPONDED TO AN AMBULANCE CALL AT A TRAILER PARK AT 1700 S CURRY PK. V2 ARRIVED FIRST AND WAS PARKED ON THE PRIVATE DRIVE OF 1700 S CURRY PK. WHEN V1 ARRIVED D1 ATTEMPTED TO PARK BUT DUE TO THE SMALL SIZE OF THE DRIVE, AND THE AMOUNT OF VEHICLES IN THE AREA, V1 SIDE SWIPED V2 AS V1 WAS GOING OVER A SPEED BUMP. BOTH V1 AND V2 HAD MINOR DAMAGE TO THE REAR PASSENGER SIDE OF BOTH VEHICLES.BOTH V1 AND V2 LEFT THE SCENE AFTER THE CALL FOR SERVICE AND I MET WITH ALL OF THE PARTIES INVOLVED AT THE VAN BUREN FIRE DEPARTMENT ON KIRBY ROAD.

Manner of Collision: HEAD ON BETWEEN TWO MOTOR VEHICLES
NARRATIVE: Spoke to D1 and he stated V1 was traveling east on W SR 45 in the area of 8778 W SR 45. D1 stated that there was crash to the east of his location and the traffic was stopping in front of him. D1 stated when he applied the brake V1 slid on the ice and could not stop. D1 stated at the last second he swerved left to miss the vehicle in front of him. He stated V1 then slid across the center line and struck V2 head on. Both vehicles the came to rest on the north side of the roadway with both facing north west. I spoke to a witness, James M Richardson, who stated he was a few cars behind V1 traveling east. James stated he saw V1 start to fish tail and proceed across the center line and strike V2 head on. James then stated he pulled off the south side of the roadway to approach the scene and make sure everyone was ok. I spoke with D2 who stated V2 was traveling west on W SR 45 in the area of 8778 when V1 came across the center line and into the path of V2. D2 stated that V1 struck the front of V2 head on with the front of V1 spinning both vehicles off the north side of the roadway. I did observe the roadway was icy and slick and there were also two other accidents in the area due to the weather conditions. I also observed it was snowing lightly. I also observed both vehicles and observed heavy front end damage consistent with a head on collision. I also observed both sets of air bags were deployed.D1 was transported from the scene due to his injuries. D1 complained of pain in his back, wrist and chest. I spoke to D2 about his injuries. D2 stated he had a slight pain on the top of his head and minor pain in his legs and knees. D2 refused transport for his injuries and was treated and released on scene. Both vehicles were towed due to disabling damage.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: Prior to the impact, V1 was was attempting to turn left into the driveway of 1410 N Jordan. V2 was traveling southbound on Jordan Ave approaching the driveway of 1410 N Jordan. W1 stated he was pulling out of the driveway for 1412 N Jordan. At the point of impact, V1 was facing south east on Jordan Ave, approximately 30 feet north of 17th St . V2 was facing south on on Jordan Ave approximately 30 feet. W1 was approximately 20 feet behind V2.D1 stated she was traveling southbound on Jordan Ave attempting to make a left hand turn into the driveway of 1410 N Jordan. D1 stated she was not on the right hand side of the road, however she believes she did move to the right a little to before she made her left turn. D1 stated V2 attempted to pass her on the left as she was turning and hit the front driver side fender of her vehicle. D2 stated he was traveling south bound on Jordan Ave approaching the driveway of 1410 N Jordan. D2 stated he noticed V1 with its break lights and left turn signal on pulled off to the right side of the road at a complete stop. D2 stated he continued southbound when V1 attempted to turn left, across both lanes, from the right hand side of the road. D2 stated he attempted to break and avoid the vehicle, but could not stop in time. W1 stated he was pulling out of the driveway for 1412 N Jordan. W1 stated he could clearly see V1's break lights on and at a complete stop on the right hand side of the road. W1 stated as V2 approached, V1 turned left in front of V2. Both vehicles sustained minor damage and were drivable. There were no injuries at the scene.

D1 AND V1 LEFT SCENE.D2 WAS PARKED IN THE PARKING LOT OF 1925 E ATWATER AVE. D2 STATED HE WENT TO GET INTO HIS TRUNK AT 2PM AND NOTICED HIS VEHICLE TRUNK WAS DAMAGED AND APPEARED TO BE HIT BY ANOTHER VEHICLE.CRIMINAL CASE COMPLETED.

D1 AND V1 LEFT SCENE. D2 WAS PARKED OUTSIDE HER APARTMENT. D2 WAS LEAVING HER APARTMENT AND RECOGNIZED NEW DAMAGE TO THE BACK DRIVER SIDE BUMPER OF HER VEHICLE. D2 SAID NO OTHER VEHICLES WERE NEXT TO HER WHEN SHE PARKEDCRIMINAL CASE COMPLETED.

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: Primary Cause-Driver Factor-Speed Too Fast For Weather Conditions: The conditions were that the roadway surface was ice covered. D1 was traveling too fast given the slick roadway surface and should have reduced her speed to avoid losing control of V1 and colliding into the guardrail. Contributory Cause-Roadway Surface Conditions: The roadway was ice covered in the area of the crash. I69 is a highway that runs in a northern and southern direction through Monroe County. The crash occurred 150 feet south of the 105.0MM. In the area of the crash the roadway in straight with an uphill/grade. The roadway surface was ice covered in the area of the crash.V1 (2004 silver Jeep Liberty) was traveling southbound on I69 in the right lane. V1 slide out of control at a 45 degree angle, clockwise. V1 then traveled of the roadway and struck the guardrail with the right front fender area, on the west side of I69.D1 (Sydnee Luallen) stated she was traveling southbound on I69 in the right lane. Her vehicle slid out of control on the ice and she traveled off the roadway striking the guardrail. She was wearing her seat belt.During the course of my investigation, I observed damage to the front passenger side bumper and fender area of V1. I also observed, minor damage to the guardrail and a damage tag was placed on the guardrail.The crash investigation showed that the primary cause of the crash is Speed Too Fast For Weather Conditions on the part of D1.This was determined by damage sustained to the vehicle and driver statement.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: Driver of vehicle 2 was traveling west on Third St. Vehicle 1 was traveling east on Third Street. At the intersection of Third Street and Franklin Road Vehicle 1 was attempting to turn north onto Franklin Road. Vehicle 2 was attempting to continue west through the intersection. Driver of vehicle 2 stated that he had a green light. Driver of vehicle 1 stated he had a flashing yellow arrow. Driver of vehicle 1 stated that he did not see vehicle 2 as he proceeded through the intersection and failed to yield right of way.

Driver 1 stated that while traveling North on SR 37 just north of Zikes Rd, She was cut off by another driver. Driver 1 stated she hit the brakes to avoid the vehicle in front of her and began sliding off of the roadway. Driver 1 stated that she slid off the road on the East side of the highway and struck a tree. A male, who was driving by and saw the vehicle off the road, checked to see if the driver was OK. He then assisted the driver by driving Unit 1 back onto the shoulder of the roadway. The male stated that he works on vehicles often and that the front right axle was damaged, and recommended that is should not be driven.

D1 advised she was driving V1 west bound in the right lane of Third Street. D1 advised she turned her blinker on and started to merge into the left lane. D1 advised when V1 merged into the right lane V1 and V2 crashed into each other. D2 advised she was driving V2 west bound in the left lane of Third Street. D2 advised while driving straight, V1 started merging from the right lane into the left lane. D2 advised when V1 merged into the left lane V1 crashed into V2. D2 advised V1 did not have its blinker on when the crash occurred.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: V2 WAS NORTH BOUND ON KINSER PIKE, AT GOURLEY PIKE. D2 SAID V1 TURNED RIGHT FROM GOURLEY IN FRONT OF HER.D1 SAID V1 WAS ON GOURLEY PIKE, AND TURNING RIGHT ONTO KINSER PIKE. SHE SAID SHE LOOKED AND DID NOT SEE ANYONE COMING NORTH BOUND. PULLED OUT, AND THE VEHICLES STRUCK IN THE INTERSECTION.NO REPORTED INJURIES.

OWNER OF V2 LEFT HIS VEHICLE AT 1500 HOURS PARKED EB IN THE PARKING GARAGE AT 302 N WALNUT ON THE FIRST FLOOR. OWNER OF V2 RETURNED TO HIS VEHICLE AT 1800 HOURS TO FIND DAMAGE TO HIS REAR DRIVER SIDE TAILLIGHT. NO SUSPECTS. DAMAGE CAPTURED ON BWC 1613.

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: In the early morning hours of 02/01/2019, this area of Interstate 69 received approximately 1.5 inches of snow. The left lane of Interstate 69 was still partially snow covered and icy. Vehicle 1 (white 1994 Ford Explorer) was traveling south on Interstate 69, in the right lane, approaching the 112.5 mile marker.Vehicle 1 began to slide on ice and left the roadway to the north. Vehicle 1 hit a large rock embankment and rolled over twice before coming to a final rest upright. Driver 1 (Samantha Carpenter) stated she was traveling south, in the right lane, when her vehicle began to "fish-tail". Driver 1 stated she lost all control and her vehicle began to roll over. Driver 1 stated her vehicle rolled over at least twice. Driver 1 stated she was not wearing a seat belt.Driver 1 was issued a citation for speed too fast for conditions. Based upon evidence at the scene, I determine the primary cause of this crash to be speed too fast for conditions.

V2 and V3 were parked near the intersection, both were facing east. V2 was parked right behind V3.V1 was traveling eastbound on West 11th Street when D1 rear ended V2, which caused V2 to rear end V3 due to the speed of V1. D1 underwent field sobriety tests and was placed into custody by Officer Raybould. Officer Raybould served a search warrant for D1's blood and then D1 was remanded to the Monroe County Jail for Operating While Intoxicated, with endangerment, Class A Misdemeanor.V1 and V2 were towed due to disabling damage. D1 complained of pain to her knees but was checked out by an ambulance and was not transported for anymore medical attention.Photos were taken and logged into evidence.

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: D1 stated he was traveling north on S Rockport Road. D1 stated he went through a curve and his vehicles back end broke loose. D1 stated he tried to correct however began fish tailing. D1 ran off the road into the ditch.

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: State Road 37 is a divided highway with a grass median. In this area State Road 37 has four lanes, two lanes primarily going south and two lanes primarily going north. State Road 37 is mainly constructed of asphalt. On this day and time the road was covered with ice/snow. The road characteristics of the crash area is straight with a grade. Vehicle 1 (Maroon. 2007 Pontiac) was northbound in the right lane on SR 37 approximately 1800 feet south of Old SR 37 in Monroe County. Driver 1(Mallori Edwards) advised that she was slowing down for traffic and lost control of her vehicle on the ice covered roads. Vehicle 1 slid off of the road, began to turn counterclockwise and struck the large rock cut out on the east side of SR 37 with the rear bumper. The driver's side tires also appeared to be flat.

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: While traveling North on SR 37 just north of Dillman Rd, Unit 1 stated they merged into the right hand lane to yield right of way to an emergency vehicle. While merging, Unit 1 stated after applying the brakes and merging, unit 1 began to slide and slid into the back of unit 2. Both parties refused medical and refused a tow truck.

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: V1, red GMC, was traveling south on I69 in the left lane. V1 left the roadway and entered the grass median. V1 struck the earth median then moved to the southbound emergency shoulder. D1, Riggs, stated he was traveling south on I69 in the left lane. D1 stated he lost control of V1 due to the icy conditions and slid into the median. D1 stated he did not make contact with anything when he entered the median. D1 stated he then moved to the southbound emergency shoulder. Evidence shows the roadway was ice covered and slick during the accident investigation. Evidence shows damage to the rear tailgate and both rear taillight assemblies.

V1 was traveling southbound on South Rogers Road just north of Baywood Dr. V2 was traveling northbound on South Rogers Road just north of Baywood Dr. V1 began to slide due to ice and snow on the roadway and lost control of her veh. V1 crossed left of center and struck v2 in the front passenger side of the veh.

D1 STATED HE WAS TRAVELING SOUTH ON DUNN STREET IN THE EASTERN MOST LANE. HE INDICATED THAT HE FAILED TO STOP AT THE INTERSECTION OF 6TH ST, WHERE THERE IS A POSTED STOP SIGN. D1 SAID HE COLLIDED WITH V2 THAT WAS TRAVELING EAST ON 6TH STREET. D2 STATED HE WAS EAST BOUND ON 6TH STREET AND HAD STOPPED AT THE INTERSECTION OF DUNN ST. HE SAID HE PROCEEDED INTO THE INTERSECTION AND WAS STRUCK BY V1.

V1 was parked in parking space facing North. V2 was in lane of travel and was WB thru parking lot. V1 backed up and V2 struck V1 in the passenger side rear bumper with the front passenger side bumper of her vehicle. D1 stated he did not see anyone coming and was backing up. D2 stated that she was headed WB in parking lot and V1 backed up in front of her.

Heather Riggins drove V2 to 2424 S Walnut ST on 02/01/2019 around 11:00 AM to do some shopping and parked V2 facing westbound in the parking lot. Heather stated she was inside the store for about 30 minutes and when she returned to her car she was confronted by Barbara, who was a witness, stating that her vehicle was in an accident and the other driver left the scene. Barbara sent photos of V1 to Heather, in return, Heather sent me the photos as well. Heather stated she had damage to the right rear bumper.Heather showed me V2 at the Bloomington Police Department, and you can see paint transfer on her right rear bumper that appears to be a silver or brown in color. Heather also pointed out damage to the right front bumper but was not sure how that had occurred and wasn't sure if that was related. I took photos of the damage to V2.I then spoke to Barbara over the phone. Barbara stated that she was waiting on a friend to exit the store and was sitting in her parked vehicle. Barbara stated V1 was reversing and V1's right rear bumper struck V2's right rear bumper and then V1 pulled back into the spot they were reversing out of. Barbara thought D1 was doing that so they could report it. However, Barbara stated V1 then reversed the opposite way and left the scene and did not stop.From the photos that Barbara took, I was able to see a license plate for V1, which was TK507MDK. I entered that license plate and found a phone number for the owner. I called the phone number and D1 answered the phone. D1 was an elderly male and stated he did not know he hit anybody. D1 did stated he was at Lucky's "last week" but was not sure if it was on 02/01/2019. D1 stated nobody else drives his truck besides him. D1 had no issue giving me the necessary information to complete the accident report so I could provide a copy to both parties.All photos that were taken were logged into evidence. No criminal charges will be filed.

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: D1 stated he was traveling south on I69 in the right lane at an unknown speed. D1 thinks he hit a patch of ice and spun out of control. D1s rear end ran off the road into the guard rail. D1 moved his vehicle down the interstate to where Deputy was working a separate accident.

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: D1 stated he was driving south on I69 in the right lane at approximately 70 MPH. D1 suspects he hit a patch of ice. D1 stated his vehicle began to slide, spin, and ultimately ran off the roadway.

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: V1 WAS NORTHBOUND ON PATTESON DR GOING TOWARD ALLEN STREET.V2 WAS SOUTHBOUND ON PATTERSON DR FROM ALLEN ST.D1 SAID HE STARTED SLIDING ON THE SNOWY STREET. HE SAID HE DECIDED TO TURN INTO THE PARKING LOT OF CATALENT AT 1300 S PATTERSON ST. HE SAID AS HE TURNED LEFT INTO THE PARKING LOT HE COLLIDED WITH V2.D2 SAID AS HE DROVE SOUTH V1 TURNED IN FRONT OF HIM TO GO INTO CATALENT PARKING LOT AND THEY COLLIDED. HE SAID HE DOES NOT THINK V1 USED IT'S TURN SIGNAL.

V2 WAS TRAVELING WB ON 11TH ST STOPPED AT ADAMS ST. V1 WAS TRAVELING NB ON ADAMS ST APPROACHING 11TH ST. AS V2 PROCEEDED WB THROUGH THE INTERSECTION, V1 DISREGARDED THE STOP SIGN AND THE FRONT OF V1 COLLIDED WITH THE REAR DRIVER SIDE OF V2. D2 THEN LEFT THE SCENE.D1 STATED THAT SHE DID NOT REMEMBER HITTING ANY VANS AT 11TH AND ADAMS. D1 HAD A STRONG ODOR OF ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGE ON HER EXHALED BREATH AND HAD BLOODSHOT, WATERY EYES.D2 STATED THAT SHE WAS WB ON 11TH ST WHERE SHE STOPPED AT THE STOPSIGN AT ADAMS ST. D2 STATED SHE BEGAN TO PROCEED WB ON 11TH ST WHEN V1 DISREGARDED THE STOP SIGN AND LEFT THE SCENE EB ON 11TH ST BEFORE COLLIDING WITH ANOTHER VEHICLE ON 11TH ST. PLEASE REFER TO B19-04486 IN REFERENCE TO THAT OTHER ACCIDENT AND THE RESULTS OF THE OWI INVESTIGATION.THROUGH MY INVESTIGATION, I BELIEVE THAT D1 DISREGARDING A STOP SIGN AND CONSUMING ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES CAUSED THIS ACCIDENT.

D1 WAS TRAVELING EB ON ST RD 46 WHEN D1 LOST CONTROL ON A PATCH OF ICE.D1 DROVE IN THE CENTER MEDIAN TRYING TO REGAIN CONTROL WHEN THE VEHICLE STRUCK A FROZEN SNOW PILE.THE VEHICLE WENT OVER THE SNOW PILE COMING TO A STOP APPROXIMATELY 1000 FEET FROM THE SNOW PILE. THE PASSENGER STATED HE WAS SLEEPING WHEN THE ACCIDENT OCCURED. THE PASSENGER COMPLAINED OF LOWER BACK AND ARM PAIN. THE PASSENGER WAS TRANSPORTED TO IU HEALTH.

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: Interstate 69 is a multi-lane divided highway that primarily traverses Monroe County in a north and south manner. In the area of this crash there are guardrails on both shoulders of the southbound lanes of Interstate 69. This portion of Interstate 69 southbound has a down hill grade and is straight with no line of sight obstructions.The temperature was approximately 16 degrees Fahrenheit and snow had fallen over night. The shoulders were completely snow covered and a portion of the left lane had snow covering it as well. There were multiple portions of Interstate 69 that were extremely slick due to ice being present on the roadway. These conditions were not isolated to only this immediate area of the crash as other roadways in the area were experiencing the same factors.Vehicle 1, a white 2013 Dodge Charger, is a marked Indiana State Police commission. Vehicle 1 was parked partially on the left shoulder and partially in the left lane with its emergency lights activated near the 116.5mm of Interstate 69 southbound to warn approaching motorists of a road hazard in a blind curve of Interstate 69 near the 116mm. There were other Indiana State Police vehicles near the 116mm attempting to help a motorist who slid off the roadway and into the median due to the icy road conditions. Vehicle 1 was struck in the rear by the rear of Vehicle 2.Vehicle 2, a white 2002 Toyota Camry, was traveling southbound on Interstate 69 in the right lane approaching the 106.5mm. Near the 106.5 mm were two marked Indiana State Police commissions with their emergency lighting activated. One of these commissions is Vehicle 1 and the other is included in this report as Witness 1. Vehicle 2 began to slide on the ice covered roadway and rotated 180 degrees so that the front of Vehicle 2 was facing north as Vehicle 2 continued to slide southbound. Vehicle 2 narrowly missed the first Indiana State Police vehicle (Witness 1). Vehicle 2 slide southbound past the marked Indiana State Police vehicle of Witness 1 on the driver's side of Witness 1 with the front of Vehicle 2 facing north. The passenger side of Vehicle 2 then struck the guardrail face just off of the left shoulder of Interstate 69 southbound. Vehicle 2 continued sliding until the rear of Vehicle 2 struck the rear of Vehicle 1.Driver 1 stated he was stopped partially in the left lane and partially on the left shoulder of Interstate 69 southbound for approximately 10 minutes. Driver 1 said that he observed Witness 1 approaching from the rear with emergency lighting activated. Driver 1 moved Vehicle 1 more onto the left shoulder of Interstate 69 southbound so that Witness 1 could take more of the left lane. Driver 1 stated that as he was monitoring traffic approaching him, he observed Vehicle 2 sliding and spin behind Witness 1. Driver 1 said that he put Vehicle 1 in gear and attempted to move forward, but was unable to do so because of the ice covered roadway. Driver 1 had a complaint of pain in his neck area.Driver 2 stated he was traveling on Interstate 69 southbound in the right lane. Driver 2 said that he was going 70 mph with other traffic. Driver 2 stated that he saw the lights on the police vehicles and applied the brakes to Vehicle 2. Driver 2 said that Vehicle 2 began to slide and then spin. Driver 2 stated that Vehicle 2 struck a guardrail face and then the rear of Vehicle 2 struck the rear of Vehicle 1.Witness 1, Indiana State Police Trooper Jeremy Cox provided the following statement:I was traveling southbound on I69 in the left lane, at the 106.5MM. I was slowing down with my rear emergency lights activated. I was approaching another Indiana State Police commission with its emergency lights activated sitting stationary on the left shoulder of I69. The commission began to travel forward as I heard the sound of a vehicle sliding on the roadway. Through my rear view mirror, I observed a white vehicle sliding out of control, traveling southbound, and traveled behind my commission with the front

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: I-69, in the area where the crash occurred, is hilly with numerous curves. The roadway surface looked wet but had numerous icy areas. The outside temperature was 19 degrees.V1, a black 2015 Lexus RX3, was traveling south on I-69, near the 106 M.M., when V1 hit a patch of ice and lost traction. V1 skidded into the passing lane and then back to the driving lane two times before striking V2 in the left front fender/ headlamp area. Once contact was made with V2, V1 slid and struck the guard rail with the right front fender. V1 came to a controlled rest after striking the guard rail.V2, a black 2013 Ford Fusion, was also traveling south on I-69, when the vehicle directly in front of V2 began to swerve in to the passing lane. V2 slowed in an attempt to avoid a collision with V1 but when V1 swerved back into the driving lane, V2 hit V1 in the right rear bumper/fender area. After the contact, V1 slid and hit the guard rail with the right front bumper/ fender. V2 came to a controlled stop on the shoulder of the roadway.D1, Nova E Carden, stated that she was traveling south on I-69. D1 stated that she had seen emergency lights ahead of her so she attempted to slow down. D1 said when she tried to slow down, she hit a patch of ice, causing her to lose control of her vehicle. D1 stated that she tried to regain control of her vehicle but ended up hitting V2 with the rear of her vehicle. D1 said after the contact was made with V2, her vehicle struck the guard rail on the west side of the roadway. After striking the guard rail, D1 said she was able to get her vehicle stopped on the east side should of the road. D1 stated that her speed prior to the crash was 72 MPH.D2, Gregory S Wisniewski, stated that he was south bound on I-69, directly behind V1, when he noticed V1 lose control and swerve from lane to lane. D2 said he slowed down to avoid colliding with with V1 but V1 swerved over and struck the front of his vehicle. D2 stated that he was able to come to a controlled stop on the east side shoulder of the road after the collision with V1.Both drivers stated that they were uninjured in the crash and did not require any medical attention.Both vehicles were towed to Bloomington, IN, by Sturgis Wrecker, due to disabling damage.

DRIVER OF VEHICLE 1 STATED SHE WAS IN THE PARKING LOT OF 1450 W COUNTYSIDE LANE. AS SHE WAS PULLING FORWARD PREPARING TO BACK INTO A PARKING SPACE, HER FOOT SLIPPED OFF OF THE BRAKE. HER FOOT WENT TO THE ACCELERATOR CAUSING HER TO MOVE FORWARD AND STRIKE VEHICLE 2. VEHICLE 2 WAS PARKING IN A PARKING SPACE.

Driver 1 stated she was behind Driver 2 when they were both stopped at the stopped at the intersection of West Gordon Pike and entrance to Bachelor Middle School. Driver 1 stated Driver 2 and began proceeding eastbound and Driver 2 began to slow down like she was going to turn. Driver 1 stated she was unsure if Driver 2 had her turn signal on. Driver 1 stated she then rear ended Driver 2. Driver 1 did state that she was reaching for her sweatshirt however maintained visual of Driver 2 and her foot was still on the clutch. Driver 2 stated she turned her turn signal on and slowed down to turn southbound onto Clear View Drive when Driver 1 rear ended her. Both vehicles moved just down the roadway from the initial collision and both drivers were out of their vehicles upon arrival. Vehicle 1 appeared to sustain no damage and Vehicle 2 sustained minor right rear end damage on the bumper. Both drivers declined medical personnel and a tow service.

D1 stated he was driving past v2 in the parking lot when V2 backed out of the parking stall into the right rear of V1.D2 stated her vehicle was half-way out of the stall and there were no vehicles in her mirrors or backup camera. As she continued backing out, the collision occurred.

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: On 2/1/2019 at approximately 0800 hours I arrived at SR 46 just east of Hedrick Road in Monroe County. Upon arrival I observed a white SUV in a field to the south of SR 46.Driver 1 stated that as he was traveling east on SR 46 he lost control of his vehicle due to ice and slide off the roadway and into the field. Driver 1 stated that his vehicle spun around and made contact with the fence surrounding the field with the rear of his vehicle.The roadway surface condition was extremely slick due to freezing rain. This crash could have been avoided if the driver was traveling at a reduced rate. There was approximately 60 feet of fence that was damaged from the crash belonging to Webb Emogene Trust. No contact information could be obtained.

VEHICLE 1 WAS EAST BOUND ON WEST ST RD 45. VEHICLE 1 SLID ON ICE IN A CURVE AND RAN OFF THE ROAD.DRIVER 1 COMPLAINED OF CHEST PAIN AND WAS TRANSPORTED BY AMBULANCE TO IU HEALTH BLOOMINGTON.VEHICLE 1 WAS TOWED BY BLANDS TO BLANDS

V1 and V2 were traveling southbound on the SR 45/46 Bypass approaching the intersection of E 3rd St. V2 began to slow down due to traffic, and V1 collided with the rear of V2.D1 advised that he was traveling southbound on the SR 45/46 Bypass approaching the intersection of E 3rd St. behind V2. D1 advised that traffic began to slow, V2 slowed down and he attempted to stop but wasn't able to before colliding with the rear of V2. D2 advised that she was traveling southbound on the SR 45/46 Bypass approaching the intersection of E 3rd St. D2 advised that as she began to slow down with traffic, V1 rear ended her.V1 sustained minor dents and scratches to the front bumper and a broken grille.V2 sustained a minor scratch to the rear bumper cover.

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: Vehicle 1 (gold Chevy) was south bound on I 69 near the 112.5 mile marker in the right lane. Driver 1( Hannah Rosebrock) advised that she had her cruise on at approximately 75 and was coming up on slower traffic. D1 slowed down and changed lanes to the left lane. D1 then lost control of the vehicle, traveled off of the roadway and rolled over. V1 came to rest on the riprap on the west side of I-69 S/B.D1 was seen at the scene by EMS and refused any further medical treatment while at the scene.

V1 left the scene. V2 was parked on the East side of 17th Street with no one inside. V2 was parked on the side of the road while the passengers in V2 went in to the Convenient Mart for no more than 5 minutes. When they came out to get in V2 the drivers side mirror was broke and moved out of place. It appears that V1 was driving North on Dunn Street when it got too close to V2 striking the drivers side mirror with the passenger side of V1 causing the mirror to break.

ALEXIS EDGIN, WHO IS THE DAUGHTER OF THE OWNER OF V2, STATED THAT SHE HAD PARKED V2 IN THE PARKING LOT OF 2894 EAST 3RD STREET.ALEXIS STATED THAT V2 WAS PARKED FACING EAST, IN THE SOUTH EAST CORNER OF THE PARKING LOT.ALEXIS STATED THAT SHE HAD PARKED V2 THERE AT APPROXIMATELY 10:50 AM.ALEXIS STATED THAT AT 3:00 PM SHE DID RETURN TO HER VEHICLE AND DID FIND THAT THE FRONT DRIVER'S CORNER OF V2 HAD BEEN STRUCK BY ANOTHER VEHICLE, RESUTLING IN THE FRONT DRIVER'S SIDE HEADLIGHT BEING DAMAGED AND SHATTERED.THERE IS NO INFORMATION ON THE SUSPECT VEHICLE OR DRIVER.

VEHICLE 1 WAS FOLLOWING VEHICLE 2. A VEHICLE IN FRONT OF VEHICLE 2 STOPPED ABRUPTLY AND WHEN VEHICLE 2 STOPPED, VEHICLE 1 STRUCK VEHICLE 2 IN THE REAR-END.ALL INVOLVED WERE UNINJURED AND DENIED ANY MEDICAL ATTENTION.BOTH VEHICLES WERE DRIVABLE AND DROVE FROM SCENE.

Spoke to D1 and she advised that V1 was traveling east on W Sr 46 in the area of 8225 W SR 46. D1 stated a deer jumped ouit into the path of V1 and she could not avoid striking the deer. V1 struck the deer with the front of V1. D1 stated the deer flew into the air and fled south. I observed damage tot he front of V1 consistent with striking a deer. I also observed deer in the broken parts of the bumper. There were no injuries involved in this crash and V1 was drive able and 1 drove it form the scene.
D-1 stated he was traveling east on SR 46 when a deer ran out in front of V-1 striking the front left side of V-1.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: D1 stated he was travelling westbound on W. 3rd Street and merged into the center lane to make a left hand turn into the Kroger gas station lot. D1 stated that V2 was in the oncoming traffic lane travelling eastbound and appeared to be slowing down to allow D1 to make the turn. D1 stated he began to turn left and collided with the front driver side of V2.D2 stated he was travelling eastbound on W. 3rd Street approaching S. Liberty Drive and noticed V1 in the center turn lane. D2 stated V1 began turning in front of him and collided with the front of his vehicle causing D2 to run off the road. A passenger in V2 complained of pain in her abdomen area from a recent surgery, but was not transported for medical treatment. D1 failed to yield to oncoming traffic which did cause the collision between V1 and V2.

V1 and V2 were slowing or stopped at the red light at 10th Street and 45 Bypass facing West. V1 and V2 were in the right hand turn lane to turn northbound on 45 Bypass. D1 stated that he though V2 was starting to go to merge in to traffic and did not notice that she had slowed and did not turn. D1 stated that he rear ended V2. D2 stated that she was sitting at the red light waiting to turn right.There was minimal damage to both vehicles. There was a tire on the rear of V2 that took the most of the impact from V1.

V1 is white in color but otherwise unidentified in this hit-and-run crash. V2 was parked facing east on the west side of 611 N Fess Ave.OP1 came to IUPD to report that her vehicle had been hit. OP1 stated V2 was parked in the parking lot west of 611 N Fess from 01/29/2019 at approximately 1800 hours until 02/03/2019 at approximately 2000 hours. OP1 stated when she returned to her vehicle on 02/03/2019 she noticed a dent on the rear driver side quarter-panel with white paint transfer. OP1 stated she waited to report the accident until she contacted her insurance company.V2 had damage to the rear driver side quarter-panel. V2 did not have any white paint transfer when it was brought to IUPD to make this report.OP1 stated she did not witness the accident and does not have a description for V1.

Driver of vehicle 1 stated he attempted to go around vehicle 2 that was parked in front of Walmart, as he went around the driver side passenger door opened striking vehicle 1 leaving a large scrape from the passenger front fender to the rear passenger door. Driver of vehicle 2 stated she was parked in front of Walmart and her daughter exited the vehicle from the rear driver side passenger door and the door impacted vehicle 1 causing damage to the corner of the passenger door of vehicle 2

V1 was traveling east in the IU Fee Lane parking garage. V2 was parked facing south in the northeast parking spot which is the spot closest to where vehicles turn the corner to continue up or down in the garage. V3 was parked in the spot directly west of V2, facing north. As V1 was turning right (west) to continue up the parking garage, V1's passenger side struck V2 on the left front bumper. The force of V1 striking V2, caused V2 to be pushed into V3. V2's right front corner panel struck the right rear quarter panel of V3. D1 stated as she was turning the corner another vehicle was coming down and around the same corner. D1 stated she turned right to avoid the collison with the vehicle coming down the garage. D1 stated that's when V1 struck V2. D1 had heavy damage to both passenger side doors. V2 and V3 were unoccupied and parked in parking spots at the time of the accident. V2 had minor damage to the left front bumper and heavy damage to the right front quarter panel. V3 had minor damage to the right rear quarter panel. D1 stated she did not need medical attention.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: D1 STATED HE WAS TRAVELING SOUTH ON COLLEGE AVE IN THE CENTER LANE. D1 INDICATED THAT HE WAS DRIVING SLOW WITH HIS LEFT SIGNAL ON, LOOKING FOR THE ALLEY THAT LEADS TO THE BUSINESS WHERE HIS APOINTMENT WAS. D1 SAID HE SAW THE ALLEY AND BEGAN TO MERGE LEFT WHERE HE COLLIDED WITH V2. D1 INDICATED THAT D2 WAS EXCEEDING THE SPEED LIMIT AND FORCED HIS VEHICLE INTO THE LEFT LANE AS SOON AS THE LANE OPENED. D2 STATED HE WAS TRAVELING SOUTH ON COLLEGE AVE IN THE CENTER LANE BEHIND V1. HE INDICATED THAT V1 WAS DRIVING SLOW WITH HIS LEFT SIGNAL ON AND ADDED THAT IT WAS ON FOR A PERIOD OF TIME. D2 SAID HE MERGED INTO THE EASTERN MOST LANE AND AS HE WAS PASSING, V1 MERGED LEFT INTO THE SIDE OF HIS VEHICLE. D2 SAID HIS VEHICLE WAS THEN PUSHED LEFT INTO THE CURBING.

V1, V2, V3, and V4 were traveling eastbound on W 3rd Street approaching S Patterson Drive. V2, V3, and V4 began to slow down for the red light at S Patterson Drive. V4 was the closest to the intersection, with V3 behind it, V2 behind V3, and V1 behind V2. D1 stated that she momentarily turned around to look at her children in the backseat of V1, as D1 turned back around, she could not slow down in time. D1 stated that she did not know the light was red when she turned around. V1 then collided with V2 causing V2 to be pushed into V3 and V3 into V4. V1 and V2 were towed due to heavy damage. V3 and V4 were able to be driven from the scene. Ambulance services were on scene due to the unknown nature of the accident, however no party was transported to the hospital. D1 was distracted due to looking behind her while operating V1, resulting in a rear end collision with V2. This collision with V2 caused secondary collisions with V3 and V4.

V1 was backed into a parking space at 400 N. Daniels way between 3:30am to 4:30pm on 02/04/2019. An unknown vehicle struck V1 in the front bumper and left the scene. Security is checking video footage for any vehicle involved during that time of accident.

On 02/05/2018 OP1 advised me that she parked V2 in the Wilkie North Parking Lot facing eastbound on 02/04/2018 around 2010 hours. She stated that she returned to the vehicle to find damage to the front end. V1 is unknown at this time. OP1 advised me that she pulled into the parking space on the east side of the Wilkie North parking lot facing east. In front of her vehicle was grass and a sidewalk. She advised me that she checked the vehicle last night around 2010 hours and did not notice damage to the vehicle. She stated that she woke up around 0520 hours this morning to find damage to the vehicle. She stated that she drove to the SRSC parking lot in the morning afterward, but does not believe it the collision occurred there. She stated that she does not remember colliding with any other vehicles and was not sure how the front bumper of her vehicle could have had the paint transfer. I noticed white paint transfer on the front bumper of her vehicle and it was loose. V1 is unknown at this time. I did not notice any tread marks in the grass near where she stated that her vehicle was parked last night. I checked, but could not find any video cameras in the area.On 02/13/2019, I spoke with OP1. She advised me that she was not sure when the vehicle was involved in the collision. She stated that on 02/04/2018 during the evening hours, she drove from Luddy Hall to the East Concourse of Memorial Stadium. She stated that the vehicle could have been struck at one of those locations. She was not clear on a date or time in which she knew the vehicle did not have damage to it. She also advised me that it was her boyfriend that first noticed the damage on 02/05/2018. She stated that he was the one to drive her vehicle to the SRSC around 0520 hours from the Wilkie parking lot. She stated that he noticed the damage to the vehicle and told her about it later in that day.I checked IU Milestone camera footage, but there were no cameras that faced the east concourse of Memorial Stadium. The time and location of the collision are still unknown at this time.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: V1 was turning southbound onto N. Daniels Way from the westbound exit of the Ivy Tech Community College parking lot. V2 was traveling northbound on N. Daniels way. Both D1 and D2 stated that V1 turned out in front of V2 and V2 did not have enough time to prevent from crashing into V1. D1 stated that he did not see V2 coming. Neither V1 nor V2 sustained disabling damage.

V1 was traveling south bound on State Road 4546 approaching the 10th St. intersection.V2 was stopped at a red traffic signal facing south on State Road 4546 at the 10th St. intersection.D1 left the scene before police arrived to take the report but did exchange all of his information with D2.D2 stated she was stopped at the red traffic signal for several minutes when she was suddenly struck from behind very hard.The only damage that is known on V1 is that it is on the front bumper.V2 has damage to the center of the rear bumper. I was unable to contact D1 at the time of the initial report.

AFTER BEING DISPATCHED TO AN ACCIDENT UNKNOWN, FIRE WAS THE FIRST TO ARRIVE. FIRE ADVISED THE VEHICLE WAS INVOLED IN AN ACCIDENT, BUT WAS COLD AND HAD BEEN AT THAT LOCATION FOR A WHILE. AFTER RUNNING THE PLATE, THE OWNERS INFORMATION WAS DISPLAYED. I WAS UNABLE TO CONTACT THE OWNER DUE TO THE PHONE NUMBER ON RECORD WAS DISCONNECTED. THE VAN WAS TOWED TO BLANDS. IT SHOULD BE NOTED THAT AFTER APPROACHING THE VEHICLE, I COULD SMELL A STRONG ODOR OF ALCOHOL COMING FROM THE INTERIOR OF THE VEHICLE.

THE DRIVER OF UNIT 1 STATED THAT SHE WAS FOLLOWING UNIT 2 WHILE TRAVELING EAST ON STATE ROAD 45. UNIT 2 HAD JUST REALEASED THE BRAKE PEDAL AND STARTED TO ACCELERATE WHEN UNIT 1 REAR ENDED UNIT 2. UNIT 1 STATED SHE THOUGHT UNIT 2 WAS ACCELERATING FASTER THAN WHAT IT WAS. SHE THEN STATED HER FOOT SLIPPED OFF OF THE BRAKE PEDAL DUE TO HER SHOE BEING WET. SHE WAS ALSO DISTRACTED BY THE VEHICLE BEHIND HER.

V1 and V2 were both facing westbound on 10th Street at Union Street. V1 was directly behind V2. V2 proceeded to turn right onto Union Street when light turned green. V2 came to a direct stop since pedestrian had right of way crossing the street. D1 said she was traveling westbound on 10th Street in V1. D1 said she was directly behind V2 in V1. D1 said the light turned green for them to go. D1 said V2 started to turn right onto Union Street and suddenly stopped after almost making the turn completely. D1 said she did not know if V2 had its signal on. D1 said she struck V2 in the rear with V1. V1 had minor damage to the front passenger quarter panel. D2 said she was traveling westbound on 10th Street in V2. D2 said she was directly in front of V1. D2 said the light turned green for them to go. D2 said she was turning right onto Union Street and came to a stop as she was turning due to the pedestrian walk sign and a pedestrian crossing the street. D2 said she had her signal on when turning. D2 said V1 the struck V2 in the rear. V2 had damage to the rear driver side tail light and quarter panel area. OP1 (Ronald Eller Driver Ed Instructor with Bloomington Driving School) said V2 was westbound on 10th Street in front of V1. OP1 said they had the green light to turn right onto Union Street. OP1 said D2 used her signal when turning. OP1 said the pedestrian walk signal came on where a student walked into the crosswalk while looking at their cell phone. OP1 said D2 sopped due to pedestrian in the crosswalk. OP1 said that's when V1 struck V2 in the rear.

Prior to police arrival, V1 was facing south parked in a parking space and V2 was parked facing north in a parking space. V1 was backing up at the same time V2 was backing out. Upon arrival there was multiple vehicles in the parking lot.D1 was asked what occurred? D1 said she was backing up in the parking lot in V1. D1 said V2 was backing up at the same time. D1 said that's when both V1 and V2 crashed into one another. V1 had damage to the rear passenger side bumper area of the vehicle.D2 was asked what occurred? D2 said she pulled into the parking lot and was going south in V2. D2 said she then turned left to find a parking space in the second row. D2 said she then parked facing south. D2 said she realized she was parked crooked and wanted to re-adjust her parking of V2. D2 said she saw V1 drive by her so she then pulled straight out to re-adjust V2 parking. D2 said V1 for some reason reversed and backed into V2. V2 had damage to the driver side rear bumper of V2.

D1 AND V1 LEFT SCENE. I MET WITH THE OWNER OF V2 AT THE BLOOMINGTON POLICE DEPT.OWNER2 STATED SHE WAS PARKED FACING SOUTH IN PRIVATE LOT OF SAM'S CLUB. O2 STATED THERE IS DAMAGE TO REAR DRIVER'S SIDE BUMPER AND WHEEL WELL AREA.O2 STATED SHE CAME OUT TO HER CAR AT AROUND 4:30 PM ON 2/5/2019 FROM SAM'S CLUB AND NOTICED THE DAMAGE LATER.CRIMINAL CASE COMPLETED. NO LEADS AT THIS TIME.

V1 STRUCK V2 AT THE INTERSECTION OF 2ND STREET AND WALKER STREET.D1 STATED THAT SHE WAS TRAVELING EAST ON 2ND STREET AND HAD THE GREEN LIGHT BEFORE V2 PROCEEDED INTO THE INTERSECTION. D1 STATED THAT SHE STRUCK V2.D2 STATED THAT SHE WAS SITTING AT THE RED LIGHT UNTIL THE LIGHT TURNED GREEN. D2 STATED THAT SHE PROCEEDED THROUGH THE INTERSECTION BEFORE SHE WAS STRUCK BY V1. D2 STATED THAT V1 RAN THE RED LIGHT AND HIT HER VEHICLE.

V2 was parked unattended. V1 was backing up heading East. V1 is a US Foods Delivery truck. There was no one in V2 at the time of the incident. The owner of V2 stated that on 02/05/2019 at 1045 hours he noticed that there was damage to the front drivers side area around the tire. The owner looked at the video footage to see V1 back up to deliver food and clipped the front end of V2. D1 did not know it happened and left the scene. I was able to make contact with D1 and get the information I needed to complete the report and get his side of what happened.I attempted to make contact with US Foods for a month and a half. I finally made contact with D1s supervisor. D1s supervisor advised that the situation had already been taken care of in house and did not realize there was a police report that needed finished.

V1 and V2 were both traveling north on SR 46 approaching the intersection of SR46 and 17th street. V1 was in the left lane, and V2 was in the right lane, following a different vehicle. The stop light had turned red at the intersection. V2 changed lanes, moving into the left lane, not realizing the light had turned red. V1 had come to a stop at the stop light. V2 struck V1 in the driver side rear bumper, with the front bumper of V2. D2 stated she was traveling north on SR46, and came to a stop at the intersection of SR46 and 17th street. D2 said after she had come to a complete stop, she was then struck in the rear end by V1. D2 complained of slight pain to her neck, and also stated she had a small child in the back seat. D2 requested EMS to the scene, only to check on her child. EMS arrived on scene. EMS checked on D2 and her child, and determined both were ok.D1 stated he was raveling north on SR46 in the right lane behind a different vehicle. D1 said he changed lanes, moving to the left lane, just before the intersection of SR46 and 17th street. D1 stated he did not realize the light had turned red, and when he changed lanes V2 was stopped, and he didn't have time to react, ultimately striking V2 in the rear end. D1 did not complain of any pain, and was also cleared by EMS on scene. There was significant damage to the rear of V2, but the vehicle was able to drive away. V1 had light damage to the front end, and was also able to drive away.

Manner of Collision: HEAD ON BETWEEN TWO MOTOR VEHICLES
NARRATIVE: V1 was traveling north on N Kinser Pike at a high rate of speed approaching W Briarcliff Drive. As V1 exited the curve on N Kinser Pike, he noticed the Witness vehicle stopped on N Kinser Pike, facing north, to turn left onto W Briarcliff Drive. In order to avoid a collision with the witness vehicle, V1 swerved into the left lane of oncoming traffic. V2 was traveling southbound on N Kinser Pike, and as V1 swerved into the west lane, it collided with V2. The head on collision caused V1's airbags to deploy. Both vehicle were towed by Ken's Westside Towing for disabling damage. All parties corroborated the same story. D2 was transported to the IU Health hospital for a complaint of pain. D1 was not injured. The witness vehicle was not damaged.

Walnut Street, at the intersection of Third Street in Bloomington, is a 2-lane, 1 way northbound road. Both lanes are northbound and are demarcated by painted traffic control devices and a traffic signal at this intersection. The right lane of northbound Walnut Street is a dual use right turn or through lane. Third street at this intersection is a 4-lane, 2-way street with a raised central divider. It runs roughly east-west in this area. The dominant landmark at this intersection is the Bloomington Public transit station that sits on the southeast corner of the intersection. Both streets are asphalt, well lit and clearly marked with signage and lane control. The road surface at the time of the collision was very wet due to ongoing rain. Vehicle 1 (silver Toyota car) was driving northbound following Vehicle 2 (black Jeep SUV). V2 was slowing in preparation for a right turn from the right lane of northbound Walnut St onto eastbound 3rd St when V1 made contact. V1 showed damage to the front end and hood, while V2 showed damage to the rear bumper area. Neither driver was hurt and the airbags did not deploy on either vehicle. Both drivers denied treatment or a tow truck. Vehicles were moved from the lanes of traffic to a parking lot to conduct the crash investigation. Driver 1 (Hannah Bentz) stated that she had been driving north when the vehicle in front of her slowed. She stated that she tried to brake but "just couldn't get stopped fast enough." Driver 2, (Shea Slayter) stated that she had been slowing in preparation for a right-hand turn when she was struck from the rear. Troopers Wagner and I were assisting EMS and Bloomington officers on a medical emergency on the sidewalk in front of the transit station at the intersection corner. We immediately responded upon hearing the sound of the collision happening approximately 50 feet to the southwest of the corner. It is the opinion of the investigating officer that the cause of the collision was driver inattention by driver 1, and as such Driver 1 is at fault.RRK

D1 did state that she believed she had the green light.D2 stated she driving northbound on Curry, through the intersection at Jonathan in the fast lane when V1 turned into her vehicle from Jonathan. D1 did say she had the green light and was operating in the far left lane.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY

V2 was going east on 17th St going straight when the accident occurred.D1 stated she was turning east out of gate 6 on to 17th St. D1 stated that she believed her passenger said that she was clear to turn east on to 17th St. D1 explained that her passenger had actually stated she was clear after the next car. D1 stated that she began turning east on to 17th St and as she was turning she collided with V2's rear driver's side wheel.D2 stated he was traveling east on 17th St. D2 stated he was just passing gate 6 when V1 pulled out of gate 6 and collided with his rear driver's side wheel. D2 stated he attempted to get out of the way but he could not.

V2 WAS STOPPED ON EAST COVENANTER, IN FRONT OF 2700 EAST COVENANTER, AND ATTEMPTING TO TURN LEFT WHEN THE FRONT OF V1 STRUCK V2 IN THE BACK LEFT DRIVERS SIDE BUMPER.D1 STATED HE WAS DRIVING EAST ON EAST COVENANTER AND DIDNT REALIZE V2 WAS SLOWING/STOPPING. Spoke to D1 and he stated V1 was traveling south on Kirby Rd and approached the T intersection of Kirby Rd and Airport Rd.
