Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: 9305/21/2019Officer Pesa assisted with traffic controlV1 was traveling southbound in the left hand turn lane on the SR 45/46 Bypass to turn onto N. Range road. V2 was traveling North on the SR 45/46 Bypass in the left lane.V1 was traveling south and attempting to turn left off of the SR 45/46 Bypass onto N. Range Road. V1 turned in front of V2 attempting to travel east on N. Range Rd while V2 was traveling north on the SR 45/46 Bypass. V1 made the turn at around 30 mph attempting to turn onto N. Range Rd. V1 failed to yield to V2 which led to a collision between the two vehicles.V2 was traveling north on the SR 45/46 Bypass in the left lane at around 45 mph. V2 was originally traveling in the right lane but changed lanes to the left lane as a construction vehicle was slowly traveling partially in the right hand lane and partially the side of the road about 150 feet ahead of V2. V2 switched to the left lane approximately 100 feet before the SR 45/46 Bypass and N. Range Road intersection. V1 was traveling southbound on the SR 45/46 Bypass and attempted to turn onto N. Range Rd to travel east. V1 did not have enough time to complete the turn as V2 was traveling north through the intersection. V2 and V1 then collided. D1 stated that she was attempting to turn onto N. Range Rd to travel east form the SR 45/46 Bypass. D1 stated that she initially thought V2 was going to make a U-turn as she saw V2 move out of the right lane into the left lane and begin to slow heading north. D1 thought she had enough time to pull out in front of V2 to complete her turn onto N. Range Rd but ended up colliding with V2 instead. D1 stated she thought she had enough time to complete her turn but did not.D2 stated that she was traveling northbound on the SR 45/46 Bypass in the right lane. D2 stated that she switched to the left lane about 100 feet prior to the SR 45/46 intersection with N. Range Rd as she witnessed a construction vehicle partially blocking the right hand lane of the northbound SR 45/46 traffic ahead of her. After she switched to the left lane she began to slow her vehicle for slowing traffic ahead of her. D2 stated she then saw V1 pull out in front of her which led to the collision.Both drivers did not complain of pain and did not request an ambulance at any point of the accident investigation. Later after both parties had arrived at their destinations after the accident, D2 contacted IUPD requesting an ambulance to check her out as she began to feel pain from the accident. Bloomington Hospital Ambulance Service unit 2164 responded to D2's residence to evaluate her. I responded to the residence as well. D2 complained of pain to her chest from the seatbelt and pain to her left arm from the airbag deployment. D2's left arm was visibly red and appeared to be starting to swell. D2 denied the offer to be transported to the hospital for further evaluation and stated she would go to the doctor if the pain worsened. It is to be noted that there is no traffic signal at the intersection of the SR 45/46 Bypass and N. Range Rd. Traffic turning onto N. Range Rd or off onto the SR 45/46 Bypass must yield to traffic traveling on the SR 45/46 Bypass.Photographs of the scene were saved under this case number.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: V1 pulled into traffic from a private lot on the South side of W. 3rd St. to turn Westbound. V1 pulled out in front of V2 who was traveling Eastbound on W. 3rd St. V1 collided with the front passenger side bumper of V2 with its driver side bumper. V1 then scraped down the passenger side of V2 and then struck the rear bumper of V2.V1 left West on W. 3rd St without providing the necessary information for the accident.Neither of the witness could provide a plate number, but both stated that the driver of V1 fled West bound on W. 3rd St. Nick (W1) stated that V1 was possibly a 2006 Buick Lesabre or Lacrosse.A criminal case was completed for this case. Photographs were logged into evidence. V1 / D1 were never located. V2 had heavy front end, passenger side, and rear end damage from the collision. No injuries were reported.

Owner of vehicle 2 (V2) advised that his vehicle was parked in the area from 6:00pm-7:30pm. He advised that when he returned to the vehicle he found damage on the front wheel well on the driver's side of V2. V2 was parked on W 7th Street facing eastbound.While I was observing the vehicle it appeared that there was possibly red paint transfer. I took photographs of the damage and uploaded them as Evidence per department policy and procedure. Based on the damage, I was unable to determine a direction of travel of the other vehicle involved. I also attempted to locate and check video cameras in the area, but was unsuccessful in locating any that would have recorded the area of the incident.

V1 AND V2, BOTH COMCAST BUCKET TRUCKS, WERE TRAVELING NORTHBOUND ON S FAIRFAX ROAD WHEN V3, IN FRONT OF V1, STOPPED ABRUPTLY DUE TO UTILITY WORK IN THE AREA. V1 THEN REAR ENDED V3 AND V1 WAR REAR ENDED BY V2. D3 ADVISED D1 THAT THERE WAS NO DAMAGE TO V3; THEREFORE, D3 LEFT THE SCENE.THE UTILITY WORKERS IN THE AREA ALSO LEFT THE SCENE PRIOR TO MY ARRIVAL.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: DUE TO A ROAD BEING BLOCKED, UNIT 1 PULLED INTO A DRIVEWAY TO TURN AROUND. UNIT 1 BACKED OUT INTO THE ROAD, INTO THE PATH OF UNIT 2. UNIT 1 SUSTAINED DAMAGE TO THE PASSENGER SIDE REAR BUMPER AND UNIT 2 SUSTAINED DAMAGE TO THE FRONT PASSENGER SIDE DOOR AND QUARTER PANEL. THE VIEW OF UNIT 1 WAS OBSTRUCTED BY A LARGE BUSH LOCATED NEXT TO THE ROAD, BLOCKING THE VIEW OF UNIT 2.

V1 WAS TRAVELING WEST ON STATE ROAD 46. D1 STATED THAT V2 WAS SLOWING VERY RAPIDLY DUE TO A VEHICLE AHEAD OF V2 THAT WAS STOPPED IN THE ROADWAY, ASSISTING A DOG THAT WAS LOOSE. V2 CAME TO A STOP, AND D1 STATED THAT SHE WAS UNABLE TO STOP IN TIME TO AVOID STRIKING V2 FROM THE REAR. D2 SAID HE SAW THAT V1 WAS NOT GOING TO BE ABLE TO STOP IN TIME AND HE WAS STRUCK FROM THE REAR.

The owner of the fence stated a semi truck drove onto his property to back up heading westbound. According to the owner, D1 backed the semi and sideswiped his fence causing damage. The owner also advised D1 then struck a utility pole causing damage. It was reported this incident occurred on either Monday 5/20/19 or Tuesday 5/21/19 at an unknown time. Due to D1 leaving the scene of the accident without providing the proper information, there will be a local case report done.

V1 and V2 were traveling westbound on 3rd Street. V1 struck V2 in the rear.D1 stated that he was looking ahead to the light and saw it turn green. He did not realize that V2 had not started moving forward and had looked down. Upon looking up, he was unable to avoid striking V2.D2 stated that he was stopped in traffic and that V1 struck him in the rear.V1 did Strike V2 in the rear causing damage to both vehicles.W1 observed V1 strike V2 and has dash cam video that she will save.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: D1 STATED SHE EXITED ONTO WINSLOW RD FROM THE CREDIT UNION PARKING LOT IN THE NORTHERN MOST LANE. SHE INDIATED THAT SHE BEGAN TO MERGE LEFT INTO THE TURN LANE AND DID NOT SEE V1 PRIOR TO MAKING HER LANE CHANGE. D1 SAID V2 MUST HAVE BEEN IN HER BLIND SPOT AND SHE COLLIDED INTO THE PASSENGER SIDE OF V2. D2 STATED HE WAS TRAVELING WEST ON WINSLOW RD AND AS HE WAS APPROACHING THE CREDIT UNION EXIT, V1 PULLED ONTO WINSLOW IN THE NORTHERN MOST LANE. HE SAID V1 THEN MERGED OVER INTO HIS LANE, COLLIDING INTO THE SIDE OF HIS VEHICLE.

D1 STATED SHE WAS ADJUSTING HER REAR VIEW MIRROR WHEN SHE VEERED TO THE RIGHT SIDE OF THE ROAD, STRIKING A CONCRETE CULVERT ON THE RIGHT HAND SIDE OF THE ROADWAY. D1 WAS HAD JUST TURNED N/B ONTO S SMITH RD FROM STONEGATE PRIOR TO THE ACCIDENT. AIRBAGS DID DEPLOY, NO INJURIES TO D1. NO NOTICEABLE DAMAGE TO THE CONCRETE BARRIER.

Narrative By Chief Deputy William Jay HumphreyEllettsville Police DepartmentDriver of Vehicle #1 going West Bound on Temperance St . At the Intersection of Temperance St. And Hartstrait Rd. Vehicle #1 struck rear of Vehicle #2 who was stopping and slowing down on Temperance St in refernce to Traffic Signal light .
V2 was parked on the SW end of the parking lot at 1915 S Walnut street and was facing North. V1 struck V2 in the front bumper causing damage to V2. V1 then left area without stopping.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: D2 STATED SHE WAS TRAVELING WEST ON 3RD STREET IN THE SOUTHERN MOST LANE. SHE INDICATED AS SHE ENTERED THE INTERSECTION OF COLLEGE MALL RD, V1, WHICH WAS TRAVELING WEST IN THE NORTHERN MOST LANE, MERGED INTO THE PASSENGER SIDE OF HER VEHICLE. D2 STATED AFTER THE COLLISION SHE MERGED RIGHT BEHIND V1 AND ASSUMED THEY WERE GOING TO PULL INTO THE RED LOBSTER PARKING LOT. D2 SAID SHE PULLED INTO THE LOT AND V1 CONTINUED WEST. D2 DID NOT GET A PLATE NUMBER OF THE OFFENDING VEHICLE BUT DESCRIBED IT AS A TAN MINI VAN.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: D1 STATED HE WAS PULLING OUT OF FORCE FITNESS PARKING LOT. D1 STATED HE PULLED TO THE END OF THE DRIVE AND STOPPED AT SOUTH WALNUT ST. WHICH CROSS TRAFFIC DOES NOT STOP. D1 STATED HE LOOKED LEFT AND DID NOT SEE ANY CARS. D1 STATED HE THEN LOOKED RIGHT AND DID NOT SEE ANY CARS. D1 STATED HE PULLED INTO THE INTERSECTION AND WAS THEN STRUCK BY V2 IN THE BACK DRIVERS SIDE OF HIS VEHICLE.D2 STATED SHE WAS TRAVELLING SOUTH ON SOUTH WALNUT ST. D2 STATED D1 PULLED TO THE EDGE OF THE ROADWAY LEAVING FORCE FITNESS AND CAME TO A STOP. D2 STATED D1 PULLED OUT IN FRONT OF HER ATTEMPTING TO TURN LEFT (NOTH). D2 STATED SHE ATTEMPTED TO APPLY HER BRAKES, BUT WAS UNABLE TO STOP IN TIME. D2 STATED THE FRONT OF HER VEHCILE STRUCK THE BACK DRIVERS SIDE OF V1 CAUSING DAMAGE TO BOTH VEHICLES.W1 STATED HE WAS FOLLOWING D2 TRAVELLING SOUTH ON SOUTH WALNUT ST. W1 STATED D1 CAME TO A STOP WHEN HE APPROACHED SOUTH WALNUT ST. ATTEMPTING TO LEAVE FORCE FITNESS. W1 STATED D1 THEN PULLED OUT IN FRONT OF D2 ATTEMPTING TO TURN NORTH. W1 STATED D2 WAS UNABLE TO STOP IN TIME. W1 STATED V2 HIT THE BACK DRIVERS SIDE OF V1 CAUSING DAMAGE TO BOTH.

V1 was traveling WB on State Road 45/46 bypass approaching Milo Sampson Road when the accident occurred. When I pulled on scene, I observed the deer deceased and laying in the middle of the right most WB traffic lane. D1 stated he was traveling WB on the bypass in the right most lane when he observed a deer run in front of V1. D1 stated he had no time to respond and struck the deer with the front bumper of V1. I observed the front bumper area and hood of V1 had been damaged due to the deer strike. D1 was able to drive V1 away from the scene.

V2 was driving northbound on N. Kinser Pike with V1 following behind V2. After passing through the intersection of N. Kinser and W 17th st, V2 stopped to avoid hitting a vehicle she was following and then V1 collided with the rear of V2. The vehicle in front of V2 was turning off of the roadway in an attempt to turn around. V2 did not collide with the other vehicle.D2 stated that she was driving northbound and the vehicle in front of her stopped abruptly and turned its turn signal on to turn east into a private drive. D2 said that she braked hard as to not hit the vehicle. V1 then collided with the rear of her vehicle.D1 stated that he was following V2 northbound on N. Kinser when V2 stopped abruptly. D1 said that he did attempt to brake to avoid colliding with V2 but was not able to stop in time. D1 said that his anti-lock brakes did engage as he attempted to stop.The collision cause moderate damage to the front of V1 and the rear of V2. Both vehicles were still operable and were driven away from the scene. No injuries to involved parties.

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: V1 WAS EASTBOUND ON COUNTRY SIDE LANE APPROACHING RCA PARK DRIVE.D1 SAID AFTER HE WENT OVER A SPEED BUMP HE LOST CONTROL ON THE WET PAVEMENT AND RAN OFF THE ROAD STRIKING A TREE.

Vehicle 1 (silver 2008 Ford Taurus) was traveling north on I69, 50 feet south of the 105.0MM in the left lane. Vehicle 2 (silver 2018 Toyota 4 Runner) was north on I69, 50 feet south of the 105.0MM in the right lane. Vehicle 1 moved in to the right lane, striking the driver's side of vehicle 2. This resulted in damage to both vehicles.Driver 1 ( Janet Riggins) advised that she was traveling north on I69, in the left lane. She advised that she was following a semi and vehicle 2 was behind her. She advised that she attempted to move in to the right lane and in doing so struck vehicle 2. She advised that she did not see vehicle 2 move in to the right lane before she attempted to change lanes.Driver 2 ( Scott Deon) advised that he was traveling north on I69, in the right lane. He advised that as he traveled north, vehicle 1 changed lanes in to his vehicle.Both vehicles involved in the crash were driven from the scene. No injuries were reported at the time of the investigation.

D1 ADVISED SHE WAS ON HER BUS ROUTE DROPPING SCHOOL KIDS OFF WHEN SHE PASSED ONE OF HER STOPS AND ADVISED SHE STOPPED QUICKER THAN NORMAL AND WAS REAR ENDED BY V2.D2 ADVISED SHE CAME TO A STOP AS THE SCHOOL BUS IN FRONT OF HER HAD STOP. D2 THEN NOTICED THE BUS REVERSE LIGHTS CAME ON AND BACKED INTO V2.

V2 was stopped northbound on E. State Road 45 attempting to turn left into the driveway of 5025 E. State Road 45 while yielding to southbound traffic. V1 was traveling northbound on E. State Road 45 behind V2 and stated that she did not see V2 stopped in the roadway. V1 rear ended V2 causing disabling damage to V1 also forcing both vehicles partially into the southbound lane. V3 was traveling southbound on E. State Road 45 at the time of the crash. V3 was forced to run off the west side of the roadway striking the mailbox of to avoid colliding with V1 and V2 causing very minor damage to the passenger side of V3.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: V2 WAS WEST BOUND ON HILLSIDE DRIVE, AT WOODLAWN AVE. D2 SAID V1 PULLED OUT FROM WOODLAWN STRIKING V2 AND SPINNING IT AROUND IN THE INTERSECTION.V1 WAS SOUTH BOUND ON WOODLAWN AVE. D1 SAID SHE WAS TRYING TO CROSS HILLSIDE SOUTH BOUND. SAID THAT THERE WERE OTHER CARS ON HILLSIDE, TURNING. SHE DID NOT SEE V2, STARTED TO CROSS, AND STRUCK V2.NO REPORTED INJURIES.

Primary Cause-Driver Factor-Following Too Closely: D1 was following too close given the conditions. The conditions were that rain fall was occurring and the roads were wet. D1 should have maintained adequate distance from V2 to avoid colliding into the rear of V2.SR45 is a highway that runs primarily in a eastern and western direction through Monroe County. Duncan Road is a county road that runs in a northern and southern direction and intersects with SR45, 500ft east of the crash. The roadway surface was wet and rain fall was occurring during the time of the crash.V3 (2006 silver Pontiac), V2 (2019 white Terrain), and V1 (2000 maroon Pontiac) were all traveling westbound on SR45. V3 came to an abrupt stop due to a vehicle that had struck a dog in front of V3. V2 stopped abruptly behind V3. V1 was unable to stop before colliding into the rear of V2. This action caused V2 to travel forward and strike V3 in the rear. The vehicles had been moved prior to my arrival.D3 (Melissa Griffitts) stated that she was traveling westbound on SR45. The vehicle in front of her struck a dog in the roadway and had came to a stop. D3 stated she applied the brakes abruptly and stopped to avoid colliding into the rear of the vehicle. D3 stated she then was struck from the rear by V2. She was wearing her seat belt.D2 (Jordan Wilcher) stated that he was traveling westbound on SR45 when V3 stopped abruptly in front of him. He applied the brakes and had come to a stop. D2 stated he was then struck in the rear by V1, which propelled him forward causing his vehicle to strike V3 in the rear. He was wearing his seat belt.D1 (Charles Gwyn) stated that he was traveling westbound on SR45. V2 stopped abruptly in front of him. D1 stated he applied the brakes, but did not have time to stop before colliding into the rear of V2.During the course of my investigation, I observed Damage to the rear of V3, damage to the rear and front end of V2, and damage to the front of V1. No injuries were reported as a result of this crash. However, D3's son was bitten by the dog that had been struck while attempting to remove the dog from the roadway. Monroe County Animal Control investigated the dog bite.The crash investigation showed that the primary cause of the crash was Following Too Closely on the part of D1. This was determined by driver statements and damages sustained to all three vehicles.

BOTH VEHICLES WERE NORTHBOUND ON PETE ELLIS DR. V1 REAR ENDED V2 AS V2 WAS SLOWING DOWN TO TRAFFIC UP AHEAD. V1 HAD DAMAGE TO THE FRONT BUMPER. V2 HAD DAMAGE TO THE REAR BUMPER. D1 HAD ABRASIONS TO HER FACE AND A COMPLAINT OF PAIN TO THE AREA BETWEEN HER INDEX FINGER AND THUMB. D1 STATED SHE STRUCK HER HEAD AGAINST THE STEERING WHEEL DURING THE COLLISION. D1 WAS MOST LIKELY FOLLOWING TOO CLOSELY IN ADDITION TO DRIVING TOO FAST RESULTING IN NOT HAVING ENOUGH TIME AND DISTANCE TO BREAK BEFORE A COLLISION.SUPPLEMENT 5/31/19: ADDED ABRASIONS TO FACE IN NARRATIVE. NO INJURIES WERE REPORTED FOR D2. HE DECLINED MEDICAL TREATMENT WHILE EMS WAS ON SCENE.

D1 STATED SHE WAS TRAVELLING WEST ON W. 3RD ST. D1 STATED SHE WAS UNSURE WHERE SHE WAS GOING AND WAS LOOKING AT HER PHONE FOR DIRECTIONS. D1 STATED WHEN SHE LOOKED UP, D2 WAS STOPPED IN FRONT OF HER AND SHE WAS UNABLE TO STOP IN TIME. D1 STATED HER VEHICLE COLLIDED WITH V2 CAUSING DAMAGE TO HER VEHICLE.D2 STATED HE WAS STOPPED AT A STOP LIGHT FACING WEST ON W. 3RD ST. D2 STATED V1 HIT HIM IN THE REAR OF HIS VEHCILE CAUSING DAMAGE TO V2 AND POSSIBLY V1.

V2 WAS TRAVELING SOUTH ON LEONARD SPRINGS RD. V2 SLOWED TO A STOP, WAITING FOR ONCOMING TRAFFIC TO GO BY SO SHE COULD TURN INTO THE APARTMENT COMPLEX. V1 THEN COLLIDED WITH THE REAR OF V2 CAUSING MINOR DAMAGE. V2 TURNED INTO APARTMENT COMPLEX AND NOTIFIED POLICE OF THE INCIDENT. BEFORE OFFICERS ARRIVED ON SCENE V1 FLED SOUTHBOUND ON S LEONARD SPRINGS RD WITHOUT EXCHANGING INFORMATION WITH D2.V2 WAS STILL OPERABLE AND THERE WERE NO REPORTED INJURIES.

V1 was pulling out to go northbound on Campbell Street, and V2 was parked stationary facing northbound on Campbell Street. V1 did not turn far enough out to clear V2. V1 struck V2.D1 said he backed into the dock area and dropped off a delivery. D1 said he was pulling out, and turned to go northbound in V1 on Campbell Street. D1 said he did not turn wide enough causing V1 to strike V2 with V1 passenger's side rear area of the flatbed. V1 had no damage. D1 said V2 was parked stationary.OP1 who was the driver of V2 was unloading V2 at the loading dock. OP1 said V2 was parked stationary facing northbound on Campbell Street. OP1 said V1 was pulling out from the loading dock, and turning to go northbound on Campbell Street. OP1 said V1 did not turn wide enough, and struck V2 on the rear driver side tail light causing the tail light to be broken out. Photos of both vehicles were taken. No injuries occurred during this crash.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
Manner of Collision: HEAD ON BETWEEN TWO MOTOR VEHICLES
NARRATIVE: V2 WAS NORTHBOUND ON CURRY PIKE, GOING THROUGH THE INTERSECTION OF WEST 3RD STREET. V1 WAS SOUTHBOUND ON CURRY PIKE MADE A LEFT TURN ON WEST 3RD STREET, TURNING IN FRONT OF V2, CAUSING THE VEHICLES TO COLLIDE HEAD ON. V1 FLED THE SCENE AND NO INFORMATION WAS LOCATED ON THE VEHICLE. D1 FLED AND WAS NOT LOCATED.D2 STATED HE WAS NORTBOUND ON CURRY PIKE AT 3RD STREET WITH THE GREEN LIGHT WHEN V1 MADE A LEFT TURN IN FRONT OF HIM AT THE INTERSECION, CAUSING THEIR VEHICLES TO COLLIDE. D2 COMPLAINED OF NECK AND KNEE PAIN AND WAS TRANSPORTED TO THE HOSPITAL. W1 STATED V2 WAS NORTHBOUND ON CURRY PIKE GOING THROUGH THE INTERSECTION WITH THE GREEN LIGHT. W1 STATED V1 WAS SOUTHBOUND ON CURRY PIKE, MADE A LEFT TURN IN FRONT OF V2, AND BOTH VEHICLES COLLIDED HEAD ON. W1 STATED V1 FLED FROM THE SCENE WESTBOUND ON 3RD STREET.

State Road 45 is a two way, two lane state road that primarily travels north and south with numerous hills and curves. In this particular section of State Road 45 the roadway is a straight-a-way with a slight grade. The weather at the time of the crash was raining and the roadway surface was wet. It was also dawn which resulted in low light condition.Vehicle 1 (a silver 2002 Toyota Camry) was traveling south on State Road 45 just south of Duncan Road. A dog ran into the path of V1. V1 was unable to avoid a collision with the dog. V1 sustained minor damage to the front bumper. V1 was driveable and did not require a tow truck.Driver 1 (Cheryl Felton) stated that she was traveling south on State Road 45 when a dog ran into her path. D1 stated she applied the brakes, but was unable to avoid a collision. D1 did have her seatbelt on at the time of the crash. D1 stated that she was not injured in the crash and did not need medical attention. It is the opinion of this investigating officer that the primary cause of the crash was animal in the roadway.

VEHICLE 1 WAS TRAVELING SOUTH BOUND ON SOUTH STATE ROAD 37 NEAR THE INTERSECTION OF SOUTH VICTOR PIKE. WHILE APPORACHING A TRAFFIC CONTROL SIGNAL THAT HAD TURNED RED VEHICLE 1 STRUCK VEHICLE 2 IN THE REAR LEFT BUMBPER. DRIVER 1 STATED THAT WHILE APPLYING HIS BREAKS ATTEMPTING TO STOP FOR THE SIGNAL HIS TRUCK STARTED TO SLIDE. DRIVER 1 SWERVED LEFT IN ATTEMPT TO AVOID VEHICLE 2, HOWEVER WAS UNABLE TO AVOID A COLLISION. BOTH DRIVERS WERE UNINJURED AND REFUSED ANY MEDICAL ATTENTION.BOTH VEHICLES WERE DRIVABLE AND DRIVEN FROM THE SCENE.

V1 was traveling north bound on North Mount Tabor Road. D1 stated his brakes went out which caused him to run off the roadway and strike the guardrail on the west side of the roadway. V1 came to a rest and D1 moved his vehicle off the roadway prior to my arrival.
On 05/23/2019 unit 1 was traveling North on North Old State Road 37. Unit 1 ran off the roadway and traveled over a gaurdrail causing the vehicle to become inverted between two trees.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: D1 WAS AT THE STOP SIGN FACING WB ON E THORNTON DR ATTEMPTING TO TURN SB ONTO S HIGHLAND AVENUE. D2 WAS TRAVELING NB ON S HIGHLAND STREET AT THE INTERSECTION OF E THORNTON DR. AS V1 ATTEMPTED THE TURN, THE FRONT OF V1 COLLIDED WITH THE FRONT PASSENGERS SIDE WHEEL AREA OF V2. V2 DID NOT HAVE A STOP SIGN WHEREAS V1 DID HAVE A STOP SIGN.D1 STATED THAT SHE CAME TO A COMPLETE STOP AT E THORNTON DRIVE, LOOKED BOTH WAYS AND DID NOT SEE ANY VEHICLES IN THE AREA. D1 STATED THAT IT WAS AT THAT POINT THAT V2 STRUCK HER VEHICLE.D2 STATED THAT SHE WAS TRAVELING NB ON S HIGHLAND STREET. D2 STATED THAT V1 ROLLED THE STOP SIGN AT E THORNTON DRIVE AND STRUCK HER VEHICLE.W1 STATED THAT HE DID NOT WITNESS THE ACTUAL COLLISION, BUT WAS OUTSIDE OF HIS RESIDENCE AND HEARD THE COLLISION AT WHICH TIME HE LOOKED OUT AND SAW THE REST POSITION OF THE VEHICLES. W1 STATED THAT IT WAS CLEAR THAT V1 PULLED OUT IN FRONT OF V2 WHO DID NOT HAVE A STOP SIGN AND CAUSE THE COLLISION.

Driver 1 stated he was stopped at the stop sign on southbound Washington St at 16th St. Driver 1 stated he started to turn left onto eastbound 16th St when the car that was behind him pulled out and passed him on the left and proceeded to turn left onto 16th St. Driver 1 stated that when the car pulled along side of him on the left it cut him off causing driver 1 to swerve right and leave the roadway, colliding with a tree. No collision occurred between the two cars.
V2 WAS SLOWING IN TRAFFIC TO TURN INTO JIFFY TREAT AND WAS STRUCK IN THE REAR BY V1. V2 WAS TOWED DUE TO DAMAGE.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: D2 STATED SHE WAS STOPPED SOUTH ON ROGERS ST WAITING TO MAKE A LEFT TURN ONTO 4TH ST. SHE SAID WHILE WAITING SHE WAS STRUCK BY V1 WHICH HAD MADE A LEFT TURN FROM 4TH ST. D1 STATED SHE WAS STOPPED EAST ON 4TH ST WAITING TO MAKE A LEFT TURN ONTO ROGERS. D1 SAID SHE DID NOT SEE V2 AND BEGAN TO MAKE HER LEFT TURN AND COLLIDED INTO V2.

V1 WAS MAKING A RIGHT HAND TURN FROM S. HIGHLAND AVE ONTO E WINSLOW RD. V1 TOOK THE TURN TO SHARP, AND THE BACK OF THE BUS LEFT THE ROADWAY WHERE THE REAR PASSENGER SIDE THEN SIDESWIPED A NEARBY LIGHT POLE CAUSING DAMAGE TO THE POLE AND BUS.

V3 was stopped in traffic southbound on S. Curry Pk with V2 stopped behind V3. V1 was traveling southbound on S. Curry Pike and collided with the rear of V2. V2 then collided with the rear of V3. V1 and V2 both accrued disabling damage and were towed from the scene. V3 accrued minor damage.D2 and D3 stated that they were stopped in traffic waiting for a vehicle to make a left hand turn through northbound lanes. D1 stated that she was traveling south through the intersection and was distracted by a Monroe County Deputy patrol Vehicle that was in the intersection. D1 stated that she did not see the vehicles stopped in the roadway in front of her.D2 and passengers had complaint of pain and were all checked on scene by EMS. No persons involved were transported to hospital from the scene. All cleared by EMS.

D1 STATED HE WAS BEHIND V2 WHEN V2 STARTED TO SLOW DOWN FOR A VEHICLE AHEAD TO TURN OFF THE ROADWAY. INITIALLY, THE VEHICLE WAS STOPPING SLOWLY, THEN V2 STOPPED ABRUPTLY AND D1 WAS UNABLE TO STOP HIS VEHICLE IN TIME.
V1 WAS TRAVELING SOUTH BOUND ON INTERSTATED 69. D1 STATED A DEER RAN OUT INTO THE ROADWAY AND HE STUCK IT.

V1 was SB on Walnut street and was south of Country Club drive and in the right lane. V2 was also SB on Walnut street and was in the left lane. V1 made an unsafe lane change and struck V2 in the passenger side doors with the front driver side bumper of her vehicle.D1 stated that she was in the right lane and was going to merge into the left lane to continue south on Walnut street. She stated that V2 was speeding and came out of know where and that's why she struck him. D2 stated that he was behind V1 and in the left lane. He stated she was going slow and he was driving past her when she merged into the side of his vehicle.

I69 at the 118mm is a eight-lane interstate that is divided by a concrete barrier in the center.Vehicle 1 (white, 2012, Ford Econoline Ambulance) was being drive by Driver 1 (Tyler Nixon) southbound on I69 just south of the 118mm when Veh1 struck a mattress that was lying in the roadway.D1 stated that he was following a pickup truck southbound on I69 when it suddenly swerved into a different lane, revealing a mattress lying in the lane that he was driving in. Due to the size and weight of the ambulance, D1 was unable to safely swerve and struck the mattress. Officer and INDOT personnel were able to free the mattress from underneath the ambulance. No report was completed on this date as there was no visible damage to the vehicle. On June 14th, 2019, I was contacted by St. Vincent Critical Care Transport and requested to complete a crash report.RRK

Driver was east bound on Dillman Rd when he came down a hill towards and s type curve before a bridge. The driver Logan Cofresi lost control of the vehicle when he cam over a newly paved portion of the road causing the vehicle to spin around. The vehicle ran off of the roadway causing damage to the guard rail that is connected to the bridge. The vehicle came to rest sideways in entrance to the west side of the bridge.

I, Indiana Conservation Officer (ICO) Joseph Tenbarge, responded to a motor vehicle accident in Monroe County, in the Fairfax Inn area, on Saturday, May 25, 2019, at approximately 2016 hours, wearing a fully marked ICO uniform. I received information from the Monroe Reservoir property management stating that their security personnel located a motorcycle, license plate M372VC, crashed in a ditch in front of the Fairfax Inn. I walked from the boat rental dock, across the parking lot to find a purple/silver 1999 Yamaha motorcycle, license plate M372VC, facing west toward the road from the parking lot, in the ditch on its side. I observed tracks in the grass coming from the parking lot. The operator, later identified as Thomas Goodman, operated the motorcycle from the parking lot, over the embankment, down the hill, and wrecked into the ditch along the main road, causing property damage. When I arrived on scene Thomas Goodman was not around his motorcycle that was in the ditch.I photographed the motorcycle as it was when I arrived. The windshield was broken off the motorcycle and approximately two (2) to three (3) feet in front of it. Indiana Department of Natural Resources-Parks and Reservoirs Division (IDNR), has security guards that are civilians but respond to complaints and calls such as this one. The IDNR security guard had driven by the site of the accident approximately forty five (45) minutes prior to observing the motorcycle in the ditch, so the accident occurred between 2017 hours and 1932 hours.While looking over the motorcycle for any evidence, I observed blood on it and I photographed that area. I also located a few cubes of ice on the ground within one (1) foot of the motorcycle which lead me to believe the accident occurred recent being it was over eighty (80) degrees outside that day. The IDNR security guard drove up and down Fair Fax Road, in an attempt to locate a subject that appeared to have been involved in a motorcycle accident but was unable to locate anyone. IDNR Property Manager Cory Rieman also came to the scene, from his house which is right inside the gate house of Monroe Reservoir property and did not see anyone walking along the road that appeared to be in a motorcycle accident. IDNR Property Manager Cory Rieman spoke with the front desk of the Fair Fax Inn and they did not speak with Thomas Goodman as of approximately 2030 hours. IDNR Property Manager Cory Rieman also spoke with the front gate who had also not seen nor heard from Thomas Goodman. ICO Corporal Brian Bailey, who was off duty checked the bar area for Thomas Goodman and did not locate him. I spoke with the Fair Fax bar outside the gate house, which they did not serve Thomas Goodman, nor was he inside their place when I spoke with them. Monroe County Sheriff Department (MCSD) Deputies went to the address, 2525 Bryan Street in Bloomington, the address on the Bureau of Motor Vehicle Return (BMV) return from the license plate. MCSD Deputies were unable to make contact with anyone at that residence. I had Kens West Side Towing come and tow the motorcycle to their storage facility. Sunday, May 26, 2019I received a call from MCSD Deputy Miller who advised me that Thomas Goodman had called in and reported his motorcycle stolen. MCSD Deputy Miller advised me of Thomas Goodman's phone number, 812-322-8265.Saturday, June 8, 2019After several phone calls not getting answered over the previous weeks, ICO Corporal Brian Bailey went to 2525 Bryan Street in Bloomington, at 0818 hours and spoke with Thomas Goodman's parents who advised he lives at 900 N Curry Pike Trailer 26 Bloomington, IN, 47404. ICO Corporal Brian Bailey was unable to make contact with Thomas Goodman at that address. He could not get anyone at that residence to answer the door, but he did leave a card advising Thomas Goodman that I needed to speak with him. At approximately 1445 hours, Thomas Goodman called into ICO Dispatch.At 1452 hours, I was able to reach Thomas

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: Driver was west bound on Gardner Rd on a class B MDC. The driver was driving in rainy weather conditions and was carrying a heavy bag of animal feed on his MDC. When the driver approached a curve before a bridge he lost control and hit the guard rail on the south side of the bridge. The driver stated that he lost control due to the wet roadway conditions.

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: Driver Amy L Reader was north bound on S SR 446 just north of Rush Ridge Rd. The roadway conditions were wet from a recent rain making the roadway surface slick. The driver stated that she lost control of the vehicle striking a guard rail on the east side of the roadway causing the vehicle to go across both lanes and strike the guard rail on the west side of the roadway. When the vehicle struck the west side guard rail the vehicle flipped on its passenger side coming to rest in the middle of the roadway.The driver admitted to drinking 3-4 beers at a party before driving on S SR 446.

Driver of Vehicle 2 stated he slowed and stopped as Vehicle 1 was attempting to go backward (south) in the Northbound lane. Vehicle 1 continued backing until it struck Vehicle 2 causing disabling front end damage. Driver of Vehicle 1 stated he did not see Vehicle 2 behind him. He stated he was attempting to go back ward has he missed the address he needed to turn into. There was no damage to Vehicle 1. Driver of Vehicle 2 was seen by an EMTs but refused any medical assistance.

Vehicle 1 and 2 were both traveling west on E 3rd St. Vehicle 1 was in the left lane and vehicle 2 was in right lane. A vehicle that was not involved was attempting to turn south onto Park Ridge from E 3rd in front of vehicle 1. Vehicle 1 slowed for the turning vehicle and attempted to change to the right lane to go around the vehicle. Driver of vehicle 1 stated that he checked his mirrors before changing lanes but failed to see vehicle 2. Driver of vehicle 1 signaled and began changing lanes. Vehicle 2 was already next to vehicle 1 when it began to change lanes. Vehicle 1 then collided with Vehicle 2 causing moderate damage to the front passenger side of vehicle 1 and moderate damage to the front driver's side of vehicle 2. No injuries were reported and both vehicles were able to drive from the scene.

AT THE TIME OF THE HIT AND RUN, NO OCCUPANTS IN V1, WHICH WAS PARKED ON THE SOUTH SIDE OF CVS PARKING LOT IN THE NORTHERN MOST ROW. W1 STATED THAT THEY OBSERVED WHAT LOOKED LIKE AN OLDER MODEL WHITE NISSAN SENTRA WITH TWO OCCUPANTS BACK IN TO V1 AS V2 WAS ATTEMPTING TO REVERSE AND THEN LEFT THE SCENE.SUPPLEMENT 5/27/19 @ 1601 HOURS: CHANGED PRIMARY CAUSE OF ACCIDENT TO UNSAFE BACKING. D1 INFO WAS REMOVED, AS THERE WAS NO DRIVER IN V1. PRINTED OUT FIELD FORM FOR RECORDS.

Unit 1 was West bound on Kent road. Unit 2 was East bound on Kent road. Both Unit 1 and Unit 2 attempted to get off the road as much as possible without going into the ditch. Glass flew into the passenger side window causing an abrasion on the face of Unit 2's passenger. V2 was parked in a parking spot facing southwest at 528 S College Avenue, Kroger. D1 STATED SHE WAS PULLING SOUTH OUT OF HER DRIVEWAY. D1 STATED SHE DID NOT SEE V2 AND PULLED INTO THE ROADWAY CAUSING HER VEHICLE TO COLLIDE WITH V2 AND CAUSING DAMAGE TO BOTH VEHICLES. D2 STATED SHE WAS DRIVING WEST OF W. 7TH ST. D2 STATED SHE DID NOT SEE V1. D2 STATED V1 HIT HER IN THE PASSENGER SIDE OF HER VEHCILE CAUSING DAMAGE TO BOTH VEHICLES.

V2 WAS STOPPED AT STOPLIGHT, FACING N/B ON S WALNUT ST. V2 APPROACHED FROM THE REAR, REAR ENDING V2, CAUSING SLIGHT DAMAGE. D1 WAS DESCRIBED AS WHITE MALE, 60'S, HEAVY SEAT. Vehicle 1 was traveling northbound on I69 just south of the 114 mile marker when it struck a deer in the roadway. Vehicle 1 sustained minor damage and was driven from the scene.Vehicle 1, a White 2011 Dodge Charger was traveling northbound on I69 near the 114 mile marker in the left lane when a deer entered the roadway. Vehicle 1 swerved in an attempt to avoid striking the deer but was unsuccessful and struck the deer with the front bumper on the passenger side. Vehicle 1 sustained minor cosmetic damage to the front bumper as well as to the wheel liner for the front passenger side tire. Vehicle 1 was driven from the scene.Driver 1, Caleb Garvin, stated he was traveling northbound on I69 near the 114 mile marker when a deer entered the roadway from the east side of the road traveling westbound. Garvin stated he attempted an evasive maneuver to avoid striking the deer but was unsuccessful. Garvin was not injured in the crash and drove the vehicle from the scene.

AT APPROXIMATLY 1525 HOURS I OFFICER DUSTIN WHITE WAS DISPATCHED TO A MINOR REAR END COLLISION AT 8120 WEST STATE ROAD 46. ONCE ARRIVING ON SCENE I NOTICED THAT UNIT 1 HAD STRUCK THE BACK OF UNIT 2. THEY BOTH STATED THT THEY WENT TO PULL OVER FROM TWO COUNTY DEPUITES THAT HAD THIER EMERGENCY LIGHTS ON AND UNIT 1 COULD NOT STOP IN ENOUGH TIME WHICH HE ENDED UP MAKING CONACT WITH UNIT 2. THE DRIVER OF UNIT 1 AND HIS PSSENGERS ALL DENIED TO GO TO THE HOSPITAL. UNIT 2 DRIVER DENIED THE SAME HOWEVER UNIT 2'S PASSENGER COMPLIANED OF NECK PAIN BUT REFUESD TREATMENT.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: V1 was traveling E/B on 10th St. V2 was traveling N/B on Walnut ST. V1 failed to yield right of way and struck V2 causing damage to both vehicles.D1 advised that he was traveling E/B on 10th ST. D1 advised that while traveling E/B his traffic control signal was green. D1 advised that he proceeded through intersection before striking the side of V2. D1 advised that he did not see or hear the emergency vehicle of V2.D1 stated that he was traveling at 35mph. D1 advised that he had a complaint of pain to his left wrist and was treated on scene. D2 advised that he was traveling N/B on Walnut ST. D2 advised that while traveling N/B, he had emergency lights and sirens activated when he slowed down to clear the intersection of Walnut and 10th ST. D2 advised that he then saw V1 traveling at a high rate of speed as V2 was already half way through the intersection. D2 advised that V1 struck V2 causing damage. D2 was not injured. W1 advised that he was in the passenger seat of V2. W1 advised that D2 cleared the intersection with his emergency lights and sirens activated before proceeding through the intersection. W1 stated that he then felt the impact of V1. Due to V1 failing to yield, V1 struck V2 causing damage to both vehicles.Corrections on 5/28/2019 by Sgt Hines 1551. In the narrative the sentence "V1 failed to yield right of way and struck V2 causing damage to both vehicles" was changed to "V1 failed to yield right of way and struck V2 causing damage to both vehicles."Also V2 vehicle information was corrected to the correct information for the fire truck, and the owners information was also corrected to the correct owners information.

Unit 1 was travelling southbound on ST RD 446. Approximaltely 1/2 mile North of the intersection of E Pine Grove Rd, a deer ran in the roadway from the East. Unit 1 impacted with the deer and caused disabling damage to the vehicle. Unit 1 managed to pull off the road. Unit 1 was pulling a fishing which suffered no damage.

Upon arrival on scene I observed a barbed wire fence that had been driven through and had sustained damage with debris along the ground. Fire personnel was on scene prior to my arrival and treating a male subject, later identified as Joseph Ciodyk. I observed another male subject laying face up next to a motorcycle that was upright inside the field and fence. The male subject, later identified as the victim Trenton Mullis appeared to sustain an extreme laceration from the barb wire fence as there was blood and pieces of skin along the fence, the roadway, and in the field up to his body. Trenton also sustained minor abrasions and lacerations to his arms and legs, no helmet was located on scene. Medical personnel arrived on scene and determined that Trenton was deceased. Trenton and the scene were photographed. I spoke to Joseph who advised that they were both riding motorcycles and Trenton was test driving his motorcycle. Joseph noted that they turned onto North Stinesville Road from West State Road 46 and began traveling northbound. I asked Joseph if they were speeding he stated he was not sure, that he was probably going too fast so if Trenton was trying to keep up it was possible. The Coroner arrived on scene and Trenton was later transported by ambulance to IU Health Bloomington Hospital. The motorcycle was towed by Pritchards.
Driver stated they were traveling westbound on SR 45 where W Elwren Rd intersects into SR 45 when a deer ran into the roadway from the south and collided with the rear side of their vehicle.

V1 WAS TRAVELING WESTBOUND ON W SR 46 WHEN V2 BEGAN TO EXIT MCDONALDS AND MERGE INTO WESTBOUND TRAFFIC. AS V2 MERGED IT STRUCK V1 ON THE DRIVERS SIDE CAUSING MINOR PAINT DAMAGE. ACCORDING TO D1, AFTER THE COLLISION SHE STOPPED AND WAITED FOR APPROXIMATELY 5 MINUTES AND ATTEMPTED TO HAVE D2 EXIT HIS VEHICLE TO EXCHANGE INFORMATION; HOWEVER, D2 SHOOK HIS HEAD NO AND EVENTUALLY LEFT HEADING WESTBOUND. D1 WAS ABLE TO GET A LICENSE PLATE NUMBER FOR V2 AS IT WAS LEAVING AND SAID LICENSE PLATE RETURNS TO A JEEP CHEROKEE THAT IS REGISTERED IN OWEN COUNTY. I HAVE BEEN UNABLE TO MAKE CONTACT WITH D2 AND I WILL SUPPLEMENT IF I MAKE CONTACT.D1 INITIALLY WENT TO THE ELLETTSVILLE POLICE DEPARTMENT TO REPORT THE ACCIDENT BUT WAS INFORMED, INCORRECTLY, THAT THE ACCIDENT OCCURRED IN COUNTY JURISDICTION. D1 THEN CAME TO THE SHERIFFS OFFICE TO REPORT THE ACCIDENT.

V-1 is a State of Indiana owned vehicle, commission number 1869. V-1 was backing from a parking spot on the west side of a parking lot for Starbucks located at 284 Jacob Drive. V-2 was in a parking spot in the same parking lot as V-1. However, V-2 was parked one space north and on the east side of the parking lot from V-1. V-2 was also backing from a parking space.Both driver's stated that they were backing from a parking lot and backed into each other. D-2 further stated that he was backed out far enough that he was about to place his vehicle in drive when the vehicles crashed.Crash Photos taken and submitted by Trp Jeremy Cox.

This accident occurred just North of E Kirkwood Ave on N Walnut Street. Vehicle 1 (V1) was driving northbound on N Walnut Street when it ran off the roadway and struck Vehicle 2 (V2), which was parked on side street parking. Witness 1 (W1) advised that he was standing on the corner of N Walnut St and E Kirkwood Ave when he heard a loud crash. W1 stated that he observed a black Honda strike a black Ford Mustang that was parked on side street parking. W1 reported that he then observed the black Honda to not slow down and continue northbound on N Walnut Street. W1 described the black Honda as having a loud exhaust pipe and the trunk to be open. Witness (2) explained that she was located two vehicles behind a black Honda Civic. W2 stated that she had been behind the vehicle since the area of S Walnut Street and E Grimes Street. W2 explained that she observed the Honda Civic to run off the road and hit (V2) just north of the E Kirkwood Avenue intersection. W2 advised that she then observed the Honda Civic to leave the scene northbound on N Walnut Street. W2 advised that she followed the vehicle for a period of time. W2 reported that she took a photograph of the license plate on the vehicle. W2 provided me with a copy of the photograph. In the photograph you can observe the trunk to be open on the vehicle as W1 had described.I then was able to observe video footage from the local restaurant, Malibu Grill. In the video footage you can view V1 strike V2 and continue to leave the scene northbound.The car was bearing IN license plate 287REZ. It should be noted that this plate does not return to a Honda Civic, but a black 2004 Chevy Impala. The plate returned to a Zachary Huelsman in Bloomington, IN.I was then able to contact the owner of V2, who provided me with insurance information for his vehicle in order to work on the vehicle exchange information. I informed him that there was damage to both wheel panels on the driver's side of the vehicle. I also explained that was minor damage to the front bumper and the driver's side side mirror had been broken off. I was later able to locate V1 at the address of Huelsman. The vehicle had matching damage on the right front passenger side of the vehicle. Huelsman would not speak with me in regards to the vehicle or accident. If any more information is obtained this report will be supplemented accordingly.

V1 WAS BACKING OUT OF THE DRIVEWAY OF 7585 W AIRPORT ROAD WHEN IT STRUCK V2 AT A RIGHT ANGLE. D1 ADVISED THAT AS HE WAS BACKING OUT HE WAS WAVED ON BY ANOTHER DRIVER WHO WAS WAITING IN THE ROADWAY. D1 DID NOT SEE V2 DUE TO THE FACT THAT IT WAS PARKED IN THE ROADWAY DIRECTLY BEHIND HIM. THERE WERE FLAGGERS ON BOTH ENDS OF THE CONTRUCTION AND SIGNAGE WAS POSTED ALONG THE ROADWAY.

Walnut Street at Hillside Avenue is a multiple lane undivided roadway with two or more lanes in each direction that primarily runs north and south. Vehicle 1 (white Buick passenger car) was traveling north on Walnut Street at Hillside Avenue, in the far right lane.Vehicle 2 (white Dodge Darango) was traveling north on Walnut Street at Hillside Avenue, in the far right lane. Driver 1 (Thomas) stated he was traveling north on Walnut Street, behind Vehicle 2. Driver 1 stated there was a UPS truck, in front of Vehicle 2, with its four way flashers activated. Driver 1 stated that all three vehicles were stopped at a red light, at Hillside Avenue, when the light turned green, the UPS truck proceeded North through the intersection and came to a stop just north of the intersection, causing Vehicle 2 to come to a stop abruptly. Driver 1 stated he was unable to come to a stop before rear-ending Vehicle 2. Driver 2 (Wickizer) stated she was traveling behind a UPS truck that had stopped to make a delivery just south of Hillside Avenue. Driver 2 stated that the UPS driver got back in the UPS truck and proceeded to travel north on Walnut before coming to a stop at a red light at Hillside Avenue. Driver 2 stated that when the light turned green, the UPS truck proceeded through the intersection, turned its four way flashers on and came to a stop just north of Hillside Avenue. Driver 2 stated she came to a stop behind the UPS truck and was rear-ended by Vehicle 2.Based upon driver's statements, this officer determines primary cause of the crash to be speed too fast to avoid collision by Driver 1.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY

V1 failed to yield the right of way and pulled out to turn left and was struck by V2 in the driver side rear quarter panel. She stated she didn't see V2 coming until she was already committed to the turn. She stated she tried to speed up but was hit by V2. Upon arrival Driver 1 was located on the ground outside his residence, located at 315 West Gordon Pike Trailer 2. I observed the male to have abrasions on his arms and legs and additional a compound fraction to his left forearm. Fire and medical personnel had began treating Driver 1 who was later transported to IU Health Bloomington Hospital due to his compound fracture, medical personnel advised additional he might have internal injuries as well. I spoke with two witnesses on scene. Witness 1 stated she was facing westbound attempting to turn into 315 West Gordon Pike when she saw Driver 1 traveling westbound towards her at a high rate of speed. Witness 1 stated Driver 1 attempted to brake to slow down however was unable to do so and he down his bike sliding down the roadway westbound into a small rock pile. Witness 1 stated Driver 1 then quickly got up and proceeded to his residence. Witness 2 also provided the same statement as she was outside facing the north and 315 West Gordon Pike. I did photograph the scene and observed long skid marks then scrap marks which ended in a small rock pile. Vehicle 1 sustained damage along the right side however it was moved prior to my arrival and was left at Driver 1's residence. Driver 1 stated he was traveling westbound and got behind Witness 1 who had their turn signal but was still in the westbound lane and not in the median. Driver 1 stated he might have been speeding but tried going around Witness 1 as he was also going to turn into 315 West Gordon Pike, at that time he stated Witness 1 got back over which resulted in him losing control and wrecking.

V1 Was traveling southeast on S Sare Road when D1 stated he fell asleep at the wheel as he was entering the round about at S Sare Road and E Rogers Road.D1 stated he drove up over the center median, back into the roadway on the south side of the roundabout and into the curb on the south-side of the roundabout and came to a stop.

9305-30-2019V2 was traveling west on E 10th Street in front of V1. V2 was attempting to turn off of E. 10th Street to turn right onto a private drive to get to work while V1 was continuing to travel west on E 10th Street behind V2. D1 stated that she was traveling behind V2 and did not realize that V2 was making a right hand turn off of E 10th Street onto the unnamed road. D1 also stated that she was distracted due to personal family issues at the time. Due to not seeing V2 attempting to make a right hand turn, V1 hit the left rear portion of V2 with the front right portion of her vehicle. D1 stated she was traveling around 25 miles per hour.D2 stated that she was traveling west on E. 10th Street and was attempting to make a right hand turn onto the unnamed road to get to work. She stated that she saw V1 approaching behind her and initiated her right turn signal with enough time for D1 to realize that she was turning off of the road. She stated V1 continued to get closer and collided with her vehicle while she was attempting to make the turn onto the unnamed road.D2 complained of back and neck pain when I arrived on scene. I requested EMS be sent to the scene. IU Health Ambulance Service unit 2164 arrived and checked out D2's complaint of pain. D2 was not transported but stated she would be going to the doctor at a later time.Chandler's Automotive towed V2 via Dolly Tow to Royal South Toyota at the request of D2.

D1 STATED HE WOKE UP AND REALIZED HE HAD CRASHED INTO THE GUARDRAIL AT THIS EXIT RAMP.

V1 was parked in a parallel parking spot across the street from 808 N College Avenue.V1 was struck in the rear by V2 sometime between 8:30am and 11:00am. There were no cameras in the area and no witnesses.

THE REPORTING PERSON, THE DAUGHTER OF OWNER OF V2, BELIEVES THAT AN UNKNOWN V1 WAS ATTEMPTING TO BACK OUT OF A PARKING LOT LOCATED TO THE SOUTH OF HER VEHICLE WHICH WAS PARKED FACING WB IN FRONT OF 517 E 14TH STREET. THE REPORTING PERSON STATED THAT SHE BELIEVES AS V1 WAS ATTEMPTING TO BACK OUT OF THE PARKING LOT, THE REAR OF V1 COLLIDED WITH THE REAR DRIVERS SIDE QUARTERPANEL OF V2 CAUSING DAMAGE TO THE AREA AROUND THE GAS COVER.

BOTH VEHICLES WERE EXITING SOUTH BOUND I-69, ONTO WEST BOUND SR 45 (BLOOMFIELD RD). D1 SAID THAT SHE THOUGHT V2 HAD PULLED OUT, AND STARTED FORWARD, REAR ENDING V2.D2 SAID HE WAS TRYING TO MERGE ONTO SR 45, AND WAS REAR ENDED BY V1.NO REPORTED INJURIES.

D1 stated he was traveling southbound on N Madison St approaching a stopped V2 at the intersection of W 17th St. D1 stated the light turned green and he thought D2 was accelerating. D1 stated he then rear ended V2. D2 stated she was sitting at a red light on N Madison St facing south. D2 stated after the light turned green V1 rear ended her V2.D2 stated she did have pain in her back from the accident, but reported prior history of back surgery.

D1 stated that they had merged on to the exit ramp 117 towards state road 45 from southbound I69. D1 stated that when merging on to west state road 45 from the exit ramp, V2 was in front of them near the merging area, where there was a yield sign. D1 stated they had gotten too close to V2 when both vehicles were looking for oncoming traffic in order to merge, and ended up striking the rear of V2.D2 stated they were yielding to oncoming traffic while attempting to merge on to west state road 45 from the exit ramp at exit 117 when they felt V1 strike the rear of their vehicle.

Driver of vehicle 1 stated that he did not notice traffic had stopped in front of him before he hit vehicle 2 in the rear. Vehicle 1 sustained moderate front end damage including radiator damage. Driver of vehicle 2 stated he was stopped in traffic when vehicle 1 struck his vehicle from behind. Vehicle 2 sustained damage to rear bumper.Driver of vehicle 1 was cited for driving on a suspended license/prior (IC 9-24-19-2), Operating a motor vehicle with false plate (IC 9-18.1-4-5(a)(1)), and Operating a motor vehicle without financial responsibility -(IC 9-25-8-2)

Manner of Collision: HEAD ON BETWEEN TWO MOTOR VEHICLES
NARRATIVE: V1 was traveling north bound on Pete Ellis Dr and attempted to turn right onto Braeside Dr. V2 was traveling west on Braeside Dr. V1 crossed left of center and struck V2.D1 stated that there was a vehicle behind her that was following to close and forced her off the roadway. D1 was turning into Braeside Dr and she was unable to avoid striking V2.D1 stated she was traveling westbound on Braeside Dr and was approaching the intersection. She was slowing for the stop sign when V1 crossed left of center and struck her.V1 did drive left of center and struck V2 causing damage to both vehicles.

V1 was traveling South on I69 in the area of Mile Marker 120.5 when V1 struck a deer in the roadway. The deer was thrown from the roadway and found under the guard rail median. V1 sustained moderate damage to the front end of the vehicle. D1 stated that he was not injured during the crash and did not require medical attention at the time. V1 was drivable.D1 is a Police Detective with the Bloomington Police Department and a Task Force Officer with the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, and Firearms. D1 was working in these capacities at the time of the crash. D1 submitted to a PBT at the scene which returned a result of 0.00% Breath Alcohol Content.

9305-31-2019Officer Skaggs assisted on scene with information gathering and traffic control.Both vehicles were traveling northbound on N. Jordan Ave. V2 was turning left to travel westbound onto University Ave while V1 was traveling north bound on N. Jordan Ave the wrong way in the south bound lane.V2 was traveling north on N. Jordan Ave and turned into the left turn lane to turn onto University Ave. When D2 saw no one was traveling southbound on N. Jordan Ave, she made the turn to travel west onto University Ave. As she was crossing thought he southbound lane of N. Jordan Ave, V2 was struck by V1, which was traveling north on N. Jordan Ave in the south bound lane. The front portion of V1 struck the driver side door of V2.V2 was towed due to the damage sustained by V1. Ken's Westside Tow took the vehicle form the scene. V1 was towed due to the vehicle not being insured. The driver of V2 was cited for being unable to provide proof of financial responsibility for the vehicle. Ken's Westside Towing transported the vehicle. There is a hold on the vehicle until valid proof of financial responsibility can be provided. The driver of V2 stated that he had insurance on his personal car, however he was not on the policy for V2. Officer Skaggs advised D2 that the burden to prove financial responsibility is on him, and if his insurance is going to cover him driving another vehicle, he needs to contact us with that information to be added with the report, have them fill out the SR-21 showing the state that he has insurance. After completing those steps, if he is found to have financial responsibility, he was advised to go to the clerk's office with questions regarding his citation.Photos of the vehicles were taken on scene. An SD card containing images of the vehicles was turned in as evidence to be attached to this case.

V2 was driving West on E 3rd Street. V1 was following V2. V2 began to slow due to traffic. V1 then collided with the rear of V2 causing minor damage. Driver of V2 had a complaint of pain in her right leg. Front passenger had complaint of pain in her lower back. All involved refused medical treatment on scene.

Interstate 69 near the 107 mile marker is a rural interstate with a grass median. The highway primarily runs in a northeast-southwest direction. Vehicle # 1 is a tri-axle tank truck carrying a water/oil mixture. Vehicle # 1 was traveling northeast on Interstate 69. Vehicle # 1 ran off the south side of the highway and struck the end of a guard rail, bending part of the guard rail forcing it to block the right lane. The vehicle continued over the guard rail and guard rail posts eventually striking a flashing signal and post, along with the 107 mile marker post. The vehicle flipped/rolled and came to rest on the passenger's side on top of the guard rail facing north. During the course of the events, the tank dislodged from vehicle # 1and came to rest in a ditch. Both lanes of the northbound interstate were periodically closed with periodic right lane closure. On Saturday June 1, 2019, I spoke to witness # 1 and learned she was northbound on the interstate following vehicle # 1 in the left lane. Witness # 1 was preparing to pass vehicle # 1 that was in the right lane. Witness # 1 said vehicle # 1 did not appear to be speeding. Witness # 1 said the vehicle crossed the fog line and struck the guard rail. On Sunday June 2, 2019, I attempted to interview driver # 1. This crash remains incomplete pending my interview with driver # 1. On the evening on Wednesday June 5, 2019, I spoke to driver # 1 and learned he dozed off prior to running off the roadway. Driver # 1 denied having used any prescriptions or illegal drugs. This crash was supplemented on June 6, 2019 and reflects the changes.

93 05-31-2019Object name (see in narrative) - An outdoor event tent supported by metal poles.V1 was backing (northeast) on a private drive near the grandstands at Bill Armstrong stadium. V1 was slowly backing his street sweeper vehicle and collided with an outdoor event tent. D1 stated the sun was in his eyes as he was backing the vehicle and could not see how close he was to the tent. The rear left portion of V1 collided with a metal pole supporting the tent. The collision caused minor scraping damage to V1 and bent the metal support pole for the tent.An SD card containing photos of the damage to V1 and the tent pole was submitted as evidence to be attached to this case.

Driver 1 stated she was westbound on SR46 in the right lane approaching the intersection with SR 446. Driver 1 stated that just before the intersection, a vehicle that was traveling in the left lane of SR 46 next to her suddenly swerved into her lane. Driver 1 stated she swerved to the right to avoid colliding with the vehicle and in doing so, collided with the curb along the north side of SR 46. The driver of the other vehicle, David Notz, stayed at the scene and advised that he had been westbound on SR 46 approaching SR 446 in the left lane. Mr Notz advised that a pickup truck pulling a boat was stopped in front of him in the left lane of SR 46, waiting to turn left without a turn signal, as he came around the curve. Mr Notz advised he swerved to the right to avoid colliding with the boat trailer as vehicle 1 was passing him, which resulted in vehicle 1 running off the roadway. There was no collision between vehicle 1 and Mr Notz's car.

D1 BACKED INTO AN UNOCCUPIED V2 WHILE IN THE PARKING LOT OF KROGER NORTH. IMMEDIATELY AFTER THE COLLISION A PASSENGER IN V1 ADVISED D1 THAT SHE BACKED INTO THE VEHICLE BEHIND HER AND TOLD HER TO LEAVE. D1 THEN LEFT THE SCENE WITHOUT PROVIDING INFORMATION TO THE OWNER OF V2 WHO WITNESSED THE COLLISION. LATER AT D1'S ADDRESS OFFICERS MITCHELL AND MCGLONE ADVISED THAT D1 STATED SHE PANICKED AND LEFT THE SCENE. V1 HAS DAMAGE TO THE REAR PASSENGER SIDE BUMPER IN THE FORM OF PAINT TRANSFER AND SCRAPES. FRONT BUMPER ON V2 WAS DISLODGED.

Vehicle 1 was traveling westbound on Tapp Road going through the traffic circle at Adams Street when it struck a curb causing disabling damage to the driver's side front tire. No injuries were reported in the crash and Vehicle 1 was towed from the scene.Vehicle 1, a black 2017 Ford Explorer, was traveling westbound on Tapp Road going through the traffic circle. As it exited the traffic circle to continue westbound on Tapp Road, Vehicle 1 struck the curb on the center median dividing east and westbound traffic on Tapp Road. Vehicle 1 sustained disabling damage to the driver's side front tire when it struck the curb and came to a rest in the roadway just west of the intersection. Vehicle 1 was towed from the scene by Ken's Westside due to the disabling damage.Driver 1, Kobe Davis, stated he was on his way home from a high school graduation party and was traveling westbound on Tapp Road going through the traffic circle at Adams Street. Driver 1 stated as he entered the traffic circle, he saw a vehicle traveling southbound on Adams Street approaching the intersection at a high rate of speed. Driver 1 did not think the vehicle was going to stop in time for the intersection and over-steered to the left to avoid a possible collision. Driver 1 stated he could not correct in time and struck the east most part of the curb and traveled along it until he was able to correct back to the right. At that time, the driver's side front tire locked up and became inoperable. Driver 1 stated he was not injured in the accident and submitted to a PBT on scene which returned a reading of .000% BAC.

D2 STATED HE WAS DRIVING SOUTH IN FRONT OF 140 N. GATES DR (FIVE BELOW). D2 STATED V1 WAS DRIVING DIRECTLY TOWARDS HIM. D2 STATED V1 SWIPED THE SIDE OF HIS VEHICLE BREAKING HIS DRIVERS SIDE MIRROR. D2 STATED V1 THEN TURNED WEST ONTO THE SIDEWALK, BACK UP, AND DROVE OFF.THE FRONT SEAT PASSENGER STATED V1 WAS DRIVING DIRECTLY AT THEM AS THEY TRAVELLED SOUTH IN FRONT OF FIVE BELOW. THE FRONT SEAT PASSENGER STATED V1 SWIPED THE SIDE OF THEIR VEHICLE THEN DROVE ONTO THE SIDEWALK BEFORE DRIVING AWAY.

V2 WAS UNOCCUPIED AND PARKED IN A PARKING SPOT OF LOWE'S FACING SB. V1 WAS BACKING OUT OF A SPOT WITH NEXT TO V2. AS V1 WAS BACKING THE REAR OF V1 GOT STUCK ON THE REAR BASKET OF V2. THE WITNESS ALERTED D1 THAT HE WAS CAUGHT AND HELPED D1 ADJUST V1. THERE WAS DAMAGE TO THE BASKET OF V2 AND IT IS UNKNOWN IF THERE IS MORE DAMAGE TO THE UNDERSIDE OF V2. D1 ADVISED THERE WAS NO DAMAGE TO V1.

This collision took place at 5167 East State Road 46 at Longs Landing Furniture's parking lot.Vehicle 2 (2008 Honda Civic) was parked in a parking spot on the east side of the parking lot. Vehicle 1 (2019 White GMC W3500) was parked next to V2, just north of V2. V1 backed up, and struck V2 in the back left side of the vehicle. V1 caused damage to its own back right side, and damage to V2's back left side. Driver 1 (Alexandrea McIntosh) stated that she was parked to the left of V2. D1 stated that she backed up, and turned too sharp and struck V2. V2 was not occupied during the crash, but the owner of the vehicle provided all necessary information to the investigating officer. Based off the facts and circumstances, I have determined the primary cause to the crash was unsafe backing. No citations were issued at the scene of the crash.
V2 was parked facing South on N Washington Street behind V3, which was also parked facing South. V1 approached from the North and sideswiped V2, causing V2 to collide with V3.

BOTH OCCUPANTS STATED THAT AFTER ENTERING INTO A CURVE TOO FAST, THE DRIVER LOST CONTROL AND RAN OFF THE ROADWAY. THE VEHICLE SPUN AROUND, AND THE DRIVER'S SIDE BRAKE LIGHT IMPACTED A FENCE POST. THERE WAS MINIMAL DAMAGE TO THE FENCE POST.

UNIT 1 ARRIVED AT THE PARKING LOT AT 8 AM FOR WORK. WHEN SHE ARRIVED AT HER CAR IN THE EVENING, SHE BAGAN TO BACK UP TO LEAVE. AS SHE WAS BACKING UNIT 1 OUT OF THE PARKING SPOT, SHE HEARD A NOISE COME FROM THE BUMPER. THE DRIVER OF UNIT 1 OBSERVED THAT HER BUMPER WAS RIPPED OFF DUE TO THE BALL HITCH OF THE TRUCK THAT BACKED INTO THE SPOT IN FRONT OF HER. AFTER CONTACTING THE OWNER OF THE TRUCK, HE STATED THAT HE PARKED HIS TRUCK, BUT DID NOT HEAR THE HITCH CONTACT THE FRONT BUMPER OF UNIT 1. HE STATED THE BLUE FORD FOCUS WAS THERE PRIOR TO HIS ARRIVAL.

D1 stated that she was coming around a corner and was looking at another police vehicle which was sitting on the side of the road. She stated that she didn't see V2 slowing in the road to assist the other officer. D2 stated he was slowing down to assist another officer and observed V1 traveling at a high rate of speed approaching from the rear. D2 stated that he attempted to drive forward to avoid the accident but was unable to.W1 stated that V2 slowed down in the roadway to check on his status, at which time V1 came around the curb and collided into the rear of V2.

On June 2nd 2019 at approximately 00:25 hours I was dispatched to 1405 W 13th Street in reference to an accident LSA. Upon arrival, I met with owner of Vehicle 2. She explained that she was sitting on her back porch when she observed a dark colored, believed to be black, Chrysler 300 back into her vehicle. She stated that the vehicle was backing up at a fast pace from a parking space across from her vehicle. She explained that once the vehicle struck hers, she immediately approached the suspect vehicle but the individual fled the area. It should be noted that the owner has seen the suspect vehicle in the area before and will try to get a plate number at a later date. I did observe V2 parked facing northbound in the very northwest stall in the parking area behind 1331 W 13th Street. The vehicle had minor damage to the rear bumper consistent with the complainant's story. On June 2nd 2019 at approximately 21:40 hours I was contacted by Officer Penter in regards to this case. He explained that V1 had been located and that he had spoken to D1 who took responsibility for the accident. I went to D1's residence. I observed V1 parked out on the street with damage to the rear bumper consistent with the damage to V2 and the story given by the owner of V2. I then spoke with D1. He explained that he had been in an accident the night before in the parking lot and that was his fault. He explained that he believed he had struck a trash can, but did not get out of his vehicle to check the damage. He explained that he had already given the owner of V2 his insurance and personal information with Officer Penter. I issued D1 a misdemeanor citation for leaving the scene of an accident. Due to V1's unsafe backing resulted in the collision between V1 and V2.

V1 HIT V2 WITH A CAMPER THAT IT WAS TOWING AT 4895 S SR 446. V1 PULLED INTO THE PARKING LOT AND MADE A WIDE 180 DEGREE TURN SO IT COULD BACK THE CAMPER UP TO A PARKING SPOT. WHILE TURNING, V1 HIT V2 WHICH WAS PARKED NEAR A BUILDING FACING EAST. D1 STATED THAT HE HIT V2 WHILE ATTEMPTING TO MAKE A TURN. FOLLOWING THE COLLISION, V1 AND V2 MOVED FROM THE POINT OF COLLSION. THEREFORE NO DIAGRAM COMPLETED.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: V1 WAS AT THE STOP SIGN WAITING TO TURN EB ONTO N OLD STATE ROAD 37 OFF ON N DUNN STREET. V2 WAS TRAVELING WB ON N OLD STATE ROAD 37. V1 ATTEMPTED TO ENTER THE TRAFFIC LANE AND AS D1 PULLED OUT ONTO N OLD STATE ROAD 37, THE FRONT OF V1 AND THE DRIVERS SIDE OF V2 COLLIDED. V2 PROCEEDED TO RUN OFF THE ROAD INTO A SMALL DITCH STRIKING A BIKE ROUTE STREET SIGN KNOCKING IT OUT OF THE GROUND. D1 STATED THAT HE ATTEMPTED TO ENTER THE TRAFFIC LANE AND DID NOT SEE V2. D1 STATED HE SAW A DODGE CHALLENGER TRAVELING EB ON N OLD STATE ROAD 37 AND COULD NOT SUCCESSFULLY ENTER THE TRAFFIC LANE AND ENDED UP COLLIDING WITH V2.D2 STATED THAT V1 PULLED OUT INTO TRAFFIC STRIKING THE DRIVER'S SIDE OF HIS VEHICLE.

Driver 1 states that he was transporting two subjects from downtown Bloomington to East Chambers Pike in Bloomington for Uber when something struck the front passenger side of his vehicle. Driver 1 does not know the exact location of the collision and states that he and his passengers exited the vehicle immediately after the collision and were unable to locate the object that caused the damage. Driver 1 was not familiar with the general area of the collision and was not able to find a way to contact the passengers that he was transporting due to the Uber ride being closed. Driver 1 described exiting I69 onto sample road and traveling along the east side of the interstate on an access road to chambers pike. The area described by driver 1 and the GPS route map from the Uber transaction show that he was on Wayport road from Sample Road to Chambers Pike. This area was checked by Deptuties, however no damage or debris was located in this area. Chambers Pike from Simpson Chapel to North Old State Road 37 was also checked and no damage was located. Driver 1's front passenger quarter panel and headlight were damaged, however no hair, blood, or any other material transfer was evident to indicate what kind of object struck the vehicle.Driver 1 appeared normal and had no indicators of impairment or deception during the investigation and seemed genuinely unfamiliar with the area. Areas of thick fog were also present along I69 and surrounding areas due to recent rainfall.
V1 WAS STRUCK IN THE DRIVER'S SIDE REAR BUMPER WHILE THE OWNER WAS INSIDE WALMART AT 3585 W SR 45 SOMETIME BETWEEN 1400-1430 ON 6/2/19.

V1, V2, V3, and V4 were traveling westbound on Tapp Rd. V1 struck V2 in the rear causing a chain reaction.D1 stated that she was having brake problems and was not able to stop to avoid V2 which was stopped in traffic.D2 and D3 stated that they were stopped in traffic and were hit from behind.D4 stated that he was stopped in traffic waiting for a car to turn when he was struck from behind. He stated that he had just started to accelerate when he was hit.V1 did strike V2 causing a chain reaction which caused damage to all vehicles.

V1 was parked in the Tieman Tire parking lot unoccupied while the owner was inside the business. When V1 was pulled into the building for service the owner noticed damage to the drivers door that wasn't there when he went in the business. The other vehicle involved in the accident had already left the parking lot. Tieman Tire was able to provide video footage of the accident from thier cameras on the outside of the business. The camera showed a red in color Honda Civic back into the drivers door of V1. Vehicle 2 then pulled forward and backed around V1 and left the parking lot.Tieman Tire was able to provide me with a license plate number of V2 and I was able to make contact with the driver of V2. D2 was backing out of the parking lot at Tieman Tire and turned too soon striking V1 in the drivers door. D2 stated that he was unaware that he struck a vehicle when he was backing out of the parking lot.

V1 WAS IN THE DRIVING LANE BEHIND V2 THATWAS IN A DESIGNATED PARKING AREA. WHEN V1 WAS ATTEMPTING TO BACK UP EAST BOUND INTO A PARKING AREA NEXT TO V2. V2 WAS ATTEMPTING TO BACK OUT OF D2 PARKING SPOT SOUTH BOUND WHEN V1 AND V2 COLLIDED WITH ONE ANOTHER.D1 STATED IT WAS D1'S FAULT AS HE WAS BACKING UP TO TALK TO HIS FRIEND.NO INJURIES ON SCENE.V2 SUSTAINED TAIL LIGHT DAMAGE, V1 SUSTAINED LEFT SIDE DAMAGE.

DRIVER 1 ADVISED HE WAS NB ON I69 SOUTH OF MM 120 WHEN HE EXITED THE ROAD SURFACE TRAVELED DOWN A STEEP HILL ACROSS A DITCH AND BACK UP ON THE OTHER SIDE OF THE DITCH. DRIVER 1 ADVISED HE BELIEVED HE MAY HAVE FALLEN ASLEEP. DRIVER 1 SUBMITTED TO SFST'S AND FAILED THEM AT THE ROADSIDE. DRIVER 1 WAS TRANSPORTED TO THE IU HEALTH BLOOMINGTON HOSPITAL FOR A BLOOD DRAW REFERENCE THE OWI INVESTIGATION BY DEPUTY WILLAMSON THE RESULTS OF WHICH ARE PENDING.WITNESS 1 ADVISED HE WAS PARKED ON THE SHOULDER OF THE I69 AT APPROXIMATELY THE 119.5 MM WHEN VEHICLE 1 NARROWLY MISSED STRIKING HIS TRUCK AND PROCEEDED AROUND THE GUARDRAIL AT A BREAK IN THAT LOCATION ON THE EAST SIDE OF THE ROAD AND TRAVLED DOWN THE EMBANKMENT THROUGH THE DITCH AND PARTIALLY UP ON THE OTHER SIDE. WITNESS 1 ADVISED VEHICLE 1 WAS TRAVELING AT WHAT APPEARED TO BE A HIGH RATE OF SPEED.

On 6/3/2019 at approximately 4:50pm, I, Officer Byerley, was dispatched to a personal injury accident at 804 N College Avenue.D1 of V1 and D2 of V2 were both driving South on College Avenue. D1 said she attempted to merge from the center lane to the left lane and then hit D2 on the right side of the vehicle.D2 said he was driving southbound in the left lane when D1 began merging left, striking his vehicle.Based on the damage to both vehicles, my investigation has yielded that while both vehicles were traveling southbound on N College Ave, D1 performed an unsafe lane movement, striking the front right passenger side of D2.

V1 and V2 were traveling W/B on 11th ST. V1 attempted to improperly pass V2 on the right and collided with V2. D1 advised that he was traveling W/B on 11th St. D1 advised that V2 was directly in front of him and he advised V1 left hand turn signal was on. D1 advised that he proceeded to go around V2 when he collided with V2. D1 did not have any injuries.D2 advised that he was traveling W/B on 11th ST. D2 advised that he proceeded W/B, when he was struck by V1. D2 advised that he never had his left turn signal on. D2 was not injured.Due to D1 improper lane usage, V1 struck V2.It should be noted that I corrected the diagram to this state report.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: D1 of V1 stated that he was driving East on SR 45. D2 of V2 stated that he was driving South on N. College Ave. D1 of V1 stated that he had a green light when he came close to the intersection and entered the intersection. D1 of V1 stated this is when he struck D2 of V2. D2 of V2 stated that he was in slowed traffic while driving South through the intersection of SR 45 and N. College Ave. D2 of V2 stated that he was trying to get through the intersection and was struck by V1. D2 of V2 stated that after initial impact, V2 spun around and hit V1 causing front end damage as well as passenger side damage from the initial impact.There was also a witness that stated that V2 was driving south and was slowed in traffic. The witness then stated that V1 had a green light and he heard the impact. Based on the witness statement and the damage to both vehicles. I determined that V1 did not yield to the traffic slowed in the intersection and therefore hit V2.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: V1 WAS TURNING W/B ON COUNTRY CLUB DR. V2 WAS TRAVELING E/B ON COUNTRY CLUB DR, ATTEMPTING TO TURN ONTO PRIVATE DRIVE. V1 PROCEEDED INTO THE INTERSECTION AND STRUCK V2. D1 ADVISED THAT HE WAS TURINING W/B ONTO COUNTRY CLUD DR. D1 ADVISED THAT TRAFFIC HAD CAME TO A COMPLETE STOP AS HE ENTERED INTO TRAFFIC. D1 ADVISED THAT HE THEN STRUCK V2. D1 ADVISED THAT HE DID NOT SEE V2 IN THE ROAD WAY. D1 DID NOT HAVE ANY INJURIES.D2 ADVISED THAT SHE WAS TRAVELING E/B ON COUNTRY CLUB, STOPPED IN TRAFFIC. D2 ADVISED THAT WHILE ATTEMPTING TO TURN ONTO PRIVATE DR, SHE FELT THE IMPACT OF V1. D1 ADVISED THAT SHE HAD A COMPLAINT OF PAIN TO HER BACK AND HEAD AND WAS TREATED ON SCENE. DUE TO D1 FAILURE TO YIELD, V1 STRUCK V2 CASUING DAMAGE TO V2.

D1 STATED HE WAS PARKED AT 2002 W 3RD ST. D1 STATED HE BEGAN BACKING UP INTO THE DRIVE BETWEEN 2002 W 3RD ST. AND THE NEIGHBORING BUSINESS. D1 STATED HE DID NOT SEE V2. D1 STATED HIS VEHICLE MADE CONTACT WITH V2 AND CAUSED DAMAGE TO BOTH.D2 STATED SHE WAS TURNING LEFT INTO THE DRIVE BETWEEN 1918 W 3RD ST. AND THE NEIGHBORING BUSINESS. D2 STATED SHE LOOKED BOTH WAYS AND BEGIN TO PULL INTO THE DRIVE WHEN V1 BACKED INTO THE FRONT PASSENGER SIDE OF HER VEHICLE CAUSING DAMAGE.

Unit 1 was parked in front of unit 2 in a unlined parking lot. While unit 2's driver was inside the store the driver of unit 1 got into his vehicle and began to back up when he made contact with the front of unit 2's vehicle.The driver of unit 1 was issued a citation for not having the proper vehicle identification paperwork after buying the vehicle. This report has been modified on 06-17-2019 at 1500 hours

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: Vehicle 2 was traveling south on Liberty Dr. Vehicle 1 was traveling north on Liberty Dr. Vehicle 1 was attempting to turn west in the parking lot of 2100 S Liberty Dr. Driver of vehicle 1 stated that she did not see vehicle 2 and turned in front of it. Driver of vehicle 2 stated that she did not see vehicle 1 turning and was unable to avoid hitting vehicle 1. Vehicle 2 struck vehicle 1 in the front passenger side door with the front of vehicle 2. Vehicle 1 has moderate damage to the front passenger door and vehicle 2 has minor damage to the front. Vehicle 1 failed to yield the right of way to vehicle 2 when turning into the parking lot. Driver of vehicle 2 was cited for leaner permit violation and operating without financial responsibility.

On 6/4/2019 at approximately 3:25 pm, I, Officer Byerley, was dispatched to attempt to locate a large black truck that had just been involved in an accident and had left the scene. The accident happened north of the Walnut St and E Blue Ridge Drive intersection in the northbound lane.D2 was following D1 heading N on Walnut just N of the intersection of E Blude Ridge Dr. D2 stated that D1 started veering to the right and off the road. D2 slowed down and then attempted to pass D1 on the left when D1 suddenly steered quickly to the left, impacting her vehicle down the entire passenger side of the vehicle. D2 came to a stop on the right side of the road while D1 was making a U-turn and drove away southbound on Walnut.D1 could not be located by officers. D2 could only describe D1 as a large black truck.

Driver 2 stated that he was driving Vehicle 2 east on E. Moores Pike while a vehicle in front of him slowed down to turn north on S. Fenbrook Ln. Driver 2 said he slowed down and at that moment Vehicle 1 struck Vehicle 2 in the rear. Driver 1 stated that she was driving Vehicle 1 east on Moores Pike and her vehicle collided with something. Driver 1 also stated that as a result of the collision, she lost control of vehicle 2 and her vehicle ran into the ditch located south edge of Moores Pike.D1 did have minor cuts to her hands and neck, but did refuse to go to the hospital. She was treated on scene.V1 was towed by Ken's Westside due to disabling damage to the vehicle.

D2 of Unit 2 stated that he was riding his bicycle west on W. Kirkwood Ave. D2 of Unit 2 stated that a truck was behind him and attempted to go around him. D2 of Unit 2 stated that the truck then got very close to him and possibly hit D2 of Unit 2 causing Unit 2 to crash. D2 stated that this happened at 03:20pm and reported it at the police department at 04:51pm. D2 of Unit 2 had some scraping and bruising but did not call 911 at 3:20pm when the incident occured.

D1 STATED HE WAS TRAVELLING WEST ON W 3RD ST. D1 STATED HE ATTEMPTED TO TURN SOUTH ONTO S. HICKORY DR. D1 STATED HE BEGAN SLIDING BECAUSE OF BAD FRONT TIRES. D1 STATED HE IMPACTED THE TRAILER OF THE VEHICLE CAUSING DAMAGE TO V1 ON THE DRIVERS SIDE.D2 STATED HE WAS STOPPED ON S. HICKORY DR. FACING NORTH WAITING TO TURN. D2 STATED D1 TURNED SOUTH ONTO S. HICKORY DR. D2 STATED D1 PUSHED HIS ACCELERATOR CAUSING HIS CAR TO LOSE CONTROL. D2 STATED D1 OVERCORRECTED HIS SLIDE CAUSING V1 TO CRASH INTO HIS TRAILER. D2 STATED HIS TRAILER SUSTAINED DAMAGE AS WELL AS V1.

DRIVER OF VEHICLE 2 STATED HE WAS WEST BOUND IN THE LEFT LANE ON THE SR 46 BYPASS, EAST OF N WALNUT STREET. A VEHICLE IN FRONT OF HIM BRAKED QUICKLY, SO D2 APPLIED HIS BRAKE. AT THAT TIME, V2 WAS REAR ENDED BY V1. DRIVER 2 PULLED TO THE NORTH SIDE OF THE ROAD WHILE V1 STOPPED IN THE MEDIAN. D1 TOLD D2 HE WAS GOING TO LOOK FOR A PLACE TO PULL OFF THE ROADWAY AND LEFT WEST ON SR 46. D2 COULD NOT LOCATE D1 FROM THAT POINT.
V2 WAS STOPPED AT THE LIGHT AT 46 AND SMITH. D2 STATED THAT HE WAS LOOKING AT HIS PHONE AND STRUCK V1. D1 ADMITTED HE WAS AT FAULT AS SOON AS I ASKED WHAT HAPPENED.
