This crash occurred on 3rd Street at the overpass of Interstate 69. This roadway is State Road 48 immediately west of the area of impact and 3rd Street at the area of impact. State Road 48 / 3rd Street is a multi-lane road that has a raised concrete curb in parts and double yellow dividing line in other areas. There are two lanes of travel for westbound traffic and two lanes of travel for eastbound traffic. The eastbound portion of the roadway at the crash site has two through lanes to travel eastbound on 3rd Street into Bloomington and two dedicated turn lanes to proceed northbound on Interstate 69. Environmental conditions at the time of the crash were clear, dry, no precipitation and approximately 71 degrees (according to a temperature gauge in my issued police vehicle). The time frame of this crash was at sunset and the position of the setting sun was in the line of sight for traffic proceeding westbound on 3rd Street.Vehicle 1, a white 2016 Dodge Charger, is a fully marked Indiana State Police commission. Vehicle 1 was facing eastbound on State Road 48 (also known as 3rd Street at the crash site) in the right most dedicated turn to proceed northbound on Interstate 69. Vehicle 1 started the process of turning from eastbound State Road 48 to northbound Interstate 69. Vehicle 1 was struck in the passenger rear door by the front of Vehicle 2. Vehicle 1 rotated approximately 90 degrees in a clockwise manner and came to rest facing eastbound in the right lane of westbound 3rd Street.Vehicle 2, a white 1993 GMC Sonoma, was westbound on 3rd Street. Vehicle 2 continued into the intersection where traffic eastbound on State Road 48 (3rd Street) makes a turn to proceed northbound on Interstate 69. The front of Vehicle 2 struck the passenger rear door of Vehicle 1.Driver 1 stated that he was at a complete stop facing eastbound on State Road 48 at an automatic signal. Driver 1 said that his dedicated turn indicator was red and that is why he was stopped. Driver 1 stated that his dedicated turn indicator changed from red to green and he began to make his turn to proceed northbound on Interstate 69. Driver 1 said that he then observed that Vehicle 2 did not appear to be stopping and he accelerated more in an attempt to avoid a collision. Driver 1 stated that the front of Vehicle 2 struck the rear passenger door area of Vehicle 1.Driver 2 stated that he was westbound on 3rd Street travelling approximately 30 to 35 mph. Driver 2 said that he could not see the automatic signal indicators due to the glare of the setting sun. Driver 2 stated that when he observed Vehicle 1 making its turn, he applied his brakes but was unable to stop in time. Driver 2 said that Vehicle 2 then struck Vehicle 1.Evidence at the scene included fresh tire marks in the left lane of westbound 3rd St. The tire marks began near the white stop line for westbound 3rd Street and continued to the area of impact between Vehicle 1 and Vehicle 2. These tire marks were consistent with a braking maneuver and consistent with the statement of Driver 2. I measured these tire marks to 41 feet 0 inches. I also observed tire marks that began near the area of impact and lead to the final rest of Vehicle 1. These marks were consistent with Vehicle 1 rotating after impact. The reported path of travel for Vehicle 1 from the white stop line of the right most dedicated turn lane on State Road 48 (3rd Street) eastbound to the area of impact was measured to be 56 feet 8 inches.The left lane of westbound 3rd Street, the lane of travel for Vehicle 2, is newer asphalt with some normal wear from vehicular traffic. I utilized a coefficient of friction scale provided by Trimble Forensics Reveal software in order to provide a speed determination range for Vehicle 2. Based on my observation of the roadway at the scene and the statement of Driver 2, I used a coefficient of friction range of .55 to 1.2. Using this information and the measured brake mark of Vehicle 2, a speed range for Vehicle 2 was

Driver one who was westbound in the 8200 blk of west sr 46 came upon driver two who he says had his left turn signal on and thought that he was going to turn. Driver one then started to pass on the right side when driver two suddenly veers to the left and strikes the driver's front corner panel of his vehicle. Driver one stated that he had his left turn signal on but missed where he was going to turn and decided to let driver one pass him. Driver one also said that he saw driver one and he was very close to his bumper. Driver one turned on his right signal and veered to the right to let driver one pass. Driver two's passenger side bumper made contact with driver one's front driver's side corner panel.After driver one left driver two told me that he did not turn on the left turn signal because he was not turning left. Vehicles pulled ot side of road prior to officers arrival (no Diagram)

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: WHILE TRAVELING MAKING A LEFT HAND TURN FROM PROW ROAD ONTO ARLINGTON DRIVE, V1 PULLED INTO THE NORTHBOUND LANE OF TRAFFIC (ARLINGTON DRIVE) WHEN IT WAS STRUCK BY V2. D1 WAS TRANSPORTED TO THE BLOOMINGTON HOSPITAL TO BE EVALUATED, BY BLOOMINGTON HOSPITAL AMBULANCE SERVICE, AFTER HE HAD COMPLAINT OF PAIN IN HIS SHOULDER. V2 WAS TRAVELING NORTHBOUND ON ARLINGTON DRIVE WHEN V1 PULLED OUT IN FRONT OF V2. V2 COLLIDED WITH V1 CASUING DAMAGE TO BOTH VEHICLES. D1 WAS EVALUATED ON SCENE AND RELEASED. A WITNESS, NICHOLAS MARTEL STATED HE WAS BEHIND V2 AND WHILE TRAVELING NORTBOUND, V1 FAILED TO YIELD THE RIGHT OF WAY AND PULLED OUT IN FRONT OF V2 AND V2 COLLIDED WITH V1.

Accident took place at 11:00 AM was reported on station at 4:00 PM by the pedestrian. V1 fled the scene. There was minimal information regarding the vehicle. P1 stated that he was crossing the road at the designated crosswalk between Foster and McNutt Dorms. P1 stated that he was already entering the roadway when V1 ran over his right foot and struck his left elbow and right arm. P1 stated that he did not stay to report it at the time due to him having 3 classes in a row. I asked P1 if he was in pain when making the report, P1 stated that his back and shoulder muscles felt sore, but that he did not want an ambulance to check him out. P1 stated that if he ended up in more pain he would go see a doctor.

V1 WAS TRAVELING EB ON 2ND AT WALKER. V2 WAS TRAVELING SB ON WALKER AT 2ND. THE FRONT OF V1 COLLIDED WITH THE PASSENGER SIDE OF V2 CAUSING V2 TO ROLLOVER.D1 STATED THAT HE WAS EB ON 2ND ST APPROACHING WALKER. D1 STATED THAT HE BELIEVED HE HAD THE GREEN LIGHT TO PROCEED THROUGH THE INTERSECTION. D1 STATED THAT V2 COME SB IN FRONT OF HIM AND THE FRONT OF V1 COLLIDED WITH PASSENGER SIDE OF V2. D1 STATED THAT, WHEN HE GOT OUT OF HIS VEHICLE, HIS LIGHT TO GO EB WAS GREEN.D2 STATED THAT SHE WAS SB ON WALKER APPROACHING 2ND ST. D2 STATED THAT HER LIGHT TO PROCEED SB WAS GREEN AND, AS SHE ENTERED THE INTERSECTION, THE FRONT OF V1 COLLIDED WITH THE PASSENGER SIDE OF V2 AND V2 ROLLED OVER. D2 STATED THAT HER MOST SIGNIFICANT INJURY WAS A COMPLAINT OF PAIN TO HER UPPER ARM AND SMALL LACERATIONS ON HER HANDS.W1 WAS E OF WALKER GOING WB ON 2ND ST. W1 STATED THAT THE LIGHT WAS RED TO GO WB. W1 STATED V2 WAS GOING SB THROUGH THE INTERSECTION AND THE FRONT OF V1 COLLIDED WITH THE PASSENGER SIDE OF V2. W2 WAS W OF WALKER GOING EB ON 2ND ST. W2 STATED THAT THE LIGHT TO GO EB WAS RED AND V1 DID NOT SLOW DOWN BEFORE GOING EB THROUGH THE INTERSECTION. W2 STATED THAT THE FRONT OF V1 COLLIED WITH THE PASSENGER SIDE OF V2.THROUGH MY INVESTIGATION, I BELIEVE THAT D1 DISREGARDING A RED SIGNAL CAUSED THIS ACCIDENT.

Owner of V2, Pamela Ferguson, came into the police department lobby to report that her vehicle was struck overnight. There was white paint transfer on the back bumper of V1. I believe that the height of V1 would be consistent with a passenger vehicle. Pamela did not witness the accident, but believes that the suspect vehicle struck her parked vehicle while V1 was trying to reverse into a parking space. A criminal case was completed. Photographs were logged into evidence.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: D1 advised she was driving V1 northbound on the 46 Bypass. D1 advised she had the green arrow to turn west bound onto 17th Street. D1 advised when she began turning westbound V1 and V2 crashed into each other. D2 advised she was driving V2 south bound on the 46 Bypass in the right lane. D2 advised she had the solid green light to continue straight, past 17th Street. D2 advised while she was driving V2 straight through the intersection V1 turned and crashed into V2.

No other officers assisted with the accident investigation.Vehicle Use (explain in narrative) - V1 is an Indiana University owned pickup truck used by Landscaping Services.V1 was parked in a valid parking stall. D1 was on the job site and filled the bed of the pickup with brush and tree limbs.D1 then entered V1 and began to reverse the truck out of the parking stall without noticing a concrete pole behind him. The tree limbs in the bed of the truck obstructed his view and he continued to back into the pole. There was no damage to the concrete pole. V1 had moderate damage to the passenger side portion of the bumper.There were no injuries and the vehicle was still safe to drive from scene.

Driver lost control of Vehicle on wet roads as he came over the hillcrest on roadway. Over-corrected/Over-steered. Vehicle 1 left the roadway, traveled down an embankment and came to rest in a spillway against a culvert.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: D1 STATED THAT HE WAS STOPPED AT THE INTERSECTION OF SOUTH SWAIN AND EAST 2ND STREET, FACING SOUTH.D1 DID NOT SEE V2 TRAVELING WEST ON 2ND STREET. D1 DID THEN DRIVE FORWARDS, RESULTING IN THE FRONT OF V1 MAKING CONTACT WITH THE PASSENGER SIDE OG V2.V1 AND V2 BOTH SUSTAINED DAMAGE.IT SHOULD BE NOTED THAT D2 DOES NOT HAVE A STOP SIGN WHEN TRAVELING WEST ON 2ND STREET.D2 EXPLAINED THAT HE WAS TRAVELING WEST ON 2ND STREET WHEN V1 DID PULL FORWARDS, GOING SOUTH FROM SWAIN. THE FRONT OF V1 DID THEN MAKE CONTACT WITH THE PASSENGER SIDE OF V2, RESULTING IN DAMAGE TO BOTH VEHICLES.

VEHICLE 1 WAS TRAVELING SOUTHBOUND ON SOUTH LIBERTY DRIVE NEAR THE INTERSECTION OF CONSTITUTION WAY. SOUTH LIBERTY DRIVE WAS UNDER CONSTRUCTION AND THE SOUTHBOUND LANE WAS CLOSED. UNKNOWN VEHICLE TRAVELING EASTBOUND ON WEST ELWREN ROAD NEAR THE INTERSECTION OF SOUTH GREEN COUNTY LINE ROAD. UNKNOWN VEHICLE DROVE OFF ROAD AND STRUCK A POLE WITH INDENTIFIERS OF UDWI 146711. I arrived on scene to fine vehicle 1 had ran off the road and smashed a power box, sign, and fence belonging to Bloomington Parks and Recreation. Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: WHILE UNIT 2 WAS TRAVELING NORTH ON PROFILE PARKWAY, UNIT 1 EXITED A PARKINGLOT INTO THE PATH OF UNIT 2. UNIT 2 STATED THAT SHE DID NOT HAVE ENOUGH TIME TO STOP PRIOR TO COLLIDING. THE DRIVER OF UNIT 2 LATER COMPLAINED OF HEAD AND NECK PAIN AND WAS SEEN ON SCENE BY EMT'S.

V1 was traveling southbound on N. Stone Mill Rd. just south of E. Bayles Rd. D1 stated that she was "only" traveling approximately 45 mph on N. Stone Mill Rd., which is a gravel road, when the passenger side tire of V1 caught the grass on the edge of the roadway causing her to lose control of V1. V1 ran off the westside of the roadway, down into a ditch then into a tree. V1 was towed from the scene due to disabling damage.

Explain in Narrative:Primary Cause: D1 stated he had a green light and was traveling westbound on Tenth Street. D1 stated he swerved his motorcycle on the ground to avoid a bus that he said he saw late. Type of crash: D1 stated he swerved and fell off of his motorcycle to avoid a collision with a bus. Driver Factors: D1 stated he was not paying attention and not looking at the bus in front of him and swerved to avoid a collision. D1 was traveling westbound on Tenth Street.D1 stated he was traveling westbound on Tenth Street. D1 stated he was traveling approximately 15-20 miles per hour on Tenth before he saw a bus in front of him and swerved his motorcycle down to avoid a collision. D1 stated he did not make contact with another motor vehicle or object, just the ground. D1 did not complain of injury. D1 stated he then walked his motorcycle to the SPEA parking lot (1315 E Tenth Street) and tried to turn his motorcycle on. D1 stated his motorcycle began making noises so he turned it off. D1's motorcycle was not towed.

UPON MY ARRIVAL I SPOKE TO BPD WHO SAID THEY HAD TALKED TO D1 AND SAW NO APPARENT IMPAIRMENT OR REASON TO BELIEVE HE WAS IMPAIRED. THEY ALSO STATED HE SIGNED A REFUSAL OF TREATMENT WITH THE AMBULANCE CREW.D1 STATED HE HAD A MANIC EPISODE LAST NIGHT AND WAS UP THE ENTIRE NIGHT. STATED HE HADN'T SLEPT SINCE THE NIGHT PRIOR (SUNDAY 9/22/19 INTO MONDAY 9/23/19). D1 STATED HE KNEW HE FELT TIRED HOWEVER DIDN'T THINK IT WAS BAD ENOUGH THAT HE WOULD FALL ASLEEP WHILE DRIVING. THE WITNESS HAD LEFT SCENE PRIOR TO MY ARRIVAL SO I DID NOT GET A CHANCE TO TALK TO THEM HOWEVER I DID ATTACH INFORMATION AND D1 STATED THAT WAS WHO CALLED IN THE ACCIDENT AND WITNESSED THE INCIDENT.D1 DESCRIBED RUNNING OFF THE ROAD AND HITTING A MAILBOX AS WHAT HE WAS TOLD HAPPENED. AFTER SPEAKING WITH D1 I PROVIDED HIM WITH THE NAME AND NUMBER OF THE PERSON WHO CALLED IN ABOUT THE HIT MAILBOX, THEN WENT TO THE ADDRESS OF WHERE HE RAN OFF THE ROADWAY AND SPOKE TO THE FATHER OF THE PERSON RENTING THE HOME. THE FATHER IS THE NEXT DOOR NEIGHBOR. THE FATHER STATED HE WAS GOING TO FIX THE MAILBOX FOR THE TIME BEING AND I PROVIDED HIM WITH A COPY OF D1'S INFORMATION.V1 HAD DAMAGE TO THE RIGHT SIDE OUTSIDE MIRROR AS WELL AS A BUSTED OUT PASSENGER SIDE FRONT WINDOW. THE COMPLAINANT AT 5931 E SR 46 STATED HE FOUND THE MIRROR AND BROKEN GLASS AROUND WHERE THE MAILBOX WAS HIT.

V2 was parked outside of 701 W Dixie St, on the northside of W Dixie St, facing east. Owner of V2 later observed new damage to the rear passengers side of V2. W1 described V1 as being a small white car, but was not able to provide any further information. W1 stated that V1 was seen pulled over to the side of the road, on the same side of V2 where V2 had suffered damage. This report will be updated if and when new information is obtained.

D1 advised she was following V2 in traffic through a construction zone traveling N on S. State Road 37. D1 stated that V2 stopped in front of her and she struck the rear of the vehicle. D1 advised the traffic was slow moving through the construction zone. D1 refused treatment and did not request an ambulance to the scene, but did have complaint of pain to her lower back, wrist, and possibly neck, but declined medical. D2 stated he was traveling N. On S. State Road 37 through a construction zone when V1 struck the rear of his vehicle. D2 stated that the traffic was stop and go through the construction zone, and further stated he noticed D1 following close to his vehicle. It should be noted that V2 sustained damage to the rear reese hitch ball, but it did not appear contact was made to the bumper.

V1 WAS WESTBOUND ON WINSLOW RD APPROACHING HENDERSON STREET.V2 WAS STOPPED DIRECTLY IN FRONT OF V1.D1 SAID SHE LOOKED OVER BRIEFLY TO SET HER PHONE DOWN. SHE SAID WHEN SHE LOOKED AHEAD V2 HAD STOPPED IN TRAFFIC. SHE SAID SHE BRAKED BUT REAR ENDED V2.D2 SAID AS SHE SAT IN TRAFFIC AT THE INTERSECTION V1 HIT HER FROM BEHIND.WITNESS #1 SAID HE WAS WEST OF THE CRASH ON FOOT. HE SAID HE SAW V1 REAR END V2.

V2 WAS UNATTENDED IN PARKING LOT, PARKED IN A PARKING STALL. CIRCUMSTANCES OF THE ACCIDENT ARE UNKNOWN. BASED ON THE LAYOUT OF THE PARKING LOT IT IS BELIEVED THAT V1 HAD IMPROPERLY TURNED OUT OF AN ADJACENT PARKING STALL AND SIDE SWIPED V2 WHILE ATTEMPTING TO ENTER INTO THE LANE OF TRAVEL BETWEEN THE COLUMNS OF PARKING STALLS.

O1, whom was the parent of D1 and a passenger in the vehicle. O1 stated D1 was traveling eastbound on W. 17th Street approaching the intersection at N. Willis Drive. O1 advised D1 did not see V2 which was stopped in the roadway to make a left hand turn. O1 advised D1 rear ended V2. D2 stated she was stopped on W. 17th Street facing east. She was waiting to turn left onto N. Willis Drive to head north when she was rear ended by V1. D2 denied medical assistance but had a complaint of pain in her neck and head.

Vehicle 1 was westbound in the 6100 Block of East State Road 46 in Bloomington, Monroe County, Indiana when crossed the centerline and traveled off the south side of the roadway and into a steep embankment and above ground fiber-optic cable box. Vehicle 1 then collided with a large and rotated nearly 180 counter-clockwise and came to rest facing eastbound in the driveway of 6196 East State Road 46. Vehicle/Driver 1 were found by a passing motorist a short time after the collision occurred. Driver 1 was found unconscious in the front driver seat of the vehicle. Evidence from vehicle 1 suggests that driver 1 was not wearing a seatbelt at the time of the collision. Driver 1 appeared to impact the dashboard of the vehicle during the collision as blood and other impact marks were observed on the upper portion of the center console and front passenger dashboard areas. Alcoholic beverage containers found within the vehicle and around the scene, along with the the odor of alcohol on driver 1's body, suggests alcohol impairment was likely a factor in the collision. Deputy Leland Hutchens obtained a search warrant to obtain a blood sample from driver 1 for chemical analysis as part of his operating while intoxicated investigation. Results are pending at the time of this report. Property damage resulting from the collision was determined to be a telephone/fiber-optic utility box and a stone drainage culvert at 6196 East State Road 46.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: V1 was traveling WB through the Indiana University Police Department, 1469 E. 17th Street, parking lot attempting to turn north and park in a parking space when the accident occurred. V2 was parked, unoccupied, facing south in the parking space west of the space V1 was attempting to park.The owner's son of V2 had parked V2 in the lot earlier in the night and came out around 2115 hours to find damage to the front driver side quarter panel and door of V2. He advised the damage was new and no one had left any information regarding the accident. After receiving the report, video footage from IUPD's outside camera was reviewed showing a light colored, possibly grey, vehicle (V1) pull into the lot at 1918 hours and attempt to park next to V2. The footage clearly shows V1 striking the driver side of V2. V2 was seen moving as V1 pulled forward and again when it backed up. V1 then left the parking lot traveling to the west, out of the frame of the camera. At 1920 hours, two individuals were seen walking from the west towards the back door of 1469 E. 17th Street. One of those individuals, later identified as being D1, walked over to V2 and appear to assess the damage to V2 and then proceeded to walk into the building. D1 stated he had pulled into the parking lot and attempted to park in the first parking space on the east side of the lot. D1 stated as he turned into the space he thought he hit a curb at first. D1 denied noticing V2 move when he struck it and back away from it. D1 stated he thought he didn't have enough room to park in that space so he moved V1 into a space in another parking lot. D1 admitted to walking up to the vehicle to assess the damage. After seeing the damage to V2, he stated he knew that he had struck V2. V2 also admitted that he didn't know whose vehicle he had struck and he had no intention to notify the owner of the damage.

Both vehicles were facing north on Woodlawn Avenue, south of 10th Street. V2 was stopped at the bus stop. V1 attempted to pass V2 on the left. V1 sideswiped V2's left rear brake light. D2 stated while sitting at the bus stop at 10th Street and Woodlawn Avenue, V1 tried passing and struck V2. D2 stated V1 then stopped at the traffic light before turning west on 10th Street. V2 had damage to the left rear brake light housing. I eventually was able to speak with D1. D1 stated she did not even feel or hear her strike V2. V1 has 3 turn signal lights that run along each side of the vehicle. The right rear light struck V2's brake light. V1 only had damage to the plastic housing for the turn signal. Photographs were taken of the damage to each vehicle.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: D1 was headed W/B on W 3rd St, approaching the intersection of S Liberty Dr. D2 was headed N/B on S Liberty Dr, approaching the intersection of W 3rd St. D1 proceeded through the intersection at the same time D2 proceeded through the intersection, causing V2 to strike V1 in the passenger side with it's front side. It should be noted that a witness of the accident stated that D1 went through the intersection on a red traffic signal, and did not have the right of way. D1 stated that she was headed W/B on W 3rd St, approaching the intersection of S Liberty Dr. D1 stated that she proceeded through the intersection believing she had a green traffic signal, indicating her having the right of way. D1 stated that as she proceeded through the intersection V1 was struck by V2 on the passenger side. D2 stated that he was headed N/B on S Liberty Dr, approaching the intersection of W 3rd St. D2 stated that he proceeded through the intersection and believed he had a green traffic signal, indicating his right of way. D2 stated that as he proceeded through the intersection D1 pulled directly into his path of travel, causing V2 to strike V1 in the passenger side.

D1 stated he was travelling westbound on W. 3rd Street in the left lane when a UPS truck attempted to get over into his lane. D1 stated this caused him to swerve to his left and collide with a curb. D1 stated he did not make contact with the UPS truck. D1 advised he did not have any injuries and did not wish to be seen by EMS. The UPS driver advised he did attempt to go into the left lane but quickly swerved back into the right lane after seeing D1.I did obtain contact information for a witness which will be added to this state report. I also obtained the UPS driver's information that will also be included as a participant.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: WHILE UNIT 2 WAS TRAVELING NORTH ON S STATE RAOD 37 AT THE INTERSECTION OF SMITHVILLE ROAD, UNIT 1 WAS ATTEMPTING TO CROSS SR 37 ON SMITHVILLE ROAD HEADED EAST. THE DRIVER OF UNIT 1 STATED THAT HE NEVER SAW UNIT 2 DRIVING ON SR 37 AND CONTINUED ACROSS THE ROAD. UNIT 2 STRUCK UNIT 1 ON BOTH DOORS LOCATED ON THE PASSENGER SIDE. UNIT 1 WAS PUSHED OFF THE EAST SIDE OF THE ROADWAY AND ROLLED ONTO ITS DRIVER SIDE. UNTI 1 LOST THE FRONT DRIVER SIDE TIRE AND CAME TO A REST ON THE EAST SIDE OF THE HIGHWAY AS WELL. ALL OCCUPANTS WERE TRANSPORTED TO THE HOSPITAL FOR TREATMENT.

V2 WAS PARKED IN THE PARKING LOT OF KROGER AND D1 WAS ATTEMPTING TO PARK NEXT TO V2. THE WITNESS KIP BOWER STATED D1 PULLED INTO THE PARKING LOT DRIVING NB AND ATTEMPTED TO PARK NEXT TO V2 TO THE EAST. MS. BOWER STATED THAT SHE SAW V1 ENTER THE PARKING SPACE HOWEVER DIDN'T TURN SHARP ENOUGH AND V1 HIT V2. V1 HAD DAMAGE TO THE LEFT FRONT AND V2 HAD DAMAGE TO THE RIGHT SIDE DOOR.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: V1 was traveling eastbound on W. That Road at the intersection of S. Victor Pike. V2 was traveling southbound on S. Victor Pike at the intersection of W. That Road. There is a four way stop sign at this intersection. D1 stated that he failed to yield to V2, as he did not look his way before entering the intersection and struck V2 on the passenger side. D2 stated that V1 failed to stop at the stop sign before crashing into V2. V2 was towed from the scene due to disabling damage.

D1 was facing south on Fess Avenue, just north of Atwater Avenue, attempting to travel eastbound on Atwater Avenue. D2 was facing north on Fess Avenue, just south of Atwater Avenue, attempting to continue traveling northbound on Fess Avenue. D1 stated he was stopped at the north stop sign at the intersection of Atwater Avenue and Fess Avenue attempting to turn left to begin traveling east on Atwater Avenue. D1 stated he then began to turn left on Atwater Avenue when he struck D2. D1 stated he did not see D2. D1 admitted fault on scene. D2 stated that he was stopped at the south stop sign of the intersection of Atwater Avenue and Fess Avenue attempting to travel north on Fess Avenue. D1 stated he entered the intersection and was struck by D2. D1's vehicle was towed due to the damage to his front bumper. There was coolant almost leaking due to the damage. There was heavy damage to D1's front bumper on the driver side. D2's vehicle was not towed. D2 had slight damage to the driver side door and step of his vehicle.Neither party complained of injury.

Ingrid stated she returned home around 1430 hours and noticed the limestone pillars protecting her driveway were damaged. Ingrid stated there was a piece of a vehicle left at the scene indicating a vehicle hit her pillar. Ingrid stated there are no witnesses, suspects, or video footage of the incident. Ingrid stated the cost of repair would be nearly $1000.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: At approximately 1710 hours on 9/25/2019 a collision occurred between V1 and V2 at the intersection of 13th Street and Walnut Grove. V1, northbound, failed to yield the right away, entering the roadway and not giving V2, westbound, enough time to brake. This caused the front bumper of V2 to strike the rear passenger tire of V1, causing heavy damage to both.D1 advised that he had stopped at the stop sign, looked both ways, and believed he had enough time to successfully make it across the street. He advised that after entering the roadway he realized he had misjudged the amount of time required. D1 immediately claimed responsibility for the collision. There was significant damage to the rear passenger side tire, making the vehicle almost inoperable. D1 advised that he had a valid parking permit and moved the vehicle a short distance to the nearby parking lot.D2 advised that she had been travelling approximately the speed limit, west on the 13th, while approaching the intersection of 13th and Walnut Grove. D2 advised that V1 pulled out in front of her, not giving her enough time to brake and avoid collision. When asked whether D1 had stopped at the stop sign, D2 advised she could not be certain. There was significant damage to the front end of V2, making it inoperable. Neither party claimed injury or requested medical attention.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: Driver 1 was merging onto West State 46 when he stated he was attempting to get over into the lane of travel when Driver 2 would not let him over. Driver 1 stated after a couple attempts to get over into the lane of travel he just began to get over. Driver 1 stated he did not know he was initially involved in a collision however did sustain damage on the driver's side. Driver 2 stated she was in the lane of travel, which was limited to only one lane instead of two lanes due to construction. Driver 2 was traveling westbound when Driver 1 came into her lane and collided with her front passenger seat. Driver 2 declined medical personnel and tow services. Driver 2 continued down the roadway until parking as Driver 1 did not initially stop due to not believing he was involved in an accident.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: D1 ADVISED HE PULLED ACROSS W SR 45 FROM W ELWREN RD INTO THE PATH OF V2, THIS ACTION CAUSED V2 TO VEER TO THE NORTHSIDE OF W SR 45 AND ROLLOVER COMING TO REST ON ITS WHEELS IN THE DITCH/GRASS AREA JUST NORTH OF W SR 45. D1 ADVISED HE DID NOT NEED MEDICAL ATTENTON AND V1 WAS TAKEN FROM HE SCENE VIA TRUCK AND TRAILER BY V1'S OWNER. D2 ADVISED SHE WAS TRAVELINIG WESTBOUND ON W SR 45 WHEN V1 STRUCK HER IN THE DRIVERSIDE, CAUSING V2 TO VEER OFF THE ROADWAY AND ROLLOVER. D2 ADVISED SHE WAS HAVING CHEST PAIN FROM THE SEATBELT AND ROLLING OVER. SHE SIGNED A RELEASE FORM WITH BLOOMINGTON HOSPITAL AMBULANCE SERVICE DECLINING TO BE TRANSPORTED FOR MEDICAL TREATMENT. V2 WAS TOWEED FROM THE SCEN VIA AUTO MOBILE WRECKER SERVICE.

Owner of V2 was not present but her daughter, Devon Bray, was. Bray stated that she parked V2 outside of her residence at 828 W 7th Street at approximately 1730 hours on 9/24/2019 and found it with damage at 0800 hours on 9/25/2019. Bray stated that the only damage was to the driver's side mirror of V2. There was no paint transfer on the damage to V2.There are no cameras that could have captured the incident. There are currently no suspects.

On 09/26/2019 at approximately 0823hours, I was dispatched to the area of 611 N Walnut Grove for a property damage accident. Upon arrival I spoke with the complainant Donald Dixon. Dixon advised he was notified by a co-worker his vehicle, a Gray Ford Fusion with plate XNW590, was possibly involved in an accident. Dixon then said he went to check since he was working in the Geology building at the time of the accident.Dixon said his vehicle a gray 2012 Ford Fusion was parked stationary and the vehicle was unoccupied on the east side of Walnut Grove facing northbound. Dixon's vehicle was also parked in an area marked no parking. Dixon said he was told they were allowed to park there since they were doing construction in the Geology Building. Dixon said his friend he identified as Douglas McCracken was doing work on the third floor and told Dixon his vehicle may have been involved in an accident and the vehicle left the scene. I then asked Dixon if he would be able to contact McCracken to have him come down and speak with me. Dixon called McCracken on the phone and he came downstairs to speak with me regarding what occurred. McCracken arrived downstairs where the accident occurred. I informed McCracken I was wanting to get a recorded statement on what he witnessed. McCracken said he was walking down the stairs in the Geology Building and observed a black in color Mercedes Benz appearing have a difficult time trying to park or leave. McCracken said he noticed it was a co-worker Donald (D.J.) Dixon's car. McCracken said when he noticed it was Dixon's vehicle he pulled out his phone and took a couple pictures and video. McCracken said he noticed Dixon's vehicle move forward slightly where McCracken felt the Mercedes definitely made contact with the Fusion. McCracken said the Mercedes Benz appeared to have struck Dixon's Ford Fusion on the rear driver side bumper with the front passenger side panel of the Mercedes. McCracken said the Mercedes then left the area, and drove around the corner to the parking lot just north of the location for the Multi Science Building located at 702 N. Walnut Grove. McCracken said Dixon was able to locate the vehicle. McCracken said after notifying Dixon he went back to work until Dixon called him to speak with me. McCracken then emailed me the photos. I viewed the photos on scene where it shows the Mercedes being close to the Ford, and the video shows the vehicle only driving off, not the actual crash that occurred. After speaking with McCracken I spoke with the owner and victim of the Ford Fusion Dixon who also gave a taped statement. Dixon said he was at work and his buddy McCracken was looking out the window and observed a Black Mercedes back into his vehicle. Dixon said after speaking with McCracken he went downstairs to see if the Mercedes struck his vehicle. Dixon said he observed the vehicle park. Dixon said he went and took pictures of the damage on the Mercedes and the license plate for the Mercedes being Pet Friendly PL5489. Dixon described the driver of the vehicle who he saw at a distance being a Asian male, 5'8, wearing black hoody, and black pants, and carrying a backpack. Dixon said he then called police to make a report. After speaking with Dixon and McCracken they took me to the parking lot to show me where the vehicle had parked. Both said the vehicle was parked in the third row. Upon getting to the area the vehicle was no longer there. I then made contact with Officer Smolen also with IUPD to have him meet me on scene due to having camera issues. I was able to photograph the scene and Dixon vehicle where the damage was located. I then made contact with IUPD Dispatch with the information provided by Dixon on the Mercedes. Dispatch advised they located the phone number and an off campus address. I called the phone number provided and the call went to voicemail with not being able to leave a message. Officer Smolen and I then drove the area and was unable to locate the vehicle. Office
BOTH VEHICLES WERE TRAVELING NORTH ON MORTON STREET APPROACHING 7TH STREET.V2 WAS STOPPED FOR A VEHICLE TO BACK OUT OF PARKING SPOT.V1 REAR ENDED THE BACK OF V2 AND COULD NOT GET STOPPED IN TIME.

Driver 1 was traveling westbound in the 5600 Block of East State Road 46 in Bloomington when a deer ran into the roadway and collided with vehicle 1. The deer was not located or around the roadway in the area of the collision, however a significant amount of animal hair was observed on the front of vehicle 1. Vehicle 1's cooling system was severely damaged during the collision and driver 1 requested the vehicle towed back to Columbus, Indiana.

D1 informed me that she was driving V1 northbound, attempting to enter the parking garage of 501 N. College Ave., when the top of V1 struck the ceiling of the garage. D1 then stated that when she heard the impact, she accidentally accelerated, striking and destroying the security arm of the parking garage entrance. Once on scene, I did observe damage to the front, rear, and top of V1.It should be noted that the cause of the accident was due to D1 being unaware of the dimensions of V1, which exceeded the maximum clearance level of the parking garage she was attempting to enter.

On September 26, 2019 at approximately 11:44 A.M. the Bloomington Police Department responded to the area of Walnut St. just south of the intersection of 3rd St. The Bloomington City Transit Bus Terminal is also located at this location. On the south side of the terminal V1 was facing west towards the exit of the bus terminal lot onto Walnut St. V1 then began to exit the bus terminal to turn north onto Walnut St. While making the right turn onto Walnut St. P1 began to run up to the passenger side of V1 attempting to get the driver's attention of V1 to stop the bus, so she can get on. P1 appears to fall down, while attempting to keep up with V1 while it is traveling. When P1 falls down on the roadway, she then goes underneath V1 and is struck by V1's tires. D1 stated that when he pulled out onto Walnut St. from exiting the bus terminal, he felt as though he ran over a curb. After realizing that P1 had been struck, he then stopped V1. P1 was pronounced deceased at the scene and appeared to have extensive internal injuries.

Vehicle 2 was parked on the side west side of Mitchell street in front of 612 S Mitchell St facing south. Vehicle owner noticed damage to the rear passenger side of the door around 06:00 PM. Unknown exact time of the accident or suspect vehicle information. Vehicle has moderate damage to the rear passenger door with what appears to be white paint transfer. Vehicle 2 was parked facing south at the time of the accident.It is unknown what direction vehicle 1 was traveling or how the accident occurred. At this time the cause of the accident is listed as driver-other due to the lack of accident information.

D2 advised he was sitting in traffic facing North just south of Fairfax and saw that the light had turned green, at which point he felt his vehicle being struck from behind. D1 advised she was behind V2 and also saw the light turn green. D1 stated that one of the five children in her vehicle began to scream/cry and she tried to console them and reached behind her seat, but didn't stop the vehicle before hitting V2.Note: all "other participants" are juveniles who were located within v1.

At approximately 1415 hours on 9/26/2019 a collision occurred between V1 and the parked V2. V1 attempted to park on the curb just north of V2 and sideswiped the front driver side fender. Minimal damage occurred to V1, however there was significant damage to V2. V1 WAS TRAVELING EB ON E ATWATER AVE APPROACHING THE INTERSECTION OF S MITCHELL ST. AS V1 HAD THE RIGHT OF WAY TO CONTINUE EB ON E ATWATER, A DARK COLORED SUV FAILED TO YIELD TO THE RIGHT OF WAY, PULLED OUT IN FRONT OF V1, CAUSING D1 TO LAY HIS MOTORCYCLE DOWN AND CRASH. BASED ON STATEMENTS, THE OTHER VEHICLE THAT LEFT THE SCENE WITHOUT STOPPING WAS NEVER INVOLVED IN AN ACTUAL COLLISION, HOWEVER, CAUSE V1 TO CRASH.D1 STATED THAT HE WAS TRAVELING EB ON E ATWATER AVE WHEN ANOTHER DARK BLUE SUV PULLED OUT IN FRONT OF HIM CAUSING HIM TO CRASH HIS BIKE. D1 WAS UNSURE IF ANY COLLISION ACTUALLY OCCURRED WITH THE OTHER VEHICLE.W1 STATED THAT SHE AND W2 WERE TRAVELING IN THEIR VEHICLE ON E ATWATER AVE TRAVELING EB IN THE NORTHERN MOST LANE TO TURN NB ON S MITCHELL ST. W1 AND W2 STATED THAT THE DARK COLORED SUV PULLED OUT IN FRONT OF V1 CAUSING HIM TO CRASH AND THEN FLED SB ON S MITCHELL WITHOUT STOPPING TO CHECK ON D1. W1 AND W2 PROVIDED A LICENSE PLATE OUT OF MISSOURI OF 'EC3PJ7' HOWEVER, THAT PLATE WAS NOT ON FILE THROUGH THE BMV.W3 STATED THAT SHE WAS TRAVELING WB ON E ATWATER BEHIND THE DARK BLUE SUV. W3 STATED SHE WAS AT THE INTERSECTION OF E ATWATER AVE AND S EASTSIDE DR WHEN SHE OBSERVED THE SUV PULL OUT IN FRONT OF V1 CAUSING V1 TO CRASH HIS MOTORCYCLE.

Driver of vehicle 2 stated that he was stopped and attempted to back into his drive way when vehicle 1 struck him. Driver of vehicle 1 stated repeatedly that the driver of vehicle 2 backed into him causing the damage and the driver of vehicle 2 stated he was simply trying to back into his driveway when vehicle 1 struck his vehicle.There was minor rear bumper damage on vehicle 2 and minor front end bumper damage to vehicle 1.

V-1 and V-2 were both traveling eastbound on 7th St. From N. Walnut St. D-1 came to a stop just in front of a southbound alley way and prepared to exit the vehicle. D-2 began to overtake V-1 as V-2 appeared to come to a stop. D-1 began to open the driver doorway, striking V-2 as it continued eastbound.D-1 says that as she began to exit her vehicle, she was not aware of V-2 traveling eastbound and struck V-2 with the driver's door. D-2 was also traveling eastbound on 7th St. approaching the intersection of 7th St. and Washington St. As V-2 began to pass V-1, D-1 opened V-1's driver door and impacting V-2's passenger side. Minor damage was caused to Vehicle-1's driver doorway, but remained functional. V-2 sustained minor damage to the passenger side from the front to the rear of the vehicle, including the passenger side mirror.
V-1 was traveling south on Interstae 69 when D-1 lost control of V-1 and struck the guard rail. V-1 then left the roadway coming to rest in the side ditch.

D2 stated that she showed up for work on 9/27/2019 and parked V2 in the parking lot at 9:00am, and didn't return to her car until she left work at 5:30pm. D2 stated that's when she noticed the damage along the driver's side of her car, including the front and rear doors, as well as the rear fender. There appeared to be red scuff marks along the driver's side of the car, as well as dents and scraped paint on the driver's side doors, which appeared to be from V1 hitting V2 as D1 pulled into the parking spot next to V2. D2 stated that when she parked her car, there were no cars next to hers, and when she returned to her car, there were no red cars around her car. There were no cameras in the area to possibly review camera footage, and there are no suspects at this time.

D2 ADVISED AS SHE APROACHED THE INTERSECTION, SHE THEN CHANGED HER MIND AND INIATED HER LEFT TURN SIGNAL AND CONTINUED STRAIGHT ON BLOOMFIELD. DUE TO DAMAGE, BOTH VEHICLES WERE TOWED FROM THE SCENE.

D1 ADVISED HE WAS TRAVELING EAST ON E SR 46 W V2 QUICKLY APPLIED ITS BRAKES TO TURN INTO A DRIVEWAY. D1 ADVISED HE COULD NOT STOP IN TIME AND STRUCK V2 IN REAR END. D2 HAD NO VISABLE SIGNS OF INJURY OR NO COMPLAINT OF PAIN BUT WAS TRANSPORTED TO IU HEALTH AT THE REQUEST OF HER FATHER.

V1 was being driven by d1 and company employee of tieman tire, located at this address. While he was backing the vehicle up to be placed into the working bay and struck v2 in the bumper. Vehicle 1 was traveling northbound on South State Road 37 approaching the Zikes Road intersection in Bloomington, Monroe County, Indiana when it collided with vehicle 2 that was parked on the right-hand shoulder of the roadway approximatley 1000 feet south of the intersection. After the collision both vehicles caught on fire.Vehicle 1 sustained massive damage to its front end and all safety restraint systems appeared to function as designed. Driver 1 reported only a sore wrist and was evaluated by EMS personnel at the scene. Vehicle 2 was unoccupied due to mechanical troubles and was not moving or powered on at the time of the collision. Vehicle 2 did not have any warning devices activated or placed behind the vehicle at the time of the collision. Vehicle 2 sustained extensive collision and fire damage to nearly the entire vehicle. Minor abrasions and gouges are visible on the freshly applied asphalt roadway surface. The section of roadway where the collision occurred was recently paved with asphalt within the last 30 days and only has a white dotted center lane divider marking as of the date of the collision. The roadway in this area does not yet have inner yellow or outer white roadway edge lines. Driver 1 reported that due to the roadways deep, glossy black appearance and the reflection of the vehicle headlights, she was unable to determine where her vehicle was within the right-hand lane of the roadway. Evidence suggests vehicle 2 was parked along the shoulder section of the roadway, however both the right-hand lane and right-hand shoulder are constructed of the same material and appear to be a single large travel lane due to no delineating markings. The shoulder on this section of roadway is nearly an actual lane width, however the only separation from the right-hand travel lane is a slight seam where the two sections of roadway meet.

D1 STATED HE WAS WEST ON SR46W AND TRIED TO MERGE INTO RIGHT LANE, STATED HE DID NOT SEE V2, V1 THEN STRUCK FRONT OF V2 WITH PASSENGERSIDE REAR OF V2. D2 STATED THAT VEH 1 ATTEMPTED TO MERGE INTO LANE STRICKING THE FRONT DRIVERSIDE OF V2 WITH RIGHT REAR OF V1.

ON 09/28/2019 UNIT 1, A MOTORCYCLE DRIVEN BY DRIVER 1 IDENTIFIED AS MIGUEL MAGNO-CHAVEZ WAS TRAVELING SOUTH BOUND ON OLD STATE ROAD 37 SOUTH WHEN A DEER RAN OUT IN THE ROADWAY. UNIT STRUCK THE DEER CAUSINH UNIT 1 TO RUN OFF THE ROADWAY. MR. MAGNO-CHAVEZ WAS EJECTED FROM THE MOTORCYCLE AND CAME TO A REST IN A NEARBY DITCH. THE DEER WAS NOT LOCATED AT THE SCENE.

Interstate 69, is a multi-lane interstate with a concrete wall divider, is straight and level in this portion of Bloomington, Indiana. Vehicle 1 (white 2008 Honda) was traveling north on Interstate 69, approaching the 117.5 mile marker, in the far left lane. Vehicle 1 left the driving lane to the left and struck the concrete wall divider, continuing north for approximately 1/2 mile, still striking the wall, before coming to a rest.Driver 1(Thla Hlei) was unconscious upon my arrival to the scene. Medical personnel were able to get Driver 1 conscious and exit the vehicle. Driver 1 had no visible injuries, however had suffered a medical episode and would not speak. I was advised by medical personnel, that Driver 1 had suffered a stroke. They also advised there were no signs of drug or alcohol use. Driver 1 was transported to Bloomington Hospital for evaluation. Witness 1 (Tara Langley) was traveling north on Interstate 69, in the middle lane, approaching the 117.5 mile marker. Witness 1 stated that she observed Vehicle 1 abruptly go left and strike the concrete wall. Witness 1 stated she pulled over and exited her car to assist Driver 1. Witness 1 stated that Driver 1 was unconscious upon her arrival to Vehicle 1 and Driver 1 had blood coming from his mouth. Primary cause of this crash was driver illness.

D1 STATED HE WAS BACKING OUT OF SPOT IN THE PRIVATE LOT OF 401 W HOOSIER COURT, HOOSIER COURT APARTMENTS TRAVELING WEST AND V2 STRUCK HIM WHILE HE WAS BACKING OUT.D2 STATED WAS DRIVING NORTH IN PARKING LOT OF PRIVATE LOT OF 401 W HOOSIER COURT AVENUE, HOOSIER COURT APARTMENTS AND V1 BACKED OUT INTO HIM. D2 STATED HE WAS DRIVING ABOUT 10 MILES PER HOUR.NO INJURIES.*SUPP 10/2/2019. DIRECTION OF TRAVEL FOR BOTH VEHICLES IN NARRATIVE AND LOCATION OF ACCIDENT IN NARRATIVE FOR EACH. *

V1 WAS TRAVELLING WEST ON ST RD 46 E. V1 LEFT THE ROADWAY TO THE NORTH AND ENTERED THE DITCH. V1 CONYINUED IN THE DITCH UNTIL STRIKING THE EMBANKMENT, AT WHICH RIME THE VEHICLE APPERED TO GET AIRBORNE OVER LOWER BIRDIE GALYAN RD AND LANDED ACROSS LOWER BIRDIE GALYAN RD TO THE WEST, NOSE DOWN IN THE DITCH.

D1 Driver Factors "other explain in narrative" - V1 experienced engine failure and would no longer move. As a result, D1 had turned V1 off in order to try and restart it. During this process, V1 was left in the roadway without any lights on.D3 Driver Factors "other explain in narrative" - D3 was traveling behind V2 and the roadway was curved and not lighted. V2 stopped very suddenly as a result of striking V1. D3 was then given little time to react or avoid colliding with V2 due to the dark lighting condition, curved roadway, and speed limit of 45mph. D3 was also driving alone on an expired Illinois Instruction Permit.Prior to the crash, V1 was stopped in the right lane for southeast traffic on SR 45/46 Bypass as a result of engine failure. V2 was driving southeast in the right lane approaching V1. V3 was driving southeast in the right behind V2. D1 said he was driving southeast in the right lane on SR 45/46 Bypass when he experienced engine failure and came to a stop. D1 said his headlights and tail lights were on, but he then turned V1 off and tried to restart it. During this process, the lights may have turned off. Before D1 could get V1 started again, it was struck from the rear by V2. D2 said she was driving southeast on SR 45/46 Bypass at approximately 45mph. As D2 drove through the curve in the road she quickly came up behind V1 stopped in the roadway. D2 said she did not see any tail lights on, and did not see V1 with enough time to react. D2 struck the rear of V1. D3 said he was driving southeast on SR 45/46 Bypass at approximately 45mph behind V2. D3 said V2 came to an extremely abrupt stop and he was unable to avoid colliding with V2. The front passenger side corner of V3 struck the rear driver side corner of V2 as D3 tried to swerve and avoid the collision. Immediately following the collision with V2, D3 exited V3 and did not put V3 in park. V3 then rolled away unoccupied. V3 drove over the curb raised median with a grass center, across the northwest lanes of travel, over another curb and off the roadway. Once off the roadway, V3 rolled down a steep hill into a ditch lined with rocks, through approximately 130 feet of grass, into bushes, and finally struck the IU Foundation building (1500 State Rd 46).V1 sustained damage across the rear bumper. V2 sustained heavy front end damage and damage across the rear. V3 sustained heavy front end damage and damage to the underbody. All three vehicles were towed by Bland's Wrecker Service due to disabling damage. After leaving the roadway, V3 ran over multiple small bushes in front of the IU Foundation. When I arrived on scene there was approximately one inch between the front of V3 and the building. There was a small black scuff and thin crack in the outside limestone wall directly in front of the bumper. D2 sustained injuries to her nose and jaw, complaining of extreme pain and believing her nose was broken. D2 was transported to IU Health Bloomington Hospital by Bloomington Hospital Ambulance Service for treatment. D3 complained of pain in his left wrist and right knee. D3 was treated on scene by Bloomington Hospital Ambulance Service and refused transportation to the hospital.Photographs of the scene and vehicles involved were taken.

D1 reported his vehicle has been parked for the past three days. D1 discovered his vehicle had been damaged. V1 stated there was no note left on his vehicle of who was responsible. D1 also stated no one has contacted his claiming responsibility.A Honda emblem was stuck to D1's vehicle, it is suspected vehicle two is a Honda passenger car.**********SUPPLEMENT*****************11/06/2019The suspect driver, D2, was located on 11/06/2019. His vehicle was observed to have front end damage consistent with colliding with D1. D2 stated he has a medical condition that affects his memory. D2 stated he does not remember colliding with D1 however acknowledged it was possible he was involved. D2 stated he remembers striking another vehicle approximately 1 month prior however he thought it was at the Kroger south parking lot (approx. 1/4 mile down the road from where the collision occurred). D2 thought he struck a the tire of a truck, got out, looked at his vehicle, and left because he did not observe any damage. D2 did not contact law enforcement at the time of the collision.

D1 was in the north most lane of 3rd Street traveling westbound attempting to turn left to travel south on Highland Avenue. D2 was in the south most lane of 3rd Street traveling westbound attempting to continue traveling westbound. D1 stated that he was traveling westbound on 3rd street in the north most lane attempting to make a left turn to begin traveling south on Highland Avenue. D1 stated he had his turn signal on and was turning left from the north most lane (far right lane) when he crossed over the south most lane (left lane) and was struck by D2. D2 had damage to his rear driver side door as well as his rear quarter panel. D2 did not complain of injury and his vehicle was not towed. D1 stated he was going approximately 5 miles per hour at the time of the collision.D2 stated he was in the south most lane traveling westbound on 3rd Street going straight. D2 stated D1 then turned from the north most lane into his lane which caused D2 to strike D1 with his front bumper. D2 stated he was going approximately 15-20 miles per hour at the time of the collision. D2 had significant damage to his front passenger side bumper and was missing a part to his front bumper on the driver side. D2 did not complain of injury. D2's vehicle was towed due to fluid leaking from his vehicle.

V1 WAS TRAVELLING E/B ON W 17TH ST DIRECTLY BEHIND V2. AS V2 SLOWED DOWN TO TURN LEFT ONTO N WILLIS DRIVE, V1 CONTINUED FORWARD, STRIKING V2 ON THE PASSENGER SIDE REAR BUMPER. D1 ADMITTED FAULT OF THE ACCIDENT AND STATED SHE DIDN'T SEE THAT V2 WAS TURNING.

D1 is uknownOwner of vehicle 2 stated his vehicle was parked outside his apartment on 396 E. Varsity Ln. Owner of vehicle 2 stated he last used his car at 8:30P on 9/28/2019. Owner of vehicle 2 stated he was walking his dog on 9/29/2019 at 3:30P and noticed the damage to the rear of his vehicle.

Vehicle 2 was parked on the south side of the parking lot located on the west side of 601 W 2nd St., west of the emergency department facing east. NARRATIVE: D1 STATED THAT SHE WAS DRIVING SOUTH ON DUNN STREET AND THAT SHE WAS APPROACHING THE INTERSECTION OF EAST 3RD STREET. D1 EXPLAINED THAT SHE DID HAVE THE GREEN LIGHT AND SHE WAS IN THE LEFT LANE.AS D1 WAS IN THE INTERSECTION TRAVELING SOUTH, THE FRONT OF V2 DID MAKE CONTACT WITH THE DRIVER'S SIDE OF V1.BOTH VEHICLES DID SUSTAIN DAMAGE BUT WERE ABLE TO BE DRIVEN TO A NEARBY PARKING LOT.D2 STATED THAT HE WAS TRAVELING WEST ON 3RD STREET, APPROACHING THE INTERSECTION OF SOUTH DUNN.D2 ALSO STATED THAT HE HAD THE GREEN LIGHT AND THAT V1 NEVER STOPPED AT THE THE INTERSECTION.D2 DID CONTINUE DRIVING THROUGH THE INTERSECTION UNTIL THE FRONT OF V2 DID MAKE CONTACT WITH THE DRIVER'S SIDE OF V1.I DID THEN SPEAK WITH A WITNESS, IDENTIFIED AS TIMOTHY PFEIFER.TIMOTHY STATED THAT HE WAS STANDING NORTH OF THE INTERSECTION WORKING ON LANDSCAPING WHEN HE DID HEAR THE ACCIDENT OCCUR. TIMOTHY MENTIONED THAT HE DID IMMEDIATELY LOOK UP AND DID SEE THAT THE LIGHTS, FACING NORTH, WHICH ARE THE LIGHT THAT D1 WOULD HAVE SEEN, WERE RED.TIMOTHY EXPLAINED THAT HE DOES THINK THAT D2 HAD THE GREEN LIGHT AND THAT V1 DID HAVE THE RED LIGHT.

THE OWNER OF V2 STATED THAT SHE HAD PARKED HER VEHICLE IN THE DRIVEWAY OF HER RESIDENCE, LOCATED AT 3201 SOUTH PICCADILLY STREET, FACING EAST.THE OWNER OF V2 STATED THAT SHE LATER RETURNED TO HER VEHICLE AND SAW THAT THE PASSENGER SIDE REAR DOOR HAD BEEN STRUCK BY ANOTHER VEHICLE AND APPEARED TO HAVE SEVERAL SCRATCHES AND TWO SCUFF MARKS.THE OWNER OF V2 STATED SHE DID NOT SEE THE DAMAGE TO HER VEHICLE UNTIL 7:00 PM BUT SHE DOES NOT REMEMBER SEEING ANY DAMAGE TO THE PASSENGER SIDE OF V2 THIS MORNING WHEN SHE HAD RETURNED HOME AT 5:00 AM.THE OWNER OF V2 STATED, AND IT APPEARS BASED ON THE DAMAGE TO V2, THAT ANOTHER VEHICLE HAD ATTEMPTED TO TURN LEFT/RIGHT AND HAD LIGHTLY STRUCK THE REAR PASSENGER DOOR OF V2.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: BOTH VEHICLES WERE ON ADAMS ST, JUST NORTH OF PATTERSON DR.D1 SAID SHE WAS TRYING TO TURN LEFT INTO THE GAS STATION PARKING LOT, AND WAS SIGNALLING HER TURN. SHE SAID SHE DID NOT SEE V2 COMING EAST BOUND.D2 SAID SHE WAS IN THE RIGHT LANE, WHEN V1 SUDDENLY TURNED LEFT IN FRONT OF HER. Vehicle 2 stopped in traffic. Vehicle 1 slowing and stopping in traffic, approached Vehicle 2, experienced brake fade, struck the rear of Vehicle 2.

V2 was southbound on Old State Road 37 at SR 37 slowing or stopping for traffic when V1 rear ended V2. Both drivers had their seat belts on. D2 stated the light was changing and stopped for the light while D1 thought D2 was going to proceed through the light.

Driver 1 stated she was south on Henderson St just past Hillside Dr. Vehicle 2 was parked on the west side of Henderson St facing south, just south of Hillside Dr. Driver 1 stated traffic was filling up both northbound lanes of Henderson St and she had to squeeze the bus between that traffic and vehicle 2. Driver 1 stated her bus hit the mirror of vehicle 2 as it passed.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY

D1 stated he was travelling westbound on W. Grimes Lane. D1 stated he went to make a right hand turn into the lot of 130 W. Grimes Lane, and while doing so side swiped a power line pole. I did observe damage along the passenger side of the bus. No injuries were reported. Utilities was advised of the damage to the power line.

UNIT 1 WAS PULLING INTO THE PARKING LOT OF CLEAR CREEK ELEMENTARY SCHOOL ON CLEAR CREEK DRIVE THE SAME TIME ANOTHER SCHOOL BUS WAS ATEMPTING TO EXIT THE PARKING LOT. UNIT 1 THEN PROCEEDED TO BACK OUT TO ALLOW THE OTHER BUS TO EXIT. WHILE BACKING, UNIT 1 DID NOT SEE UNIT 2 AND BACKED INTO THE DRIVER DOOR.

On Monday, September 30, 2019 at 18:32, Ryan Miller responded to a crash on Tower Ridge Rd. Tower Ridge Rd is a narrow two lane gravel roadway that runs primarily east to west. The area of this collision occurred at the exit of a right hand curve in a slight downward grade.V1, red GMC, was traveling west on Tower Ridge Road. V1 traveled off the south side of the roadway and began to rotate in a clockwise direction. V1 continued to rotate and travel west along the south side of the roadway. V1 struck a tree along the driver's side just behind the cab. V1 then changed rotation and began to rotate in a counterclockwise direction as it continued west. V1 came to final rest along the south side of the roadway parallel to a dry creek bed facing to the north. I arrived on scene to find V1 abandoned with the doors locked. I observed significant damage to the bed along the driver's side just behind the cab. The rear axle was broken with both rear tires deflated. The front passenger tire was deflated. The front driver's tire was the only tire inflated. The driveshaft was lying along the south side of the roadway near the front of V1. The tailgate from V1 was lying along the south side of the roadway west of the dry creek bed. I walked to the east of V1 and observed what appeared to be the area of impact involving a tree along the south side of the roadway. I observed yaw marks in the gravel leading to the tree. I observed fresh scrape marks on the tree consistent with an impact by V1. I observed a single GMC center cap lying just behind the tree with the scrape marks. V1 had the same center caps. The driver's side rear wheel was the only wheel missing a center cap. D1, Mitchell, arrived as I was photographing the scene. D1 stated he had been traveling west on Tower Ridge Rd. D1 stated he believed the front passenger tire went flat which caused him to lose control of V1. D1 stated he began to slide on the gravel before striking a tree. D1 stated he obtained a ride after the collision due to poor cell signal and returned with his father. V1 was occupied by a single passenger who as also present with D1. The passenger identified himself with an Arizona Driver's license as August Nicholas Acosta, DOB 10-13-1997, OLN D10878338. Neither D1 nor Acosta complained of injury. Evidence shows significant damage to the front driver's side portion of the cargo bed consistent with the area of impact involving the tree. Evidence shows D1 failed to maintain lane and traveled off the south side of the roadway before striking the tree. It is not clear if the front passenger tire became deflated prior to the collision with the tree or after impact. V1 traveled approximately 62 feet west from the area of impact to final rest. The tailgate was approximately123 feet west of the area of impact. Evidence shows the odor of an alcoholic beverage coming from D1's person during the accident investigation. D1 indicated he consumed alcoholic beverages prior to the collision. A PBT was administered at approximately 1930 hours with a positive result of .074% BrAC.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: It should be noted that the on-scene investigation for this accident was conducted by IUPD Officer Line (D588). All information henceforth, including scene diagram, was provided by Officer Line to be entered into ARIES:D1 stated she was traveling northbound on N. Lincoln St. When she stopped at the traffic control sign posted on the south side of the intersection of E. 10th St. D1 stated that she thought the intersection was clear, and proceeded through northbound, when she struck D2 on the rear driver side.D2 stated he was traveling westbound on 10th St, through the intersection of 10th and N. Lincoln, when he was struck by D1.Based on statements from D1/D2, and damage observed at the scene, Officer Line's investigation has yielded that D1 failed to yield to oncoming traffic, attempting to cross E. 10th St., and struck D2 on the rear driver side of his vehicle.

Both vehicles were facing east on State Road 45/46 Bypass. V2 was sitting at the Fee Lane traffic light. V1 was slowing behind V2. V1 rear ended V2. V1 was also pulling an empty trailer. D1 stated as he tried to slow V1 down, V1 started to lose power. D1 stated V1's power brakes went out and effected his stopping distance. V1 rear ended V2. V1 had front end damage along the entire front of the vehicle. D1's head struck the visor which caused a scratch on his forehead and minor bleeding. He denied any medical attention. D2 could not provide any information besides that he was completely stopped at the Fee Lane intersection in traffic when he was rear ended. D2 denied any medical attention.I looked at the brakes of V1 but could not visually identify any malfunctions. D1 stated if his vehicle started he would have power brakes and be able to move from the roadway. V1 was able to start and it was driven around a corner to a parking lot. I followed V1 to make sure he got to the parking lot safely. The brakes appeared to be working as he drove to the parking lot. D1 stated he was going to call people to give him a ride home and a wrecker for V1.

V1 and v2 were traveling westbound on 3rd street. V1 and v2 went through the intersection of 3rd and Jordan Ave. V1 was in the right lane, and V2 was in the left lane. A bus was stopped in the right lane just ahead of both vehicles. V1 made an aggressive lane change to avoid the bus, and move into the left lane. V1 sideswiped V2 in the process, and kept driving. D2 stated after she was sideswiped by V1 she continued following V1 down 3rd street. D2 was able to get license plate information of V1. D2 eventually lost sight of V1 and stopped to call the police.There was slight damage to the passenger side front fender of V2. Photographs were taken and added to the case.

D1 stated she was travelling southbound on S. Walnut Street in the left hand lane. D1 stated she thought she was rear ended by an unknown vehicle, which caused her to rear end V2 which was stopped in the roadway. After looking at D1's vehicle and speaking with her it was determined she was not rear ended. D2 stated she was travelling southbound on S. Walnut Street in the left lane when she noticed V1 stopped in the roadway. D2 stated she came to a stop. D2 advised she was suddenly rear ended by V1 which caused her to go forward and rear end V3. D3 advised she was stopped behind an uninvolved vehicle preparing to make a left turn. D3 stated she was facing southbound in the left lane. D3 advised while stopped in traffic she was rear ended by V2. No injuries were reported at this time.

D1 stated she was waiting behind V2 at a four way stop facing eastbound. D1 advised she though V2 was going so she accelerated and rear ended V2. D2 advised she was facing east at a four way stop. Just as she began to let off the brake to go forward she was rear ended by D1. D2 did have a complaint of pain in her neck and back. D2 was transported from the scene by EMS.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: D1/V1 STATED "I WAS NORTHBOUND ON S. PETE ELLIS DRIVE. I DID NOT SEE V2. I ENTERED THE INTERSECTION OF PETE ELLIS AND LONGVIEW AND COLLIDED WITH V2 ON THE PASSENGER SIDE DOOR PANEL".D2/V2 STATED "I WAS STOPPED AT THE STOP SIGN EASTBOUND ON E. LONGVIEW DRIVE. NORTH AND SOUTH LANES OF TRAVEL WENT THROUGH AND IT WAS NOW EAST/WEST BOUND TURN TO ENTER THE INTERSECTION. AS I ENTERED THE INTERSECTION OF S. PETE ELLIS, V1 RAN THE STOP SIGN AND COLLIDED WITH MY VEHICLE. V1 NEVER STOPPED AT THE STOP SIGN."

Vehicle 1 sideswiped Vehicle 2 as he was passing Vehicle 2 northbound, same direction.A witness called in and gave the plate number of the violator vehicle.Reporting officer got a BMV return on the plate number given. Matched vehicle description and physical description of driver given by the witness. Reporting officer attempted to locate the offending vehicle with information given. Unable to locate as of the time of this report.

At 1000 hours on 10/1/2019 V1 collided with a fence post that had been dug out and laid on the ground near the west entrance to the tailgating fields southeast of 17th Street and Indiana Avenue. D1 stated that as he was pulling into the lot the front of the truck obscured his view of the object laying in the road. He advised that the driver side running board had collided with the fence post and damaged the running board. There was a large crack running down the middle of the running board and no other damage to the vehicle. Photographs are attached.

D1 EXPLAINED THAT HE WAS DRIVING NORTH ON SOUTH ROGERS STREET AND WAS THEN ATTEMPTING TO TURN LEFT ON TO WEST PATTERSON DRIVE TO HEAD WEST ON PATTERSON.D1 EXPLAINED THAT AS HE WAS TURNING LEFT THAT HE DID NOT REALIZE THERE WAS A TURN LANE, TO TURN NORTH ON ROGERS STREET, FROM PATTERSON.AS D1 TURNED LEFT ON TO PATTERSON THE FRONT DRIVER'S CORNER OF V1 MADE CONTACT WITH THE FRONT DRIVER'S CORNER OF V2 RESUTLING IN DAMAGE TO BOTH VEHICLES.D2 THEN STATED THAT HE WAS STOPPED IN THE TURN LANE ON PATTERSON, FACING EAST, WHEN V1 ATTEMPTED TO TURN LEFT ON TO PATTERSON FROM SOUTH ROGERS STREET.D2 EXPLAINED THAT THE FRONT DRIVER'S CORNER OF V1 MADE CONTACT WITH THE FRONT DRIVER'S CORNER OF V2 RESULTING IN DAMAGE TO BOTH VEHICLES.

V1 was stopped at the stop sign on S. Walnut Street Pike at the intersection with S. Fairfax Rd. yielding to east and west bound traffic on S. Fairfax Rd. which does not have a stop sign. V2 was pulling out of the driveway of 5152 S. Fairfax Rd. which is directly across the street from S. Walnut Street Pike. V2 pulled out of the driveway to proceed straight on S. Walnut Street Pike. D1 stated that he looked both left and right as both directions were clear he proceeded to turn left onto S. Fairfax Road however D1 did not see V2 pulling out of the driveway to proceed straight. V1 crashed into V2 in the intersection. V1 sustained minor damage on the front drivers side and V2 sustained disabling damage on the rear drivers side.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: PEDACYCLIST WAS TRAVELING EB ON W 1ST ST, D1 WAS TRAVELING WB ON W 1ST ST. AT THE INTERSECTION OF S COLLEGE AVE, THE LIGHT WAS GREEN FOR EB AND WB. PEDACYCLIST ADVISED THERE WERE TWO VEHS IN FRONT OF THEM TRAVELING EB AND THEY FOLLOWED. ONCE THE TWO VEHS CLEARED, D1 TURNED SB ON S COLLEGE AVE. PEDACYLIST ADIVSED THEY SAW D1 ACTIONS AND ATTEMPTED TO AVOID THE COLLISION BY TURNING SB. PEDACYCLIST AND D1 COLLIDED ON THE PASSENGER SIDE OF V1. PEDACYCLIST FELL OFF BIKE AND GOT BACK UP. V1 LEFT. PEDACYCLIST ADVISED THEY LATER WENT TO THE HOSPITAL FOR A BROKEN CLAVICAL. ON THE WAY TO THE HOSP, PEDACYCLIST LOCATED V1 AND LATER FILED THE REPORT WITH POLICE. WAS ABLE TO LOCATE D1. D1 ADVISED HE DID NOT BELIEVE THE ACCIDENT CAUSED DAMAGE OR INJURY SO THEY DID NOT STOP. INSURANCE INFORMATION WAS THEN OBTAINED FROM D1. NO CRIME.

D2 was sitting in her vehicle at the fuel pump when V1 pulled in and collided with V2. D2 then stated she spoke with D1 for brief minute and recognized him from prior involvements as Mr. Lacomb. D1 attempted to give D2 a false name until D2 stated she knew who he was. D1 then gave D2 an insurance card and the vehicle owners phone number and asked D2 not to call the police. D1 then left the scene, traveling south on S Leonard Springs Rd.I later located the vehicle (V1) at the address on the registration and noticed damage consistent with the crash. I attempted to speak with Mr. Lacomb but they would not answer the door. A copy of the drivers exchange form was left under the windshield wiper of V1. At this time, D1 or the owner of V1 have called in to discuss the accident.

V1 is unknown. V2 was parked facing east in the Indiana Memorial Union parking lot #1.The owner of V2 stated he parked the vehicle at 4:00 PM and then came out at 7:30 PM and saw damage to his driver's side rear bumper.There were no witnesses. Pictures were taken of the damage and turned in with the report.

See Narrative- Other Location of Investigation: I met with D2 on scene of the accident. I met with D1 at IUPD at 1469 E. 17th Street, Bloomington, IN. D1 was backing up going south attempting to begin traveling north in the parking lot. V2 was parked stationary in the south side of the parking lot facing south.D2 stated that her vehicle was parked in the south side of the parking lot facing south. D2 stated that on 10/01/2019 at approximately 1600 hours, she noticed her vehicle had heavy damage to the bumper on the passenger side. D2 stated she was not in the car at the time of the accident. I viewed camera footage provided by a resident of 928 E. 3rd Street that showed D1 backing into V2 traveling south. The footage showed V2 leaving the scene of the crash headed north in the parking lot. That footage will be attached to the case. I met with D1 on station and through my investigation determined that D1 did not know he was involved in a crash. D1 stated he had backed up in the parking lot but did not realize that he had hit V2. I looked at V1 and did not notice any damage to the vehicle. Because D1 did not realize he had been in a crash, he did not know what happened. I am not seeking enforcement actions on D1 due to him having no malicious or criminal intent. There were no reported injuries. Neither car was towed.

WHILE BACKING IN THE SOUTHWEST DIRECTION IN FRONT OF 1141 SOUTH ADAMS STREETVEHICLE 1 STRUCK VEHICLES 2,3, AND 4. VEHICLES 2,3, AND 4 WERE FACING IN THE NORTHWEST DIECTION AND WERE PARKED IN FRONT OF 1141 SOUTH ADAMS STREET.VEHICLE 1 LEFT THE SCENE AND DROVE TO A SPOT IN FRONT OF 1331 SOUTH ADAMS STREET AND PARKED.DRIVER 1 WAS UNINJURED AND REFUSED MEDICAL TREATMENT. V1 WAS NORTHBOUND ON ROGERS STREET APPROACHING PROSPECT ST.V2 WAS DIRECTLY IN FRONT OF V1 AND WAS STOPPED IN TRAFFIC.D1 SAID WHEN HE SAW V2 SLOW DOWN TO STOP HE WAS NOT ABLE TO GET STOPPED BEFORE COLLIDING WITH V2.D2 SAID AS HE SAT IN TRAFFIC AND V1 HIT HIM FROM BEHIND.

VEHICLE 1 IS A SKID STEER CONSTRUCTION IMPLEMENT. V2 WAS FORCED TO GO AROUND INTO LEFT LANE JUST BEFORE COLLISION.D1 STATED HE WAS OPERATING SKID STEER IN PRIVATE LOT OF ALDI 2035 S LIBERTY DRIVE BACKING THE SKID STEER GOING SOUTH WHILE FACING NORTH. D2 STATED HE TURNED AROUND IN THE LOT WHERE D1 SHOULD HAVE SEEN HIM. D2 STATED HE THEN WENT INTO THE LEFT LANE DUE TO RIGHT LANE BEING CLOSED. D2 STATED HE WAS WAITING FOR TRAFFIC TO CLEAR ON S LIBERTY DRIVE WHEN V1 BACKED INTO HIM.D2 STATED THAT THERE WAS SUPPOSED TO BE A "SPOTTER" WATCHING THE REAR OF THE SKID STEER FOR THESE SUCH EVENTS. D2 CLAIMS THERE WAS NOT A "SPOTTER" AT THE TIME OF THE ACCIDENT. NO PICTURES.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: D1 stated that she was driving through the gas station parking in between 2 other vehicles. When she passed V2 she caught her right front bumper on the left rear of V2 causing damage to her vehicle. Vehicle owner of V2 stated he was not in the vehicle and that there was only a small scratch on the left rear of his vehicle.

V1 WAS FACING WEST AND BACKING EASTBOUND OUT OF A PARKING SPACE AT 3585 W. ST. RD. 45 (WALMART). V2 WAS FACING EAST AND BEGAN BACKING WESTBOUND OUT OF A PARKING SPACE AT 3585 W. ST. RD. 45 (WALMART). D1 STATED SHE WAS STOPPED IN THE ISLE GETTING READY TO DRIVE AWAY WHEN V2 BACKED QUICKLY OUT OF HIS SPACE AND STRUCK THE REAR PASSENGER SIDE OF V1.D2 GOT OUT OF HIS VEHICLE LOOKED AT THE DAMAGE, GOT BACK INTO HIS VEHICLE AND TOLD D1 THAT HE HAD TO LEAVE TO GO TO WORK AND D2 LEFT THE SCENE WITHOUT PROVIDING ANY INFORMATION.

Sergeant Don Teague was patrolling northbound on South Walnut Street at South Drive in Bloomington, Monroe County, Indiana when we observed vehicle 1 traveling at approximately 80+ MPH in the 30 MPH speed zone. Sergeant Teague began to turn around on the vehicle at which time it attempted to turn into the Lucky's Grocery store at 2424 South Walnut Street. While still traveling at a high rate of speed, the Malibu was unable to make the sharp curve into the southern entrance for the Walnut Park shopping center where Lucky's is located and traveled through/over the square, concrete curbing near the entrance. The force of the collision with the curb caused extensive damage to vehicle 1. Specifically vehicle 1's front bumper was ripped off and became stuck underneath the frame once stopped, the vehicle's radiator was severely damaged from striking the curb while entering and exiting the landscaped area of the southern entrance to the complex.Front passenger complained of pain to his right rear thigh area and was seen by EMS personnel at his request. No immediate medical concerns were located and the passenger was released form the scene. Sergeant Teague conducted an OWI investigation with driver 1 and additional information regarding those tests and results can be obtained from the Monroe County Sheriff's Office records division.

DRIVER 1 STATED HE WAS EN ROUTE TO A POLICE MATTER AND LOOKING FOR THE LOCATION OF THE SCENE WHILE GOING STRAIGHT, AS HE WAS DOING THIS TRAFFIC CAME TO A STOP AND HE COULD NOT BRAKE IN TIME TO AVOID A COLLISION WITH VEHICLE 2. THE COLLISION WITH VEHICLE 2 CAUSED VEHICLE 2 TO COLLIDE WITH VEHICLE 3 CAUSING A SIMULTANEOUS COLLISION.DRIVER 2 STATED TRAFFIC HAD COME TO A STOP AND SHE WAS REAR ENDED BY VEHICLE 1 WHICH CAUSED HER VEHICLE TO COLLIDE WITH VEHICLE 3. REAR PASSENGER OF VEHICLE 2 HAD A COMPLAINT OF PAIN IN HER NECK, HOWEVER SHE DID REFUSE MEDICAL TREATMENT ON SCENE.DRIVER 3 STATED HE WAS IN TRAFFIC AND WAS REAR ENDED BY VEHICLE 2.

On 10/2/19 at an unknown time, V2 was struck by V1 while parked in the parking lot of the apartment complex.V2 was parked facing West, Vehicle Owner 2 found her vehicle scratched and dented on the right passenger side fender. Parked next to V2 was V1. V1 had damage to its front left drivers side fender. There was white paint transfer on V1 and a dent. Photographs of V1 parked next to me were provided to me by V2 owner. V2 owner stated when she found the damage on her vehicle, V1 was parked next to it but the owner had not been located. V2 owner took photographs of both vehicles. V1 was later moved before a driver could be identified. I have been unable to located a driver for V1.

D2 stated that he was traveling East or Southeast on E. SR 46, when a vehicle with a wide load traveled towards him. D2 advised that the vehicle directly in front of him slowed/stopped abruptly at which time D2 slowed. However, D2 advised that the vehicle behind him was unable to slow in time due to the vehicle stopping abruptly in front of him. Ultimately V1 hit the rear end of V2. D1 provided me with the same course of events. D1 stated that there was a wide load traveling West on E. SR 46 when a vehicle in front of V2 stopped quickly, at which time V2 was able to slow his speeds. However, D1 stated that he was unable to slow in time and attempted to swerve to the right, but observed that there was a ditch and decided against utilizing the right side of the roadway and ultimately struck the rear end of V2.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
Manner of Collision: HEAD ON BETWEEN TWO MOTOR VEHICLES
