State Rd. 37.V1 entered the intersection as V2 continued eastbound when given a green signal.V1 struck V2 with it's front passenger bumper.V1 sustained moderate damage to the front passenger corner.V2 sustained moderate damage to the front left quarter panel and driver doorway.
DRIVER #1 STATED HE WAS SOUTH BOUND ON FAIRFAX AND SWERVED TO MISS A DEER AND COLLIDED WITH A UTILITY POLE AND FLIPPED HIS CAR.

V1 WAS TRAVELING EASTBOUND ON W STATE ROAD 46, EAST OF THE W ARLINGTON ROAD INTERSECTION WHEN IT REAR ENDED V2 WHICH CAUSED V2 TO REAR END V3.D1 STATED THAT HE BRIEFLY LOOKED AT HIS PHONE THAT WAS AFFIXED TO HIS WINDOW, LOOKED UP AND SUDDENLY STRUCK V2.

Collision occurred in the gas station parking lot at 5100 S Victor Pike. D1 stated he was parked in the parking lot and moved his vehicle to the gas pumps to get gas. D1 stated he was driving towards one of the pumps however there was already a vehicle at that pump therefore he turned to pull into another pump. D1 turned too wide and side swiped a concrete barrier adjacent to the fuel pump. The barrier was pushed over.An employee with the gas station advised that the same concrete barrier had been previously hit however they do not believe it had been pushed over as far as it was now.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: D1 was headed E/B on W 2nd St, approaching the intersection of S Rogers St. D2 was headed W/B on W 2nd St, approaching the intersection of S Rogers St. D1 began to make a left turn onto S Rogers St as D2 came through tge intersection, causing a collision. D1 stated he was headed E/B on W 2nd St, approaching S Rogers St. D1 stated that he stopped at the intersection and waited for the green traffic signal to give him the right of way. D1 stated that he did receive the green turn signal and began to make his left turn onto S Rogers St. D1 stated that D2 then came through the intersection and struck V1 in the front drivers side. It should be noted that D1 did not speak English and this information was translated from his son, who is the owner of the V1. D2 stated he was headed W/B on W 2nd St, approaching the intersection of S Rogers St. D2 stated that as he approached the intersection he saw that he had a green traffic signal giving him the right of way, so he proceeded through the intersection, at which point D1 turned in front of him, causing V2 to strike V1.

Owner of vehicle 2 parked on N Park Ave facing south just north of the intersection of E 10th St at approximately 05:00 PM. When she returned to the vehicle at approximately 06:45 PM she noticed her driver's side mirror had been damaged as well as her driver's side fender. No known suspect information or cause of the accident. The cover for mirror of vehicle 2 was located behind the rear driver's side tire. It is possible that vehicle 1 was traveling west on 10th and turned onto Park and turned wide and struck vehicle 2 causing the mirror cover to end where it is located. It is also possible vehicle 1 was traveling south on park and side swiped vehicle 1 and then got out to check damage and moved mirror cover before leaving the scene.Vehicle 2 was able to drive from the scene.

No other officers assisted with the accident investigation.V1 was parked, engine off, next to a building while the owner was inside.V2 was parked in a valid parking stall behind, and to the left, of V1.The owner of V1, referred to as O1, had stated he was having vehicle troubles as his vehicle would not turn on. He then left his vehicle in the private residence's parking lot while he went back inside which was also his place of employment. He stated that he came back outside to his vehicle and noticed it had now rolled backwards approximately 40 feet into a parked car. O1 was not sure how the vehicle slipped out of gear and rolled backwards, but he stated he was positive the transmission was in 'park'.There was a third vehicle, a red Ford Mustang, that was also parked that V1 made contact with. However, after contacting the owner of the Mustang it was determined there was no damage sustained and therefore its information is not mentioned in the report.Due to the unsafe condition that V1 was apparently in, it was towed by Ken's Westside towing.

D2 EXPLAINED THAT HE WAS DRIVING WEST ON 3RD STREET, APPROACHING THE INTERSECTION OF 3RD AND WALNUT WHEN ANOTHER VEHICLE, A SILVER FORD TAURUS DID TURN ON TO THE CURB IN ORDER TO PULL IN TO THE FIRESTONE CAR SHOP.D2 DID STATE THAT HE DID BEGIN TO SLOW HIS VEHICLE DOWN, AS THE SILVER FORD WAS STILL PARTIALLY IN THE ROADWAY.THE FRONT OF V1 DID THEN MAKE CONTACT WITH THE REAR OF V2 RESULTING IN DAMAGE TO BOTH VEHICLES.D1 STATED THAT HE WAS DRIVING WEST ON 3RD STREET, APPROACHING THE INTERSECTION OF WALNUT AND 3RD STREET WHEN V2 DID HIT ITS BREAKS. THE FRONT OF V1 DID MAKE CONTACT WITH THE REAR OF V2.D1 MENTIONED THAT THEY DID HAVE THE GREEN LIGHT TO TRAVEL WEST ON 3RD STREET.V1 WAS TOWED DUE TO DISABLING DAMAGE.
V1 WAS TRAVELING NORTH ON UNION VALLEY NEAR MAEFILED ST WHEN A DEER RAN IN FRONT OF THE VEHICLE. D1 ADVISED SHE WAS UNABLE TO AVOID STRIKING THE DEER.

D1 stated that she was traveling northbound on S Walnut Street in the west lane, approximately 150 south of W Smith Avenue. D1 stated that she was going approximately 15-20 miles per hour when she began to sneeze multiple times. D1 stated that she did not notice traffic slowing while she was sneezing, and she ran into the rear of V2. D2 stated that he was traveling northbound on S Walnut Street in the west lane, just south of W Smith Avenue, and he was stopped in traffic for approximately 10 seconds. D2 stated that while stopped in traffic waiting for the traffic signal to change, V2 was struck in the rear by V1. Both drivers denied an ambulance and both stated that they were not injured. Neither vehicle had disabling damage and both vehicles were able to be driven from the scene.
DRIVER STATED HE WAS NORTHBOUND ON SR 37 NORTH OF INGRAM ROAD WHEN A DEER JUMPED INTO THE ROADWAY AND COLLIDED WITH HIS VEHICLE.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY

V1 WAS ATTEMPTING TO ENTER THE LANE OF TRAVEL FROM A PARKING SPOT LOCATED ON THE SOUTH SIDE OF THE STREET WHEN IT MADE IMPACT WITH V2 CAUSING DAMAGE. V2/D2 STATED AS HE WAS STOPPING AT THE INTERSECTION HIS VEHICLE WAS STRUCK BY V1 AS IT APPEARED TO EXIT THE PARKING SPOT. V1 SUSTAINED DAMAGE TO THE FRONT LEFT 1/4 PANEL PORTION OF THE DRIVERS SIDE. V2 SUSTAINED DAMAGE TO THE FRONT RIGHT BUMPER POTION OF THE VEHICLE.

Driver of the vehicle was traveling northbound on I69 and was taking the 120A eastbound exit. Driver said that when he braked to take the exit, his vehicle became shaky and his brakes were not responding. Driver said that his vehicle left the roadway and he no longer had any control, then his vehicle flipped after hitting a small hill off the roadway. His vehicle came to rest upside down and driver sustained a minor injury to his head.

Driver of vehicle 1 stated it was dark and she did not see the curve in the road until it was too late. She ran off the road and hit a Monroe County Highway sign indicating there was a curve there. The sign was knocked down. Vehicle one was pulled back on the road by a passing truck. Vehicle 1 sustained front end damage to the hood and front bumper.

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: V1 on Oard Road at Vernal Pike, speed to fast for road conditions. D1 admitted to traveling to fast, left roadway, collided with large boulders at 7650 Vernal Pike resulting in minor yard damage. Damage to vehicle was disabling.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: V1 was traveling eastbound on State Road 46. V2 was traveling westbound on State Road 46 approaching N. Deer Park Drive. V3 was stationary on N. Deer Park drive facing south. V1 attempted to turn left (north) onto N. Deer Park Drive. In doing so, V1 pulled in front of V2. V2 hit V1, and then V1 hit V3. D1 was only able to state that he attempted to turn left and V3 was stopped past the stop sign and into the roadway. D1 was unable to provide any more detail about turning in front of V2. D1 stated the V3 was the reason for the wreck.V1 has damage along the right side of the vehicle and left front.D2 stated while traveling westbound, V1 suddenly turned in front of him. D2 was unable to stop or avoid a collision. D2 stated V1 attempted to turn in between V2 and V3.V2 had damage to the right front. D3 stated he was sitting at the stop sign when V1 turned left suddenly. D3 stated V1 attempted to go between himself and V2 but was struck by V2 and hit V3. V3 had damage to the right front bumper. All parties stated they did not need medical attention. D1 was investigated and booked into the Monroe County Jail for Operating While Intoxicated-Endangerment.
D1 NB on SR 37 @ Smithville Road when a deer entered path of travel and resulted in a front end collision.

Vehicle 3 was traveling west on Bloomfield Rd. Vehicle 2 was traveling directly behind vehicle 3 and vehicle 1 was traveling directly behind vehicle 2. Vehicle 3 was attempting to turn south into 1455 W Bloomfield Rd. Vehicle 3 was stopped waiting on east bound traffic. Vehicle 2 came to a stop behind vehicle 3. Driver of vehicle 1 stated that he looked out the side window for a second and when he looked back he noticed vehicle 2 and 3 had stopped in the roadway. Driver of vehicle 1 was unable to stop and collided with the rear of vehicle 2 moving vehicle 2 forward into the rear of vehicle 3. Vehicle 3 has no noticeable damage. Vehicle 2 has very minor damage to the front and moderate damage to the rear. Vehicle 1 has significant damage to the front.Vehicle 1 and 2 were towed due to disabling damage. No injuries were reported.

V1 was traveling west on E State Road 45 when a deer ran out in the roadway in front of V1. D1 stated he was unable to avoid hitting the deer. V1 sustained minor damage to the front drivers side of V1.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: On 10/05/2019 at approximately 2349 hours, I arrived at the intersection of 10th Street and the State Road 45/46 Bypass to take a report of a pedestrian vs vehicle accident. Prior to my arrival, dispatch advised that the pedestrian did not want an ambulance. I arrived on scene and noticed that V1 was stopped facing northwest on the bypass from 10th Street with a shattered windshield. V1 looked as though it was attempting to turn northbound onto the bypass from 10th Street.I met with the pedestrian that was struck by V1. P1 was up and moving and seemed to have an adrenaline rush but did not seem hurt. I asked several times if he wanted an ambulance to come check him out and he stated he did not need an ambulance and would just see a doctor in the morning if he felt sore or like something was wrong. He only stated he felt that he may have a cut on his left knee but was otherwise fine.P1 stated that he was traveling eastbound on the crosswalk on the bypass. He stated he had the walk sign and was on his electric skate board. P1 stated he saw V1 stopped on 10th Street facing westbound trying to turn northbound onto the bypass. P1 stated he saw V1 start to accelerate and tried to catch D1's attention because P1 was unable to stop his electric skate board in time. Once he was close and knew he was going to get hit by V1, P1 stated he jumped up and landed on V1's windshield. I then spoke with D1. D1 stated he was stopped at the red light on 10th Street facing westbound at the intersection of the 45/46 Bypass. D1 stated he wanted to turn northbound onto the bypass and was inching forward trying to make sure there was no oncoming traffic. He stated he did not see P1 until he was right in front of him. D1 stated P1 was just north of the crosswalk when he struck him and immediately came to a stop. D1 stated his finger was bleeding and refused an ambulance. D1 stated he had a prior, minor cut on his finger and that he gripped the steering wheel so hard during the collision that it opened back up. V1 sustained damage to the windshield and the hood of the car. The windshield was shattered and had a hole on the driver's side where P1 had landed. The hood of the vehicle also had several scuff marks where P1 and his backpack and made contact when getting on/off the car. I took pictures of V1. The SD card was sealed in an evidence bag and placed in locker number .V1 was towed by Ken's Westside.

WITNESS ADVISED DRIVER 1 BACKED OUT OF A PARKING SPACE AT 3201 W SR 45, SAMS CLUB AND PLACED V1 INTO DRIVE. AT THAT TIME, DRIVER 1 HAD A SIGNIFICANT MEDICAL EVENT AND LOST CONCIOUSNESS. V1 ROLLED INTO V2. DRIVER 1 WAS TRANSPORTED TO THE HOSPITAL AND COULD NOT GIVE A STATEMENT. VEHICLE 2 WAS NOT OCCUPPIED.

On 11/06/2019 around 0046 hours I, Officer Shaffer, responded to the area of E North Drive and S Walnut Street for a report of a possible accident involving a green SUV. I arrived on scene and observed a Green Jeep Cherokee with Indiana License Plate WPS291 wrecked just south of E North Drive. The license plate returned to a Donald L. Drake JR. The Jeep was unoccupied and appeared to have struck a nearby tree resulting in heavy front end damage to the front passenger side and damage to the tree. There was also a bumper and various pieces of car lights on the base of the tree from the Jeep. The keys were also in the ignition and appeared to be turned into the engine on position, however, the Jeep was not running. I observed marks on the road, curb, and grass that indicated the car was possibly driving west bound on E North Drive before going over the curb sideways or at an angle (4 different tire marks n grass/rubber marks on curb) before striking the tree. Because the vehicle was abandoned and heavily damaged I requested a tow truck to remove the vehicle. While I was waiting for the Chandler's Towing, a burglary in progress was dispatched at 772 E RIDGE CREST CT which is not very far to the east of where this accident occurred. The male subject in the burglary was described as a male in a red shirt. I was then told over the radio that this male would be the subject from the accident that had left the scene. Officer Owen met with the Jeep and Chandler's towing to complete an inventory and Tow form while I met with Officers on Ridge Crest Court. When I arrived the male in the red shirt, later identified by his Indiana License as Donald Lee Drake III, was already detained in handcuffs as he had been possibly attempting to burglarize the residence. When I had contact with Drake I could smell the odor of alcoholic beverage on his exhaled breath, I observed watery and glossy eyes, and Drake's speech was slurred and at times incoherent. Drake also had numerous cuts and scrapes to his knees and head, including a bloody nose. There was also mud on his shoes and legs. Based on what I observed at the crash, Drake's state of being, and his proximity to the crash, I read Drake his Miranda Warning to which he said he understood his rights and would speak with me. Drake advised he did not remember being in crash but when asked again if anyone else was in the car with him he said no and when asked if he was the only one in the vehicle Drake said yes. I asked Drake when the last time he drank alcohol was and he advised a few hours ago (from 0100 hours when questioned). Drake did not initially elaborate on what type of alcohol, though. Because of the nature of the accident I did not perform standard field sobriety tests because it was unclear if he may have had any underlying injuries, therefore I decided I would also take him to the Hospital. Based on Drake admitting to being the only occupant of the car, advising the Green Jeep was his car, leaving the scene without properly notifying any police department, admitting to consuming alcoholic beverages, having alcoholic beverage odor emitting off his person and exhaled breath, slurred and incoherent speech, and watery and glossy eyes, I had probable cause to believe Drake operated a vehicle while intoxicated. I read Drake Indiana Implied Consent to which he said he understood and would submit to a chemical test (Blood Draw). I transported Drake to IU Health Bloomington, removed the handcuffs from Drake, and read over the consent form with him to make sure he understood. Drake and I then both signed the form. Drake's Blood was taken and placed into an Indiana Department of Toxicology kit vials on 11/06/2019 at 0149 hours. I labeled and sealed the kit. In speaking with Drake I asked him what type of alcohol he consumed tonight and he advised it was a mixture of Beer and Whiskey/Liquor. Drake underwent many more tests including a cat scan before being medically released. While at the hospital Drake
V-1 was traveling south on fairfax road when a deer ran into V-1 lane of travel striking the front of V-1.

On 11/06/2019 Unit 1 was traveling North on I-69 near the 110 mile marker. While traveling North, a deer ran out in front of the vehicle. Unit 1 driven by Driver 1 identified as Zachary Bartlett, struck the deer causing unit 1 to travel off the roadway and come to a rest on the shoulder of North I-69 at mile marker 110 against a gaurdrail. The deer was not located at the scene of the accident and the driver reported no injuries.

V1 was SB on Walnut street pike and was turning right onto E Burks drive. V1 ran off the road on the SW side of the road and struck a stop sign.D1 stated she was on her phone while driving and ran off the road and hit a stop sign.

D1 stated he reversed his vehicle and heard the noise of his rear bumper colliding with the rear tow hitch on D2. D1 attempted to pull forward away from D2 however the tow hitch was now stuck to the rear bumper. As D1 pulled forward, it pulled the rear end of D2 into D3.Both D2 and D3 were parked and unoccupied.

CAMILLE CORNIL, WHO IS THE DAUGHTER OF THE OWNER OF V2, STATED THAT SHE HAD PARKED V2 IN FRONT OF HER RESIDENCE AT 2372 SOUTH HENDERSON STREET.V2 IS FACING WEST IN THE PARKING LOT, IN A PARKING SPACE.DURING THE NIGHT OF NOVEMBER 6, 2019 THE DRIVER'S SIDE OF V2 WAS STRUCK BY A WHITE VEHICLE, RESULTING IN WHITE PAINT TRANSFER, SCRATCHES, AND A DENT TO THE DRIVER'S SIDE OF THE VEHICLE.IT APPEARS THAT V1 WAS ATTEMPTING TO BACK OUT OF THE PARKING SPOT NEXT TO V2 AND AS V1 WAS BACKING OUT OF THE PARKING SPOT THE FRONT PASSNEGER CORNER OF V1 DID MAKE CONTACT WITH THE DRIVER'S SIDE OF V2.THE DAMAGE WAS INDICATIVE OF AN OPPOSITE DIRECTION SIDE SWIPE.THERE IS NO SUSPECT INFORMATION OR INFORMATION FOR V1 AT THIS TIME.

Driver 1 stated she was behind vehicle 2 when they slowed to turn and she rear ended vehicle 2 with the front of her vehicle. Driver 2 stated she was turning right onto Kirkwood Ave from S Walnut Street when she was rear ended by vehicle 1.

V2 was making a left hand turn off of I-69 onto West 3rd Street, with the green light. V1 was eastbound on 3rd street, disregarded the red stop light at I-69, and struck the passenger side of V2.D1 stated he was westbound on 3rd Street when he possibly disregarded the stop light and struck the passenger side of V2.D2 stated she was making a left hand turn off of I-69 onto West 3rd Street when V1 struck the passenger side of the vehicle.

Driver 1 was traveling northbound on South State Road 446 approaching East Grubb Road when a deer proceeded onto the roadway in her lane of travel. Driver 1 was unable to avoid the deer and struck in causing heavy front end damage. Driver 1 did not require medical personnel and Ken's Westside towed the vehicle due to the heavy front end damage.

V1 was at the intersection of Woodlawn Ave and Indiana Ave facing north. V2 was stopped in traffic at the intersection of Woodlawn Ave and Indiana Ave facing north on Woodlawn Ave.D1 stated she was at the intersection of Woodlawn Ave and Indiana Ave facing north. D1 stated that she was too far in the intersection so she started to back up. D1 stated that she backed up too far and collided with V2.D2 stated that he was stopped in traffic at the intersection of Woodlawn Ave and Indiana Ave facing north when V1 suddenly started to back up and collided with his front bumper.Pictures were taken of the minor damage to V2 and turned in with this case.

V1/D1 IS UNKNOWN.V2/D2 STATED ON SCENE "I DONT KNOW WHAT HAPPENED."D2 STATED AT THE IU HEALTH HOSPITAL ER ROOM 11, "I WAS STOPPED AT THE RED LIGHT ON W. 17TH ST, HEADING EAST TOWARD IU CAMPUS. AS MY LIGHT TURNED GREEN AND TAN OR SILVER SEDAN RAN THE NORTHBOUND RED LIGHT AND CLIPPED MY MOTORCYCLE."SKID MARKS ARE PRIOR TO THE INTERSECTION OF 17TH/WALNUT AND THE DAMAGE IS NOT CONSITANT WITH D2 STATEMENT. IT APPEARS V2 MAY HAVE REARENED AN UNKNOWN VEHICLE. EXTREME FRONT END DAMAGE, NO OTHER VEHICLE PARTS LEFT BEHIND, AND THE SKID MARKS SHOW MOTORCYCLE WAS LAID DOWN PRIOR TO THE INTERSECTION AND THAT V2 WAS IN MOTION AT THE TIME V2 WAS ON THE GROUND. HELMET WAS LOCATED ABOUT 25 FT WEST OF THE CRASH. SEARCHING FOR VIDEO IN THE AERA.NO VIDEO AT THE MAY AGENCY INSURANCE COMPANY, NO VIDEO AT SCHOLAR ROCK APTS, NO VIDEO AT RESTURANT ACROSS THE STREET.

V1 WAS TRAVELING WB ON W 3RD ST APPROACHING THE INTERSECTION OF S KIMBLE DR. D1 ADVSISED THEY WERE TRAVELING AT APPROXIAMLTY 30MPH. D1 STATED SHE DID NOT SEE ANYONE IN THE ROADWAY, SHE LOOKED UP AT THE LIGHT TO SEE IF SHE NEEDED TO SLOW DOWN AND WHEN SHE LOOED BACK AT THE ROADWAY, SHE STATED SHE SAW A BACKPACK. SHE THEN HEARD A PERSON HIT HER CAR. SHE BELIEVES THE PERSON STRUCK HER REAR PASSENGER SIDE, SHE THEN IMMEDIATLEY STOPPED AND GOT OUT TO ASSIST THE PEDESTRIAN. THE PEDESTRIAN ADVISED SHE DID NOT SEE ANY VEHICLES AND CROSSED THE ROADWAY, WHEN SHE WAS STRUCK BY V1. THE PEDESTRIAN HAD A COMPLAINT OF PAIN TO HER KNEE AND WAS TRANSPORTED TO THE HOSPITAL. IT SHOULD BE NOTED, THE PEDESTRIAN DID APPEAR TO BE INTOXICATED. SHE HAD SLURRED SPEECH AND HAD THE ODOR OF ALOCOHOLIC BEVERAGE ON HER EXHALED BREATH. THERE DID NOT APPEAR TO BE ANY DAMAGE TO V1.
V-1 was traveling east on SR46 when the right rear wheel and tire came off of V-1 and traveled into V-2 lane of travel striking the right rear side of V-2.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: D1 stated that he was traveling west on State Road 45, and had attempted to turn south onto S Curry Pike. D1 stated that the light was green for his direction of traffic, but there was no arrow displayed on the stop light. D1 stated that he did not see D2 coming when he attempted to make his turn, and collided with V2 as he turned into the intersection. The front driver's side bumper of V1 collided with the rear driver's side fender area of V2.D2 stated that he was driving east on State Road 45, going through the intersection of S Curry Pike. D2 stated that the light was green for his direction of traffic. D2 stated that as he was going through the intersection, he saw V1 to his left out of the corner of his left eye, when he suddenly felt an impact to his vehicle coming from V1.

V1 and V2 were traveling westbound on Burks Dr. V1 stopped and backed up striking V2.D1 stated that she was on the phone and did not see V2 and struck it while backing up.D2 stated that he was behind V1 and that it stopped in front of him and began to back up. He was stopped and did honk his horn, however V1 struck him while backing.V1 did strike V2 causing damage to both vehicles.

V1 was SB on S Park avenue and was approaching E Hunter Ave. V2 was parked on the west side of the Park avenue facing SB. V1 was driving past V2 and then moved to the right. As V1 moved to the right, she hit the front driver side bumper of V2 with the passenger side of V1.D1 stated that she drove past V2, which was about 2ft off the curb. As she was going past V2, she began to move back to the right and hit the front of V2. It should be noted that V2 was parked more than 10" from the curb and in violation of city ordinance. V1 still should have been able to avoid hitting V2.

V1 was traveling straight going southbound on the SR 45/46 Bypass towards Tenth Street. V2 was stopped traveling southbound on the SR 45/46 Bypass towards Tenth Street. V1 did not notice that V2 was stopped and continued going straight. V1 then rear ended V2. V1 had minimal damage to the front bumper. V2 had moderate damage to the rear bumper.D1 stated that he saw traffic on his right continuing to move so he thought that his lane would move forward as well. D1 stated that he did not see that V2 was stopped and accidentally rear ended V2.D2 stated that she was stopped in traffic and was jolted hard when V1 rear ended her vehicle. D2 stated that she did not see V1 coming. D2's 10 year old son, Owen, was in the rear passenger seat in a booster seat and hit his head during the collision. EMS arrived in Ambulance #2159 and checked on Owen who complained of pain to the back of his head. Owen was cleared by EMS and signed an SOR. EMS said that he would be sore tomorrow but did not need immediate medical attention. No vehicles had to be towed from the scene. There is nothing further at this time.

V1 was EB on E. 10th street and was nearing N. Smith road. V2 was in front of V1 and was stopped in traffic. V1 failed to get stopped and struck V2 in the rear with the front of her vehicle causing damage to both vehicles.D1 stated that she was headed EB on 10th street and as she came over a hill she noticed V2 was stopped. She stated she was unable to get stopped before striking V2 in the rear bumper.D2 stated that she was EB on 10th street and the vehicles in front of her had stopped for a funeral procession going WB. She was able to get stopped and was then hit in the rear by V1.

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: When I arrived on scene, I observed a white Ford F150 (V1) on the south sidewalk against the embankment just south of the intersection of 17th St and 45/46 Bypass.I spoke with the driver, Dominic Alexander (D1), who stated that he was driving south on the bypass in the right lane of travel. D1 claimed that another vehicle (P1) performed a right on red turn off of 17th St in front of him causing him to swerve into the left lane of travel. As he swerved left, he lost control of the vehicle. The tail end of the vehicle swerved left then back right, over the curb, onto the sidewalk, and backwards into the stone embankment. V1 did not make contact with any other vehicles.There was no information or description of P1.D1 complained of head, neck, and upper back pain. He was transported to Bloomington Hospital by ambulance.V1 sustained moderate damage to the driver side rear bumper, tailgate, and fender. It was able to be driven. Bland's Towing towed the vehicle to their lot.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
Manner of Collision: HEAD ON BETWEEN TWO MOTOR VEHICLES
NARRATIVE: DRIVER ONE STATED HE WAS ATTEMPTING TO TURN LEFT ONTO WEST 3RD STREET FROM A DRIVEWAY ON THE SOUTH SIDE OF THE ROAD. TRAFFIC WAS SLOWING AND HE WAS WAVED ON BY ANOTHER DRIVER TO CUT ACROSS THE EAST BOUND LANES OF TRAFFIC, AS HE DID SO DRIVER 1 STRUCK VEHICLE 2 HEAD ON.DRIVER 2 STATED THAT SHE WAS GOING STRAIGHT IN THE EAST BOUND LANES OF WEST 3RD STREET WHEN VEHICLE 1 CUT ACROSS EASTBOUND TRAFFIC LANES ATTEMPTING TO TURN LEFT TO GO WEST AND THEN STRUCK HER VEHICLE HEAD ON. NO INJURIES.DRIVER 2 REQUESTED A PRIVATE TOW FROM BLAND'S.

OWNER OF VEHICLE 1 STATED V1 WAS PARKED IN FRONT OF 454 S WESTPLEX AVENUE BETWEEN 1900 HRS AND 0845 HRS THIS MORNING. WHEN SHE CAME OUT TO MOVE IT, THERE WAS A NOTE UNDER HER WINDSHIELD WIPER, BUT SHE DID NOT GET OUT IN THE RAIN TO LOOK AT IT AND IT SUBSEQUENTLY BLEW OFF WHEN HER WINDSHIELD WIPERS CAME ON. AFTER MOVING V1, SHE OBSERVED DAMAGE TO THE PASSENGER SIDE AND REALIZED THE OTHER DRIVER HAD LEFT A NOTE FOR HER, BUT SHE WAS UNABLE TO LOCATE IT.

U1 was traveling S on N Stinesville Rd. U1 lost control of the vehicle causing her to run off the road way and into a small tree. D1 stated there was a car driving N on Stinesville Rd. D1 stated that vehicle crossed the center line, D1 then lost control of her vehicle causing her to run off the road. D1 did not have a valid DL and was issued a ticket. The vehicle was towed by Rick's Towing.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: V1 was traveling eastbound on Winslow Rd and was attempting to make a left turn. V2 was traveling westbound on Winslow Rd. V3 was stationary facing south on Henderson St.V1 turned in front of V2, striking V2 and then hitting V3.D1 stated that she did not see V2 and thought she had a clear path to turn. She stated that she had a green light and not a green arrow.D2 stated that she thought she had a green light and that V1 turned in front of her.D3 observed V1 turn in front of V2, striking V2, and then hitting himV1 failed to yield to V2 causing damage to all three vehicles.

Interstate 69 runs North to South through Monroe County in Indian Creek Township. This section of roadway is a multi-lane interstate with a grass median that separates the north and south bound lanes. The roadway in the area of the crash is flat with a slight curve. The roadway was dry and clear on debris. At the time of the crash it was dark with little ambient light and no street lights. Vehicle #1(2017 Red Kia Sorento) was traveling north bound in the right line of the north bound side. A deer ran out in the roadway from the median. V1 slowed its speed to attempt to avoid the deer. V1 struck the deer and came to a stop on the right shoulder in the north bound lane.Driver #1(Kimberly Dwyer) stated that she was traveling northbound at approximately 70MPH. D1 stated that she observed the deer in the median and slowed down incase it ran out in the road. D1 was unable to avoid the deer and struck it. When I arrived I observed the grill and the hood of V1 damaged with debris on the roadway. V1 was leaking radiator fluid. I was unable to locate the deer at the scene.

OWNER OF V1 ADV SHE PARKED V1 IN THE PARKING LOT OF KROGER AT 528 W COLLEGE AVE BETWEEN 11:50 AM AND 12:15 PM. SHE SAID WHEN SHE RETURNED IT HAD BEEN HIT ON THE REAR PASSENGER SIDE OF THE BUMPER. STORE SECURITY WAS CHECKED AND UNABLE TO GET SUSPECT INFORMATION.

V1 was Northbound on Curry Pike, approaching West Profile Parkway, when it struck the rear end of V2 which was stopped the intersection.D1 could not recall what happened, only bumping into the rear end of V2.D2 stated she was stopped at the stop light when she was rear ended by V1.

D1 STATED HE WAS DRIVING EAST ON W. STATE ROAD 45 COMING UP TO S. DUNLAP RD WHEN A DEER RAN ACROSS THE ROAD AND V1 STUCK THE DEER WITH THE FRONT OF THE VEHCILE. D1 DID NOT HAVE ENOUGH TIME TO AVOID THE DEER. VEHICLE MOVED PRIOR TO MY ARRIVAL.

Vehicle 1 (White 2013 Ford Explorer) was traveling north on SR37, 500 feet south of Monroe Dam Road. Vehicle 1 was in the right lane when a deer struck the front driver's side. This resulted in damage to vehicle 1.Driver 1 (Cindy Stout) advised that she was traveling north of SR37 when a deer ran into the driver's side of her vehicle. Driver 1 advised that she was unable to the collision.Evidence at the scene was consistent with the information provided by driver 1. Deer hair and blood were located in the damaged portion of vehicle 1. The deceased deer was located near the scene of the crash. No injuries were reported by the occupants of vehicle 1 and vehicle 1 was driveable.

Vehicle 1 ( Silver 2007 Mazda) was traveling south on SR37, 53 feet south of Old SR37 in the right lane. Vehicle 1 traveled off the west side of the roadway. Vehicle 1 traveled at a 45 degree angle, coming to rest upon striking a tree. This resulted in damage to Vehicle 1 and injury to a passenger of the vehicle.Driver 1 (Alexis Capps) advised that she was traveling south on SR37, enroute to Bedford, IN. Driver 1 advised that she did not know why her vehicle left the roadway. This crash resulted in injury to Tate Stewart, a passenger of vehicle 1. Stewart complained of pain to his head. He was transported to IU Health Bloomington to be checked out. There was no evidence or witnesses to the crash that could assist in an explanation for this crash. Driver 1 did not complain of injuries at the time of the investigation.No occupants from the vehicle were able to assist with an explanation of how the crash occurred. No witnesses to the crash were located at the time of the investigation. The roadway was free from yaw marks or any signs that driver attempted to brake or prevent the crash from occurring.Vehicle 1 was towed from the scene by Summit Towing.

V1 WAS TRAVELING WESTBOUND ON W STATE ROAD 46 JUST WEST OF CURRY PIKE WHEN A DEER RAN OUT IN FRONT OF THE VEHICLE. THE V1 COLLIDED WITH THE DEER, KILLING IT. V1 HAD SIGNIFICANT DAMAGE TO THE FRONT RIGHT SIDE OF THE VEHICLE. BOTH OCCUPANTS AGREED TO DRIVE THE VEHCILE AWAY FROM THE SCENE AND DID NOT REQUEST A TOW TRUCK.NEITHER OCCUPANT WAS INJURED, AND NONE REQUESTED MEDICAL ATTENTION.

On 11/08/2019 at approximately 1932 hours, I arrived at 17th Street and Walnut Grove Street to take a crash report.I spoke with D2 who stated he was driving eastbound on 17th Street approaching Walnut Grove Street and put his turn signal on to turn right (south) onto Walnut Grove. D2 stated he was about halfway through his turn when he felt an impact on the right side of V2 and thought he had hit a curb. Instead, he realized that V1 had been in his blind-spot on his right side and V1 and V2 collided. V2 sustained damage to the right side. The front passenger's side door was scratched and dented in and the front passenger's side wheel was also scratched. The back passenger's side door was also damaged with scratches and part of the door was bent outward.D1 stated he was driving eastbound on 17th Street approaching Walnut Grove. D1 stated that the road was wide enough for two lanes of travel going eastbound and thought he was in the "right lane" on 17th Street. D1 stated he was going faster than D2 was and was going to pass. He then saw that V2 had it's turn signal on to turn south onto Walnut Grove and he did not have time to get out of the way. 17th Street going eastbound only has one lane of eastbound travel. The lane for eastbound traffic is oversized, however, there are no painted lines indicating that there are two eastbound lanes. V1 sustained damage to the front driver's side. The driver's side headlight was shattered and the bumper was dented above the front driver's side wheel. The front driver's side door also could only open slightly but not enough for anyone to get into the car from that door.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: BOTH VEHICLES WERE IN THE 100 BLOCK OF N. LINCOLN ST, JUST NORTH OF KIRKWOOD AVE.D1 SAID HE WAS EXITING A PARKING SPACE ON THE WEST SIDE OF THE STREET, AND DID NOT SEE V2 COMING NORTH BOUND.V2 WAS NORTH BOUND ON LINCOLN ST.NO REPORTED INJURIES.

V1 was turning east onto S. Fairfax Rd from a gas station on the north east corner of the intersection. V2 was sitting in traffic facing west attempting to let V1 cross his lane to turn east. V1 did not see another car in the eastbound lane, over corrected to the left, and struck V2.D1 stated he exited to gas station and crossed over the westbound lane. D1 stated as he was entering into the eastbound lane he noticed a car coming eastbound. D1 stated he did not know what to do and turned left, striking V2. V2 stated he was sitting in traffic facing westbound. D2 attempted to left V1 out of the gas station to cross into the eastbound lane. D2 stated V1 pulled out in front of a car and then V1 turned into V2. Both vehicle has front left damage from where they struck. Both vehicles were towed by Hawkin's Towing. All parties involved denied EMS.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: V1 WAS NORTHBOUND ON MORTON ST STOPPED AT THE STOP SIGN FOR 11TH STREET.V2 WAS EASTBOUND ON 11TH STREET AND MORTON ST.D1 SAID AFTER STOPPING SHE TURNED LEFT BUT DID NOT SEE V2 COMING. SHE SAID WHEN SHE ENTERED THE INTERSECTION SHE COLLIDED WITH V2.D2 SAID AS HE DROVE EAST V1 PULLED OUT AND HIM HIM.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: V2 WAS EASTBOUND ON WEST 11TH STREET, APPROACHING NORTH DIAMOND ROAD, WHEN V2 MADE A LEFT HAND TURN ONTO NORTH DIAMOND STREET FROM 11TH STREET, PULLING OUT INFRONT OF V2. V1 AND V2 THEN COLLIDED IN THE INTERSECTION. AFTER THE COLLISION V2 CONTINUED OFF THE SOUTH EAST SIDE OF THE ROADWAY, STRUCK A STOP SIGN, AND THEN COLLIDED INTO A HOUSE (903 WEST 11TH STREET).D1 STATED HE WAS WESTBOUND ON 11TH STREET AND MADE A LEFT HAND TURN ONTO NORTH DIAMOND STREET. D1 STATED WHEN HE MADE THE LEFT TURN HE DID NOT SEE ANY VEHICLES COMING EASTBOUND ON 11TH STREET. V1 STATED WHILE HE WAS MAKING THE TURN SHE HEARD A VEHICLE HONKING A HORN AND HE STOPPED IN THE EASTBOUND LANE OF 11TH STREET. V1 STATED AT THAT TIME HE SAW V2, AND V2 COLLIDED INTO HIS VEHICLE.D2 STATED SHE WAS EASTBOUND ON 11TH STREET WHEN V1 MADE A LEFT HAND TURN IN FRONT OF HER. D2 STATED SHE ATTEMPTED TO AVOID THE COLLISION BUT HER VEHICLE STRUCK V1. D2 STATED AFTER STRIKING V1, HER VEHICLE CONTINUED OFF THE SOUTH EAST SIDE OF THE INTERSECTION AND HER VEHICLE STRUCK A RESIDENCE.

DRIVER OF VEHICLE 1 STATED SHE WAS DRIVING NORTH ON INTERSTATE 69 WHEN SHE SWERVED TO MISS A DEAD DEER IN THE MIDDLE OF THE ROADWAY. WHEN SHE SWERVED TO MISS THE DEER SHE RAN OFF THE ROAD WAY STRIKING A MILE MARKER SIGN AND LANDING IN A DITCH 10 YARDS OFF THE HIGHWAY. HEAVY FRONT END DAMAGE TO VEHICLE REQUIRING A TOW.

Driver 1 (D1) stated the following: On 11/08/2019 while traveling south on I69 in the area of the 121mm Vehicle 1 (V1) struck a deer. The deer entered the roadway from the west and struck the front passenger corner of V1. V1 received Damage to the passenger headlight as well as the hood. The deer continued east across the roadway. V1 continued to the next exit and requested a crash report due to the damage. Both driver and passenger requested no medical attention. V1 was drivable.

D2 stated she was heading South on Henderson Street approaching Winslow Road.D2 stated that she was in the right lane and was going to turn West on Winslow Road.D2 stated that V1 was in the left turn lane facing South on Henderson Street. D2 stated that V1 pulled out of the left turn lane into her lane and sideswiped the driver side of her vehicle. D2 stated that after V1 struck her vehicle, V1 turned left on Winslow Road and left the area. D2 describe the V1 as an older tan truck, unknown make or model, that was being driven by a black male in his late 30's to early 40's. I did not locate the V1 in the area.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: D2 ADVISED THAT HE WAS TRAVELING SOUTH ON OLD STATE ROAD 37 WHILE V1 WAS AT THE BETHEL LANE STOP SIGN. THERE IS ONGOING CONSTRUCTION IN THE AREA WHERE FLAGGERS ARE BEING USED TO CONTROL TRAFFIC. D1 STATED HE WAS WAVED THROUGH THE INTERSECTION BY ONE OF THE CONSTRUCTION WORKERS WHEN V1 PULLED IN FRONT OF V2 CAUSING V2 TO STRIKE V1 ON THE RIGHT FRONT QUARTER PANEL.D1 ADVISED THAT SHE WAS STOPPED AT THE STOP SIGN AT BETHEL AND OLD STATE ROAD 37 WHEN THE CONSTRUCTION WORKER THERE MOTIONED IN WHAT SHE UNDERSTOOD AS TO PROCEED THROUGH THE INTERSECTION. D1 ADVISED THAT AS SHE WAS PULLED ONTO OLD STATE ROAD 37 FROM BETHEL LANE SHE PULLED IN FRONT OF V2 CAUSING V1 TO STRIKE HER FRONT PASSENGER SIDE QUATER PANEL.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: D1 stated she stopped at the stop sign at 13th and Indiana facing Eastbound.D1 stated she thought the traffic was clear to proceed through the intersection. D1 stated as she went through the intersection she struck V2 in the driver side. D2 stated she was driving North on Indiana Avenue approaching the intersection at 13th Street. D2 stated that as she went through the intersection V1 struck her in the driver side.

D1 ADVISED SHE WAS DRIVING WEST ON W. STATE ROAD 45 COMING UP TO W. AIRPORT RD. D1 LOOKED AT THE TRAFFIC LIGHT AND THOUGHT IT WAS GREEN. D1 THEN LOOKED DOWN TO TURN THE HEAT ON AND V2 WAS STOPPED AS THE LIGHT WAS NOW RED AND V1 REAR ENDED V2.D2 ADVISED SHE HAD CAME TO A STOP AT W. STATE ROAD 45 AND W. AIRPORT RD AT THE TRAFFICE LIGHT. V2 WAS THEN REAR ENDED BY V1.THERE WAS MINOR DAMAGE TO THE REAR OF V2 AND NO DAMAGE TO V1.

D1 STATED SHE WAS TRAVELING EAST ON 3RD STREET IN THE NORTHERN MOST LANE. SHE INDICATED AS SHE WAS APPROACHING MADISON, HER CHILD IN THE BACK SEAT WAS GETTING UPSET AND SHE TURNED TO HAND THE CHILD HER PHONE. AS D1 TURNED SHE SAW V2 STOPPED IN THE ROADWAY. D1 SAID SHE HAD NO TIME TO REACT AND COLLIDED INTO THE REAR OF V2. D2 STATED HE WAS TRAVELING EAST ON 3RD STREET AND STOPPED AT THE INTERSECTION OF MADISON IN THE NORTHERN MOST LANE. D2 SAID AS THE TRAFFIC SIGNAL HAD TURNED GREEN HE WAS STRUCK FROM BEHIND BY V1.
V1 ASUMMED TO BE ATTEMPTING TO PARK. V2 PARKED IN PARKING LOT AT 1421 N WILLIS DR. V1 STRUCK V2 ON FRONT LEFT. V1 LEFT SCENE WITHOUT PROVIDING INFORMATION. V2 WAS UNOCCUPIED AT THE TIME OF THE CRASH.

Vehicle 2 was traveling south on east State Road 46 directly behind vehicle 1. Both drivers stated that traffic was back up on the roadway from the intersection of 3rd street. Vehicle 1 and 2 were just south of the 7th street intersection. Driver of vehicle 1 stated the vehicle in front of him started to go and then suddenly stopped, so he hit his brakes to avoid striking the vehicle. Driver of vehicle 1 stated he did not notice vehicle 2 stop and ran into the back of it. Vehicle 1 has significant damage to the front and was towed from the scene due to damage. Vehicle 2 has moderate damage to the rear and was able to drive away from scene. No injuries were reported.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: D1 was facing westbound on 13th Street stopped at a stop sign attempting to continue traveling westbound on 13th Street. D2 was traveling southbound on Woodlawn Avenue attempting to continue traveling southbound on Woodlawn Avenue. D1 stated that he was stopped at the stop sign of 13th Street and Woodlawn Avenue attempting to travel west. D1 stated that he did not see D2 traveling southbound and entered the intersection. D1 stated he then suddenly struck V2 with V1's front bumper as V2 was attempting to clear the intersection. D1 stated that he believed that D2 was speeding and that is why D1 did not see V2. D2 stated he was traveling southbound on Woodlawn Avenue attempting to continue southbound as he approached the intersection of 13th Street and Woodlawn Avenue. D2 stated that D1 then suddenly pulled out in front of D2 and V2 was struck by V1's front bumper on V2's front driver side quarter panel and front driver side door. D2 stated he believed that he was traveling at 30 mph. Neither D1 or D2 had any complaint of pain. Neither vehicle was towed. Both drivers pulled off on to 13th Street just west of Woodlawn Avenue. There was damage to V1's front bumper. There was damage to V2's driver side front quarter panel and front door.

D1 WAS TRAVELING IN THE AREA OF E RHORER RD AND DERBY DRIVE WHEN TWO DEER RAN INTO THE PASSENGER SIDE OF HER CAR. THIS CAUSED DAMAGE TO THE FENDER AND BOTH DOORS. DUE TO THE LOCATION OF THE CRASH, D1 ELECTED TO COME TO THE SHERIFFS OFFICE INSTEAD OF PULLING OVER IN A DRIVEWAY OF A DARK UNLIT AREA. I WITNESSED DEER HAIR IN THE TRIM ON THE PASSENGER SIDE OF V1.

V1 was headed East bound on East Sr. 46. D1 stated a deer ran across the roadway from the South and the deer collided with V1 in the front portion of V1. V1 had heavy front end damage. The deer ran off before our arrival.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: V1 was traveling north bound on N. Waypoint Rd approaching the roundabout. V2 was eastbound on Sample Rd and was going through the roundabout. V1 rolled too far into the lane of the roundabout and struck V2 as it went through.D1 stated she was distracted while approaching the roundabout by a parked car on the side of the road. D1 stated she rolled out into the roundabout while looking at the vehicle. V1 had damage to the left front head light and bumper. D2 stated he was traveling through the roundabout when V1 rolled too far forward striking the side of V2. V2 had minor cosmetic damage and denting on the passenger side door. Both involved parties denied medical attention.

V1, an Enterprise box truck, was traveling southeast in the 500 block of West Vine Street. D1 attempted a right (southwest) turn onto North Fifth Street. Two vehicles parked along the east side of the roadway prevented D1 from using this space to make a wide turn (in consideration of the size of V1). D1 made a turn that was too sharp onto North Fifth Street and collided with V2 which was unoccupied and parked in a legal parking spot outside of the apartment located at 501 West Vine Street.North Fifth Street is a one-lane two-way road. Gravel has been placed on the east side of the roadway between the rear of the Ellettsville Post Office and West Vine Street, but it is unclear if this area is part of the roadway. There are not any "NO PARKING" signs posted in the gravel section. This section is commonly used by delivery trucks to made wide turns onto North Fifth Street when they make deliveries to the Ellettsville Post Office.V2 had moderate damage to the rear bumper and taillight on the driver's side. I was unable to locate any damage to V1. D1 could not provide any information as to where V1 collided with V2, so the diagram POI is estimated based on the height of V2 and the physical attributes observed on V1. Photographs of both vehicles were taken and copies are available upon request.Copies of in-car and body-worn camera footage are also available upon request.No injuries were reported to me at the time of this investigation.
V-1 was traveling south on SR446 when a deer ran into his lane of travel striking the front of vehicle.

DRIVER OF VEHICLE 1 STATED SHE WAS FATIGUED FROM WORKING LONG SHIFT AT WORK AND SHE RAN OFF THE ROAD AND WAS NOT ABLE TO GET THE CAR OUT OF THE DITCH SHE SAID SHE DRIFTED INTO. I DETECTED AN ODOR OF ALCOHOL AND INFORMED THE OTHER RESPONDING OFFICER WHO PERFORMED FIELD SOBRIETY TESTS. PBT RETURNED A READING OF .149

Primary Cause-Animal/Object in the roadway: Driver #1 (Avila Nicolasa) was unable to maneuver Vehicle #1 (Silver 2004 Dodge Grand Caravan) in a way to avoid hitting a deer crossing the roadway.I69 is an Interstate that runs in a northern and southern direction through Monroe County, Indiana. The roadway in the area of the crash is straight with no grade. There are both center and fog lines on the roadway. The roadway was dry and crash scene was dark with no ambient light from street lights or nearby residences. Vehicle #1 was northbound on I69 near the 107 mile marker. A deer on the east side of the road traveled west into the roadway and into the path of Vehicle #1. The front right of Vehicle #1 collided with the deer. Driver #1 state she was traveling northbound on I69 at approximately 65mph. Driver #1 stated she observed a deer on the east side of the roadway travel east onto the roadway and in to the path of her vehicle. Driver #1 state she was unable to stop or maneuver her vehicle in a safe manner to avoid colliding with the deer. Driver #1 stated she, along with her passengers were wearing their safety belts at the time of the crash.

D1 stated that he was traveling westbound on W 2nd Street, and that he did not notice the stop sign at S Woodlawn Avenue. D1 stated that he believed he had the right of way and that north/south traffic on S Woodlawn Avenue needed to yield for him. D1 stated that as V2 began to pull in front of him at the four way stop, he swerved to the right in order to avoid a collision. D1 stated that V1 then struck the front passenger side of V2. D1 said that after the collision with V2, he could not stop in time and ran off the road, striking a street sign, stop sign, and finally a brick wall at the residence of 528 S Woodlawn Avenue. D2 stated that he was stopped at the four way stop at W 2nd Street and S Woodlawn Avenue, and after making a complete stop, began to straight northbound on S Woodlawn Avenue. D2 stated that V1 then ran the stop sign coming westbound on W 2nd Street, swerved, and struck the front of V2. W1 confirmed D2's account, and stated that V1 disregarded the stop sign, and struck V2 prior to colliding with the street signs. Neither party stated that they were injured and both declined an ambulance. V1 needed to be towed due to the street sign being lodged in its front axel. Photographs of this incident were taken and submitted to as department evidence. D1 was issued a citation for disregarding a posted stop sign.

VEHICLE 1 WAS WESTBOUND ON EAST STATE ROAD 46 NEAR THE INTERSECTION OF SOTH LOWER BIERDIE GALYAN ROAD. VEHICLE 1 RAN OFF THE ROAD INTO A DITCH, AND WHEN VEHICLE 1 APPROACHED THE INTERSECTION AT SOUTH LOWER BIRDIE GALYAN ROAD VEHICLE 1 JUMPED THE ROAD AND LANDED ON THE WEST SIDE OF LOWER BIRDIE UPSIDE DOWN. DRIVER 1 STATED THAT SHE HAD TAPPED THE BREAKS AND THE CAR STARTED SLIDING AND RAN OF THE ROAD.DRIVER 1 WAS TRANSPORTED TO IU HEALTH VIA AMBULANCE FOR MULTIPLE ABRASIONS, A POSSIBLE BROKEN CLACICAL, AND WRIST. DRIVER 1 ALSO HAD PAIN IN HER RIGHT LEG.VEHICLE 1 WAS DISABLED AND TWOED TO BLANDS TOWING BY BLANDS TOWING.

V3 WAS STOPPED IN TRAFFIC ON SR45 TRAVELING EAST FROM THE INTERSECTION OF 45 AND N KINSER PIKE. V2 WAS TRAVELING BEHIND V3 AND WAS SLOWING DUE TO TRAFFIC. V1 WAS TRAVELING BEHIND V2. V1 COLLIDED WITH THE REAR OF V2 CAUSING V2 TO MOVE FORWARD AND COLLIDE WITH THE REAR OF V3. D1 STATED THAT SHE WAS DISTRACTED AND STARING OFF INTO THE HORIZON AND WAS NOT AWARE OF TRAFFIC STOPPING IN FRONT OF HER. D1 STATED THAT SHE REALIZED THAT V2 WAS CLOSER THAN SHE THOUGHT AND WAS ALMOST AT A STOP. D1 STATED SHE PRESSED THE BRAKES AS HARD AS SHE COULD AND THAT HER VEHICLE DID NOT SEEM TO STOP. D1 STATED THAT SHE HEARD HER TIRES SQUEALING. D1 STATED THAT SHE THEN COLLIDED WITH THE REAR OF V2 CAUSING DISABLING DAMAGE TO HER VEHICLE. D2 STATED THAT HE WAS STOPPING IN TRAFFIC BEHIND V3 AND HE HEARD THE SOUND OF TIRES SKIDDING AND THEN FELT SOMETHING HIT THE REAR OF HIS TRUCK. D2 STATED THAT THE MOMENTUM OF THE IMPACT FORCED HIS TRUCK FORWARD AND INTO THE REAR OF V1. THE COLLISION CAUSED NON-DISABLING DAMAGE TO THE REAR AND FRONT OF HIS VEHICLE.D3 STATED THAT SHE WAS STOPPED IN TRAFFIC AND WAITING FOR THE LIGHT TO TURN GREEN. D3 STATED THAT SHE HEARD TIRES SKIDDING AND LOOKED IN HER REAR VIEW MIRROR, HEARD A CRASH, AND THEN SAW V2 LUNGE FOWARD AND COLLIDE WITH THE REAR OF HER VEHICLE. CAUSING NON-DISABLING DAMAGE.V1 WAS TOWED FROM THE SCENE DUE TO DISABLING DAMAGE.
V-1 was traveling south on I69 and took the exit on to Sample road then ran off roadway down an embankment.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: V1 and V2 were both at the intersection when V1 attempted to turn left directly in front of V2 causing a collision. V1/D1 stated she had been traveling eastbound on E State Road 46 and was attempted to turn left into the parking lot of Bruster's when her vehicle was struck by V2. D1 stated she believed V2 had an activated left-hand turn signal, indicating it would be turning left onto S State Road 446 prior to V2 colliding into her vehicle. V2/D2 stated was westbound in the left hand lane of E State Road 46 when V1 attempted to turn left directly in front of it. D2 stated he was unable to avoid a collision due to the close proximity of the vehicles. When asked, D2 stated he did not have an activated left-hand turn signal which would have indicated he would be turning left onto S State Road 446. V1 sustained damage to the right rear 1/4 panel and was driven from the scene. V2 sustained damage to the right front bumper portion and was driven from the scene.

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: On Monday, November 11, 2019 at 18:49, Ryan Miller responded to a crash on I69 northbound near the 118.5 mile marker. At the time of the crash, the weather was snowing and the road surface was covered with snow/ice.V1, white Toyota, was traveling north on I69 in the left lane. V1 began to slide on the snow covered roadway. V1 slid across the northbound lanes and struck the right side guardrail face with the passenger side of V1. V1 then traveled back across the northbound lanes and struck the inside concrete divider with the front of V1. V1 came to final rest in the left, number 1, lane facing the concrete divider. D1, Saini, stated he was traveling north on I69 in the left lane. D1 stated he began to slide on the snow covered roadway. D1 stated he struck the guardrail along the right side of the roadway then traveled back across the northbound lanes. D1 stated he then struck the concrete divider with the front of V1. D1 complained of chest pain but denied medical treatment from EMS personnel who responded to the scene. Evidence shows the roadway was snow covered during the accident investigation. Evidence shows damage to the passenger side of V1 consistent with sideswiping a guardrail face. Evidence shows significant damage to the front of V1 consistent with impact with the concrete divider.

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: V1 was traveling west bound on E. 10th St. just west of N. Fess slowing down in traffic.V2 was stopped in traffic, facing west bound on E. 10th St. just west of N. Fess.D1 stated he began to slow down to stop behind V2 and began to slide on the snow and ice in the road way. D1 was unable to come to a stop in time and D2 in the rear.D2 stated he was stopped in traffic and was suddenly struck from behind.D1 has damage to the front bumper and hood and was towed by Auto Mobile due to damage.D2 has slight damage to the rear bumper.

D1 STATED HE WAS NORTHBOUND ON SMITH PIKE WHEN A CAR HAD PULLED OUT IN FRONT OF HIM, CAUSING HIM TO RUN OFF THE ROADWAY. D1 WAS FOUND IN POSSESSION OF ILLEGAL DRUGS AND REMANDED TO MONROE COUNTY CORRECTION CENTER FOR OWI AND POSSESSION.

I was dispatched to speak with both parties at the Indiana University Police Department for a prior crash that occurred on today's date at 12:10pm. I was advised by both parties the crash occurred at the intersection of 10th Street and Woodlawn Avenue. No injuries occurred. D1 said he was traveling northbound on Woodlawn in V1, and was directly behind V2. D1 said V2 who was directly in front of him started going forward to make a right turn onto 10th Street. D1 said V2 then came to a quick stop due to a pedestrian running southbound into the crosswalk having 5 seconds left on the pedestrian light to cross the street. D1 said when V2 came to a sudden stop due to the pedestrian's action, he stopped quickly causing V1 to slide forward due to the wet road conditions sliding into V2 rear bumper. V1 had minimal damage.D2 said she was traveling northbound on Woodlawn in V2, and was directly in front of V1. D2 said she was going to make a right turn onto 10th Street and had to stop quickly due to a pedestrian running southbound across the pedestrian crosswalk having 5 seconds left on the pedestrian light to cross. D2 said when she stopped, V1 struck V2 in the rear bumper area causing minor damage. D2 requested a report to be made. Both parties said they were also wanting to work this out among themselves if possible.

Vehicle 1 was traveling southwest from the top end of the parking lot attempting to slow down as she approached the rear of Vehicle 2. Vehicle 2 was stopped facing southwest at the parking booth of 1601 E Law Lane paying her parking fee. Driver 1 advised she turned southwest from the top end of the parking lot and immediately began attempting to slow down as she went down the hill, traveling towards the rear of Vehicle 2. Driver 1 stated the parking lot was icy and she immediately began sliding down the hill. She advised that she was unable to stop and slid all the way down the hill into the rear of Vehicle 2.Driver 2 stated she was stopped at the gate paying for her parking when she was struck from the rear by Vehicle 1.No one involved complained of injuries.Vehicle 1 had damage to the front bumper, grille, and hood. Vehicle 2 did not have any apparent damage.

D1 stated that she was traveling east on W 2nd Street, just east of S Walker Street, when the traffic in front of her began braking and slowing down. D1 stated that she began braking, but was unable to slow down and stop in time before rear ending V2. The front bumper of the V1 struck the rear bumper of V2.D2 stated that he was traveling east on W 2nd Street, just east of S Walker Street, when the traffic in front of him began braking and slowing down. Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: V2 was stopped at the intersection of North Woodlawn Avenue and East 10th Street, facing south. V2 had multiple vehicles between it and the intersection at the time of the accident. Roadway conditions were poor with precipitating snow fall and wet snow on the roadway. D1 informed me that he was traveling between 3-5mph as he approached V2. D1 stated that while attempting to come to a complete stop, his vehicle slid forward towards V2. D1 said he attempted to avoid V2 by maneuvering his vehicle into the left lane, However, D1 said he did not have enough room to make the correction, causing the front right bumper of V1 to hit the rear left bumper of V2.

On Monday, November 11, 2019 at 20:07, Ryan Miller responded to a crash on Earl Young Rd approximately 1000 ft north of E Everett Arnold Dr. At the time of the crash, the weather was snowing and the road surface was snow and ice covered. The area of this collision on Earl Young Road is a narrow gravel county road along a steep hill that is posted as being not maintained. V1, red Chevrolet, was traveling south on Earl Young Road. V1 began to ascend the hill and lost momentum due to the snow/ice covered roadway. V1 then slid backwards and left the west side of the roadway. V1 slid down a steep ditch and came to rest on a fallen tree above a creek bed. D1, Parker, stated she became lost and was utilizing a mapping system on her phone as a guide. D1 stated she was directed onto Earl Young Road and began to climb the hill. D1 stated she lost momentum and began to slide. D1 stated she left the roadway and came to rest in a ditch.Evidence shows the roadway as snow and ice covered during the accident investigation. Evidence shows V1 was resting on a fallen tree above a creek bed along the west side of Earl Young Road. Evidence shows damage to all sides of V1 consistent with traveling off the roadway. V1 was not towed from the scene during the accident scene due to the dangerous road conditions. Bland's Towing was called to remove the vehicle on a later date.

Vehicle 1 was traveling east on E 10th street. It was snowing outside and the roadway was ice/snow covered. The driver stated that has he crested the hill near 3960 E 10th and began down the hill. Driver noticed vehicles that looked stuck on the hill. Driver stated that he noticed a person standing in the roadway. Driver attempted to slow down but began sliding and was forced to go off the roadway down an embankment on the north side of the roadway instead of striking the pedestrian because he was unable to stop the vehicle due to the roadway surface condition. No injuries from this accident. Vehicle was towed due to damage.

Manner of Collision: HEAD ON BETWEEN TWO MOTOR VEHICLES
NARRATIVE: V1 WAS TRAVELING NB ON S PATTERSON DR. V2 WAS TRAVELING SB ON S PATTERSON DR. THE ROADWAY WAS COVERED WITH SNOW AND SLUSH AND IT WAS CURRENLTY SNOWING AT THE TIME OF THE ACCIDENT. D2 ADVISED V1 CROSSED LEFT OF CENTER AND STRUCK V2 HEAD ON. D1 ADVISED SHE DID NOT KNOW WHAT HAPPENED. D1 HAD A COMPLAINT OF HEAD, NECK AND JAW PAIN AND HAD DRIED BLOOD ON HER MOUTH. D1 REFUSED TREATMENT BY EMS. D2 HAD A COMPLAINT OF CHEST, HEAD AND KNEE PAIN. D2 WAS TRANSPORTED TO THE HOSPITAL. WHEN D1 WAS ASKED ABOUT INSURANCE, D1 STATED V1 WAS OWNED BY A FRIEND AND SHE DID NOT KNOW WHERE THAT INFORMATION WAS. OFFICERS WERE UNABLE TO LOCATE INSURANCE INSIDE OF V1. IT SHOULD BE NOTED, D1 DID APPEAR TO BE IMPAIRED AND AN OPERATING WHILE INTOXICATED INVESTIGATION WAS COMPLETED. SHE WAS REMANDED TO THE JAIL AT THE CONCLUSION OF THAT INVESTIGATION. BOTH VEHICLES WERE TOWED FROM THE SCENE DUE TO DAMAGE.
D1 stated she was traveling south on I69 when a deer ran into her path. She was unable to avoid striking the deer.
Driver 1 stated she was backing out of an area that was not designated a parking spot in the lot near 3425 E John Hinkle Place and struck a support post for a carport.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: V1 was making a left hand turn from E. Kirkwood Ave. on to N. Indiana Ave. traveling north east. P1 was crossing at the crosswalk at N. Indiana Ave traveling west bound. Visibility was poor due to heavy snowfall at the time.D1 stated he came to a stop at the stop sign at the intersection of Kirkwood and Indiana. He then stated he did not see P1 crossing and began to make a left hand turn. When he heard P1 scream and attempted to stop. D1 stated he was unable to stop and struck P1 on the driver side of the bus.P1 stated she was crossing at the crosswalk on Indiana, heading west bound after seeing V1 come to a stop at the stop sign. P1 then stated she noticed V1 was going to strike her and she tried to jump out of the way. P1 was unable to make it out of the way and was struck on her left side, by the driver side of V1.W1 stated she was walking behind P1 and noticed V1 come to a stop at the stop sign before proceeding through the intersection. Before P1 had crossed, W1 stated V1 tried to stop but slid into P1.P1 was transported to the IU Bloomington Hospital where she was treated and released with minor contusions and bruises.V1 is a city bus and is equipped with video equipment. The video was not immediately available at the scene but a bus supervisor stated it would be made available as soon as possible.D1 showed no signs of intoxication.

D1 stated that he was traveling north on North Curry Pike, just north of Profile Parkway, when his vehicle lost traction in the snow. D1 stated that when the vehicle lost traction, his vehicle slid and hit the curb on the east side of the road. The bumper of V1 was stuck on the curb, and the right side tires were angled from apparent damage to the frame.
D1 SAID HE WAS NORTHBOUND ON BUSINESS 37 WHEN HE WENT OVER A BUMP AND STARTED TO SPIN OUT IN THE ICE AND SNOW. WHILE SPINNING HE RAN INTO THE GUARD RAIL ON THE WEST SIDE OF THE ROADWAY.

When I arrived on scene, both vehicles had been moved from where the crash occurred. I spoke with the people involved in the crash and none of them complained of any injuries. The crash involved a black Honda (V1), driven by Tabitha May (D1), and a red Ford (V2), driven by Elizabeth McDowell (D2).They both stated the same story. They were westbound on 3rd St in the left lane with V1 following V2. Traffic came to a stop and V2 stopped but V1 was not able to in time. V1 rear ended V2.Both drivers were unsure of the cross street but they pointed at Fess Ave so I believe that is where the crash occurred. V1 sustained moderate damage to the front bumper and grill. V2 sustained moderate damage to the rear bumper and trunk lid.Both vehicles were able to be driven from the scene.

On Monday, November 11, 2019 at 14:55, Ryan Miller responded to a crash on SR 48 approximately 2500 feet west of Vernal Pike. At the time of the crash, the weather was snowing and the road surface was wet. V1, gold Ford Explorer, was traveling east on SR48 approaching a left hand curve. V2, white Ford Transit, was traveling west on SR48 in a right hand curve. V1 began to slide on the wet roadway and crossed the center line. V1 struck the left rear corner of V2 with the left rear corner of V1 in the westbound lane of SR48. V1 continued to spin after impact with V2 and came to final rest in a ditch along the north side of SR48. V2 continued west on SR48 and came to a controlled stop in the westbound lane. D1, Colson, stated she was traveling east on SR48. D1 indicated the tires on V1 needed replacement due to poor tread. D1 stated she began to slide on the wet roadway. D1 stated she traveled across the center line into the westbound lane of SR48. D1 stated she struck the rear of V2 then struck a ditch along the north side of the roadway. D2, Shelton, stated he was traveling west on SR48. D2 stated V1 traveled left of center into the westbound lane of SR48. D2 stated V1 struck the left rear corner of V2.Evidence shows damage to the driver's side and front of V1. Evidence shows damage to the left rear corner of V2. Evidence shows there was snowfall and the roadway was wet during the accident investigation.**Location: SR48 approximately 2500 feet west of Vernal Pike. Map feature within the report incorrectly identifies the location of the collision**

V2 was passing on the left a line of vehicles that were stopped for pick up and drop off on the north side of the School of Public and Environmental Affairs located at 1315 E. 10th Street. Driver 1 stated he was backing out of a parking space at 3021 E 3rd St and did not see vehicle 2 driving past in the lot. Driver 1 stated he backed into vehicle 2. Driver 2 stated she was driving through the lot when vehicle 1 backed out of a parking spot and hit the side of her vehicle.

V1 WAS TRAVELING NORTH ON N UNION VALLEY ROAD WITH IT'S TRUCK BED PARTIALLY RAISED WHILE SPREADING SALT AND SAND. D1 ADVISED HE DID NOT THINK KNOW HE BED WAS UP HIGH ENOUGH TO STRIKE THE POWER LINE. RAISED TRUCK BED STRUCK POWER AND PHONE CABLES CAUSING DAMAGE TO THE POLE, CABLES AND TO THE BED OF THE TRUCK.

Vehicle 1 was westbound on Morningside approaching the stop sign at Smith Road. Vehicle 1 slid on icy road and continued into the intersection and struck the side of Vehicle 2 as Vehicle 2 was continuing north through the intersection with the right of way.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: Vehicle 1 was stopped at the stop sign facing east on 7th Street at Woodlawn Avenue. Vehicle 2 was stopped at the stop sign facing west on 7th Street at Woodlawn Avenue.Driver 1 advised he was waiting to turn north on Woodlawn Avenue after Vehicle 2 continued west on 7th Street. Driver 1 stated as Vehicle 2 went through the intersection he began turning. He advised Vehicle 2 stopped quickly while still partially in the intersection and he struck the driver's side of her vehicle with the center driver's side of Vehicle 1. Driver 1 stated that he believed someone stepped out in front of Vehicle 2 causing her to stop in the intersection last minute.Driver 2 advised she was traveling west on 7th Street through the intersection of Woodlawn Avenue when a female pedestrian walking out in front of her vehicle with no warning as Vehicle 2 was exiting the intersection. Driver 2 advised she hit her brakes and came to an abrupt stop to avoid hitting the pedestrian with her vehicle. Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: D1 advised he was traveling north on State Road 45 east, at approximately 35 mph, when he crested the hill near 5019 E State Road 45 and lost control of his vehicle on a patch of ice in the roadway. Upon my arrival male was outside of the vehicle and vehicle was on its side. Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: No other officers assisted with the accident investigation.V2 was stopped in westbound traffic on 17th Street at the Fee Lane intersection.V1 was approaching V2 from the rear.D2 stated she was stopped in traffic waiting for the traffic light to turn green. V1 then collided into the rear of her vehicle causing moderate damage to her rear bumper. D2 stated he was going approximately 20mph prior to the collision and made contact with V2 at around 10-15mph. Neither D1 nor his passenger were injured. Both vehicles were safe to drive from the scene.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: V1 was stopped waiting for a break in oncoming traffic, to make a left turn.V1 then turned and collided with V2 causing non disabling damage to the rear passenger side of V1 and disabling damage to the front of V2.D1 stated that as he was waiting to turn left across oncoming traffic, a vehicle in the nearest southbound lane had stopped to allow D1 to drive across traffic lane. D2 said he was driving straight and V1 suddenly crossed in front of him from the east side of the road. D2 said he attempted to apply his breaks but was unable to stop and collided with the passenger side of V1.

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: All parties corroborate the below information:V1 was approaching the stop sign and started to brake. D1 thought he would have enough room to stop, even with the weather, not realizing that there was a significant amount of ice on Adams St. V3 had started through the intersection headed east on Allen St from the four way stop, when V3 was struck by V2. Driver #1 was south bound on Old State Road 37 and as he was turning right onto Dillman Rd slid on the ice and collided with V#2.

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: D1 stated that she was driving westbound on W Bloomfield Road just west of S Basswood Drive, behind V2. D1 stated that V2 began to slow down, and due to the very icy road conditions, she could not get V1 to a stop. D1 stated that V1 then slid into the rear of V2, and V1 then slid to the south side of the roadway before coming to rest.D2 stated that while traveling westbound on W Bloomfield Road, just west of S Basswood Drive, V1 ran into the rear of V2. It did not appear that salt had been put on the roadway at that time. Both parties stated that they were not injured, and both declined an ambulance.Both vehicles were towed due to disabling damage.

DRIVER OF VEHICLE 1 STATED HE WAS WEST BOUND ON BLOOMFIELD ROAD APPROACHING THE TRAFFIC LIGHT AT THE NORTH BOUND RAMP TO SR 37. THE WEST BOUND TRAFFIC LIGHT HAD CHANGED TO GREEN AND D1 OBSERVED V2 STARTING FROM STOP AT THE INTERSECTION. D1 ATTEMPTED TO SLOW DOWN, BUT THE ICE ON THE ROADWAY CAUSED V1 TO SLIDE. V1 SLID INTO THE REAR OF V2.DRIVER OF VEHICLE 2 STATED HE WAS ON WEST BOUND BLOOMFIELD ROAD, STOPPED AT THE TRAFFIC LIGHT AT THE SR 37 NORTH BOUND RAMP. WHEN THE LIGHT FOR WEST BOUND TRAFFIC TURNED GREEN, D1 ATTEMPTED TO ACCELLERATE, BUT V2 COULD NOT GAIN TRACTION DUE TO THE ICE ON THE ROADWAY. AS V2 SLOWLY MOVED FORWARD, IT WAS REAR ENDED BY V1.

DRIVER OF VEHICLE 1 STATED HE WAS WEST BOUND ON BLOOMFIELD ROAD APPROACHING S CURRY PIKE. D1 MERGED INTO THE TURN LANE TO GO SOUTH AND AS HE APPLIED THE BRAKE, V1 STARTED TO SLIDE ON THE ICE THAT COVERED THE ROADWAY. AS D1 WAS PUMPING THE BRAKES, HIS FOOT HIT THE ACCELERATOR CAUSING V1 TO LURCH FORWARD. V1 REAR ENDED V2. DRIVER OF VEHICLE 2 STATED HE WAS STOPPED AT THE TRAFFIC LIGHT ON WEST BLOOMFIELD ROAD PREPARING TO TURN SOUTH ONTO CURRY PIKE WHEN V2 WAS REAR ENDED BY V1.

D2 SAID IT KEPT GOING AND HE TRIED TO HONK AND STOP THEM, BUT V1 TURNED WEST. HE DID GET A LICENSE PLATE FOR V1. I GOT A LICENSE PLATE RETURN AND CALLED THE OWNER OF V1, WHO WAS AT WORK NEARBY. HER HUSBAND WAS ACTUALLY THE DRIVER, AND HE RETURNED TO THE SCENE.D1 SAID HE DID NOT THINK THE VEHICLES ACTUALLY TOUCHED. HE SAID V1 HAD NO VISIBLE DAMAGE. D1 SAID HE THOUGHT D2 WAS HONKING AT HIM FOR CUTTING HIM OFF, WHEN HE PULLED OUT WITH HIS VIEW PARTIALLY OBSTRUCTED BY HIS SNOWY CAR.NO INJURIES REPORTED.
