On Tuesday, November 12, 2019 at 8:15am, Harris, Matthew responded to a crash on State Road 37 at intersection of Victor Pike. SR37 is a four lane two way highway that runs primarily north and south. The Victor Pike intersection is ran by a fully operational traffic light. At the time of the crash, the weather was sunny and clear but the road surface was snowy and icy. The traffic lights had snow on them from the the night before. Vehicle 1, a black Chrysler Pacific, was traveling south on SR37 at the Victor Pike intersection. Vehicle 2, a red Chevrolet Cruz, was turning left (south) onto SR37 from west bound Victor Pike. V1 struck the rear end of V2. V1 spun out of control and ended up in the ditch to the southwest of the intersection. V2 was able to come to a controlled stop on the west side shoulder of SR37 just south on the intersection. Driver 1, Brenda Chipman, told me she was driving south on SR37 approaching the Victor Pike intersection. D1 said she was holding her hand up to shield her eyes from the sun as she approached the intersection. D1 told me that she thought she had the green light to continue. D1 told me that while she was attempting to cross the intersection a semi truck crossed the intersection from the west side and turned north onto SR 37. D1 stated she had to maneuver around the semi in order not to hit it. After getting around the semi truck D1 told me that she struck the rear end of V2. D1 said she never saw V2 until she hit it. D1 told me after hitting V2, she spun out of control and ended up in the ditch towards the southwest corner of the intersection. Driver 2, Jacob Rose, told me he was turning south (left) onto SR37 from west bound Victor Pike. D2 said when the light turned green he turned left (south) onto SR37 as a semi truck turned north onto SR37 from the east bound Victor Pike side of SR37 intersection. D2 said he had almost completed the transition from Victor Pike to SR37 when he suddenly felt his vehicle getting struck from behind. D2 told me that after he was stuck he pulled over to the side of the road and checked on V1, which was down in the ditch. Evidence shows minimal damage to the front side of V1. Evidence shows minimal damage to the rear bumper of V2. Evidence shows V1 spun out of control into a ditch. Evidence shows the roadway was icy. Evidence shows that while the traffic light were operational the south bound traffic lights were slightly covered by snow. Evidence shows it was sunny at the time of the crash.

Manner of Collision: HEAD ON BETWEEN TWO MOTOR VEHICLES
NARRATIVE: V1 was driving west on Rappel rd. V2 was driving north on Rappel rd. V1 veered into the lane of V2 and the two vehicles collided head on causing disabling damage to the front of both vehicles.D1 stated that she was driving and looked down for a second and when she looked back to the roadway, V2 was in front of her and the vehicles collided.D2 stated that he turned onto Rappel and was beginning to drive around the corner when V1 veered into his lane and the vehicles collided.
Traffic westbound on W. Country Club was slowed/stopped. Vehicle 1 struck Vehicle 2 in the rear, causing Vehicle 2 to roll forward and strike Vehicle 3.

V1 and V2 were traveling E/B on W Bloomfield RD. D1 attempted to stop at the traffic control signal, before colliding with V2.D1 advised that while traveling E/B on W Bloomfield RD, the traffic control signal turned red. D1 advised that due to the weather conditions, she attempted to come to a complete stop, when V1 began to slide. D1 advised that V1 sled into V2 causing damage to the vehicle. D1 was not injured. D2 advised that while traveling E/B on W Bloomfield RD, the traffic control signal had turned red. D2 advised that while at a complete stop at the intersection, she felt the impact of V1. D2 advised that she was not injured.

V1 WAS FOUND IN A DITCH ON THE NORTH WEST SIDE OF THE ROAD ON MT. GILEAD, JUST NORTH OF GETTY'S CREEK RD. MONROE COUNTY HIGHWAY FOUND THE TRUCK PARTIALLY BLOCKING THE ROAD AS THEY WERE ATTEMPTING TO PLOW. THERE WERE NO OCCUPANTS OF THE VEHICLE WHEN I LOCATED IT. THERE WERE NO KEYS WITH V1 AND I ATTEMPTED TO CALL THE REGISTERED OWNER OF V1 BUT NOBODY ANSWERED. V1 WAS STUCK IN THE DITCH AND HAD STRUCK A TREE HEAD ON CAUSING DAMAGE TO THE DRIVERS SIDE OF THE FRONT END. DO TO THE WAY V1 WAS STUCK A LARGE WRECK HAD TO COME PICK IT UP. I AM COMPLETING THIS REPORT BECAUSE THE VEHICLE WAS TOWED, NOT BECAUSE THE OWNER REPORTED IT. THERE WAS NO DAMAGE TO ANYTHING ELSE.
VEHICLE 1 WAS PARKED IN THE PARKING LOT NEAR THE DOG PARK AT 910 S ADAMS ST IN BLOOMINGTON INDIANA WHEN IT WAS STRUCK IN THE BACK DRIVERSIDE BY AN UNKNOWN VEHICLE.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
Manner of Collision: HEAD ON BETWEEN TWO MOTOR VEHICLES
NARRATIVE: DRIVER 1 STATED HE WAS ON THE SOUTH SIDE OF THE STREET ATTEMPTING TO TURN LEFT TO GO WEST ON KIRKWOOD AVENUE WHEN AN ONCOMING VEHICLE "LET HIM IN" TO CUT ACROSS. WHEN HE PULLED ACROSS THE EASTBOUND LEFT LANE, VEHICLE 2 DID NOT STOP AND DRIVER 1 STRUCK VEHICLE 2 HEAD ON.DRIVER 2 STATED HE WAS GOING EAST ON KIRKWOOD WHEN VEHICLE 2 CUT ACROSS HIS LANE OF TRAVEL AND COLLIDED WITH THE FRONT OF HIS VEHICLE.NO INJURIES.

On Tuesday, November 12, 2019 at 12:07, Harris, Matthew responded to a crash on State Rd. 37 at intersection of S Victor Pike. SR 37 is four lane two way road that runs primarily north and south. The S. Victor Pike intersection is controlled by a fully operational four way traffic light. At the time of the crash, the weather was clear but the road surface was icy. Due to the previous nights snowfall the traffic light had a light cover snow on it. Vehicle 1, a brown Buick Enclave, was traveling south on SR 37 at the S Victor Pike intersection. Vehicle 2, a white Ford F-250, was turning north onto SR 37 from east bound S Victor Pike. As V1 was traveling south through the intersection it stuck the rear driver side of V2. V1 spun out of control and came to a stop facing northwest in the middle of south bound traffic in the intersection. V2 spun out of control, of the roadway, towards the southwest corner of the intersection. V2 ended up in the ditch pinned against a tree facing west. Driver 1, William Eldridge, was traveling south on SR 37 at the S Victor Pike intersection. D1 told me that as he came to the intersection he thought he had enough time to get through the light before it turned red. D1 said he didn't see V2 untill the last second. D1 said by the time he saw V2 he had no time to stop. D1 told me he struck V2 with his SUV.Driver 2, Jed Hollars, was traveling east on Victor Pike. D2 told me that when the light turned green he attempted to turn north on SR 37. D2 said he was struck by V1 in the middle of the intersection. Witness 1, Richard Hall, was sitting at the light (on the shoulder) on S Victor Pike facing westbound at the time of the crash. W1 stated that he witnessed V1 travel through the intersection and hit V2. W1 said that it appeared as if V1 never slowed down. It also appeared as if west and east bound traffic had a green light while north and south bound traffic had a red light. Evidence shows heavy damage to V1. Evidence shows V1's airbags were deployed. Evidence shows damage to the passenger side of V2. Evidence shows V2 was struck by V1 and was spun out due to the hit. Evidence shows the ground had ice on it a the time of the crash. **Witness 1 was sitting in my police car due to his vehicle breaking down at the intersection.**

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: D1 SAID HE WAS ENTERING THE PARKING LOT AT BLOOMINGTON HIGH SCHOOL SOUTH, 1965 S. WALNUT ST, AND TRYING TO TURN RIGHT IN THE LOT. HE SAID V1 BEGAN TO SLIDE ON THE WET PAVEMENT DUE TO ICE/SNOW, AND SLID INTO A CURB. THIS CAUSED DAMAGE TO V1'S DRIVER FRONT TIRE. D1 SAID HE FIGURED HE WAS GOING TOO FAST TO MAKE THE RIGHT TURN.

V1 was heading North bound on Lakeview Dr. D1 stated a deer ran from the East side of the road and D1 hit the deer. Upon arrival on scene the deer was located. I observed minimal damage to the front right of V1.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: V2 was traveling E/B on Tapp RD. V1 was stopped facing N/B on Deborah RD. V1 pulled out into traffic and disregarded the stop sign colliding with V2. D1 advised that she was stopped at the intersection of Deborah RD & Tapp RD. D1 advised that she attempted to turn onto Tapp RD heading W/B, when she collided with V2. D1 advised that she pulled out into traffic and did not see V2 until she collided with V2. D1 was not injured. D2 advised that he was traveling E/B on Tapp RD. D2 advised that while traveling E/B he observed V1 turning W/B onto Tapp RD. D2 advised that he attempted to swerve and come to a complete stop, when he brakes locked up. D2 stated that V1 and V2 collided. D2 was not injured.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: The injured pedestrian stated that he was crossing the intersection, and walking west on the crosswalk. According to the pedestrian, while he was in the middle of the intersection, Driver of V1 failed to yield and V1's front driver tire ran over his left foot. The pedestrian stated that he had a walk sign from his direction.Driver of V1 stated that he was driving west on E. 3rd St. And was attempting to turn south on S. College Mall Rd. According to Driver of V1, he did not see the pedestrian crossing the intersection due to his vehicle's B-pillar blocking his view. Driver of V1 explained that by the time he saw the pedestrian, it was too late and V1 had struck the pedestrian. However, Driver 1 stated that the pedestrian crossing sign was showing a solid hand when the incident took place.Witness stated that she was stopped at the traffic light, facing north. According to the witness, Vehicle 1 had a turning arrow from it's direction. Witness explained that when Vehicle 1 was in the middle of the turn, the pedestrian walked into the turning V1. Witness does not know if the pedestrian had a walk signal or not.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: On Wednesday, November 13, 2019 at 11:55, Ryan Miller responded to a crash on W Alexander Drive approximately 375 ft west of N Jacob Drive. At the time of the crash, the weather was clear and the road surface was dry. Alexander Drive is a private roadway located in a shopping center. The location of this collision occurred at a four-way intersection that is controlled with a stop sign. The intersection is south of Lowe's and north of Bed Bath and Beyond. The north/south intersecting roadway is a private parking lot entrance/exit. V2, gray Honda, was stopped in the eastbound lane of Alexander Drive at the four-way intersection. V1, white pick-up, was traveling east on Alexander Drive behind V2. V1 failed to stop and struck the rear of V2 with the front of V1. V2 pulled into the parking lot southeast of the intersection. V1 failed to stop after the collision and left in an unknown direction. D2, Neff, stated she was stopped in the eastbound lane of Alexander Drive at the stop sign. D2 stated a white pick-up that was behind her struck the rear of V2 with the front of V1. D2 described V1 as an unknown make and model white pick-up that was operated by a white male. D2 stated D1 failed to remain at the scene after the collision and left in an unknown direction. D2 was unable to provide any further information. Evidence shows a small hole and scuff mark on the rear bumper cover of V2 consistent with a rear-end impact.

Primary Factor: SPEED TOO FAST FOR WEATHER CONDITIONS
NARRATIVE: V1 WAS LOCATED NEAR THE INTERSECTION OF DENNY RD AND N BOTTOM ROAD. VEHICLE HAD HEAVY FRONT END DAMAGE AND WAS AGAINST A TREE UPON MY ARRIVAL. I CHECKED THE AREA AND DID NOT LOCATE ANY PERSONS IN THE AREA, AND WAS ADVISED BY A PASSERBY THAT THE VEHICLE HAD BEEN HERE SINCE BEFORE 11 AM ON THIS DATE AND NO ONE WAS AROUND THE VEHICLE THEN.THE SHERIFF'S OFFICE RECIEVED NO PRIOR CALLS FROM THE VEHICLE OWNER ABOUT THIS CRASH AND THE CRASH DAMAGE SOME BARB WIRED FENCE ASSOCIATED WITH PROPERTY NEAR THE 6700 BLOCK OF NORTH BOTTOM ROAD.DRIVER WAS LATER LOCATED AT HIS WORK IN ELLETTSVILLE IN 47429 AND IDENTIFIED AS KYLE STIERWALT. KYLE INDICATED THAT HE WAS UNAWARE THAT HE NEEDED TO CONTACT LAW ENFORCEMENT AFTER THE CRASH AND HAD ALREADY CONTACTED HIS INSURANCE ABOUT THE CRASH. AS MR. STIERWALT FAILED TO REPORT THE CRASH TO LAW ENFORCEMENT HE WAS ISSUED A MISD CITATION FOR THIS CHARGE. MR. STIERWALT ADVISED HE WAS TRAVELING SOUTHWEST ON BOTTOM ROAD NEAR DENNY ROAD WHEN HE LOST CONTROL ON A PATCH OF ICE AND STRUCK THE TREE.

Trooper Griggs had reported that he was behind a vehicle that was believed to have struck another parked vehicle in the area of 803 N Monroe Street; The Boys and Girls Club. Trooper Griggs later performed a traffic stop on the vehicle in the area of W 3rd Street and S Patterson Drive. Trooper Griggs later advised that he believed that the female driver of the vehicle was intoxicated on an unknown substance and that he would be working a case for the possible operating a vehicle while under the influence. Trooper Griggs also advised that there was damage to the front passenger side of the vehicle. I then arrived in the area of 803 N Monroe Street and observed a parked vehicle (V2) that had been struck on the driver's side. I observed there to be blue paint transfer in the areas where the vehicle had damage. This matched the color of the suspect vehicle (V1). I was able to speak with Driver 2 who advised that his vehicle had been parked on the roadside for the majority of the day and that the damage on the vehicle was new. Trooper Griggs advised that the Driver of Vehicle 1 was uncertain of what day it was or what time of the day it was. Trooper Griggs stated that she did not know what had occurred or know anything about any accident. I then went inside the Boys and Girls Club and was able to observe camera footage of the incident. At 4:36pm, V1 is observed to strike V2 while traveling south on N Monroe Street. V1 briefly stops and then leaves the scene heading south bound. I was able to take photographs of both vehicles.

V2 WAS SB ON MORTON APPROACHING 6TH ST. V1 WAS PARKED FACING WB ON MORTON N OF 6TH ST. V1 BEGAN BACKING EB ON TO MORTON AND THE REAR BUMPER OF V1 COLLIDED WITH THE FRONT PASS SIDE OF V2.D1 STATED THAT SHE WAS PARKED FACING EB ON MORTON JUST NORTH OF 6TH ST. V1 BEGAN BACKING EB INTO THE SB LANE OF MORTON WHEN THE REAR BUMPER OF V1 COLLIDED WITH THE FRONT PASS SIDE OF V2.D2 STATED HE WAS SB ON MORTON APPROACHING 6TH ST WHEN V1 BACKED INTO HIS LANE OF TRAFFIC AND THE FRONT PASS SIDE OF V2 COLLIDED WITH THE REAR OF V1. NO INURIES WERE REPORTED TO ME ON SCENE.

D1 was traveling northbound on Walnut Grove Street. V2 was parked facing northbound on Walnut Grove Street. D1 stated he was traveling northbound on Walnut Grove Street attempting to pull off to the east curb of Walnut Grove Street. D1 stated that there were two vehicles in front of him parked with their hazard lights flashing so he attempted to pull in behind the vehicles to try and park his vehicle near the east curb of Walnut Grove Street. D1 stated he then struck V2's front driver side quarter panel with V1's passenger side rear quarter panel and rear passenger side door. D1 stated he then pulled off to the east curb to allow traffic to pull through. D1 stated he did not see anyone in the vehicle, so he immediately called police. I was able to locate somebody associated with V2. The person associated with V2 was not the registered owner but was able to provide information in reference to the insurance and registered owner of V2. Because nobody was in V2 at the time of the crash, she did not know what had happened. Neither party was injured and neither vehicle was towed. Pictures of the vehicle are attached to the case.

No other officers assisted with the accident investigation.V1 was attempting to reverse into a parking stall that was adjacent to V2.V2 was parked in a valid parking stall.D1 is an employee with Indiana University and was attempting to back his vehicle into a parking stall so he could complete a work order. He did not have as much room as he thought he did and collided into V2. The damage caused no noticeable damage to his vehicle; however, the impact was on the rear, driver side corner of his vehicle.V2 was parked. The collision caused moderate damage to the rear, driver side quarter-panel to the vehicle.There were no injuries reported at the time of the report. Neither vehicle needed towed due to disabling damage.

V1 AND V2 WERE BOTH TRAVELING NORTHBOUND ON INTERSTATE 69 NEAR MILE MARKER 30 IN MONROE COUNTY. D2 STATED THAT D1 SWERVED INTO HIS LANE AND SIDE SWIPED V2. D1 STATED SHE DID NOT BELIEVE SHE KNEW EXACTLY WHAT HAPPENED. V2 WAS IN THE FAST PASSING LANE AND V1 WAS IN THE DRIVING LANE. D2 STATED THEY WERE DRIVING APPROXIMETELY 76 MILES PER HOUR.

V1 and V2 were traveling West on Third Street approaching Indiana Avenue. D1 stated that he was in the right lane (North Lane) sitting behind a bus at the bus stop about 157 feet from Indiana Avenue when he decided he was going to go around the bus. D1 continued to say he did not think there were any cars behind him or even approaching him when he went to proceed to the left lane (South Lane) to go around the bus. D1 stated that he did not see V2 in the blind spot and side swiped V2. D2 stated that she was not sure exactly what happened. D2 stated that she was driving in the left lane when D1 side swiped her vehicle. There was damage to the front drivers side bumper on V1 and damage to the passenger side of V2. The damage to the passenger side of V2 was done primarily to the front door.

Driver 2 stated he was stopped in traffic on 3rd St at Bryan Ave westbound. Driver 2 stated while stopped he was hit from behind by vehicle 1. Driver 1 stated she was stopped behind vehicle 2 and said the light turned green and she thought traffic would start moving. Driver 1 stated she started forward, but vehicle 2 didn't move and she ran into the rear of vehicle 2.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: V1 AND V2 WERE BOTH TRAVELING SOUTH ON N COLLEGE AVE WHEN V2 WAS ATTEMPTING TO TURN LEFT ONTO W 10TH ST. IN DOING SO, V1 MADE IMPACT INTO THE TRAILER PORTION OF V2. IN HIS ATTEMPT TO DO, HIS VEHICLE THEN MADE IMPACT INTO THE REAR LEFT WHEEL ASSEMBLY AREA OF THE TRAILER. V1 SUSTAINED DAMAGE TO THE RIGHT FRONT BUMPER PORTION OF THE VEHICLE. V2 SUSTAINED NO VISIBLE INJURY. BOTH VEHICLES WERE DRIVEN FROM THE SCENE.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: Vehicle 2 was traveling west on east 3rd St. Vehicle 1 was traveling north on S Rose. At the intersection of 3rd and Rose, Vehicle 1 is required to stop at the intersection and vehicle 2 is not. Driver of vehicle 1 stated she was in a hurry and stopped at the intersection, quickly looked both ways and proceeded into the intersection and did not see vehicle 2. Vehicle 1 failed to yield the right of way to vehicle 2 when entering the intersection. Vehicle 2 then struck vehicle 1 in the passenger side.Vehicle 2 has significant damage to the front and was towed from the scene due to the damage. Vehicle 1 has significant damage to the passenger side with airbag deployment and was also towed due to damage. No injuries were reported.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY

V1 was traveling westbound on State Road 46. V2 was turning eastbound (right) onto W. Chafin Chapel from State Road 46. V3 was facing west on W. Chafin Chapel stopped at the stop sign to turn onto State Road 46. V1 ran off the roadway striking V2 and then striking V3. D1 stated she was unable to slow down for traffic while traveling westbound. D1 stated she wanted to avoid striking any cars so she went to the right. D1 was stated when she went off the road she was unable to stop and struck V2 and V3. V1 had minor body and cosmetic damage to the front bumper. D2 stated he was turning onto W. Chafin Chapel when V2 was struck in the right rear tire. D2 had damage to the right rear tire and right rear quarter panel. D3 stated he did not see what happened due to vehicles turning onto W. Chapel. V3 had damage along both driver's side front and passenger door.All parties denied EMS.

DRIVER OF VEHICLE 1 STATED HE WAS WEST BOUND ON 1ST STREET APPROACHING THE INTERSECTION WITH S HENDERSON ST. D1 OBSERVED V2, WHICH WAS ALSO WEST BOUND ON 1ST ST, ACTIVATE ITS HAZARD LIGHTS AND PULLED TO THE LEFT SIDE OF THE ROAD. D1 THOUGHT V2 WAS PARKING, SO HE STARTED TO PASS V2 ON THE RIGHT. AS V1 STARTED AROUND V2, V2 BEGAN BACKING UP AND COLLIDED WITH V1. D1 ADVISED HE DID NOT SEE THE BACK UP LIGHTS ON V2 ACTIVATE. DRIVER OF VEHICLE 2 STATED HE WAS WEST BOUND ON 1ST ST APPROACHING THE INTERSECTION WITH S HENDERSON ST. D2 DECIDED TO BACK INTO AN ALLEY ON THE NORTH SIDE OF THE STREET, SO HE ACTIVATED V2S HAZARD LIGHTS AND PULLED TO THE LEFT TO GET AN ANGLE ON THE ALLEY TO BACK UP. D2 DID NOT SEE V1 APPROACHING FROM THE EAST. AS V2 STARTED TO BACK UP, IT COLLIDED WITH V1. WITNESS 1 STATED HE WAS APPROXIMATELY 150 WEST OF THE COLLISION SCENE. HE OBSERVED V2 WITH ITS HAZARD LIGHTS ON AT AN ANGLE IN THE STREET. HE THEN SAW V1 ATTEMPTED TO PASS V2 ON THE RIGHT AS V2 WAS BACKING UP AND SAW THEM COLLIDE.

V1 AND V2 WERE BOTH ON S LIBERTY DR AND AT THE INTERSECTION WITH W 3RD ST WHEN V1 MADE CONTACT WITH V2 CAUSING DAMAGE.V1/D1 STATED HE SAW THE VEHICLE IN FRONT OF V2 PROCEED ONTO W 3RD ST AND OVERLOOKED V2 DIRECTLY IN FRONT OF HIM. D1 STATED HIS VEHICLE THEN MADE CONTACT WITH V2. V2/D2 STATED SHE WAS STOPPED AT THE INTERSECTION DUE TO THE TRAFFIC SIGNAL WHEN HER VEHICLE WAS STRUCK FROM BEHIND BY V1. D2 AND HER PASSENGER HAD COMPLAINTS OF PAIN AS RESULT OF THE COLLISION. V2 WAS TOWED FROM THE SCENE BY CHANDLERS DUE TO DISABLING DAMAGE.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: V1 WAS EB ON 8TH ST, V2 WAS NB ON ROGERS. V1 ENTERED THE INTERSECTION AND THE FRONT OF V2 COLLIDED WITH THE PASS SIDE OF V1.D1 STATED THAT HE STOPPED ON 8TH ST FACING EAST AT ROGERS, D1 STATED THAT HE PROCEEDED EB THROUGH THE INTERSECTION AND DID NOT SEE V2. THE FRONT OF V2 THEN COLLIDED WITH THE PASS SIDE OF V1.D2 STATED THAT HE WAS NB ON ROGERS ST AT 8TH ST. D2 STATED THAT V1 CROSSED IN FRONT OF HIM EB AND THE FRONT OF V2 COLLIDED WITH THE PASS SIDE OF V1.THROUGH MY INVESTIGATION, I BELIEVE THAT D1 FAILING TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY CAUSED THIS ACCIDENT.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: DRIVER OF VEHICLE STATED HE WAS FACING WEST ON VERMILYA AND TURNING LEFT TO GO SOUTH ON TO SOUTH WALNUT STREET AND IN EXECUTING HIS TURN, HE STRUCK A MALE ON A BICYCLE WHO HAD CROSSED IN FRONT OF HIM WHO HE SAID HE DID NOT SEE UNTIL HE HAD STRUCK HIM.BICYCLIST STATED HE WAS RIDING HIS BICYCLE SOUTH ON THE SIDEWALK PARALLEL TO SOUTH WALNUT AND CROSSING INTO THE STREET OF VERMILYA WHEN HE WAS STRUCK BY VEHICLE 1. HE BELIEVED THAT DRIVER 1 SAW HIM BEFORE HE WAS STRUCK.BICYCLISTS MOST SEVERE INJURY WAS A BROKEN NOSE.
V1 was backing out of a parking spot. V2 was parked next to V1. V1 struck V2 while backing.D2 stated V1 struck her as it backed out. V1 then fled the scene.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: D2 stated he was traveling eastbound on Patterson in V2, just east of Grimes, when V1 pulled out of the exit of the Dermatology of Southern Indiana parking lot, striking his vehicle causing damage to the right rear tire and bed of his vehicle. D1 stated that he was sitting at the exit of the parking lot of the Dermatology of Southern Indiana and traffic was stop and go on Patterson. Unit 1 and Unit 2 were westbound on 10th Street approaching the intersection with Jordan Avenue. Unit 1 was directly behind Unit 2. Unit 1 collided into the rear of Unit 2, damaging both vehicles.Driver 1 stated she was stopped in traffic as the fourth vehicle from the red stop light when traffic started to move. Suddenly, all of the vehicles came to an abrupt stop and she could not stop Unit 1 in time from colliding with the rear of Unit 2.Driver 2 stated he was stopped in traffic as the third vehicle from the red stop light when traffic started to move. A pedestrian was apparently running across the street, causing the front vehicle to have to suddenly stop. When that vehicle stopped, the car behind it suddenly stopped and that forced Unit 2 to require an immediate stop. Driver 2 stated that after Unit 2 came to a stop, Unit 1 suddenly collided into the rear of Unit 2.I observed damage to the rear of Unit 2 and the front of Unit 1 consistent with a low speed rear end collision.All involved parties stated they were not injured.

On Friday, November 15, 2019 at 03:10, I was on duty and responded to a dispatch of a police vehicle involved in a car/deer crash on I69, near the 125.5 mile marker on I-69 northbound. I arrived at approximately 03:20 and found a 2020 white Chevrolet Traverse, bearing Sheriff's plates 8463. The driver, Kaden Reed SUTER, DOB: 03/19/1994, was uninjured. I69 in this area is a 6 lane divided highway that runs primarily north-south, is an asphalt-paved road with a wide outer shoulder, painted lane control, and rumble strips near the fog lines. The speed limit in this area is 70 miles per hour. The road condition was dry, the lighting was dark, with no artificial lighting in this area. A major feature of this area is Oliver Winery, which lies to the east side of the highway directly where the crash occurred. The vehicle displayed front end damage consistent with striking a deer. There was blood and bits of fur embedded within the front bumper, which also sustained damage. There was damage to front left quarter panel and the driver's door, which did not close properly. A large buck was found dead approximately 200 feet south of where the vehicle had come to a controlled stop on the right shoulder. The driver, who was a Morgan County Sheriff's deputy, denied medical treatment. He was administered a portable breath test at the scene, which registered .000% BrAC/210 litres of breath. After taking photos, I took a statement from the driver. The driver, SUTER, stated that he had been travelling northbound at approximately 70 miles per hour on I69 when a large deer had crossed the road from west to east. He had braked to avoid a collision but was unable to avoid striking the deer. He then brought the vehicle to a controlled stop on the right side of the road and called central dispatch to inform them that the collision had occurred. After completing my investigation, I departed the scene. The vehicle was still drivable and left the scene under its own power. All the above events occurred in Monroe County, Indiana.

D1 stated he was driving East on 3rd Street approaching Cory Lane.D1 stated he did not notice V2 stopped and he struck V2 in the rear.D2 stated she was stopped at the red light facing East on 3rd Street and was struck in the rear by V1.D2 did have a complaint of pain to her left knee.

D1 of V1 left the scene just after the accident according to D2 and D3. D2 of V2 was driving south on S. Henderson St when he stated that V1 began swerving into the opposite lane.D2 stated that he attempted to get off the road and out of the way when D1 side swiped D2 on the drivers side. D3 stated that he was driving north on S. Henderson St when he witnessed D1 side swipe D2. D3 stated that D1 then "bounced" off of D2 and struck D3 in the front drivers side wheel. D3 and D2 stated that after they both were struck by D1, D1 then went on to strike D4 in the rear V4. D4 of V4 stated that she was at the stop sign of S. Henderson and E. 2nd St when she was struck in the rear by D1. D4 stated that she then drove on through the intersection as the impact had pushed her into the middle of the intersection. Both D2 and D3 advised that a male was driving V1 and advised that after the crash, D1 and the passenger of V1 both got out of the drivers side and began running south west behind a house on S. Henderson St. D3 of V3 had a complaint of pain to his left shoulder however, he denied medical treatment and did not want an ambulance. Photo's were taken of the scene and a criminal report was completed.

D1 and D2 were headed S/B on N Walnut St approaching the intersection of E SR 46. D1 was distracted by his radio which caused V1 to strike V2 in the rear. D1 stated that he was headed S/B on N Walnut St, approaching the intersection of E SR 46. D1 stated that he looked down to change the station on his radio and did not see V2 in front of him. D1 stated that V1 then struck V2 in the rear. D2 stated that she was headed S/B on N Walnut St, approaching the intersection of E SR 46. D2 stated that as she crossed the intersection V2 was struck from the rear by V1.

V1 WAS SOUTHBOUND ON CURRY PIKE NORTH OF PROFILE PARKWAY.V2 WAS DIRECTLY IN FRONT OF V1. THEY WERE LEFT LANE.D1 SAID WHEN SHE SAW THAWT V2 HAD STOPPED FOR TRAFFIC AHEAD SHE BRAKED BUT COULD NOT GET STOPPED BEFORE COLLIDING WITH V2.D2 SAID AS HE SAT IN TRAFFIC V1 HIT HIM FROM BEHIND..

V1 was NB on Headley road and as he approached a slight corner, he ran off the roadway on the east side of the road and hit a small tree and then went down into a ditch.D1 stated that he was headed north and it was dark. He said the road curved a bit and he didn't realize that and he ran off the road and hit a small tree and then went into a ditch.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: V1 WAS IN THE PARKING LOT OF 1531 S. CURRY PIKE, WENT IT MADE A LEFT (WESTBOUND) TURN INTO A LANE TO EXIT THE PARKING LOT AND STRUCK V2 THAT WAS TRAVELING WB THROUGH THE PARKING LOT. D1 STATED THAT SHE THOUGH THE LANE TO EXIT THE PARKING LOT WAS SEPERATED INTO TWO LANES. D1 TURNED INTO THE CLOSEST SIDE LANE TO THE PARKING LOT AND CLIPPED V2 THAT WAS TRAVELING ON THE SIDE OF THE LANE THAT WAS FARTHER FROM THE PARKING LOT. I ONLY OBSERVED ONE SINGLE TRAFFIC CONE IN THAT LANE, IT IS NOT CLEAR THAT THE LANE IS SEPERATED INTO TWO LANES THROUGH THE ENTIRE LENGTH OF THE PARKING LOT. AT THE END OF THE PARKING LOT ARE TWO TURN LANES TO EXIT THE LOT ONTO CURRY PIKE. D2 STATED THAT HE THOUGHT THAT HE WAS IN HIS LANE AND WAS STRUCK BY V1 WHEN HE PASSED THE BUILDING (1531 S. CURRY PK) AND ENTERED THE LANE TO EXIT THE PARKING LOT.

V1 was southbound proceeding to enter through the crosswalk southbound in direction to enter Jones Avenue. Pedestrian was eastbound on his skate board on the sidewalk.I was dispatched to the area of Jones Avenue in front of Read Hall circle drive on the south side of the building. Upon arrival I located both parties involved. I spoke with the Pedestrian 2 first. P2 said he was on his skate board traveling east bound in direction on the sidewalk. P2 said he entered the crosswalk which is located on the south side of Read Hall for the circle drive. P2 said he was then bumped by V1 front bumper when V1 entered the crosswalk causing him to get pushed off the skate board. P2 said he then placed his hands on the hood of V1 as he got bumped and pushed off V1 hood. P2 said he was feeling shaken up. I asked if anywhere on his body was struck. P2 said his right leg. I called for an ambulance to check out P2. Medics arrived on scene and checked out P2. P2 signed a signature of release to decline any medical attention. P2 said his skate board on the deck accrued damage. D1 said he was leaving the circle drive on the south side of Read Hall south bound in direction in V1. D1 said he was moving forward to the crosswalk in V1 when P2 entered the crosswalk on a skate board east bound in direction. D1 said V1 and P2 collided causing P2 to get pushed off the skate board. V1 had no apparent or noticeable damage to the vehicle.D1 said he has an in car dash camera containing video footage. D1 was advised to hold onto the video footage. I also provided D1 a business card and asked him to email me the video so I could attach it to the case report. I have not received an email at this time from D1 pertaining to the video footage.

Primary Cause-Driver Factor-Unsafe Speed: V1 was traveling too fast for the conditions. The conditions were that V1 was attempting to make a left turn and ran off the roadway out of control. D1 should have driven at a reduced speed to avoid running of the roadway and colliding with V2.Curry Pike is a local road that runs in a northern and southern direction through Monroe County. Woodyard Road runs in a eastern and western direction and intersects with Curry Pike. There is a traffic control light at the intersection which was functioning properly when I arrived on scene. Vehicle 1, gold Mitsubishi Galant, was turning left from northbound Curry Pike onto westbound Woodyard Rd. V1 left the roadway and struck a sign with the right front bumper area of V1. V1 continued traveling back onto Woodyard and crossing the center line striking V2 in the left drivers side rear wheel and bumper area with the left front bumper of V1. Vehicle 2, white Chevrolet Equinox was stopped in traffic eastbound on Woodyard Rd. After striking V2, V1 then traveled off the roadway again on the south side of Woodyard where it came to a controlled stop. {Driver Statements} D1 (Alexis Jackson) stated she was traveling north on Curry Pike and attempted to make a left turn (westbound) onto Woadyard Rd. D1 stated the traffic signal had turned yellow and she was attempting to make it through the intersection before the signal changed to red. D1 stated she thought she slid on ice and ran off the roadway striking the sign. She then traveled back onto the roadway (Woodyard Rd.) and struck V2 in the drivers side rear area. She was wearing her seat belt.D2 (Andrew Fawbush) stated he was stopped in traffic eastbound on Woodyard Rd. when V1 struck his vehicle in the rear wheel area. He was wearing his seat belt.During the course of my investigation, I observed tire marks in the grass where V1 left the roadway striking the sign. The tire marks continue back onto Woodyard Rd. This was consistent with both drivers statements. I observed damage to the entire front end of V1. I observed damage to the drivers side left rear wheel and bumper area of V2. No injuries were reported as a result of this crash. I attached a damage tag to the sign for repair.The crash investigation showed that the primary cause was Unsafe Speed on the part of D1. This was determined by both driver statements and damage to both vehicles.

V1 was headed south bound on Interstate 37 just south of the Monroe dam exit. D1 stated that a deer ran across from the east side and V1 struck the deer. The deer was unable to be located. I observed substantial damage to the front of the vehicle.

At approximately 11:00 pm on 11/15/2019, Unit 1 was travelling northwest on Breeden Rd, approaching the intersection of W Graves Rd. Driver stated loose sand in roadway caused accident, This could not be identified at the scene. Barbed wire fence of private property was damaged during this incident.Driver of Unit 1 did not report accident, it was discovered at 08:30am on 11/16/2019. Driver was cited for Leaving the Scene of an Accident

DRIVER OF VEHICLE 1 STATED SHE WAS EAST BOUND ON GRIMES LANE, JUST PAST S MORTON ST. D1 DID NOT NOTICE UNTIL TOO LATE THAT EAST BOUND TRAFFIC HAD SLOWED SIGNIFICANTLY. D1 stated he was heading North on Old Sate Road 37.D1 stated that he looked at his phone as he was going around a corner and ran off the roadway. W1 stated that he was behind V1 in his personal vehicle. W1 stated that V1 ran off the roadway and struck an embankment and rolled over.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: V1 was parked on a yellow curb on E. 7th street on the North side of the road facing West. V2 was SB on N. Dunn street and was stopped at stop sign with E. 7th street. V3 was parked in front of V1. V2 turned right onto E. 7th street and V1 pulled out of his parking space into the lane of travel and V2 struck V1 in the driver side front with the passenger side of her vehicle. When I arrived on scene, the vehicles had been moved from where the crash occurred therefore no diagram was completed. The crash involved a silver Subaru (V1), driven by Kelly Watson (D1), and a white Toyota (V2), driven by Jennifer Lady (D2). None of the occupants involved in the crash complained of any injuries.Both drivers told the same story. V2 was following V1 east on 10th St from the 45/46 Bypass. V1 turned into a private drive that leads to multiple IU buildings and Stone Belt. Once V1 pulled into the drive and stopped, V2 turned into the drive and stopped behind V1. V1 started backing and crash into V2. V1 was going to back into the roadway to get their vehicle turned around because they made a wrong turn.V1 sustained light damage to the driver side rear corner of the bumper and fender. V2 sustained moderate damage to the front bumper and grill. Both vehicles were able to be driven from the scene.

V1 BACKED INTO V2 WHILE BOTH VEHICLES WERE ATTEMPTING TO BACK OUT OF PARKING SPACES AND LEAVE A PRIVATE LOT. D1 STATED SHE COULD NOT SEE OUT OF HER REAR WINDSHIELD BECAUSES OF BOXES IN THE VEHICLE AND BACKED INTO V2.

I witness the accident through camera footage and vehicle 1 was facing west behind the business and back into the passenger side of vehicle two damaging the passenger door and then leaving the scene of the accident. Vehicle 2 was parked facing south and no one was in the vehicle at the time of the accident.

No other officers assisted with the accident investigation.Primary Cause - Driver Distracted (explain in narrative) - D1 stated that he was looking out his driver-side window and not paying attention to the vehicles stopped in front of him.V2 was stopped behind an unknown vehicle that was attempting to make a left, northbound turn into a private parking lot.V1 was traveling eastbound and approaching V2 from the rear.D2 stated he was stopped behind and unknown vehicle which was attempting to turn left into a private parking lot. V1 then collided into the back of his vehicle.D1 stated that he was looking out his driver-side window and was not paying attention to the vehicles stopped in front of him. He then collided into the rear of V2. I asked D1 how fast he thinks he was traveling prior to the collision to which he replied, "The speed limit." I asked D1 what the speed limit was to which he stated, "30 or 40?" When asked what his speed was at the time of the collision he estimated at approximately 10 mph. Neither driver reported injuries at the time of the report. Neither vehicle needed towed due to disabling damage.

At 1524 hours on 11/15/2019 a collision occurred between V1 and V2. V1 was travelling westbound on Kirkwood Avenue in the area of Kirkwood and Maple when he struck a pedestrian crosswalk signpost in the roadway. Officer Wagner was attempting to stop V1 on a traffic stop when V1 fled the scene. Officer Wagner attempted to stop V1 at Kirkwood and Rogers when V1 then fled, turning right into an alleyway just northeast of Kirkwood and Rogers. V1 then continued to drive turning right on Madison and then another right to turn back west on Kirkwood Avenue. V1 then fled westbound on Kirkwood Avenue as Officer Wagner began to terminate the pursuit per IUPD policy. V1 then began driving left of center, crossing the double yellow lines into the eastbound lane of traffic, eventually striking the pedestrian crosswalk sign at the intersection of Kirkwood and Maple. V1's erratic driving forced another vehicle to turn right onto Maple from Kirkwood as V1 passed them. From there, V1 continued driving westbound into the eastbound lane of traffic after striking the sign. At this time, V1 and D1 are still outstanding as they fled the scene. Officer Wagner is planning to follow up with D1 and take criminal action as he was able to identify D1 after the collision.

Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY

D2 STATED SHE WAS STOPPED EAST BOUND IN THE PARKING LOT WAITING FOR A VEHICLE TO BACK FROM A PARKING SPACE. D2 SAID WHILE WAITING SHE FELT AN IMPACT TO THE REAR OF HER VEHICLE. D1 STATED SHE WAS DRIVING WEST ON W KIRKWOOD AVE APPROACHING S ROGERS STREET. D1 STATED SHE FELL ASLEEP AND WHEN SHE WOKE UP THE ACCIDENT HAD ALREADY OCCURRED. Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY
NARRATIVE: Upon my arrival V1 and V2 were both parked northbound on Stadium Drive which connects to the parking lot of the Wells Library. All parties advised there were no injuries. D1 said she was driving around in V1 in the parking lot looking for a place to park. D1 said she was in the very last row of the parking lot facing west to make a right hand turn to go north. D1 said she came to a stop, and had her right turn signal on prior to making the turn. D1 said she turned right. D1 said V2 was traveling what she believed was quick north in direction on Stadium Drive which connects to the parking lot. D1 said as V2 was north in direction she had already begun turning. D1 said V1 then struck V2 on the read passenger door area causing damage. V1 obtained damage on the driver side front bumper area. D2 said she was traveling in V2 westbound on 7th Street and came to a stop at the intersection of 7th St. and Stadium Drive at the stop sign. D2 said she signaled at the stop sign to make a right turn to go north on Stadium Drive. D2 said she was looking to make a left turn to go to the Radio/TV Building from Stadium Dr. D2 said V1 failed to yield to a complete stop prior to turning in the parking lot and just went forward. D2 said as she was going north she was then struck in the rear passenger door by V1. V2 obtained damage to the rear passenger door. Neither vehicle had a stop sign. However, Stadium Dr. Is more of a street than the parking lot and people exiting the parking lot should yield to people already on the drive.

DRIVER 1 ADVISED THEY WERE NB ON S SR 37 NEAR THE INTERSECTION OF S SR 37 AND S OLD SR 37. DRIVER 1 ADVISED THEY WERE DISTRACTED AND DID NOT NOTICE THAT THE LIGHT HAD TURNED RED AT THE INTERSECTION. Primary Factor: FAILURE TO YIELD RIGHT OF WAY

AS V1 TURNED SB ONTO S SMITH ROAD, THE FRONT OF V2 AND THE PASSENGER SIDE DOOR AREA OF V1 COLLIDED IN THE INTERSECTION.D1 STATED THAT HE WAS WAITING TO TURN SB ON S SMITH ROAD AS HE HAD THE YIELD GREEN LIGHT. W1 STATED THAT SHE OBSERVED V1 PULL OUT IN FRONT OF V2 CAUSING THE COLLISION. W1 STATED THAT SHE BELIEVED D1 MISJUDGED THE DISTANCE OF V2 TO HIS VEHICLE AND MISTAKENLY PULLED OUT IN FRONT OF HER. W1 STATED THAT BOTH EB AND WB TRAVELING TRAFFIC ON E 3RD STREET HAD GREEN LIGHTS AND THAT V1 HAD A YIELD GREEN LIGHT.

D1 STATED THAT HE WAS HEADED WEST ON SR46W WHEN A WHITE SUV CAME PAST AND RUN HIM OFF THE ROAD, HE THEN WENT UP ON CURB STRIKING 3 MAIL BOXES, LIGHT POLE AND A STREET SIGN AND THAT THE OTHER VEH DID NOT STOP. D2 SAID THAT SHE DID NOT KNOW WHAT HAPPEN SHE WAS IN FRONT OF VEHICLES AND WAS STRUCK IN THE RIGHT REAR BUMPER. SHE THEN SAID SHE DID NOT KNOW IF V1 WAS THE ONE THAT STRUCK HER OR NOT. FRONT BUMPER OF V1 WAS THEN CHECKED WHICH HAD MARKS ON BUMPER THAT MATCHED DAMAGE ON V2.WITNESS STATEMENT: WE WERE ON WEST 46 TOWARDS SPENCER BEFORE CHANDLER ST WHEN A BLACK TRUCK AND A WHITE CHEVY SUV RAN ONE ANOTHER OFF THE ROAD. D1 REPORTED TO CENTRAL DISPATCH THAT HE HAD FALLEN ASLEEP AND CRASHED INTO A DITCH WHILE GOING AROUND A CURVE. V1 was driving East amd crossing N walnut St on w 14th Street. V2 was traveling North on N Walnut Street and driving straight. V1 entered the traffic lane of V2.
